In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Amphistomus Lansberge, 1874 is found in Australia, New Guinea and Maluku (Moluccas) Archipelago. In Australia it comprises 18 described species and 8 undescribed species. Amphistomus speculifer, as originally described, is now known to consist of two allopatric species. Amphistomus speculifer is confined to New South Wales only.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.
The genus Temnoplectron Westwood, 1841 occurs in Australia and New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 16 species.

This species has been recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to a newly described genus Clypeodrepanus Krikken, 2009. It is represented only in the Afrotropical region by three species that are currently considered valid.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Scybalophagus consists of five species that are distributed throughout Argentina, Peru, Chile and Bolívia. Its specimens are recognized by the following characters: mesotibia and metatibia with transverse carinae; head not elongate and dorsum monocolored.

The genus Copris Muller 1764 shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

The mega-diverse genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009)

.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide, of which around 500 species are Oriental (ScarabNet 2009).

The Afro-Asian genus Panelus numbers 26 species, of which around 22 species occur in the Oriental region. The genus is in need of a revision because the species identification is complicated. However, Panelus bakeri is currently considered valid as a species. The food preferences of Panelus species are unknown, however, it is presumed that at least many of Oriental species are saprophagous. Panelus species are typically restricted to special types of forest and have small distribution ranges.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is in Onthophagus Group 7 (d'Orbigny 1913), which may be equivalent to the Palaearctic subgenus Eremonthophagus. Group 7 is widely distributed across the savannas of the Afrotropical region.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastern Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012). This species is closely related to Onthophagus ocelliger Harold, 1877 and is often difficult to separate from it.

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992). This species is known by only the single male type specimen.
The genus Endroedyolus Scholtz & Howden 1987 comprises a single species with an extremely restricted distribution in eastern South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).
The genus Garreta Janssens 1940 is shared between the Afrotropical and Oriental regions, with eleven species currently recognized as valid in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 10 (Ferreira 1978), which shows a widespread, mostly tropical distribution across the dry to moist savannas, forests and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

The genus Scybalocanthon Martínez (1948) is a small genus of dung beetle from Central and South America. It needs taxonomic revision and many of its species can not be securely identified at this moment. So far, Scybalocanthon has 18 described species.

The genus Garreta Janssens, 1940 is shared between the Afrotropical and Oriental regions, with eleven species currently recognized as valid in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). There are several currently valid species that are claimed to be close relatives of Garreta azureus. It is suspected that two of these species described from unspecified localities in South Africa were probably described from the southeast coastline (G. caffer (Fahraeus, 1857), type locality “Caffraria”; G. fastiditus (Harold, 1867), type locality “Cape of Good Hope”). As green specimens of Garreta from the subtropical east coast of South Africa are indistinguishable from green G. azureus of equivalent body size, it is likely that an examination of type material of G. caffer and G. fastiditus will show that they are synonyms of G. azureus.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa.

The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by ca. 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009). The taxonomic status of Onthophagus hemipygus requires clarification as it was described only from a female specimen, and females often lack the necessary diagnostic characters to reliably identify Onthophagus species.

The endemic Australian genus Thyregis Blackburn, 1904 comprises four described and one undescribed species (Matthews 1976, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012). Matthews (1976) considers Thyregis to be a relict genus and Thyregis relictus or a similar species to be ancestral to Coptodactyla.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastem Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.
The genus Kolbeellus Jacobson 1906 is monotypic and restricted to South Africa.
The mega-diverse genus Onthophagus is distributed globally. It is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species (ScarabNet 2009).

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown.  They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown. They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus. Canthidium abbreviatum belongs to a group of Atlantic Forest region species which requires review.

This Glaphyrocanthon belongs to the viridis group, very near to  C. (Gl.) meridionalis . The overlap in the distribution of several subspecies was the criterion used by Rivera-Cervantes and Halffter (1999) to reclassify C. zuninoi as a new species.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009). The species Onthophagus tricolor currently is known from two populations and it is thought that they are not conspecific.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species belongs to Onthophagus group 17 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is dominated by species showing rain forest, highland grassland, or cooler climatic ranges and is widespread in the Afrotropical region.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 31 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed throughout the savanna and highland grassland of the Afrotropical region and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus Furconthophagus Zunino 1959.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).

The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is extremely closely related to Pachysoma hippocrates Macleay. Morphologically, the two species are virtually indistinguishable except by comparison of the aedeagi.

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; and Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Allogymnopleurus Janssens 1940 is currently represented by 18 Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009).

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe. According to literature data, this is a common and widespread species. However, there are some different “forms” among populations of this “species”. Thus, we cannot know its real situation without a taxonomic revision.
Sylvicanthon is known from South America, except Chile and Uruguay. Little taxonomic and biological information is available. Currently, it needs taxonomic revision.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is probable that understanding of the genus, species, and their distributional ranges would benefit from a revision.

Canthonella was described by Chapin in 1930. Halffter and Martínez (1977) synonymized Ipselissus under Canthonella. There are currently very few species described from South America, but there are likely to be many more to be described.

The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species (ScarabNet 2009). The Oriental subgenus Indachorius includes about 30 species (ScarabNet 2009). The species of this subgenus are quite small onthophagines which are very similar to each other in external morphology and can be reliably identified only by male genitalia. The representatives of this subgenus feed on dung. Some of the species roll dung balls. The majority of the species of this subgenus is strictly localized to a particular habitat in primary tropical forests and likely displays high degree of endemism. Because of this fact and the lack of detailed study, this subgenus is in need of a revision.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastern Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: (Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia). Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus can be changed.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Allogymnopleurus Janssens 1940 is currently represented by 18 Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). It is considered that Allogymnopleurus chloris (Klug 1855) is merely a shiny green colour variety of Allogymnopleurus thalassinus (Klug 1855), which comprises iridescent cupreous, green and blue varieties as well as a black variety.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
There is additional taxonomic uncertainty as the type series of this species may contain a number of different species, therefore making an accurate assessment of its extinction risk at present impossible.

The genus Lepanus Balthasar, 1966, as conceived by Matthews (1974) and subsequent workers is the most heterogeneous of the Australian Canthonini. It comprises 24 described and at least 60 undescribed species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm, G.B. Monteith pers. comm. and Gunter pers. comm. 2012). Lepanus pygmaeus as defined by Matthews (1974) is now known to be a complex of species. This assessment refers to what we now know is the true Lepanus pygmaeus.

The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Gymnopleurus virens typically shows coarse punctuation on the prothoracic disc and has been recorded in Angola, Namibia, South Africa, and Ethiopia. Metallic green individuals with a distribution on the South African Highveld, in moist coastal regions (South Africa, Mozambique), and in Zimbabwe (Australian CSIRO 1970-1986, unpublished records), that show finer punctuation of the prothoracic disc, have been treated variously as a variety of G. virens or as an outlier occurrence of G. sericeifrons Fairmaire 1887. Gymnopleurus sericeifrons is otherwise located on uplands in east and northeast Africa. There are four synonyms for G. virens, all of which were described from untraceable or unspecified localities in east and northeast Africa.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Metacatharsius Paulian 1939 is predominantly restricted to the Afrotropical region where 62 species are currently considered valid (ScarabNet 2009). A single species, Metacatharsius inermis Castelnau, extends from the Afrotropical region across Arabia to the western edge of the Oriental Region in a Saharo-Sindian pattern of distribution.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 12 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the dry to moist savannas of the Afrotropical region, and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus, Trichonthophagus.

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown.  They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

Besourenga (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) was described by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). Currently, the genus represents approximately 25 species which are yet to be described. Four of which are distributed throughout Bolivia, Peru, Brazil and Paraguay. All species that compose the genus were originally described in Trichillum or Pedaridium.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 19, which is centred in dry to moist savanna throughout the Afrotropical region and includes a number of known elephant dung specialists occurring on either deep sands or finer-grained soils (Ferreira 1978).

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Euonthophagus Balthasar 1959 is represented in both the Palaearctic and Afrotropical regions. The Afrotropical taxa remain relatively poorly known and probably comprise rather more than the sixteen species currently listed as valid (A. Davis pers. comm. 2012).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.
The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus of wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico.

The genus Isocopris is currently represented by three species described, distributed among Brazil, Argentina, Bolivia and Paraguay. So far, the specimens were recorded in Amazonian forest, Cerrado and Chacoan region. The genus is being revised by Fernando Vaz-de-Mello.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species belongs to Onthophagus Group 4 (d'Orbigny 1913), which shows a distribution restricted to tropical east African highlands and cool temperate highlands of South Africa.
The genus Amphistomus Lansberge, 1874 is found in Australia, New Guinea and Maluku (Moluccas) Archipelago. In Australia it comprises 18 described species and 8 undescribed species.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: (Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia). Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus can be changed.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.
The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is probable that understanding of the genus, species, and their distributional ranges would benefit from a revision.

The genus Sisyphus Latreille is biogeographically widespread across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic and Oriental regions, with a restricted occurrence in the Central American part of the Neotropical region. It is currently represented by 18 species in the Afrotropical region, but is in urgent need of revision. Sisyphus natalensis Balthasar currently remains a valid name but in the unpublished revision of Paschalidis (1974) it is cited as a synonym of Sisyphus sordidus Boheman 1857 described from Caffraria, an imprecise area centred on the modern province of KwaZulu-Natal and adjoining parts of the Eastern Cape. It needs to be compared with Sisyphus caffer Boheman 1857, also described from Caffraria. Both species are currently synonymised (Haaf 1955) with Sisyphus crispatus Gory, a name which has no validity as it comprises a species complex, according to the unpublished revision of Paschalidis (1974).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.
The endemic Australian genus Monoplistes Lansberge, 1874 comprises six described and two undescribed species.

The genus Temnoplectron Westwood, 1841 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 16 species  (Matthews 1974, Reid and Storey 2000, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout the Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.
The flightless endemic Australian genus Aptenocanthon Matthews, 1974 currently comprises eight species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

This Afro-Oriental genus comprises ca. 13 species, which are rare and poorly represented in collections (ScarabNet 2009). Some of them were recorded in rotten wood which suggest that they probably feed on soft rotten wood or may equally feed on fungi and microorganisms associated with rotten wood.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 23 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest, savanna and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The genus is endemic to South America and currently has five valid, described species. They are specialists of beaches (riverine and sea).

The genus Oxysternon was recently revised by Edmonds and Zídek (2004). Its consists approximately of 11 species that are distributed throughout tropical South America. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera: (Oxysternon s. str. and Mioxysternon). According to Edmonds and Zídek (2004), Mioxysternon species occur along the periphery (or outside) of the Amazon Basin, while those of Oxysternon s. str. fill it.

Oxysternon pteroderum Nevison, 1892 has been considered a rare and endemic species from the Brazilian Atlantic forest (Arnaud 2002, Edmonds and Zidek 2004, França et al. 2012).

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds (1994). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 7, which occupies a range in cooler regions found in the south and in tropical eastern highlands.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species remains unassigned to a group.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Frankenbergerius Balthasar, 1938 has been recently revalidated (Frolov and Scholtz 2005) after being in synonymy with the genus Coptorhina Hope 1830. It currently comprises seven species restricted to the eastern and southwest margins of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

According to Vaz-de-Mello (2008), Trichillum in the current sense is equivalent to 11 species distributed from Brazil, French Guyana, Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay, where it is always east of the Andes. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
The genus Pachysoma Macleay 1821 comprises thirteen flightless species with a combined range extending along the dry to arid coastal region in the southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Malagoniella is distributed throughout the Neotropical region, except in Chile and the West Indies (Halffter & Martínez, 1966). However, the greater diversity of the group is found in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and southern Brazil (Halffter & Martínez, 1966). The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera: Malagoniella and Megathopomima.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is classified in Onitis Group 17, which shows a widespread distribution in dry and moist savanna of the Afrotropical region. The group 17 species occupy distinct regional ranges but are difficult to separate leading to taxonomic confusion in the literature and, as a result, much erroneous distribution data.

The genus Cheironitis Lansberge, 1875 is centred on the Palaearctic, western Oriental and Afrotropical regions, and is currently represented by eleven species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Cheironitis scabrosus (Fabricius, 1776) is extremely closely related to an undescribed species with which there may be some limited overlap in range. Only males of the two species may be differentiated using minor morphological differences on the middle tibia.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 10, which shows a widespread, mostly tropical distribution across the dry to moist savannas, forests and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The genus Byrrhidium Harold 1869 is restricted to a small range in the arid southwest of the Afrotropical region where it currently comprises three flightless species (ScarabNet 2009).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).
The genus Pseudochironitis Ferreira 1977 is restricted to an intertropical range in the east of the Afrotropical region where it is represented by only two species.

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas that are found in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australiasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 10 (d’Orbigny 1913), which shows a wide distribution in the savannas of the Afrotropical region. A taxonomic revision is required to determine the taxonomic status of citations for Onthophagus stigmosus from southern versus east Africa.

The Oriental and Afrotropical genus Catharsius Hope 1837 is currently represented by 80 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is probable that understanding of the genus, species, and their distributional ranges would benefit from a revision.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout the Americas. However, the greatest diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.


NOTE:

D. calcaratus is in the process of being synonymised with D. mamillatus. Therefore, the older synonym mamillatus and data referring to this is being used. Revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello in prep.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.
This genus contains only one described species (Hansreia affinis).

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by ca. 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Neosisyphus Müller 1942 shows a widespread distribution in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently represented by 22 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is in urgent need of revision.

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992). This species was described from a single female collected in Ethiopia and, subsequent to having been synonymised with a Somalian-centred species, P. revoili van Lansberge, it was re-validated by Palestrini (1992) using extra non-type material from a single untraceable locality in Kenya.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 20 (d’Orbigny 1913), which occupies a range restricted to the arid southwest of Africa and the southern edge of the Sahara Desert from west to northeast Africa. It is sometimes confused with a close relative that is distributed across the deep sands of the southern Kalahari Basin.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.This species is very close to others, so miss-identification is a problem.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 31 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widely distributed throughout the savanna and highland grassland of the Afrotropical region and is equivalent to the Palaearctic and Oriental subgenus Furconthophagus.

The genus Scatimus was recently revised by Génier and Kohlmann (2003). According to the authors, Scatimus is a small genus, containing only twelve described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. Its species are distributed across Mexico, Peru and Brazil.

The genus Onoreidium was described and positioned in the subtribe Scatimina (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). Its present four species that are distributed throughout Ecuador, northern Peru, and Panama, comprising the Arid Ecuador and Tumbes-Piura in the Northwerstern South American dominion, and Eastern Central America. The species that compose the genus were originally described in Trichillum or Pedaridium.
This species has two subspecies, O. undulans undulans and O. undulans oaxacanus (according to Zunino and Hallfter 1988).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and 7 species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabeolus, which is primarily restricted to Africa. Scarabaeus xavieri Ferreira 1968 is probably a junior synonym of Scarabaeus andreaei zur Strassen 1963. The species recently cited as Scarabaeus xavieri Ferreira by van Rensburg et al. (1999), Botes et al. (2006) and Jacobs et al. (2010) is an undescribed species.

The mega-diverse genus Onthophagus is distributed globally.  Onthophagus is a genus of the Scarabaeidae or scarab beetles in the superfamily Scarabaeoidea.  It is currently represented by approximately 2000 species (ScarabNet 2009). The Afro-Oriental subgenus Parascatonomus includes approximately 50 species. The majority of them feed on carrion.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is classified in Onitis Group 17, which shows a widespread distribution in dry and moist savanna of the Afrotropical region. The group 17 species occupy distinct regional ranges but are difficult to separate leading to taxonomic confusion in the literature and, as a result, much erroneous distribution data.

The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009), of which around 500 species occur in the Oriental region. The Oriental subgenus Colobonthophagus includes about 30 species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: (Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia). Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus can be changed.

According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), the Neotropical genus Coprophanaeus Olsoufieff (1924) is currently represented by 38 species, distributed among three subgenera (Megaphanaeus Olsoufieff, Metallophanaeus Olsoufieff, and Coprophanaeus s. str.) and eight species groups. According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), C. rigoutorum can be near, or perhaps synonym to C. cyanescens. Thus, the authors consider the status of C. rigoutorum uncertain.

The genus Temnoplectron Westwood, 1841 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 16 species (Matthews 1974, Reid and Storey 2000, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
The flightless endemic Australian genus Aptenocanthon Matthews, 1974 currently comprises eight species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
Canthidium nitidum needs taxonomic study, since it may potentially be a synonym of C. angulicolle.

The genus Gyronotus Lansberge, 1874 is a flightless genus, currently comprising six species that are restricted to forest patches on the east coast of the Afrotropical region from Kenya to South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. Scybalophagus consists of five species that are distributed throughout Argentina, Peru, Chile and Bolívia. Its specimens are recognized by the following characters: mesotibia and metatibia with transverse carinae; head not elongate and dorsum monocolored.
