This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.
The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009).

Tesserodoniella was described by Vaz-de-Mello and Halffter (2006). It presents two, flightless described species (Tesserodoniella elguetai Vaz-de-Mello and Halffter and Tesserodoniellameridionalis Vaz-de-Mello and Halffter).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. This species assessment refers to two subspecies: Canthon lunatus lunatus and Canthon lunatus tibialis.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The genus Scybalocanthon Martínez (1948) is a small genus of dung beetle from Central and South America. It needs taxonomical revision and many of its species can not be securely identified at this moment. So far, Scybalocanthon has 18 described species.

The genus Metacatharsius Paulian 1939 is predominantly restricted to the Afrotropical region where 62 species are currently considered valid (ScarabNet 2009). A single species, Metacatharsius inermis Castelnau, extends from the Afrotropical region across Arabia to the western edge of the Oriental Region in a Saharo-Sindian pattern of distribution.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species remains unassigned to a group.
Canthon pacificus belongs to the virids group, and is very near to C. (Gl.) corporali (Rivera-Cervantes and Halffter, 1999).

The flightless endemic Australian genus Cephalodesmius Westwood, 1841 comprises three described and one undescribed species (Matthews 1974, Monteith and Storey 1981, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). Owing to the forest type locality of this species and the savanna associations of most of the locality records, a comparison between the type and other material might be advisable to ensure taxonomic accuracy.

The genus Copris Muller 1764 shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Copris complexus belongs to a group of species allied to Copris orion Klug 1835, which show primarily inter-tropical distributions.

Eodrepanus parallelus (Raffray, 1877) has recently been transferred from the genus Drepanocerus Kirby 1828 to the new genus Eodrepanus Barbero, Pallestrini & Roggero, 2009. Eodrepanus is represented in both the Afrotropical and Oriental regions with five species found in the Afrotropical region currently considered valid. Eodrepanus parallelus (Raffray, 1877) is often confused with a close relative Eodrepanus fastiditus (Péringuey, 1901).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992). Because of the species name, it seems doubtful that this species with an inexact type locality from the margins of the River Limpopo is representative of Kalahari populations that are usually metallic green with a yellow sheen, although these are sympatric with a few metallic green individuals with a blue sheen at Nylsvlei in central Limpopo Province, South Africa (A. Davis pers. obs.). These green / blue individuals appear relatively indistinguishable from P. aureiceps Harold. This species occurs in open vegetation on the east coastal sands of northeast South Africa and Mozambique and is also usually metallic green with a blue sheen. Its type locality is Delagoa Bay in southern Mozambique. The status as separate species of differently coloured eastern and central to western populations needs to be reviewed. In a previous review, both P. sapphirinus and P. aureiceps were shown with roughly sympatric distributions from west to east across Southern Africa (Palestrini 1992). 

For the purpose of this assessment, the species is taken to be represented by the green / yellow colour variety that occurs in the dry southern Kalahari basin of central southern Africa and in outlier islands of deep sands to the north and east of the Kalahari where it overlaps with green / blue individuals that seem indistinguishable from the east coastal P. aureiceps.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Odontoloma Boheman 1857 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where most of the twenty species currently considered valid show southerly centres of distribution (ScarabNet 2009). Owing to the very small body size and great similarity in appearance between most species, the taxonomy of this genus is difficult and requires revision.
This species belongs to the armatus complex (Matthews 1961).

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

The genus Copris Muller 1764 shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009).

Latodrepanus laticollis has been recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to a newly described genus, Latodrepanus Krikken, 2009. It is represented only in the Afrotropical region where four species are currently considered valid.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The genus Malagoniella is distributed throughout the Neotropical region, except in Chile and the West Indies (Halffter & Martínez, 1966). However, the greater diversity of the group is found in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and southern Brazil (Halffter & Martínez, 1966). The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera: Malagoniella and Megathopomima.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Tesserodon Hope, 1837 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprise 13 species (Matthews 1974, Storey 1991, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by ca. 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 3, which is widespread throughout the savannas and forests of Africa.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is classified in Onitis Group 17, which shows a widespread distribution in dry and moist savanna of the Afrotropical region. The group 17 species occupy distinct regional ranges but are difficult to separate leading to taxonomic confusion in the literature and, as a result, much erroneous distribution data.

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds (1994). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.). 

Phanaeus prasinus in particular, has four different morpho-types. According to Arnauld (2002), these morpho-types correspond to four subspecies (P. prasinus prasinus Harold; P. prasinus lugens Nevinson; P. prasinus jolyi Nevinson and P. prasinus trinidadensis Arnauld).

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: (Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia). Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus can be changed.

For this species specifically, ongoing revision may suggest that this is indeed a sub-species, so that taxonomic verification is likely to change the current assessment.

The genus Gymnopleurus Illiger, 1803 shows a range in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is currently represented by 33 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). The taxonomy of G. humanus has been recently reviewed. It was re-established that cupreous specimens from Angola, described under different names (G. modestus Lansberge, 1886; G. sericatus Erichson, 1843), were indeed synonyms of blue individuals described from South Africa as G. humanus (Davis and Génier 2007). Individuals described from the northeast savannas were removed from synonymy with G. humanus under the revalidated species name of G. humeralis Klug, 1855 (Davis and Génier 2007).
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by ca. 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).
Sylvicanthon is known from South America, except Chile and Uruguay. Little taxonomic and biological information is available. Currently, it needs taxonomic revision.
Bdelyropsis is a genus which was formed for three species, two from Mexico and Central America and one from South America.

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by  approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).
The flightless endemic genus Diorygopyx Matthews, 1974 comprises 8 species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus of wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Lepanus Balthasar, 1966, as conceived by Matthews (1974) and subsequent workers is the most heterogeneous of the Australian Canthonini. It comprises 24 described and at least 60 undescribed species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm, G.B. Monteith pers. comm. and Gunter pers. comm. 2012). Lepanus bidentatus as defined by Matthews (1974) is now known to consist of two species - Lepanus bidentatus and an undescribed species. This assessment refers to the true Lepanus bidentatus.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Sisyphus Latreille is biogeographically widespread across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic and Oriental regions, with a restricted occurrence in the Central American part of the Neotropical region. It is currently represented by 18 species in the Afrotropical region, but is in urgent need of revision. Along with four other species, Sisyphus caffer is currently still officially synonymised (Haaf 1955) with Sisyphus crispatus Gory 1833, a species whose type has not been seen since 1900 and whose identity is not verifiable using the description (Paschalidis 1974). However, Schoolmeesters (2011) lists Sisyphus caffer Boheman 1857 as a valid species with Sisyphus pygmaeus Klug 1862 and Sisyphus sordidus Boheman 1857 listed as synonyms and Sisyphus caffer goryi Harold 1859 as an infraspecific taxon. The latter two taxa are considered valid species by Paschalidis (1974).

According to Vaz-de-Mello (2008), the genus Pedaridium is monotypic. However, it contains at least one undescribed species currently under study, in addition to the type species. It is present only in the Eastern Parana subregion, in the Parana Forest and Araucaria angustifolia Forest provinces.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastern Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.

The genus Scatimus was recently revised by Génier and Kohlmann (2003). According to the authors, Scatimus is a small genus, containing only twelve described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. Its species are distributed across Mexico, Peru and Brazil.

The genus Neosisyphus Müller 1942 shows a widespread distribution in the Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently represented by 22 species in the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). It is in urgent need of revision. This species, however, is highly distinctive due to its highly spinose legs.

The genus Macroderes Westwood 1842 is restricted to the winter and bimodal rainfall regions on the west and southern coastal regions of South Africa where it is currently represented by fourteen valid flightless species and three with poor support (ScarabNet 2009). This species is known only by 21 female specimens, 14 from a single locality. There is some morphological variability but all are currently classified as Macroderes undulatus pending a study of male specimens.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). Material formerly considered to represent Copris fallaciosus was recently divided (Nguyen Phung 1988) into two closely related species, Copris denticulatus Nguyen Phung, 1988 and Copris fallaciosus Gillet, 1907, which is a nomen novum for the pre-occupied species name of Copris integer Harold, 1869. Other preceding names relate to type series containing more than one species (Copris lunarioides Waterhouse, 1891, Copris laticornis Péringuey, 1901).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

There are about 130 species of Canthidium described in tropical and subtropical forests of Central America and South America. Martínez and Halffter (1986) separated the genus into two subgenera: Canthidium and Eucanthidium. Canthidium andersoni belongs to subgenus Eucanthidium.

The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide, of which about 500 species occur in the Oriental region (ScarabNet 2009). This species is closely related to the representatives of the subgenus Gibbonthophagus.

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa. This assessment is based on the two subspecies Sulcophanaeus auricollis auricollis (Harold 1980) and Sulcophanaeus auricollis joffrei (Martinez 1988).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

The genus Euoniticellus is centred on the Afrotropical and Palaearctic regions, with representatives in the Oriental region and one species on Caribbean islands. It currently comprises some fourteen valid Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). Euoniticellus nasicornis is sometimes confused with its very widespread relative E. intermedius (Reiche, 1848).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species remains unassigned to a group.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).
The endemic Australian genus Monoplistes Lansberge, 1874 comprises six described and two undescribed species.
The genus Xinidium Harold 1869 shows a distribution restricted to moist highland grassland of southeast Africa and currently comprises three species.

The genus Diastellopalpus Lansberge, 1886 is restricted to intertropical parts of the Afrotropical region and currently comprises 32 described species (Josso and Prévost 2000), most of which show montane or rainforest distributions (Davis and Scholtz 2010).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Copris shows widespread biogeographical occurrence across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic, Oriental, Nearctic and northern part of the Neotropical regions, with a current total of 105 species known from the Afrotropical region (ScarabNet 2009). The taxonomic status of this species requires validation. Citations for its origin and collector suggest that its distributional range could lie in either southern or east Africa. As Felsche (1910) discusses this species as similar in appearance to Litocopris but not in that genus, it should, perhaps, be compared with the east African species, Copris diversus Waterhouse, 1891.

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758 ranges across the Palaearctic, Oriental and Afrotropical regions and is currently considered to comprise four subgenera (Forgie et al. 2006): Scarabaeus Linnaeus 1758, Scarabeolus Balthasar 1965, Kheper Janssens 1940, Sceliages Westwood 1837, with a representation in the Afrotropical region of 55, 27, 21 and seven species respectively. This species belongs to the subgenus Scarabaeus.

The genus Scatimus was recently revised by Génier and Kohlmann (2003). According to the authors, Scatimus is a small genus, containing only twelve described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. Its species are distributed across Mexico, Peru and Brazil.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 10, which shows a widespread, mostly tropical distribution across the dry to moist savannas, forests and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by ca. 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).
The endemic Australian genus Monoplistes Lansberge, 1874 comprises six described and two undescribed species.

The genus Odontoloma Boheman 1857 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where most of the twenty species currently considered valid show southerly centres of distribution (ScarabNet 2009). Owing to the very small body size and great similarity in appearance between most species, the taxonomy of this genus is difficult and requires revision.

This species has been recently transferred from Drepanocerus Kirby, 1828 to a newly described genus, Afrodrepanus Krikken, 2009. It is represented only in the Afrotropical region where two species are currently considered valid.

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

Paracanthon comprises only four species which are distributed throughout the Atlantic forest of south and southeastern Brazil. Its species are usually recorded in elevated areas above 1,000 m. Currently, this genus needs taxonomic revision.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 10 (d’Orbigny 1913), which shows a wide distribution in the savannas of the Afrotropical region.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).

The genus Lepanus Balthasar, 1966, as conceived by Matthews (1974) and subsequent workers is the most heterogeneous of the Australian Canthonini. It comprises 24 described and at least 60 undescribed species (Matthews 1974, Weir pers. comm, Monteith pers. comm. and Gunter pers. comm.).
The endemic Australian genus Demarziella Balthasar, 1961 comprises 14 described and two undescribed species (Matthews 1976, Matthews 1986, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa (ScarabNet 2009). Epirinus validus and E. sulcipennis Boheman are the largest-bodied of the Epirinus species.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.
The mega-diverse subcosmopolitan genus Onthophagus is currently represented by approximately 2,000 species worldwide (ScarabNet 2009).

The cosmopolitan genus Onthophagus Latreille, 1802 is the largest of the Australian dung beetle fauna and comprises 193 described and 41 undescribed species (Matthews 1972, Storey 1977, Storey and Weir 1990, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Lepanus Balthasar, 1966, as conceived by Matthews (1974) and subsequent workers is the most heterogeneous of the Australian Canthonini. It comprises 24 described and at least 60 undescribed species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm, G.B. Monteith pers. comm. and Gunter pers. comm. 2012). Lepanus ustulatus as recognised by Matthews (1974) is now known to consist of two species. The northern populations represent a new species while the southern populations represent the true Lepanus ustulatus. This assessment is based on the true Lepanus ustulatus.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

The genus is currently being reviewed by Patrick Arnaud and François Génier. Therefore, it is not safe now to report data on the number of species or internal structure of the genus. The species of Dendropaemon are restricted to South America, except Chile.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 18, which is widespread throughout lowland to upland drier savannas of the Afrotropical region on both deep sands and finer-grained soils.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically relatively well known.

The genus Cheironitis van Lansberge 1875 occurs across the Palaearctic, western Oriental and Afrotropical regions, and is currently represented by eleven species in the Afrotropical region. Cheironitis damarensis Felsche, 1907 is a junior synonym of this species (ScarabNet 2009).
The flightless endemic genus Coproecus Reiche, 1841 conprises one described and one undescribed species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown.  They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

The genus Temnoplectron Westwood, 1841 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprises 16 species (Matthews 1974, Reid and Storey 2000, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992).

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus with wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico. Some species are flightless.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 16 (d’Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in forest, savanna and grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Caccobius Thomson 1859 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by 42 species that are considered valid (ScarabNet 2009).

Scybalophagus consists of five species that are distributed throughout Argentina, Peru, Chile and Bolívia. Its specimens are recognized by the following characters: mesotibia and metatibia with transverse carinae; head not elongate and dorsum monocolored.

Onthophagus Latreille 1802 is the most species-rich genus in the subfamily Scarabaeinae, with a distribution extending from tropical to warm temperate areas in the Palaearctic, Afrotropical, Oriental, Nearctic, Neotropical and Australasian regions. There are some 791 species in the Afrotropical region that have been divided into 32 species groups, of which 29 currently remain classified within the genus (ScarabNet 2009). Some of these groups extend into the Palaearctic and Oriental regions, but they have not yet been formally integrated into the subgeneric classification system erected for these regions. This species is classified in Onthophagus Group 23 (d'Orbigny 1913), which is widespread in the forest, savanna and upland grassland of the Afrotropical region.

The genus Tesserodon Hope, 1837 occurs in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Australian fauna comprise 13 species (Matthews 1974, Storey 1991, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm. 2012).

The genus Scybalocanthon Martínez (1948) is a small genus of dung beetle from Central and South America. It needs taxonomical revision and many of its species can not be securely identified at this moment. So far, Scybalocanthon has 18 described species.

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown.  They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), the Neotropical genus Coprophanaeus Olsoufieff (1924) is currently represented by 38 species, distributed among three subgenera (Megaphanaeus Olsoufieff, Metallophanaeus Olsoufieff, and Coprophanaeus s. str.) and eight species groups. According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), Coprophanaeus corythus (Harold), formerly regarded as a subspecies of C. telamon (Erichson), assumes species status.

Matthews (1962) recognized two subspecies: C. k. klugi found in Aguascalientes, Guerrero, Mexico, Michoacan, Morelos, Oaxaca, Puebal, Veracruz, and C. k. sierrensis. However, López-Guerro et al. (2009), conducted a study of the internal genitalic characters of males and females of Copris klugi klugi Harold and Copris klugi sierrensis Matthews, and they maintain that C. klugi Harold and C. sierrensis Matthews are two distinct species.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.
For Ornithoptera chimaera, Haugum and Low (1978-85) list a total of three subspecies: O. chimaera chimaera occurs in PNG as does O. c. flavidor (in Parsons 1999); the third subspecies, O. c. charybdis, occurs

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.There are currently four subspecies recognised: the nominate subspecies croesus, subspecies lydius (Felder & Felder, 1865), subspecies toeantei Parrot & Schmid, 1894, and subspecies sananaensis Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980, which was described on the basis of a single female from Sanana Island (Parrott and Schmid 1984).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.
There are between four and six subspecies recognized, depending on the author followed (four subspecies in Haugum and Low (1974) and six in Hancock (1991), although following Parsons (1999), five subspecies are recognised). The six most commonly recognised subspecies are: the nominate subspecies paradisea, subspecies borchi (Haugum & Low, 1974), subspecies chrysanthemum (Kobayashi & Koiwaya, 1979), subspecies demeter (So & Sato, 1998) and subspecies detanii Schäffler, 2001, and subspecies arfakensis. It has been proposed that subspecies arfakensis has been erroneously treated as a distinct species by Sumiyoshi (1989) and is as a result is still referred to as a separate species in a number of subsequent publications (e.g. Matsuka 2001, Schaeffler 2001). The identity of another proposed subspecies, O.p. flavescens, originally found in Etna Bay (Rothschild 1897), is based on a sole female specimen and the status is doubtful. Some publications list additional subspecies, namely galatea from Salawati Island and occidentalis from Sorong (Matsuka 2001, Schaeffler 2001).

The species is often confused with Enallagma deserti.

Up until 2005, Enallagma cyathigerum was thought to be a single species with a circumpolar distribution. However, Turgeon et al. (2005) demonstrated that the Nearctic and Palearctic populations were really two species: E. cyathigerum (occurring in the Palearctic) and E. annexum (occurring in the Nearctic).

The type locality for this species is Surinam. There are currently five recognized subspecies in this taxon: Battus belus belus (Cramer, 1777); aureochloris (Brown, 1994); belemus (Bates, 1864); cochabamba (Weeks, 1901) and varus (Kollar, 1850).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

The recent description of Papilio rumiko, which closely resembles this species, meant that many specimens previously identified as P. cresphontes have now been assigned to the new species P. rumiko, meaning that the overall distribution of cresphontes is now primarily restricted to North America, and its extent into Central America is unknown, but unlikely to reach beyond Mexico.
There are two recognised subspecies Tarucus bowkeri ssp. bowkeri and Tarucus bowkeri ssp. transvaalensis.

Some sources list this species under genus Neographium (e.g. Butterflies of America; https://www.butterfliesofamerica.com/L/Papilionidae.htm), however, here we follow Tyler et al. (1994) and retain this species under genus Protographium.

There are several subspecies described for this species: the nominate subspecies sarpedon; subspecies nipponum (Fruhstorfer 1903);  subspecies morius (Fruhstorfer 1908); subspecies connectens (Fruhstorfer 1906); subspecies sikari (Page and Treadaway 2013); subspecies luctatius (Fruhstorfer 1907); subspecies colus (Fruhstorfer 1907); subspecies pagus (Fruhstorfer 1907); subspecies septentrionicolus (Page & Treadaway 2013); subspecies agusyantoei (Page & Treadaway 2013); subspecies rufofervidus (Fruhstorfer 1898); subspecies phyris (Jordan 1937); subspecies phyrisoides (Page & Treadaway 2013); subspecies lycianus (Toxopeus 1951); subspecies hundertmarki (Page & Treadaway 2013); subspecies rufocellularis (Fruhstorfer 1905); subspecies toxopei (Page and Treadway 2013); subspecies adonarensis (Rothschild 1896); subspecies jugans (Rothschild 1896); subspecies wetterensis (Okano 1993); subspecies kawaimitsuoi (Fujioka 1997).
The following are also likely to be subspecies; subspecies semifasciatum (Honrath, 1888);
 subspecies corycus (Fruhstorfer 1907);  subspecies melas (Fruhstorfer 1907); subspecies messogis (Fruhstorfer, 1907); subspecies temnus (Fruhstorfer 1907); subspecies timorensis (Rothschild, 1896) (Globis). This is a difficult species and the full taxonomy of this species is still somewhat uncertain and further DNA testing is required to better understand its taxonomy.
Limenitis archippus has numerous recognised subspecies: spp. archippus; spp. idaho; spp. iahontani; spp. obsoleta; spp. floridensis; spp. watsoni; and ssp. hoffmani (www.butterfliesofamerica.com).
The type locality for this species is Mexico. No subspecies are formally recognized for the taxon.

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

The American Snout (Libytheana carinenta) has several subspecies: L. c. carinenta, L. c.mexicana, L. c. streckeri, L. c. larvata, and L. c. bachmanii (the Mexican Snout); the latter was formerly recognised as a separate species, Libytheana bachmanii (Warren et al. 2016).
This species is split into several subspecies across its range (Scott 1986).

The type locality for this species is Suriname. There are currently six recognized subspecies in this taxon, according to Warren et al. (2010): Parides lysander lysander (Cramer 1775); antalcidas Tyler, Brown & Wilson, 1994; brissonius (Hübner, [1819]); mattogrossensis (Talbot, 1928); orinocoensis Costantino, Le Crom & Salazar 2002; and parsodes (Gray, [1853]).

Argynnis cybele has a number of recognised subspecies: ssp. carpenterii; ssp. cybele; ssp. eileenae; spp. krautwurmi; spp. novascotiae; ssp. pseudocarpenteri; spp. charlottii; spp. letona; ssp. leto; and spp. pugetensis.

There are at least 16 subspecies described (Ohya 2001): the nominate subspecies amphrysus, subspecies ruficollis (Butler, 1879), subspecies euthydemus (Fruhstorfer, 1913), subspecies actinotia (Jordan, 1908), subspecies flavicollis (Druce, 1873), subspecies niasicus (Fruhstorfer, 1898), subspecies vistara (Fruhstorfer, 1906), subspecies astrea Hayami, 1992, subspecies arkumene Hayami, 1994, subspecies chrysomelas Parrott & Schmid, 1984, subspecies simeuluensis Ohya, 1985, subspecies perintis Kobayashi, 1986, subspecies kuris Kobayashi & Hayami, 1987, subspecies hilbert Hayami, 1992, subspecies naokoae (Morita, 1996) Rumbucher & von Knötgen, 1999, and subspecies kecilensis (Schäffler, 1999) Rumbucher & von Knötgen, 1999. Rumbucher and von Knötgen (1999) list two additional potential subspecies: merah and zeus.

The type locality for this species is Surinam. There are currently 4 recognized subspecies in this taxon: Battus crassus crassus (Cramer 1777); hirundo (Röber 1925); lepidus (Felder and Felder 1861) and paraensis (Brown 1994)

The type locality for this species is Bolivia. There are currently three recognized subspecies in this taxon, according to Lamas (2004) and Tyler et al. (1994): Eurytides serville serville (Cramer 1777); E. s. acritus (Rothschild and Jordan 1906); and E. s. colombus (Kollar 1850). This latter subspecies is considered by some sources to be a species in its own right, e.g. in Butterflies of America (https://www.butterfliesofamerica.com/L/Papilionidae.htm). However, here, we follow Lamas (2004) and Tyler et al. (1994) and include columbus as a subspecies of serville. It should be noted that columbus is considered Least Concern at the subspecies level.

The Japanese species Sympetrum frequens (Selys, 1883) was considered as the insular vicariant of S. depressiusculum (Selys, 1841). Recent phylogenetic analyses showed that both taxa pertain to a single species. Therefore Sympetrum frequens is treated a junior synonym of S. depressisuculum (Sawabe et al. 2004).

This species was described as Petaliaeschna gerrhon by Wilson (2005) from a single male from Maoershan in Guangxi but later moved to the genus Periaeschna after the discovery of females believed to belong to the same species at two locations in Guangdong (Wilson and Xu 2008). However, serious taxonomic issues remain around the genera Cephalaeschna, Periaeschna, Petaliaeschna and allies, and it is possible that (a) this species actually belongs in Cephalaeschna and (b that the females from Guangdong are not actually the same species. Cephalaeschna shaowuensis Xu, 2006 may be a junior synonym of this species, but this requires further investigation.

As stated by Lieftinck (1948) in his original description there are no close allies within the Anisogomphus genus. The inferior appendages are distinctive and serve to separate from all other members of the genus. Chao (1995) described the nymph from Guangze County, Fujian.

This species was originally described as a subspecies of Vestalis smaragdina Selys, 1879. It was upgraded to a full species by Hämäläinen (2004) and later transferred to the genus Vestalaria May, 1935 by Hämäläinen (2006).

Lestomima flavostigma May, 1933 was assessed previously and published on the IUCN Red List in 2009, but was subsequently shown by Kalkman and Wilson (2010) to be a junior synonym of Rhipidolestes truncatidens. Schmidt (1931) described Rhipidolestes truncatidens from Guangdong based on 12 males. It is a pruinosed, large-sized Rhipidoletes with black face and wings with dark brown apical patches.
The female is undescribed.

Lieftinck (1984) produced a key to all known males of Calicnemia and described this species from material collected from Fujian. He divided the genus Calicnemia into two distinct groups: Group I containing males with a recurved penis lobe narrow and ribbon-like apical filaments and Group II comprised of males with recurved penis lobe broad, variously expanded and lacking any filaments. This species belongs to Group I. It is readily distinguished from other members of the genus by the reduced size of the yellow antehumeral stripes which are coloured red or orange in other species and broader.

Hämäläinen (2003: 6) states that “The whereabouts of types of Platycnemis rubripes and P. pierrati is unknown. Judged from the descriptions they are both Copera species” and that “pierrati, described from (at least) two male specimens from Guangdong and Jiangxi, is obviously a teneral male of C. marginipes (Rambur,1842). However, I prefer to leave any formal decisions of the identity of these Navasian species for a future revisor.” Since no formal decision has been made, P. pierrati remains listed as a valid species, although Hämäläinen’s opinion is very likely to be correct and is followed (for instance) by Zhang (2019).
Sympetrum darwinanum (Selys, 1883) was originally described as a race of Diplax frequens, type locality Japan, before Ris (1911) established the existing generic combination.

Asiagomphus hainanensis was described, solely from male material collected from Hainan and Asiagomphus septimus (Needham 1930) was described from continental male material obtained from Fujian. The holotype male A. septimus and first A. septimus female were illustrated by Chao (1953: 404, figs 12-19) and in the same publication Chao (1953: 406, figs 20-25) also figured a male A. hainanensis in his original description, which had previously been identified by Needham (1931) as A. septimus. Chao (1953) only figured the female valvular vulvae of A. septimus which are short and broadly triangular-shaped. Both Chao (1953) and later Asahina (1966) illustrated  male and female Fujianese A. septimus specimens all with conjoined 1st and 2nd yellow lateral thoracic stripes.

The males of these two species are easily separated by the structure of the posterior hamulus. The tip of the male outer hamulus of A. septimus (Chao 1953: 404, fig. 14; Asahina 1966: 109, fig. 4) is much smaller when viewed in profile than that of A. hainanensis (cf. Chao 1953: 406, fig. 22; Asahina 1966: 110-111, figs 11 and 14). In addition, the shaft of the posterior hamulus of A. septimus is much straighter than the stouter, humped posterior hamulus of A. hainanensis.

Wilson (1999) pointed out that females of A. hainanensis and A. septimus must be separated with considerable caution. Asahina (1978a: 3, 5-6, figs 3-9) illustrated male and female A. septimus material from Fujian including the female occipital margin. The occipital crest in female continental Fujianese A. septimus is strongly arched with a large U-shaped or semi-circular notch at the centre.

Asahina (1966: 111, Figs 15-16) described the female A. hainanensis for the first time, from Hong Kong material. However, in Asahina (1988a: 689-690, Fig.1) he mistakenly reidentified the Hong Kong female as A. septimus and substituted an illustration of a supposedly true female A. hainanensis occipital margin with a uniformly straight margin based on Taiwanese material (but the Figure was labelled from Hong Kong adding to the confusion). The original Asahina (1966) figure had a strongly arched occipital crest with a V-shaped notch bordered by several short, stout spines. Wilson (1999) remarked that he had collected many female specimens in Hong Kong with these characteristics and stated he was convinced that Asahina had originally identified the Hong Kong female A. hainanensis correctly in his 1966 paper. Wilson also attributed the straight occipital margin to A. hainanensis and remarked it was perhaps a ‘masculine’ A. hainanensis female form (Wilson, 1999: Fig. 22: A. hainanensis, Hong Kong: female occipital normal margin, Fig 23: A. hainanensis, Hong Kong: female occipital margin, ‘masculine form’). Wilson (1999) reidentified all previous records of A. septimus in Hong Kong as A. hainanensis. Wilson was proved correct in his assumptions when the first true female A. hainanensis occipital margin from the type-locality in Hainan was described and figured in Wilson (2009) with a strongly arched margin with V-shaped notch at the centre.

Due to the confusion regarding the true form of female A. hainanensis and its misidentification as A. septimus, many records of A. septimus may in fact relate to the widespread A. hainanensis. Even today Zhang (2019) illustrates the female occipital A. hainanensis with a straight margin, which is not its typical form that, as explained above, is strongly arched with a pronounced V-shaped notch. To add to the confusion the occipital margin of A. pacificus, widespread throughout south China, may also feature a uniformly straight occipital margin with or without a very small v-shaped notch (Wilson 2009). It is only safe to identify continental A. hainanensis with an occipital margin which is strongly arched with a pronounced V-shaped notch.
The species was described from Japan by Selys (1883). Asahina (1967) revised the genus Ceriagrion and provided a diagnostic description of the species.

The subspecies Sympetrum baccha baccha (Selys, 1884) was described from southern China and the subspecies Sympetrum baccha matutinum Ris, 1911 from Japan. The two subspecies are easily separated. The nominate subspecies has wing tips which are only slightly blackish-brown beyond the level of the pterostigma or they are entirely hyaline whereas in Sympetrum baccha matutinum the wing tips are entirely black from the level of pterostigma.

Euphaea opaca Selys, 1853, males have uniformly dark blackish wings. It superficially resembles E. superba Kimmins, 1936, and both species are known from southern China, but E. superba has bright orange-red basal wing venation.
Xu (2005) described this species as new to science based on a single female adult. The taxonomy of this species therefore needs to be confirmed.

Labrogomphus is a monotypic genus erected by Needham (1931) to receive a female specimen of Labrogomphus torvus collected from Hainan. Chao (1954) described the male and larvae specimens collected from Fujian.

The status of Idionyx victor as a species distinct from I. yolanda Selys has been repeatedly questioned, for instance Wilson and Reels (2001) state that I. victor is likely to be a “Chinese form of yolanda” and Kosterin (2014) opinions that it might be better treated as a subspecies of I. yolanda. However, the issue of the status of I. victor has yet to be resolved, and it is treated as a good species for assessment purposes (it should be noted that this does not reflect any opinion of the assessors on the issue).

Anotogaster sieboldii shows geographical variations in body size and maculation pattern in northern regions, satellite islands (e.g., Izu Islands) and the northern and middle Ryukyu Archipelago. In the past, the population of Yaeyama Island of Ryukyu archipelago, SW Japan was included in Anotogaster sieboldii, but by consideration of genetic and morphological review (Karube et al. 2012), the population has been identified as Anotogaster klossi.

Chao (1955) established the subspecies Gomphidia krueger fukienensis from Fujianese specimens, which, according to Chao (1990), differed from the nominate taxon by the presence of a pair of large lateral yellow spots on the otherwise black postclypeus and the 2nd and 3rd black lateral thoracic stripes connected by a broad bar along the sub-spiracular suture. The nominate taxon, G. kruegeri kruegeri Martin (1904) has a postclypeus with yellow spots either absent, or markedly reduced, and the 2nd and 3rd black lateral thoracic stripes are mostly conjoined, apart from two small yellow spots. Kosterin and Chartier (2018) report that Zhang Haomiao has shown that G. krueger fukienensis should be treated at species level and indeed Zhang (2019) treats G. fukienensis as a good  species. Zhang (2019) states that apart from the colour pattern differences the posterior hamulus and female vulvar laminar are structurally different. It is treated here as a  valid species G. fukienensis.

The status of this species is extremely doubtful. Although it has been recorded from mainland Asia, from India to Cambodia, as Neurothemis tullia feralis, these records are usually now treated as a form of N. tullia (Drury, 1773); Asahina (1991) concluded that this was merely a dry season form. The "true" N. feralis is apparently restricted to Java and the Krakatau islands (Van Tol 1990), with records from Sumatra considered unreliable. However as Asahina (1991) pointed out, the type of feralis is supposed to be from India, in which case feralis is a junior synonym of tullia and the species occurring on Java, if really distinct from tullia, needs another name.
Urothemis bisignata is often treated as a synonym or a subspecies of Urothemis signata; its status as a distinct species is doubtful.

Gomphidia ganeshi is known only from the holotype male, which is stated to differ from G. kirschii, a species known from the Philippines, only in details of colouration and details of wing venation. Whilst it is unlikely that G. ganeshii is a synonym of the Philippine species, its relationship to the similar G. abbotti, a species widespread in Sundaland and somewhat variable in markings, and that could occur on the Andaman Islands, needs to be investigated.

Brachydiplax yunnanensis is stated (Fraser 1924) to differ from Brachydiplax sobrina (Rambur, 1842) in subtle details of the structure of its accessory genitalia. There is a need to re-examine this species; possibly the stated differences merely represent geographical variation in B. sobrina.

Mnais icteroptera was described by Fraser (1929) on the basis of a single male specimen from ‘Kalaw, Chin Hills, Burma’ without other collecting data. The holotype is preserved in BMNH (Kimmins 1966). At present this seems to be the only known specimen of this species, the taxonomic status of which remains uncertain. Asahina (1975) supposed preliminarily that it might be a form of M. andersoni McLachlan, 1873.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Ischnura. Recent work by Yu and Bu (2011) moved Coenagrion dorothea to Paracercion.
Coenagrion tengchongensis is only known from four male specimens.

The species was described from a single male, and apparently differs from Macromia chui Asahina, 1968 only in size and small details; it may ultimately prove to be a variant of M. chui or some other Macromia species.
The genus Anonychonitis Janssens 1950 is monotypic and occupies a small range in southeast Africa.
The species was described from a single female specimen, said to resemble A. personatus (Yang et al. 2006). In these circumstances there is considerable doubt that it is a distinct species.
Asiagomphus somnolens is known from a single female reared from a larva, collected more than 80 years ago (Needham 1930).

The female of this species has not definitely been described. Zhou (1987) illustrates the supposed female based on a single specimen not associated with a male; this cannot be regarded as certainly being the female of A. forresti.

Phaenandrogomphus yunnanensis apparently differs from the poorly known P. aureus (Laidlaw, 1922) only in details of its markings (Zhou 1999), and might eventually prove to be merely a form of that species.

Lamelligomphus chaoi was described by Zhu (1999) from a single female from Yunnan, China. The female was described and figured with a predominantly yellow labrum, finely bordered with black, a pair of relatively narrow yellow synthoracic dorsal stripes, conjoined 1st and 2nd yellow lateral thoracic stripes (a unique feature in Lamelligomphus from China) and a divided yellow transverse crest on the postfrons. In keeping with the features, detailed by Chao (1990), characteristic of the genus Lamelligomphus, paired occipital horns are also present, but this feature is not unique to Lamelligomphus and without knowledge of the male cerci and secondary genitalia it is not possible to be certain that chaoi belongs to Lamelligomphus. Although Wilson and Xu (2009) produced a key to the Chinese species of Lamelligomphus, and were able to key out L. chaoi without much difficulty within a group of species allied to L. ringens, it should be noted that not all Chinese Lamelligomphus females are known and the female L. choui Chao and Liu 1989 has not yet been described. Moreover, several species of Lamelligomphus have been discovered in Yunnan that await description (Zhang 2019) but none of these species appear to be as extensively marked with yellow as L. chaoi.

Temnogomphus amurensis Bartenev, 1930, Gomphus emarginatus Okimura, 1937 and Anisogomphus m-flavum Selys, 1878 are synonyms (Bridges 1994). Asahina (1979) synonymised Anisogomphus m-flavum Selys, 1878 with Anisogomphus maacki Selys 1872 and described and illustrated adult specimens. The larvae was described by Asahina and Yamamoto (1959).

The type series of Asiagomphus corniger was in bad condition even at the time of description (Morton 1928). The only recent records are apparently in Yang and Davies (1993) (R. Dow pers. comm.), where they state “all males agree adequately with …”, implying some doubt over the identity of the specimens; indeed a number of other species treated in this publication were misidentified (Chao 1995). On the other hand, other poorly known Asiagomphus species may actually be synonyms of A. corniger.
Merogomphus chaoi Yang & Davies, 1993 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Mattigomphus pinratani (Karube and Kostern 2018).

The only definite record of this species appears to be that of the type series (Zhu 1991) from Shaanxi. Yang and Davies (1993) recorded it from Yunnan, but considerable doubt was cast over the identity of their material by Chao (1995).

Davies and Yang (1996) wrote: “It was, perhaps, unfortunate that Sjöstedt (1932) chose to name his species B. fasciata at all from a single female and with poor figures; ….; identifying a male of this species, when found, may be difficult.”

The species is distinguished from Sympetrum risi Bartenef, 1914 by details of colouration and one somewhat dubious structural character in the female. The distinctness of the two species appears somewhat doubtful.
Prior to its description in 1995 (Chao 1995) this species had been misidentified as Davidius trox Needham, 1931.

When describing Anisogomphus nitidus, Yang & Davies (1993) noted that it differs from A. anderi Lieftinck, 1948 (also known from Yunnan) only in size and markings, not in the structure of the anal appendages or penis. In the Gomphidae one would expect structural differences between different species; if there are really no structural differences, doubt must remain about the distinctness of A. nitidus from A. anderi.
The species apparently differs from Trigomphus svenhedini Sjöstedt, 1932 only in markings, and might ultimately prove to be merely a variant of that species. It is known only from the holotype.

The species was described from a single female (Fraser 1924). Morton (1928), in what appears to be the only other record of this species, described both sexes, but stated “I have a little hesitation in referring these to Fraser’s species …” and “The markings and form of the [male] anal appendages recall … Lestes gracilis peregrinus”. Thus there is some doubt as to whether Morton’s record really belongs to the same species, and if it does, as to whether I. coeruleus is really a good species or just a geographical variant of the widespread Indolestes gracilis. X. Yu (pers. comm. 2011) considers it most likely to be a synonym of Indolestes peregrinus (Ris 1916).
The species was described from a male specimen only.
Species described by Yeo (2010) from material collected in the 1800's. No taxonomic changes since.

The genus Mylothris is a large (60+ species) exclusively Afrotropical genus with many taxonomic difficulties that might not be solved without significant inputs of molecular data. However, this particular species is morphologically quite different from any other African species. It shares the Atewa forests with seven other Mylothris species and appears to occur sympatrically with all seven.

There is uncertainty if Pseudophilotes jordanicus is a  subspecies of P sinaicus or a separate species. Described in the year 2,000  by D. Benyamini, the species was separated from P. sinaicus on the basis of morphology, genitalia and a large geographic separation. However, Tshikolovets (2011) have questioned this separation and suggested only subspecies status. In this Red List assessment we treat both as separate species.
This species is valid as Brignolia bowleri (Saaristo, 2002)
This species should be known as Brignolia trichinalis (Benoit, 1979)
This species should be known as Heteroonops spinimanus (Simon, 1891)

Caridina schenkeli does not appear to be a monophyletic taxon (see von Rintelen and Cai 2009) but is treated here as a valid species.
Although Caridina vitiensis has been recorded from Fiji (type locality), Sri Lanka and New Guinea, the taxonomic status of this species is uncertain (Holthuis 1969)

This species has been considered to be a synonym of the widespread Caridina lanceifrons (see Liang 2004), but is herein considered as a valid species, following De Grave and Fransen (2011).
Caridina mccullochi is part of the C.indistincta species complex and may prove to be the same species (T. Page pers. comm. 2011).

Caridina aruensis is only known with certainty from the type specimens from the Aru Islands (eastern Indonesia) (Roux 1911).  The taxonomic status of the material reviewed by Riek (1953) from several localities in Queensland (Australia) has not been resolved and the conspecific identity of this material is questionable.  Davie (2002) treats Caridina aruensis as a synonym of Caridina nilotica, but the taxon was considered valid by De Grave and Fransen (2011)
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.  It has been synonimised with Caridina propinqua in modern literature, but has been maintained as a valid species in more recent Chinese literature.
The taxonomic status of this species requires clarification.
It is likely that Caridina typus is a species complex of two or more species (M. de Bruyn, pers. comm. 2012)

This probably is not a Theganopteryx species; its generic placement is uncertain.
Generic placement of this species is uncertain.

The name Phyllium bioculatum has been applied to leaf insects from the Indian Ocean and Asia. The Seychelles population is not conspecific with the Asian, P. bioculatum probably corresponds to the Seychelles species and not to the Asian species.
This species is very similar to, and possibly conspecific with, the Madagascan species Nasutitermes nigritus (Wasmann, 1897).

The Large Copper has several subspecies in Europe.

Identification at the species level has not posed problems, but determining its closest relatives and assignment to a genus has resulted in a few taxonomic changes. Hermes copper was originally described by Edwards (1870) as Chrysophanus hermes, then placed in the genus Tharsalea based by Scudder (1876). Wright (1905) described the species as Chrysophanus delsud, but this was a synonym (Wright 1908, Tilden 1975). Later work focused at the sub-generic level and a more complete summary can be found in Marschalek and Klein (2010).  Placement in the monotypic genus Hermelycaena is suggested based on recent morphological and ecological (Miller and Brown 1979), molecular (Pratt and Wright 2002), and larval (Ballmer and Pratt 1989) data. Pelham (2008) placed the Hermes copper in the genus Lycaena and subgenus Hermelycaena.
According to the World Spider Catalog Macrothele should be placed in its own family the Macrothelidae.

Subfamily Potamiscinae. The generic placement of Hainanpotamon globosum has been unclear for some time. Bott (1970) assigned the species to the genus Nanhaipotamon as Nanhaipotamon formosanum globosum. Froglia and Grippa (1986: 274, Pl. 1 Figs. b, e) reexamined the type material of Potamon (Geothelphusa) globosum Parisi, 1916, and correctly pointed out that the specimen reported by Bott (1970) does not belong to Parisi’s species. Ng and Dudgeon (1992: 743) also noted that “the G1 of Parisi’s types of P. globosum is clearly not that of Nanhaipotamon, but resembles that of Potamon orientalis Parisi, 1916, instead”, and that the two species would have been placed in the genus Ranguna Bott, 1966 but treated the generic placement of Potamon globosum as unclear.
Subfamily Potamiscinae. This species was assigned to Indochinamon by Yeo & Ng (2007).
Subfamily Pseudothelphusinae; tribe Potamocarcinini.
Should probably rather be treated as a subspecies under Morimus asper.
Taxonomic clarifications are required to be more precise about the distribution of this species (P. Horwitz pers. comm. 2009).

This species was first described as Parastacus araucanius by Faxon 1914. The name was then changed to Samastacus araucanius Riek 1971. Its current name (Virilastacus araucanius) was first used by Hobbs 1991.

Morgan (1997) noted the species to be extraordinarily variable across its range, both within and between populations. He acknowledged the possibility that more than one species was regarded as this species in his revision, but on morphological grounds treated them as a single polytypic species. Coughran (2008b) also discussed the possibility that the species may represent several taxa, and discussed the unusual variation in the cuticle partition for the species (a character generally considered to be the most reliable morphological character for the genus). Examination of population genetics is required to clarify the taxonomic status of the species (J. Coughran and J.M. Furse pers.comm 2009).

This species and Cherax tenuimanus were formerly thought to be the same species (C.M. Austin pers. comm. 2008). It has recently been proposed to re-combine these species, for functional clarity but not taxonomic similarity (Molony et al. 2006)

This species has been identified as representing two distinct taxons - Cherax cuspidatus and Cherax sp. nov (Munasinghe et al. 2004). The population which occurs from Brisbane to Coulondra has not been assessed (C.M. Austin pers. comm. 2009).

Sub species:
leniusculus (Signal crayfish): Astacus leniusculus was placed on the Official List of Specific Names in Zoology, name number 2244, in Opinion 855 of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature. (See Melville, 1968: 84).
klamathensis (Klamath Signal Crayfish)
trowbridgii: (Columbia River Signal Crayfish)

Recent genetic studies (Crandall lab) suggest that these different subspecies are in fact distinct.  Thus the P. klamathensis and P. trowbridgii might themselves be endangered whereas the P. leniusculus is more broad spread and indeed an invasive.
This species was previously known as Astacus bicarinatus (Gray 1845, Erichson 1846)
This species was previously known as Astacus Brasiliensis Von Martens (1869).
It is uncertain if this species is separate from Cherax quadricarinatus (C.M. Austin pers. comm. 2008).
Cambarus robustus is a species complex. Southern populations that are found to be undescribed species will likely require elevated conservation status (R. Thoma pers. comm.2010).
Originally described as Astacus pugnax by Poeppig (1835).

Cambarus monongalensis is a species complex that contains at least 3 species. Once taxonomic issues are resolved some of the populations will require elevated conservation status (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).
This species is a species complex   (R. Thoma, T. Jones, J. Cordeiro, pers. comm. 2009).
This is a species complex, that includes Fallicambarus hedgpethi (Hobbs 1948) and F. uhleri (Faxon 1884), which were synonomized by Hobbs and Robison (1989).
Two subspecies of this species are recognised, Cambarus bartonii bartonii Fabricius 1798 (Common Crayfish) and C. b. cavatus Hay 1902 (Appalachian Brook Crayfish).
This species is a complex comprised of two sub species: P. cubensis cubensis (Erichson, 1846) and P. cubensis rivalis (Faxon, 1912).
This species is part of a species complex consisting of Procambarus pubischlae publischalae (Hobbs 1942) and Procambarus pubischelae deficiens (Hobbs 1942).
Although this is a distinct species, the exact relationships between Fallicambarus burrisi, F. byersi, F. danielae, F. gordoni and this species needs to be determined (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).

This species was synonymized with Procambarus enoplosternum Hobbs by Hobbs (1981:388); the reasons cited were presented on page 398. On the basis of additional materials from South Carolina, there is reason to question this action; therefore, P. chacei was retained by Hobbs (1989) tentatively.

This is a species complex currently under investigation by Dr. J.E. Cooper at the North Carolina State Museum as some confusion exists as to the synonymy of several species of Cambarus (Lieb et al. 2008), in addition to subpopulations of this species. A genetic assessment is currently underway by Dr James W. Fetzner of all known populations of this species (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010). Dr J.E. Cooper is currently preparing new species manuscripts (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).

This species has three recognized subspecies, namely the Creole Painted Crayfish Orconectes palmeri creolanus (Creaser 1933), the Western Painted Crayfish Orconectes palmeri longimanus (Faxon 1898) and the Gray-Speckled Crayfish Orconectes palmeri palmeri (Faxon 1884). 

It is very difficult to distinguish this species from O. hobbsi in southwestern Mississippi and the Ponchartrain drainages of Louisiana.  However, clarification of this taxonomic issue will not change the status of this species.

This species is recognised as two subspecies; namely the Gapped Ringed Crayfish Orconectes neglectus chaenodactylus Williams, 1952 and the Ringed Crayfish Orconectes neglectus neglectus (Faxon, 1885).
