In the absence of evidence on intergradation between this crayfish and Procambarus ruthveni, it is accorded specific rank herein (M .López-Mejía, F. Alvarez. and C. Pedraza-Lara pers. comm. 2009).
This species is contained within a species complex that requires considerable attention (Hobbs 1989).
This species is thought to be part of a species complex   (M.  López-Mejía., F. Alvarez. and C. Pedraza-Lara pers. comm. 2009).

This species is a regarded as a distinct species within its taxonomically confused subgenus. Other new species within the subgenus Tubericambarus are in the process of being described (R. Thoma pers. comm. 2010).
This species is easy to identify (F. Alvarez pers. comm. 2009).

This species used to be a species complex comprised of four subspecies: O. difficilis difficilis, O. d. maletae, O. d. hathawayi and O. d. blacki (Walls 1985) but each subspecies has since been upgraded to species level (Fitzpatrick 1987).

Originally reported (1958) as intergrade populations between P. "pearsei pearsei" and P. "pearsei plumimanus", but Hobbs (1975) elevated plumimanus to full species and designated the "intergrade" populations as P. medialis after collection of additional specimens from additional localities.
Walls (2009) states that it is difficult to sperate O. palmeri from O. hobbsi at a species level.   Therefore, it is hard to definitively assign museum specimens to either species.
This species was formerly part of the Orconectes juvenilis complex (Taylor 2000).

The taxonomy of this species has been uncertain since it was first discovered by Erichson in 1846 (Hobbs and Bouchard 1973), although it is now better separated from Cambarus dubius taxonomically, and faces limited or no immediate threats.

Kentucky populations of Cambarus parvoculus may actually be this species according to preliminary genetic data from Roger Thoma (Taylor and Schuster 2004, C. Taylor, pers. comm. 2008). Recent genetic analysis has revealed that this species and C. parvoculus are separate species with Virginia populations of this species showing considerable genetic difference from Kentucky populations and rostral morphology also indicating the species are separate (Thoma and Fetzner 2008).  Other previously mentioned character states (Thoma 2000) and potential new character states were investigated and were found to not be significantly different for the two nominal species. A third, genetically identical species has been discovered, currently retained as C. jezerinaci, in an area between the ranges of C. jezerinaci and C. parvoculus in Tennessee between Pine and Cumberland Mountains (Thoma and Fetzner 2008).

Hayes (1973) reported what he interpreted to be intergrade populations between O. nana and O. macrus in Delaware and Ottawa Counties, Oklahoma, but in his recent revision of the genus, Fitzpatrick (1987) maintained specific status for these crayfishes.

There is some question as to whether populations from Anderson, Clairborne, Campbell, and Scott counties, Tennessee (Williams et al. 2007) and the North Fork Powell River and Guest River in Virginia (Winston et al. 1997), might be another undescribed species.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision (M. Mejia-Lopez pers. comm. 2009)

Hayes (1973) reported what he interpreted to be intergrade populations between O. nana and O. macrus in Delaware and Ottawa counties, Oklahoma, but in his recent revision of the genus, Fitzpatrick (1987) maintained specific status for these crayfishes
This species was previously assigned to P. lepidodactylus (Cooper, 1998).
Fallicambarus spectrum appears to represent only a distinctive color morph of this species and is therefore placed herein in the synonomy of it by Hobbs and Robison (1989).
This species is comprised of two subspecies: Procambarus vioscai vioscai (Penn 1946) and P. v. paynei (Fitzpatrick 1990).

Following Ortmann (1931), this species has been largely relegated to synonymy with Orconectes juvenilis (Hagen). Even Rhoades, in using the combination Orconectes putnami for the first time, considered it a synonym of O. juvenilis. Not until 1972 was it proposed that it again be accorded specific status, but its range and that of the closely allied O. spinosus have not been adequately invsetigated.

This species is no longer considered to be made up of the two subspecies commonly discussed in the literature. Jezerinac et al. (1995) reported that they are not considered true subspecies as they are not geographically restricted.
There is some difficulty in seperating  this species and P. penni as they are morphologically similar (Taylor and Adams pers. comm.2009).

There is significant taxonomic uncertainty surrounding this species.  It was previously classified as a subspecies of Procambarus acutus (Hobbs 1989), although, more recently it has been treated as a separate species (Hobbs and Hobbs 1995).  However, taxonomic revision of the whole P. acutus group is required (C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009). This species is accepted as a seperate species (M. López-Mejía, F. Alvarez. and C. Pedraza-Lara pers. comm. 2009).

This is a species complex comprising of Procambarus simulans regionmontanus (Villalobos, 1954) and Procambarus simulans simulans (Faxon, 1884). The range of this crayfish is by no means clearly defined.

The taxonomy of the subgenus Trisellescens is poorly understood, with further information the range of this species may be dramatically reduced, from that assessed here (S. Adams, G. Schuster and C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009).
This species may in fact be synonymous with P. steigmani (D. Johnson pers. comm. 2010).
This species is thought to be part of a species complex. work is currently being done on the taxonomy of this species (Mejia-Lopez pers. comm. 2009).
Although differing populations are somewhat distinct genetically, the species is valid taxonomically (Fetzner and Crandall 1999).
This species was formerly part of a complex but is now recognized as a distinct species by Taylor (2000).

Two new species, Cambarus speleocoopi and Cambarus laconensis, have been described from Marshall County, Alabama that were formerly attributed to this species (Buhay et al. 2007, Buhay and Crandall 2009).
In 1972 Bouchard elevated this species from the genus Cambarus to Barbicambarus due to its unique characteristics (Bouchard 1972, Hobbs 1974).
This species was formerly subsumed under Cambarus acuminatus Faxon, 1884, but questioned by Hobbs and Peters (1977) and Cooper and Braswell (1995) was and subsequently resurrected by Cooper (2001).
This species is likely a species complex which potentially includes some undescribed species   (R. Thoma, T. Jones, J. Cordeiro, pers. comm. 2009).

Genetic analyses reveal that Procambarus ferrugineus is a junior synonym of this species.  In addition, nested clade phylogeographic analysis and population genetic analysis suggest this species has had three rounds of range expansion throughout inferred evolutionary history and that three potentially new cryptic species from southwestern Arkansas are currently inappropriately nested within the confines of the current description of the species (Crandall et al. 2009).  New species descriptions may be warranted (G. Schuster and C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009).
Walls (2009) considered this species to have two subspecies, O. h. hathawayi to the east, O. h. blacki to the west, with an intergrade zone between the two.

Specimens of the genus from eastern Arkansas and southeastern Missouri may represent only a local variant of Faxonella clypeata. Studies of populations in eastern Arkansas and southern Missouri are badly needed (C. Taylor, G. Schuster, pers. comm. 2009).

Procambarus hagenianus is a species complex consisting of two sub species: Procambarus hagenianus hagenianus: Southern Prairie Crayfish (Faxon, 1884) and Procambarus hagenianus vesticeps: Egyptian Crayfish Fitzpatrick 1978.

There have been problems finding the reference Fitzpatrick 1983b: 198, Figure 193.
This species is related to the Procambarus acutus species complex; these are in need of taxonomic revision (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).
This species is a species complex, consisting of  Procambarus oaxacae  Hobbs 1973 and Procambarus reddelli  Hobbs 1973 (Mejia-Ortiz et al. 2003).
In the absence of evidence on intergradation between this crayfish and P. (A.) zapoapensis, it is accorded specific rank (M .López-Mejía, F. Alvarez. and C. Pedraza-Lara pers. comm. 2009).

The type of LeConte's Astacus penicillatus is no longer extant. In as much as Hagen (1870) and Faxon (1884, 1885a, 1890, and 1914) confused other species with it, and, in the latter work, Faxon included members of two species in his type series of C. barbatus (=A. penicillatus), his "Type" was designated the neotype fo LeConte's A. penicillatus to establish the identity of the latter's species (A. Eversole pers. comm. 2009).

The syntypes in the National Museum of Natural History are specimens collected by W.S. Newlon from the type locality and were received from the Kansas Museum of Natural History; presumably they represent a part of the lot that was said by Faxon (1914:420) to have been at Washburn College   (S. Adams, G. Schuster, C. Taylor, pers. comm. 2009).

This species appears to be indistinguishable from Orconectes virilis (Hagen). Further work needs to be done to distinguish between this species, O. virilis and O. nais (Hobbs 1974). In 1978, Unger presented evidence to suggest these were in fact distinct species.

Joe Fitzpatrick Jr. was working on a taxonomic revision of this species in which he believed this species was comprised of 3 other species. Through the work of Hobbs Jr, Hobbs III, and Fitzpatrick Jr., Procambarus zonagulus (Hobbs and Hobbs 1990) has already been split off; and the Mexican species Procambarus blandingii cuevachicae has been designated as a subspecies of this species (Hobbs 1967).
This species was formerly part of the Orconectes juvenilis complex (Taylor 2000).

This species has a range that overlaps that of Cambarus diogenes. Recently, recognition of  this species as a subspecies of C. diogenes is rejected, and specific rank has been afforded to it (Fetzner 2008).

The species was split into two taxa by Hobbs (1981), and Florida records are now considered to be for Procambarus talpoides. As pointed out by Faxon (1884:140), the descriptions of P. advena and C. carolinus were transposed in Hagen's monograph, and pl. 1:figs. 51-54 and pl. 3:fig. 165 are actually of P. advena. (see. Hobbs, 1981:311 for a detailed bibliography and explanation).
This species was originally described as a subspecies of Orconectes propinquus, but was elevated to a full species by Fitzpatrick (1967).
Fitzpatrick (1972) has stated that some taxonomic uncertainty exists regarding species classification, particularly with some subpopulations in this species range.

The freshwater crayfish, Orconectes difficilis, formerly had four subspecies (O. difficilis blacki, O. difficilis maletae, O. difficilis hathawayi, O. difficilis difficilis) (Walls 1985), all of which were elevated to full species status (Fitzpatrick 1987, Hobbs 1989). As such, the species currently occurs in Pittsburg and Latimer Counties, Oklahoma, into Washington County, Arkansas.  Texas records are O. maletae and Louisiana records are O. hathawayi.

This is a species complex which is currently under investigation by Dr. Chris Taylor and Professor Guenter Schuster (C. Taylor pers. comm. 2009) as there is uncertainty around whether it is a valid species, or if it is just a regional variation of Orconectes chickasawae.
This subspecies was raised to species status by Buhay and Crandall (2008).
This species has two subspecies; the nominal subspecies from the Greek island Ikaria (Stenopterus similatus similatus), and S. s. mehli Sama, 1995, from the island of Cyprus.

Some authors consider T. fuscus (Goeze, 1777) as synonym of T. mauritanicus (Linnaeus, 1758). However, most recent authors consider T. fuscus as a valid species, clearly separated from T. mauritanicus based on ecological criteria (P. Bahillo de la Puebla pers. comm. 2009).
López-Colón (2000) considers that this species belongs to genus Pseudolucanus.
This species is of questionable taxonomic status (B. Büche pers. comm. 2009).
In some works it is referred to as P. cinereus.
This species has been recently synonymized as Otolelus neglectus (Jacquelin du Duval, 1863).

The taxonomic status of this species appears to be unclear due to the varying opinions of different authors. In Spain, this species is currently regarded as a variety of C. pilosus (Gonzáles Peña et al. 2007). Sama (2000) however states this is a separate species and this is supported by Brustel et al. (2002).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species,  but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.

L'Inventaire national du patrimoine naturel (INPN; France) website uses the name Ampedus scrofa Germar, 1944 for this species as it indicates that this species is actually A. aethiops sensu Dajoz, 1962 and not that of Lacordaire, 1835. A. scrofa is also used by the Spanish authors Zapata de la Vega and Sánchez-Ruiz (2012).

Ampedus gallicus has been described as 'new to science' from France but has not been reported elsewhere. It seems unlikely that there really is an endemic French Ampedus and so this species is probably going to be synonymised with another Ampedus species at some stage in the future. Until such a review takes place, A. gallicus must remain as a separate species and be assessed for the Red List separately. It is within the A. nemoralis group.
Recorded from the Atlas Mountains in northern Africa. However, these records are thought to be related to different species (R. ungaricus and R. siculus).

The taxonomic status of the species needs to be confirmed. Wollaston (died 1878) tells in the original description: 'the only specimen which I have yet seen of this insect was captured by myself (beneath the bark of a felled Spanish chestnut-tree) at the Agua Mansa, in Tenerife. Possibly it may be but a geographical state of the European P. depressus; but further material would be necessary, for comparison, before such could be ascertained'.
According to some authors the taxonomic status of this species is doubtful, and is regarded as a synonym of A. pomorum.
The modern use of the name A. karpathicus includes the two - formerly separately recognised - species A. karpathicus (central Europe) and A. suecicus Pal (Fennoscandia).
This species was previously placed as Brachypteroma ottomanum Heyden, 1863. However, it is now recognised that the former synonym, Dolocerus reichii Mulsant, 1862 is the pre-existing senior name.
The taxonomic status is uncertain and is considered doubtful by several Elateridae experts. It is likely to be very close to other Ampedus species (A. pomoni).
This species is taxonomically uncertain and its status is questionable (B. Büche pers. comm. 2009).
Note that in Lobl and Smetana (2006) this name is spelt T. friwaldszkyi and T. frivaldszkyi.

In some data sources, P. egregius is placed in a different genus, as Callimus egregius. Bense (1995) refers to the view of Aldbauer (1988) that Callimus egregius ssp. semicyaneus (Pic, 1905) is the subspecies which occurs in Greece and south-western Turkey. P. egregius and P. semicyaneus are treated as separate species in here.
The description date of this species has been quoted as 1862, but it is actually 1863 (Boucher et al., 2013).
This species might be a synonym of M. palmi - but verification is pending.
This species has many synonyms and a taxonomic revision is needed.

Although Thymalus oblongus Reitter, 1889 may have been sometimes confused with Thymalus aubei Léveillé, 1877 and Thymalus subtilis Reitter, 1889 it is not synonymous with either. T. aubei (syn. T. subtilis), is a species endemic from Caucasus (Nikitsky et al. 1998, Kolibáč 2013).
This species was described on the basis of a single larva from the type locality in Sweden and the validity of this species is in question.

According to Dolin (1988) this species is a synonym of A. nigrinus Herbst, 1784, but Lobl and Smetana (2007), treat A. auripes and A. nigrinus as two separate species. Wurst & Kaupp (1995) accorded it the status of a valid species. Jarzabek-Müller and Müller (2008) provide a discussion on the distinction between the two species.
The taxonomic status of this species may need confirmation.
According to Dolin (1988), this species is a synonym of  A. nigerrimus, but Lobl and Smetana (2007) regard  A. brunnicornis and A. nigerrimus as two separate species.
Leipaspis lauricola has two subspecies: L. l. lauricola Wollaston, 1862 and L. l. gomerensis Wollaston, 1862 (Plata-Negrache and Prendes-Ayala 1981).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.


According to Lobl and Smetana (2006) O. barnabita is synonym of O. coriarium.
Several Elateridae experts consider this to be a synonym (simple variation) of A. balteatus therefore the status may be uncertain (B. Büche pers. comm. 2009).
This species has four subspecies: provincialis Colas, 1949, serraticornis Fairmaire, 1859, sicilianus Planet, 1899 and tetraodon Thunberg, 1806.
The female of this species is unknown.
The taxonomy of this species and its relatives in the cognatus-group is dramatic and in need of an urgent revision.
Confused with N. farinosa of eastern and southern Africa, status of the western African species requires further study.
Pinhey (1970) treated a different, as yet unnamed, species from eastern Africa as T. basitincta. Many old records under this name refer to T. aconita (see Dijkstra 2007).
Formerly placed in the genus Eothemis.
Genus Lokia is most likely a synonym to Aethiothemis (Dijkstra unpublished).

Concerning the taxonomy of the difficult supinus-group consult Dijkstra (2007). The taxonomy of this species requires further work to determine the correct identity of this species. It may be quirki , seydeli or styx .
Isomecocnemis is a synonym of Chlorocnemis (Dijkstra unpubl.).
This species will become Aethiothemis erythromelas.
The subspecies leonense (incorrect spelling: leonensis) is invalid, as the distinguishing character of the thoracic markings is variable (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Possibly all western African records follow a confusion with E. girardi.

The species was first described by Martin (1909) in the genus Psilocnemis Selys, 1863 (nom. praeoccup.), then placed in Copera Kirby, 1890 by Morton (1924). Structurally it is very similar to Platycnemis pennipes (Pallas, 1771) and was therefore regarded as a subspecies of the latter (St. Quentin 1964, 1965, Asahina 1973). But already Schmidt (1950, 1954) and later Dumont (1977) attributed full specific rank. The distribution of this east Mediterranean endemic overlaps in southeast Turkey and Syria (Schneider 1986, Kalkman and van Pelt 2006). Structural differences were described by Schneider (1983, 1986), Schneider and Moubayed (1985), and again by Dumont (1991). These authors also regarded both taxa as sister species.

The species was treated by S. Asahina as Enallagma deserti yezoensis Asahina, 1949 (junior synonym), and then as E. boreale yezoensis (Asahina, 1982). E. belyshevi Haritonov, 1975 is a junior synonym of the species (Paulson et al. 1998). E. circulatum continentale Belyshev, 1956 is a junior synonim of E. cyathigerum (Charp 1840).

The status of Calopteryx orientalis is disputable. Some authors treat this taxon as a subspecies of C. splendens. C. transcaspica Bartenev, 1911 is considered by Dumont (Dumont 1996, Dumont et al. 1997) as junior synonym of Calopteryx orientalis, but Borisov (2007) gives it a full species rank. This assessment is for C. orientalis sensu stricto, without the data on C. transcaspica.
The identification of pale species of Sympetrum is problematic and records predating the revision by Joedicke (1994) can not be trusted.
This species is likely a junior synonym of E. abjecta.

Description of Navas (1920) based on one male from "Buenos Aires" with no particular locality, too vague to establish specific identity; it could correspond to one of the other two species of Peristicta present in Argentina (P. aenoviridis or P. forceps). Never found again, type apparently lost, and species validity doubtful (Pessacq 2007)
Garrison (2006) considers this species as a possible junior synonym of Mnesarete guttifera, although he did not formally synonymize them pending examination of more specimens from Bahia State
This is the smallest Argia species (20-23 mm).
Was included in R. cornigera (Aeshna cornigera) until von Ellenrieder (2003).
This genus was recently revised by Libert (2000).
This butterfly is from one of three genera in a genus group that was revised recently by Henning and Henning (2004). No subspecies have been described for this species.
This species used to be considered a subspecies of Hewitsonia boisduvalii with which it is sympatric in the most western parts of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) (Bouyer 1997).
This genus falls into the genus group that was recently revised by Libert (1999).

It is likely to be a valid species since there are no indications that it might be an aberration. The genus was recently revised by Michel Libert who examined the quasi-totality of voucher material in public and private collections: about 70% of all are in the African Butterfly Research Institute, <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:city w:st="on">Nairobi (Libert 2007).</st1:city></st1:place><st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on"></st1:country-region></st1:place>
This endemic island species is derived from the common mainland butterfly Neptis serena, though it is now well differentiated. There are no formally recognized subspecies for the taxon.

This species was described as being from Sierra Leone but this is considered patria falsa by Larsen (2005), since none has since been collected between Sierra Leone and southern Cameroon. One record from Côte d’Ivoire is certainly just a misidentification.
This species is split into the two subspecies E. d. dorothea and E. dorothea warrengashi.
This species has two subspecies, the nominate subspecies and subspecies P. c. hermeli Nuyda 1992 (Page and Treadaway 2003).
This species has the two subspecies, H. a. auricostalis and H. auricostalis frommi. The Tanzanian subspecies name frommi may be redundant (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
Synonyms: Hypokopelates or Deudorix anettae – usually including ssp. anetia [a valid species]
This species has three subspecies: A. r. rutherfordii, A. rutherfordii cyclops and A. rutherfordii herwigii.

In the revision by Henning and Henning (2004) of the Teriomima Kirby genus group the authors added a seventh species, T. williami, to the six already described Teriomima species. Teriomima williami was described from two forests in southern Mozambique, Dondo in Sofala Province and Amatongas in Manica Province. However, taxonomic work is still required to check the specific status of T. williami to its close allies T. zuluana, T. puella and T. puellaris.
There are no subspecies of this species.
No subspecies have been described. Vane-Wright and de Jong (2003) have adopted the genus name Dacalana rather than Ancema.
Ten subspecies were recognised by Evans (1957).
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.

This taxon is usually considered a subspecies of Lepidochrysops cinerea (Bethune-Baker 1923). However it was raised it to species rank since there are slight differences in the form of the valves and the two taxa are strongly disjunt.
This species has no subspecies.
This butterfly has no recent synonyms but has three subspecies; the nominate, ssp. bamendanus, and ssp. felthami.

The nominate subspecies was described from Angola and is found also in Zambia and southern DRC. A further subspecies (ssp. kongwana) occurs in Malawi, much of eastern Tanzania, Uganda and southern Kenya. Ssp. peeli is also recorded from Somalia, but this appears to be biogeographically anomalous. It has been suggested that ssp. peeli may simply represent a dry season form of the nominate subspecies (D'Abrera 1997). Therefore, the taxonomy of this subspecies remains uncertain.
This species has no known subspecies.
There are no known subspecies of this species.

Three subspecies are described for this butterfly but some sources consider the variation best described as a cline and not in subspecific terms (Larsen 2005).

A pair of specimens in ABRI from Taï National Park in Côte d’Ivoire is ochreous rather than creamy. The male forewing apical patch is strongly developed and the underside is of the ssp. cydaria pattern with postdiscal spots. The genitalia are of the Pentila picena type, with minor differences. If constant in western Côte d’Ivoire, it represents a new subspecies – or even species – but with a single pair and no real difference in genitalia, it is not yet formally recognized.
This species was previously regarded as a subspecies of Papilio elwesi, a very similar species found on mainland China (Collins and Morris 1985).
Numerous subspecies have been described.

This butterfly has the three subspecies Paradeudorix eleala eleala, P. eleala viridis and P. eleala parallela. The subspecies P. eleala cufadana is also used by some but is probably a junior synonym of ssp. parallela (Larsen 2005).
This species was only described in 2007 following a revision of the genus (Libert 2007).
Two subspecies are formally recognized for this taxon: Cymothoe weymeri weymeri Suffert, 1904 and  C. weymeri mulatta Belcastro, 1990.
This butterfly was described by Libert as recently as 1996 and is difficult to identify with certainty.
This genus is part of the genus group Epitola that was recently revised (Libert 1999). It occurs in two subspecies.
This species was included in the genus Pseudodipsas until Sands (1971) established its association with Hypochrysops (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Tennent pers. comm. 2008).
This species has two subspecies, the nominate subspecies and subspecies P. o. cabale (Savela 2010, Page and Treadaway 2003).
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
There was one subspecies which is thought to be now extinct (Collins and Morris 1985): Papilio phorbanta nana (Oberthür).

Kersten's Ciliate Blue is closely related to the common species Anthene larydas which is distributed across equatorial and west Africa. It is suggested by M. Libert (pers. comm.) that this butterfly may in fact be a subspecies of A. larydas. However, this does not affect the assessment as both taxa are clearly Least Concern.
This butterfly has the two subspecies C. b. bocqueti and C. bocqueti oubanguiensis. The taxonomy of the “black Charaxes” is always uncertain and the status of ssp. oubanguiensis is not clear.
This species is most closely related to the common I. menas of the drier northern savannahs (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
Records for Côte d'Ivoire in Ackery et al. (1995) are based on misidentification of material belonging to Liptena similis (Larsen 2005).
There are no recently or widely used synonyms. There are two suggested subspecies currently recognised, the more widely distributed nominate subspecies and ssp. somalina found in Somaliland.

The genus, with very characteristic genitalia, is currently considered to consist of four species. However, a fifth species seems to be present as well and its relationship to the others is uncertain (dissections performed with a view on checking material from <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Nigeria</st1:place></st1:country-region> by Larsen).
This species was formerly included in the genus Castalius. The Nigeria/Cameroon population is particularly isolated and may possibly be a distinct species.

This butterfly (known as P. daplidice for the last 250 years) was recently separated into two species: P. daplidice and P. edusa Fabricius, 1777 (Geiger et al. 1988), but the latter is currently considered to be a subspecies of the former (Porter et al. 1997; Honey and Scoble 2001). Nominotypical daplidice occurs throughout northwest Africa, the Iberian peninsula, Corsica, Sardinia and northwest Europe (occurs occasionally in the UK as an infrequent migrant/vagrant). P. daplidice edusa occurs in northwest France, and Italy eastwards, with a hybrid zone in northwest Italy. The taxa were separated by electrophoretic analysis and cannot be separated with any degree of certainty on external morphology.
The male genitalia clearly demonstrate that it is a valid species, but males are also easily identified from external features.
Four insular subspecies have been described.

There are two confirmed subspecies of this butterfly, the nominate and ssp. praecyola, which intergrade in eastern Nigeria. The ssp. filaprae Suffert, 1904 from southern Cameroon, Gabon, and parts of the DRC is of uncertain status and the proposed ssp. fernandus on Bioko is better classified as a distinct species (Larsen 2005). Classification of ssp. praecyola as a ssp. of Papilio fernandus Fruhstorfer, 1903 is widely believed to be incorrect due to major morphological differences between the two.

Ackery & Vane-Wright (1984: 55) commented on the fact that E. core, with which a large number of names have historically been associated across a wide geographical range (including Australia and further east into the Pacific), was not clearly defined. Modern opinion suggests that many of what were previously considered races of E. core are distinct species, or subspecies of other Euploea species (eg. E. charox Cramer, 1780).
This butterfly is split into the two subspecies E. c. crossei and E. crossei akani.

The taxonomic status of this butterfly in relation to Megalopalpus zymna is not clear. Some authors treat the two as distinct species, others as subspecies of the latter. The taxon included as M. simplex is small and has a light underside compared to the brown of M. zymna and appears to be the only morph that flies in Tanzania and Uganda.

A number of subspecies have been defined, but the validity of many of these is uncertain because of the reliance of the species on cryptic colouration and the large amount of variation in this colouration, in response to substrate colouration, between and within subpopulations (W.J. Tennent pers. comm. 2008).
This butterfly has three subspecies, B. s. smithi, B. smithi eurypterus and B. smithi fernandina.
There are no described subspecies for this little known species.
Several subspecies have been described across the species’ wide geographical range.

Collins and Larsen (1998) reviewed the extensive material of Eresiomera held by the African Butterfly Research Institute, Nairobi. They described three new species. They also found two Cameroon males that seemed close to Eresiomera ouesso, but there were minor differences in both morphology and in the configuration of the genitalia and a definite conclusion was not possible.
Older records of the species are not trustworthy because of much recent revisionary work on the genus by Libert (1996).
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon.
Two weakly differentiated subspecies are recognised: Tuxentius carana carana Hewitson, 1876 and Tuxentius carana kontu Karsch, 1893.

Whether all populations of this species are genuinely conspecific remains to be ascertained by DNA analysis. The type locality is Mabira Forest in Uganda and the populations in western Kenya and northwestern Tanzania all belong to this species sensu stricto. Those in Kivu Province in the DRC probably also belong to this species sensu stricto, while records from Congo and Cameroon might be different. Material resembling Mylothris continua in Ghana would be a distinct species.
Several subspecies have been described.
This species was described recently following Libert's revision of the genus (2007).
This species has three subspecies: Iolaus hemicyanus hemicyanus, I. hemicyanus barbara and I. hemicyanus barnsi.

This is a very unusual element of the Afrotropical fauna since it belongs to a wholly western Palaearctic genus and seems to be derived from P. deota in the Himalaya of India. It has two subspecies. The nominate subspecies is common in the Ethiopian highlands whilst the subspecies marghanita is very rarely encountered in the northern Tanzanian highlands.
Three subspecies have been proposed (A. delicata delicata, A. delicata tanzania, A. delicata zanzibarica).
Records from west of the Dahomey Gap are misidentified females of Liptena helena (Larsen 2005).

Some of the western specimens pertain to the composita­-form, which might be a distinct species or a morph of the same species. The taxonomy of these species is still in flux. It cannot be treated as a subspecies since it is sympatric with E. themis throughout and is just possibly a distinct species. It will need close study in an area of sympatry to be sure (Larsen 2005).

The species was originally described in 1969 after a few Nigerian specimens and a female from Côte d’Ivoire (the latter subsequently reassigned to Torbenia wojtusiaki as have all other similar material from west of the Dahomey Gap). Therefore, the genus revision confirmed that the species is found only east of the Dahomey Gap (Libert 2005).
This species was described only in 2005 following Libert's revision of the genus (Libert 2005).

Specimens recently collected in Ghana and Guinea probably comprise one or more different species (M. Libert pers. comm. 2008). The assessment is therefore based on A. prouvosti sensu stricto as in the original description.
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
This butterfly has the four subspecies C. e. etheocles, C. etheocles carpenteri, C. etheocles evansi and C. etheocles ochracea.
At least three subspecies have been described.

The relationship of this species to Hewitsonia bitjeana from southern Cameroon is disputed. Bouyer (1997) considers them a single species for which the latter name would take precedence (Bouyer now tends to consider beryllina a western subspecies (pers. comm.)). Larsen (2005) considers them two species. However, very few records exist (five or six in all) for either taxon.

There is some uncertainty over the taxonomic status of the very similar forest butterfly Arhopala similis Druce, 1895, which shares the distribution of A. agesias. Rather than comprising a discrete species, it is suggested that A. similis instead represents a morph of the latter.
This butterfly consists of the following three subspecies: P. leonina leonina, P. leonina dimitris and P. leonina indentata.
Four subspecies have been described. Vane-Wright & de Jong (2003) suggested that the relationship of rosenbergi to its congenors mitisi Staudinger and hyparete Linnaeus was unclear.

This genus (along with other members of the Teriomima group) was revised by Henning and Henning (2004). There are three described subspecies for this butterfly, the nominate, ssp. subgrisea and ssp. marginata. However, the taxonomy of this genus is difficult, the species are small and the Teriomima group often lack morphological characters to distinguish them. The two northern subspecies are at least 800 km from the southern population, the nominate, and the Zambezi river would act as a barrier between the north and the south. It is very likely that more than one species is involved. The taxonomic status must be viewed with caution until more detailed work, including DNA samples, can be done.

Heath (1997) synonymized Spindasis with Apharitis, while Williams (2002) lumps both Spindasis and Apharitis into Cigaritis. Larsen (2005), in his Butterflies of West Africa, maintains the three seperate genera.
A number of subspecies have been described from specific mountain ranges.
There are no subspecies described for this butterfly.
The possibility that it is a “phantom species” cannot be ruled out and is becoming increasingly probable since no other specimens are known to have turned up.

No subspecies have been described. It has been confused with Spindasis lohita Horsfield, 1829, leading to confusion over its distribution. S. lohita is more widespread than this species and is found across Southeast Asia from India through to Java, whilst this species is limited to Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo and possibly Sumatra.
This butterfly has two subspecies, the nominate and ssp. fournierae.
The genera formerly included in the genus Epitola were recently revised by Libert (1999).

There are several uncertainties over the identification of certain records of this taxon:

Larsen (2005) believes records from Volta and Togo are misidentifications of Telipna maesseni (the characters given in its description are not always clear) and that records from western Nigeria are in error for T. acraea without a red subapical patch, which do occur as rarities.

Furthermore, Libert (2005) divides the taxon into two subspecies: semirufa (= maesseni) from Togo, Ghana and Abengourou region in Côte d’Ivoire; and ivoiriensis from Côte d’Ivoire, Liberia and Guinea.

However, it is now widely agreed that T. maesseni is a junior synonym to the senior synonym T. semirufa. Therefore, the only part of the distribution in which the taxonomy is still considered uncertain is that in Togo and Nigeria.

It may simply be an aberration of Leptomyrina gorgias, which goes into the dry zone of Kenya. Identification of species within the genus is not always easy. It has not been possible to inspect the holotype (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).

Until recently, most authors included this butterfly in the genus Neohipparchia (Tennent 1996, Tolman 1997, etc.), now commonly downgraded to the rank of subgenus. The butterfly has also been regarded by some authors as a subspecies of the very variable Hipparchia (Neohipparchia) hansii, to which it bears a superficial similarity; however, this butterfly's diagnostic features are constant and external morphology suggests that it is a distinct species. There is not much known about Powell's Grayling because it has only recently been split from Austaut's Grayling (Hipparchia hansii).
There are no described subspecies for this butterfly.

This species is only known from a single specimen caught at Kigour Forest, DRC. Some uncertainty remains over whether the taxon is distinct from Neptis rothschildi, or whether the taxa are synonymous, as proposed by E. Vingerhoedt (pers. comm. 2008). This uncertainty is likely to remain while records of the species continue to be scarce (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009).
This butterfly has two subspecies, B. e. evadne and B. evadne elionias.

It used to be thought that the range of this species stretched from <st1:country-region w:st="on">Sierra Leone</st1:country-region> to <st1:place w:st="on"><st1:country-region w:st="on">Uganda</st1:country-region></st1:place>. However, M. Libert is currently in the process of revising the Afrotropical Lycaenesthini and has divided the species into three sibling species with slight overlap in distributions (M. Libert pers. comm. 2008). Therefore, the true distribution of this butterfly is now defined as from Ghana to Cameroon.
Species in this genus were formerly included in the genus Epitola.
This butterfly has two subspecies called Precis rauana rauana and P. rauana silvicola.
Evans (1957) recognised nine subspecies.
This species had previously been confused with Ornipholidotos ntebi, which is effectively limited to east of the Albertine Rift (Kenya, Uganda, northwestern Tanzania).

This species is endemic to the Bismarck Archipelago, where it occurs on each of the major islands. Nominotypical obscura occurs on New Ireland (the type locality), the Tabar Islands (C. J. Muller: unpublished data), and Nusa Laut. It is represented on New Britain, Umboi and the Duke of York group by C. o. antippe Grose Smith, 1889; on New Hanover by C. o. hormisda Fruhstorfer, 1915; and on the Admiralty group (Manus, Los Negros, St Gabriel) by C. o. gabrielis (Müller 1999).
Vane-Wright and de Jong (2003) include this species as one of the seventeen that have been reclassified under Lohora, possibly rendering Mycalesis paraphyletic.
This butterfly has the two subspecies N. ophione ophione and N. ophione nucleata.
This butterfly has the two subspecies S. o. occidentalium and S. occidentalium penricei. Historically this species was placed in the synonymous genus Asterope.

This species was previously considered to be a form of Neptis nicomedes but was recently upgraded to species level by Larsen (2005). The taxonomic complex remains a difficult one: both species are forest butterflies which may occur together or either of them singly. In addition, more than one species may be covered under the taxon Neptis quintilla, as subpopulations of the species come in two colour morphs: one is the usual dark blackish-brown of the genus, while the other is a lighter blackish-grey with no hint of brown (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009). The valve of the grey form is 25% longer than that of the dark. As a whole, therefore, some degree of uncertainty remains over the status of this difficult taxon.
The species has been documented in Guinea and Ghana, though these records are considered to be erroneous and suggested to refer to darker specimens of Belenois theora.
There are no formally recognized subspecies for this taxon, nor are there any widely used synonyms.
In the Lagos Region of Nigeria, there is a slight overlap with Mimacraea apicalis (which was elevated to full species status during Libert's revision (2000)).

The genus Drupadia is interesting in that it occurs in some areas in “pairs” of species similar in phenotype, but with clear structural differences. One species is invariably large and sexually dimorphic; the second is smaller in size and less sexually dimorphic, with both sexes resembling the female of the larger species. Drupadia cindi and Drupadia cinderella Cowan, 1974 represent such a pairing. Both are recorded from Sabah and Sarawak.

This species was assigned to the new genus Cerautola following Libert's recent revision (1999) and it divides into four subspecies. The nominate subspecies is found from Guinea-Bissau to western Nigeria; ssp leucographa Libert, 1999 is in Cameroon, Congo, Gabon, northern Angola, Central African Republic and western Congo and ssp. holochroma Berger, 1981 flies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Uganda, with ssp. congdoni Libert & Collins, 1999 in northwestern Tanzania and Zambia.

A number of subspecies – difficult to characterize properly – are recognized. In the eastern parts of the range a number of similar species occur, which are difficult to tell apart from this butterfly.
Identification of most species from this genus requires dissection to determine subtle genital distinctions.

Three subspecies are currently recognized for this widely distributed taxon: one occurring in western Africa (from Guinea to eastern Nigeria), another in the equatorial zone, and a third in the coastal forests of East Africa (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009).
This genus was recently revised by Libert (2007), whereupon two subspecies of this butterfly were described, the nominate and ssp. depuncta.
This butterfly has the two subspecies, I. i. iasis and I. iasis albomaculatus.

A number of subspeceis have been described. The nominate caleta occurs in northern and central Sulawesi; Caleta caleta kalawara Ribbe, 1926 was described from central Sulawesi, but may be synonymous with nominate caleta (Takanami 1989). The subpopulation found on Peleng may warrant recognition as a distinct subspecies (Vane-Wright and De Jong 2003). There is some doubt regarding the status of the Philippines subpopulations, argola Hewitson, 1876, which Hirowatari (1992) regarded as a sister species of caleta, but which Treadaway (1995) treated as a subspecies of caleta.

Two subspecies are noted: Harpendyreus aequatorialis aequatorialis Sharpe, 1892 (Type locality: Kenya: Mount Elgon), and Harpendyreus aequatorialis vulcanica Joicey & Talbot, 1924 (Type locality: Tanzania: Arusha district).

Stewart, B.A. and Griffiths, C.L. 1995. Revision of the family Paramelitidae (Crustacea, Amphipoda) from South African fresh waters. Annals of the South African Museum 104 , 181-247. (A modern monograph using both cladistic and phenetic methods. The family is split into three genera. Aquadulcaris gen.nov. (type Gammarus crassicornis), with A. andronyx, A. auricularia, A. crassicornis, A. dentata, A. marunguis, and A. pheronyx (all transf. from Paramelita), Mathamelita n.gen. for M. aequicaudata n.sp. (Outenique Mountains), and Paramelita s. str., for P. aurantia, P. barnardi, P. capensis, P. flexa, P. granulicornis, P. kogelensis, P. magna, P. magnicornis, P. nigroculus, P. odontophora, P. parva, P. pillicornis, P. pinnicornis, P. platypus, P. seticornis, P. spinicornis, P. tulbaghensis, and P. validicornis. The generotype, P. ctenodactyla, is a junior synonym of P. capensis.

Stewart, B.A. and Griffiths, C.L. 1995. Revision of the family Paramelitidae (Crustacea, Amphipoda) from South African fresh waters. Annals of the South African Museum 104 , 181-247. (A modern monograph using both cladistic and phenetic methods. The family is split into three genera. Aquadulcaris gen.nov. (type Gammarus crassicornis), with A. andronyx, A. auricularia, A. crassicornis, A. dentata, A. marunguis, and A. pheronyx (all transf. from Paramelita), Mathamelita n.gen. for M. aequicaudata n.sp. (Outenique Mountains), and Paramelita s. str., for P. aurantia, P. barnardi, P. capensis, P. flexa, P. granulicornis, P. kogelensis, P. magna, P. magnicornis, P. nigroculus, P. odontophora, P. parva, P. pillicornis, P. pinnicornis, P. platypus, P. seticornis, P. spinicornis, P. tulbaghensis, and P. validicornis. The generotype, P. ctenodactyla, is a junior synonym of P. capensis.
This species is split into the two subspecies B. l. laetitia and B. laetitia vesta.
This butterfly has two subspecies, B. m. martius and B. martius sanaos.
This butterfly has the three subspecies Pseudathyma plutonica plutonica, P. plutonica expansa and P. plutonica shaba.
Paraphlebia may not belong to the family Megapodagrionidae, but may instead be related to the Costa Rican/Panamanian Thaumatoneura, which has been given its own family by some authors.
Should probably be placed in the family Paratemiidae.
The original description was by Lieftinck (1951), with holotype from Coen, Cape York Peninsula, Queensland. Further taxonomic information provided Houston and Watson (1988).
Taxonomic history provided by Houston and Watson (1988).
The original description was by Tillyard (1908), as Nannodythemis dalei. Further taxonomic information provided Houston and Watson (1988).
Originally called Metathemis guttata (Selys), var. pallida by Tillyard (1910) and later recognized as a distinct by Theischinger (1995). See Theischinger (1995) for the full taxonomic history.
Detail account on taxonomic history is provided by Theischinger and O’Farrell (1986)
Original description Diplax nigrescens, by Martin (1901), and further taxonomic information is provided by Houston and Watson (1988).
The original description was based on specimens collected from the Bellinger River, New South Wales (Tillyard 1913). Additional taxonomic information see Houston and Watson (1988).

The original description was by Tillyard (1906) based on both sexes from north-eastern Queensland. A full taxonomic history on the species was presented by Theischinger (1997), who suggested that Pseudagrion ignifer was a complex of two subspecies.
The original description was by Martin (1907) and further information is provided by Houston and Watson (1988).
Detail account on taxonomic history is provided by Watson (1991).

The original description was by J.A.L Watson, in Watson et al. (1991). The holotype was a male from Koongarra, 1252’S, 132 50’E, 15 km east Mount Cahill, Northern Territory, 6-10 March 1973, collected by Dr J.A.L. Watson. Larval description Hawking (1993).
The original description was by Tillyard (1906). Additional taxonomic history is presented by Watson and Theischinger (1984).
The original description was by Theischinger (1999). Female and larva unknown (Theischinger and Hawking 2006).
The original description was by Selys (1871) and additional information provided by Houston and Watson (1988).

The genus Archaeosynthemis was established by Carle (1995). Originally described in Selys-Longchamps (1871). Tillyard (1910) presented an updated description. An overview of taxonomic history provided by Houston and Watson (1988).
Detail account on taxonomic history is provided by Watson (1991).
The adult descriptions was by Theischinger (1999) and the larva by Theischinger and Hawking 2000).

Described in Selys-Longchamps (1874). Tillyard (1910) presented an updated description and an overview of taxonomic history is provided by Houston and Watson (1988). The species regina was transferred from the genus Synthemis to Parasynthemis by Carle (1995).

The original description was by McLachlan (1883), as Syncordulia atrifrons; referenced by Houston and Watson (1988). Further information on the adult (Theischinger and Watson 1978) and the larva (Theischinger and Watson 1984).
The original description was by Sélys (1853), and later, Fraser (1956) described a new subspecies. Additional information is provided by Stewart (1980) and Houston and Watson (1988).
Originally described as Metathemis guttata auriolineata Tillyard, 1913 and later recognized as a distinct species by Theischinger (1995). See Theischinger (1995) for the full taxonomic history.
The species was described from Victoria (Martin 1901) and further taxonomic history is provided by Theischinger (1982) and Houston and Watson (1988)

Only the female of Microgomphus verticalis is known. Fraser (1934) states that “it is closely related to, if not conspecific with, M. souteri”; this should be investigated further, if true M. souteri Fraser, 1934 is a junior synonym of M. verticalis.

A poorly known species; the only published records are from a small area of west Java. G.T. Reels and this assessor (R. Dow) found what appears to be this species at Bako National Park in west Sarawak, Malaysia in 2005 (R. Dow pers. obs. 2008). Confirmation of the identity of material from Bako awaits detailed comparison against the type series, but agreement with the original description is good, except in size and for minor details of colouration; such differences might be expected given the distance between the populations.

Onychogomphus kerri was briefly described by Fraser (1933) from two specimens in a discussion of O. saundersii, without giving the type locality. Kimmins (1966) traced the type locality from one of the specimens (in the Natural History Museum London). It is questionable whether Fraser’s one paragraph treatment of this species even constitutes a proper description.
The female is unknown.

Fraser (1929) gave a description of Allogaster parvistigma, supposing his material to be Thecagaster parvistigma Sélys, 1873. Asahina (1982) showed that Fraser's insect was not actually conspecific with T. parvistigma, the type of which has been lost, and described the species as A. ornatus. van Pelt (1993) corrected the spelling to ornata.
It is possible that this species is a form of N. latifrons (Sélys, 1878) (see van Pelt 1993).
Ram (1985) noted that I. kishori “has interesting and intermediate characters between Ictinogomphus Cowley and Gomphidia Sélys”; this should be investigated further.
The female of Orolestes durga is unknown.
Prior to 1965 this species was treated as V. amoena Sélys, 1853.

Lestes umbrina has been treated as a synonym of both L. coccinus and L. nodalis. See Lieftinck (1960) for an account of the confusion that has surrounded this species. Some records of L. umbrina are likely to be misidentifications of L. coccinus or L. nodalis.

Libellago andamanensis was originally described as a good species by Fraser, it was later downgraded to a subspecies of L. lineata (Burmeister, 1839). Later Hämäläinen (2002) re-examined Libellago species from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and restored amdananensis to full specific status.
Burmargiolestes laidlawi was described by Lieftinck in 1960 from material previously treated as B. melanothorax (e.g. Fraser 1933).
The male of Microgomphus lilliputians is unknown.

Asahina (1981) suggested that P. nocturnalis Fraser, 1927 might be a form of this species; this issue has yet to be resolved. Asahina also raised questions about the occurrence of P. magdalena in the Himalayan area.

Fraser (1933) included Aciagrion tillyardi and Enallagma assamica as junior synonyms of A. approximans. Enallagma assamica was a subject of long taxonomical confusion since the holotype of A. approximans had an unknown geographical origin, was described very briefly, and lost (Joshi et al. 2016). Many authors preferred to use the name A. tillyardi as valid for this species (see Kosterin et al. 2014 for a review). This confusion was recently resolved by Kosterin et al. (2014) in favour of Fraser’s original conclusion that A. tillyardi is a junior synonym of A. approximans (Joshi et al. 2016).

Fraser (1942) established the genus Gomphidictinus for Gomphidia perakensis Laidlaw 1902, basing his separation of the two genera almost entirely on the presence of a ventral spine on the penis of G. perakensis, absent in other Gomphidia species. In most other aspects of morphology, general appearance, habits and habitat G. perakensis strongly resembles Gomphidia species. The status of the genus Gomphidictinus needs to be critically examined.
The male of B. arthuri remains undescribed.
A subspecies, V. g. montana Fraser, 1934, has been described from south India.
The female of this species has not been described.
The status of the species is doubtful.
The male of this species is unknown.
The female of this species is unknown.

Lahiri (1987) notes that two forms of this species occur in Meghalaya, a smaller form found in marshy areas and a larger form found on rocky streams, the latter form is less common. Careful study is needed to determine if the two forms do belong to the same species. Fraser (1936) notes that specimens were captured at mountain streams and makes no mention of two forms; it appears that Fraser's works refer to the larger stream form.
Asahina (1986) described a subspecies, C. p. fernandi from Meghalya.

The history of this species in the taxonomic literature is extremely confused. It has been recorded from Sundaland and Indochina, but these records all now appear to refer to different Onychogomphus species. The relationship of O. saundersii with other closely related species with which it overlaps (e.g. O. duaricus, which has been treated as a subspecies of saundersii) needs to be critically re-examined.

Four species of Hylaeothemis are currently known: H. fruhstorferi from Sri Lanka, H. apicalis from the Western Ghats, H. gardeneri from northeastern India, and H. clementia Ris, 1909 occurring in southeast Asia, east of the Indian Region.

Fraser (1946) recognised that the species from Sri Lanka and the Western Ghats were distinct and that the name H. fruhstorferi had to be restricted to the population from Sri Lanka. He described the specimens from the Western Ghats as a new species (Hylaeothemis indica Fraser, 1946). However, he overlooked that he himself had already described subspecies H. fruhstorferi apicalis for specimens from the Coorg (Western Ghats) based on the “tips of the wings, especially those of the female, broadly tipped with black”. Therefore, H. f. apicalis and H. indica are synonyms and as the taxon H. f. apicalis precedes the taxon H. indica, the correct name for the species is Hylaeothemis apicalis (Kalkman et al. 2020).

G. williamsoni apparently differs from G. kodaguensis Fraser, 1923 only in details of colouration (Fraser 1934). The status of G. williamsoni may need to be re-examined when more material becomes available.
A subspecies, A. b. palampurensis Fraser, 1929 is known from Sikkim and Nepal. The status of A. b. palampurensis needs to be re-examined.

This species was described in 1894 by Selys based on specimens that were collected from Myanmar under the genus Onychogomphus. It was then moved to the Orientogomphus genus by Chao and Xu (1987). The genus Orientogomphus is characterised by small to medium-sized onychogomphines with divergent inferior appendages much shorter, usually about half length of superior appendages, with apical margin shallowly concave; posterior lobe (prepuce) of penile organ absent; superior appendages long, bracket-like in dorsal view, and abruptly curved apically in lateral view, with a minute peg-like process at tip.

Orientogomphus circularis is very closely related to O. minor Laidlaw, 1931 (Wilson 2008). Hence O. minor from Thailand was misidentified as O. circularis by Asahina (1986).

This species was considered a synonym of O. nanius, a species that has been considered an endemic species of Viet Nam, referred to by Martin, 1904 then Do and Dang, 2007. However, this species is only found in northern Myanmar and Lao PDR, and is distinct from the smaller O. minor found from Thailand to Malaysia, and clearly separate from O. nanius that is only known from Viet Nam.
Only the female of this species is known.

C. coromandelianum has been recorded from India to China and Japan. Asahina (1967) considered all records from outside of India and Sri Lanka as suspect and in need of revision. Wilson and Xu (2007) notes that records from China are probably the result of misidentification, and are considered as such here, along with records from Viet Nam and Lao PDR.
The male of this species is unknown.

Lieftinck (1984) writing on the female described as that of this species (Lahiri 1976) stated “[I] am much in doubt about the correctness of the sex association. Hence I consider the [female] to be still unknown.”

The status of this species, its distribution and its relationship with P. microcephalum (Rambur, 1842) and P. bengalense Laidlaw, 1919 has been the subject of considerable confusion. Lieftinck (1936) clarified the situation, and showed that P. bengalense is a synonym. However Lieftincks' work on this subject appears to have gone unnoticed by some authors and the name P. bengalense has persisted in the literature.
Two subspecies are recognised; V. a. nigrescens Fraser 1929 from Sri Lanka and V. a. submontana Fraser 1934 from India.
This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. Although there is no dispute as to this placement, the genus Sarasaeschna has not been widely recognised as yet.
The male of M. flavicolor is unknown.
There is a severe lack of information on this species. The original description by Krüger (1899) is brief and inadequate, subsequent treatments by Martin (1909) are no better.
The male of Onychogomphus cacharicus has not been described, although there is a record supposedly of a male (Prasad 1997); the identity of this male needs to be confirmed.
A. vulvalis is known only from the female. The taxonomic status of the species is doubtful.
Hämäläinen (2003) noted that some material currently treated as C. confusa in fact belongs to at least one further species.
A subspecies N. c. florida (Walker, 1853) is known from Java.
The female of this species is unknown.
A subspecies, Nychogomphus geometricus perplexus Lieftinck 1935, is recognised from Sumatra.
The female is unknown.
Indolestes bilineatus is known only from three female specimens (Fraser 1933).
The female of Bayadera kali is unknown.

A subspecies, P. k. satoi Asahina, 1997 has been described from north Viet Nam. However P. k. satoi was described from a single female; given the similarity of many species of Protosticta to one another, this female is as likely to belong to some other, unnamed, species as to a subspecies P. khaosoidaoensis. Until males are discovered, records from Viet Nam should be treated as unverified.
Indolestes assamicus is known from a single female.
See Asahina (1983) for an account of the complicated history of this species in the taxonomic literature. A subspecies, A. p. taiyal, is known from Taiwan.

D. z. zallorensis is known only from the type male. A subspecies D. z. delineatus Fraser, 1926 is also known. Both subspecies are very poorly known; the status of D. z. delineatus should be re-examined once more material of both forms becomes available.

This may be a composite taxon; this issue will only be resolved with a thorough revision of this difficult genus in Asia. Many species of Aciagrion are so similar that there is considerable scope for misidentification, adding to the confusion surrounding this species. For example A. hisopa has been recorded from China (e.g. Needham 1930) but these records are now thought to refer to A. migratum (Sélys, 1876) (see Wilson and Xu 2007). Fraser (1933) included Sri Lanka in the range of this species, but de Fonseka (2000) notes that Fraser's records, based on Laidlaw (1924), probably refer to A. occidentale Laidlaw 1919. Fraser (1921) named A. krishna from India, here treated as a synonym, but treated as a subspecies A. h. krishna by some authors. Lieftinck (1929) described A. aciculare from Java, but subsequently treated this name as a synonym.
Lieftinck (1954) expressed doubts over the synonymy of C. simillima with this species.
Two subspecies known: Diplacina paula paula and D. p. lethe. The latter is only known from Misool and further studies might show that it is better considered a full species.
Besides the nominate subspecies two other subspecies are recognised: A. l. dissoluta and A. l. biserialis.
The species has two subspecies. The nominate (Nososticta e. erythrura Lieftinck, 1932) is widespread. Subspecies N. e. efasciata Lieftinck, 1949 is only known from Bernhard Camp in Papua, Indonesia.
Procordulia karnyi was for a long time considered to be a synonym of P. sambawana and a part of the material listed under the name of sambawana by Lieftinck (1933) might refer to karnyi.
Teinobasis eximia (Selys, 1878 as Telebasis eximia) is a synonym of T. superba.
Two subspecies: Huonia a. arborophila (New Guinea, universal) and H. a. diminuta (Misima Island, Louisiade Archipelago).
Known only from the holotype male (juvenile) and may be a synonym of P. magnanimum (Selys, 1876).
Part of the material published under the name of Procordulia irregularis (Martin, 1907), P. sambawana (Martin, 1907) or P. sambawana (Lieftinck, 1953) refers to this species (van Tol, 1997).
Previously on the IUCN Red List as Zyxomma multinervinervi, the species name has now been corrected to Z. multinervorum.

Originally described as a subspecies of Agrionoptera insignis (Lieftinck, 1942) but later considered to be a species because of its "peculiar scheme of coloration and other morphological features, which deviate considerably from those linking together most other forms" [referring to other subspecies of Agrionoptera insignis]).

Mnais species are notoriously difficult to elucidate and there is still some uncertainty regarding the status of Mnais andersoni MacLachlan, 1873 and Mnais tenuis Oguma, 1913. M. andersoni specimens from the type locality in Yunnan, and tenuis from its type locality in Taiwan, clearly look like different species. Initially, when reviewing Asian Mnais, Asahina (1975b) treated andersoni and tenuis as distinct species, but later (Asahina 1975c) downgraded tenuis to a subspecies of andersoni, since intermediate forms of andersoni and tenuis occur throughout their range in Vietnam and Laos.

Nominate andersoni occurs in western China, Burma, Laos, Thailand and Vietnam. M. a. tenuis occurs in northern Guangdong. Hämäläinen (2004) treats Fujianese specimens as M. tenuis. Hämäläinen (2004) also reported that Sui and Sun (1984) erroneously recorded icteroptera from Guangdong, Jiangxi, Yunnan and Zhejiang. Actually Sui and Sun (1984) recorded earnshawi from Hainan, Jiangxi, Yunnan and Zhejiang and did not list icteroptera. However, Asahina (1975a) synonymised earnshawi with andersoni and suggested icteroptera, from Myanmar, might also be a synonym of andersoni. Bridges (1994) treats icteroptera Fraser, 1929 as a synonym of andersoni. Asahina (1975b) also synonymised M. auripennis with M. tenuis. Wilson and Xu (2007) have reviewed the status of Mnais in southern China.
Tsuda (2000) lists Sympetrum ignotum as a synonym of Sympetrum eroticum eroticum Sélys.

Three subspecies are known: D. d. shaanxiensis Zhu, Yan & Yi (1988), D. d. yunnanensis Yang & Davies (1996), and D. d. assamensis Laidlaw (1916). Davidius qinlingensis Cao & Zheng (1989) is a synonym of D. d. shaanxiensis.

Needham originally described T. citimus under the genus Gomphus Leach but later Needham transferred it to Xenogomphus when he established this new genus (Needham, 1941). Chao (1954) synonymised Xenogomphus with Trigomphus Bartenef. Asahina (1949) described the subspecies Gomphus (Trigomphus) citimus tabei from Japan.

Hämäläinen (1987) established Ceriagrion latericium Lieftinck, 1951, described from Sumatra, to be a junior synonym of C. auranticum and reinstated C. chaoi Schmidt, 1964, which had previously been synonymised with auranticum by Asahina (1971), as a genuine species. The nominate subspecies C. a. auranticum was described from Bangkok, and is known from Indonesia, Laos, Myanmar, Peninsular Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam (Tsuda 2000).

Asahina (1967) originally described the subspecies C. a. ryukyuanum as a subspecies of C. latericum Lieftinck, 1951. Hämäläinen (1987) pointed out that latericum is a junior synonym of auranticum Fraser, 1922. C. a. ryukyuanum is known from southern China (Wilson 2004), Korea (Lee 2001) and the Ryukyus Islands of Japan (Sugimura et al. 2001).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
Regarded by some authors as the same species as P. kaehleri (Bense 1995).

This species is sometimes regarded as a subspecies of Calopteryx splendens. It has been reported to be in introgression (genetic movement from one species gene pool to another) by Calopteryx splendens in places where both species meet. This phenomena is believed to induce a natural regression of C. xanthostoma by genetic assimilation and may eventually result in its disappearance on the long term (Weeker et al. 2001, Dumont et al. 2005).

A number of subspecies are recognised for Urothemis signata. Of these, U. s. aliena Selys, 1878 was described as and is still is often treated as a distinct species (e.g. Theischinger and Hawking 2006). U. s. aethiopica Nielsen, 1957 is a junior synonym of U. thomasi Longfield,1932 and is not considered further in this assessment. The whole complex should be re-examined.
This species has recently been differentiated from its sister species Orconectes virilis based on recent molecular studies and minor gonadal morphology (Mathews and Warren 2008, Mathews et al. 2008).
A number of subspecies of Zygonyx iris have been described, but it is not clear if these merely represent extremes of geographical variation or genuine subspecies.

Wilson and Xu (2008) remarked on the three closely related Asian species of Boyeria which are Boyeria sinesis Asahina 1978, Boyeria karube Yokei, 2002 and Boyeria maclachlani (Selys 1883). They considered there were clear structural differences to separate B. sinensis from B. maclachlani but there are no overt structural differences to distinguish B. karubei from B. maclachlani. The face of B. karubei is paler than B. maclachlani and the abdominal yellow colour pattern is more developed in B. karubei.

Wilson and Reels (2001) discussed the confusion concerning the male and female type specimens of Macromia calliope and Macromia urania, which were both described in the same paper from material collected from Tonkin (Ris 1916). Laidlaw (1922) reidentified the single female specimen, considered by Ris (1916) to be M. urania, as M. calliope, but Lieftinck (1929) again reidentified this specimen as M. urania. Using specimens obtained from Hong Kong, where M. calliope does not occur, Wilson and Reels (2001) were able to resolve the confusion and confirm that the M. urania type female did indeed belong to M. calliope. The first description of true M. urania female was made by Asahina (1964). True female M. urania has a much greater expanded abdomen than M. calliope (Wilson and Reels 2001). Males are also very similar but are easily separated by the position of the lateral teeth on the outside edge of the superior appendages. In M. urania the lateral teeth are distally located and in M. calliope they arise centrally.

Six subspecies are sometimes recognised for Prodasineura verticalis: P. v. verticalis, P. v. andamanensis (Fraser, 1924): P. v. annandalei (Fraser, 1921), P. v. burmanensis (Fraser, 1933), P. v. delia (Karsch, 1891), and P. v. humeralis (Selys, 1860). Prodasineura v. humeralis is treated as a good species by some authors (e.g. Orr 2005). The whole complex is in need of re-examination, with some subspecies possibly just representing extremes of variation and other subspecies and forms possibly deserving specific rank. Prodasineura autumnalis (Fraser, 1922) is structurally very similar to P. verticalis and has sometimes been confused with P. v. humeralis at least. There is considerable confusion about the identity of specimens from some areas.

Aside from the nominate subspecies, three other subspecies are recognised. O. p. neglectum is widespread in mainland Asia, O. p. schneideri occurs in the Malay peninsular and Borneo, and O. p. clelia occurs in the Philippines and Taiwan (where O. p. neglectum occurs also). O. p. clelia is likely to be a separate species, and O. p. schneideri is likely to be a junior synonym of clelia. A further subspecies is sometimes recognised, O. p. migratum, but is is consisdered here to be a separate species O. migratum.
Two subspecies of Orthetrum triangulare are currently recognised, the nominate subspecies and O. t. malaccense.
Paragomphus simplex (Lieftinck, 1934) from Sumatra may be a junior synonym (Asahina 1986).
Chao (1965) synonymised Megalestes suensoni Asahina (1956) with heros.
Once used the name Aciagrion hisopa, but later it became clear that the species distributed in southeast Asia is a different species, hence the name change (Hamada and Inoue 1985).
Originally described under the genus Gomphus Leach. Asahina (1978) transferred clathratus to the genus Stylurus Needham.

Fraser (1939) established the genus Sinictinogomphus to receive clavatus and synonymised Ictnius phaleratus Sélys with clavatus (Fabricius), which is the only other described member of the genus. Lieftinck (1942) considered Sinictinogomphus was a synonym of Ictinogomphus but Chao (1990) and subsequent authors have adopted Sinictinogomphus. Asahina (1986) and Hämäläinen and Pinratana (1999) recognise the subspecies Sinictnogomphus clavatus phaleratus Sélys from Thailand and Tsuda (2000) lists this subspecies from Myanmar, Nepal and Thailand. The 'western' phaleratus race is smaller with less extensive foliaceous flaps on abdominal Segment) 8. However, since the character states overlap through its range there appears to be little support for a distinct subspecies, Steinman (1997) considers phaleratus is a synonym.
Originally described as Diplax infuscata Sélys (1883).
A subspecies Periaeschna flinti assamensis Asahina, 1981 is known from the Khasi Hills in Meghalaya (Asahina 1981).

Lestes gracilis peregrinus was described from material collected from Japan by Ris (1916) and Needham (1930) described Lestes extranea from 'Kiangsu?', China. Fraser (1922) established the genus Indolestes to receive a small closed-winged group of Indian lestid damselflies. Lestes extranea was considered to be a subspecies of Lestes gracilis by Schmidt (1931). Lieftinck (1960) recognised both gracilis and peregrinus as distinct species and included both gracilis and peregrinus in Indolestes, which he considered a subgenus of Lestes. Chao (1962) synonymised Lestes monteili Navás, 1935 with Indolestes extranea (Needham, 1930) and Asahina (1976) synonymised extranea with Indolestes peregrinus.

Listed by Zhang (1999) in Fujian but Asahina (1973) corrected this identification to Euphaea opaca Campion, 1924. Wilson (2003) reported that Lai's (1971) record of E. opaca from Hong Kong may be superba.

Three subspecies of Brachydiplax chalybea are currently recognized. B. c. flavovittata occurs in southern China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Japan, B. c. simalura is known from a few islands of the coast of Sumatra, the nominate subspecies is known from the rest of the range.

Asahina (1982) described 'noshime' from Japan as a form of fuliginosa, which was considered by Steinmann (1997b) as a subspecies of fuliginosa. Sugimura et al. (2001) consider 'noshime' is merely a form as originally described.

May (1997) pointed out that Enallagma melanotum Sélys, 1876 was a synonym of Cercion sexlineatum (Sélys, 1883). When "Cercion" was no longer available, following the genetic analysis completed by Weekers and Dumont (2004), which showed that lindeni, the type species of Cercion, belonged to the genus Erythromma, Weekers and Dumont (2004) established Paracercion to receive melanotum and its congeners.

Two subspecies of Mesopodagrion tibetanum are known, M. t. tibetanum and M. t. australe Yu and Bu, 2009. If these subspecies are really distinct, then their distributions suggest that they might be separate species (see the map in Yu and Bu 2009, page 65). Yu and Bu (2009), in agreement with Kalkman (2008), removed the closely related M. yachowensis Chao, 1953 from the synonymy of M. tibetanum. There is a record of M. tibetanum from Chiang Mai in north west Thailand (Asahina 1990), but the specimen was not available for study by either Kalkman (2008) or Yu and Bu (2009), the former author treated it as M. tibetanum, the latter authors as M. species. For the purpose of this assessment this record is treated as M. tibetanum, although clearly it cannot be assigned to either subspecies with any certainty. The species was named tibetanum because the type locality Moupin was believed to be in Tibet (McLachlan 1896), but this is now known to be an error; Moupin is Baoxing in Sichuan (e.g. Kalkman 2008).
Hämäläinen (2004) elevated Bayadera brevicauda continentalis, described by Asahina (1973), to species status.

Brauer (1865) originally described elegans from Shanghai, China under the genus Macromia Rambur. The subspecies Epophthalmia elegans yagasakii was described by Eda (1986) from South Korean material but it is not considered appropriate to consider the Korean population a separate subspecies (Lee 2001).

Bartenev (1913) described parvulum from the Ussuri river basin in southern, far eastern Russia under the genus Thecodiplax. The synonym Sympetrum eroticoides Oguma (1922) was described from Sachalin. Asahina (1949) synonymised eroticoides with parvulum. The synonym Sympetrum fuscousus Kobayashi, 1941 was described from Honshu (Bridges 1994) and the synonym Sympetrum parvum Tada, 1942, was also described from Honshu at Takaraike, Kyoto, (Bridges 1994).
Following Hämäläinen (2006), this species has now been placed in Vestalaria.

Originally described from Taiwan under the genus Diparoneura, which is a genus now restricted to India and Sri Lanka. It is closely related to Prodasinura auricolor (Fraser 1927) and according to Lieftinck et al. (1984) is identical, or nearly so, to Caoneura longjingensis described by Zhou (1981) from Zhejiang. Wilson (1995) recorded the first mainland Chinese specimens of P. crconota and Wilson (1997) remarked: "Hong Kong specimens differ slightly from  Taiwanese croconota. The main differences being the head of Taiwanese croconota has a thin orange transverse band between the eyes covering the front ocellus whereas this band in Hong Kong croconota is reduced to two small orange spots. In addition the dorsum of the tenth abdominal segment of Taiwanese croconota is pale yellow whereas the dorsum of the tenth abdominal segment in Hong Kong croconota is predominanntly black with posterior margin finely bordered white."

The type locality for the species (Martin 1904) is 'Tonkin, Indochina'. Lieftinck et al. (1984) compared Taiwanese males with tototypical vermicularus from Tonkin, Viet Nam in the Leiden Museum and could find no overt differences other than the slightly smaller size of Taiwanese specimens. Matsuki (1978) described the larvae from Taiwanese specimens.
Prodasineura odoneli is closely related to P.autumnalis and P.nigra, and may merely be a variant of the former (the latter is a synonym of P. autumnalis in any case).
Amphiallagma parvum is often placed in the genus Enallagma, especially in older literature.
Both Fraser (1933) and Lieftinck (1960) have expressed the opinion that more than one species may be being treated under this name.

The south Asian species of Ictinogomphus are in need of a critical review. I. angulosus appears to differ from other regional Ictinogomphus species largely in details of colouration, which is frequently variable across the range of species in this genus. It is possible that I. angulosus is merely a form of some other Ictinogomphus species.
This species is closely related to M. flavicincta from which it differs by wing venation characters and in markings in labrum, abdomen and shape of anal appendages.

Aside from the nominate subspecies, another subspecies D. a. senchalensis Fraser, 1926 is known from Darjeeling district, and has more recently been recorded from Nepal. It is perhaps doubtful whether the subspecies are genuine or merely reflect extremes of variation.

Drepanosticta polychromatica apparently differs from D. carmichaeli (Laidlaw, 1915) only in details of colouration and small and probably meaningless differences in wing venation. The relationship of these species to each other needs to be re-examined.
A subspecies, Indothemis limbata sita Campion, 1923, occurs in Sri Lanka and parts of peninsular India.
There is only one specimen of this species known and it may be a junior synonym of G. bayadera.

The nominate subspecies is known from India and Sri Lanka, subspecies E. v. sundana is known from Java and Sumatra, the subspecies to which specimens from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, and from Viet Nam, belong is unclear.
