The known distribution of the species is somewhat strange; all available material needs to be re-examined.

Several subspecies of Neurothemis intermedia have been recognised, but for this assessment apart from the nominate subspecies only N. i. excelsa Lieftinck, 1934, known from Java and the Lesser Sunda Islands, is recognised. N. i. excelsa has a range disjoint from the nominate subspecies.

Phaenandrogomphus aureus is still sometimes placed in Onychogomphus. Lieftinck (1964) claimed that this species could not be maintained as distinct from the very poorly known Onychogomphus maculivertex (Selys, 1891), but his opinion has not been followed by later authors.
Agriocnemis keralaensis Peters, 1981 is likely to be a junior synonym of A. pieris.

The only records of this species since the 1930s are from Lahiri (1987), who notes that his material differs in the structure of the male anal appendages from Fraser's descriptions (e.g. Fraser 1933); this suggests that a re-examination of all available material is needed.
The relationship of this species with A. tillyardi Laidlaw, 1919 needs to be rexamined; the latter species may be a junior synonym of A. approximans.
Mortonagrion simile Ris, 1930 is a junior synonym of this species, as was demonstrated by Hämäläinen (1989); however this publication appears to have been widely overlooked.
The female of this species is not known.
This species is placed by some authors in its own genus Paracypha.
Fraser (1933) noted that this species is probably a synonym of L. malabarica.
A subspecies, C. b. folia Fraser 1929, was described from Uttranchal.
The male of this species is not known. The female, known from two specimens, has an extremely distinctive prothorax, so that there is no doubt that it is a good species.
Subspecies M. moorei fumata and M. moorei malayana have been recognised, but it is unclear if these represent genuine subspecies or just extremes of variation.
This assessment includes subspecies Orthetrum testaceum soembanum Förster, 1903.
The female of this species has not been collected.

A number of subspecies of Copera vittata have been described, and still more unnamed forms are known. The whole complex stands in need of revision, but is treated as a single species for the purposes of this assessment.
The female of this species is not known. Many Asian Macromia species are poorly known, and the extent of intraspecific variation is not understood; the genus needs to be revised.
The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful (Mitra 2002).

Trithemis adelpha Selys, 1878, known from the Philippines, is sometimes considered to be a junior synonym of T. aurora, which also occurs in the Philippines. For the purposes of this assessment the two are treated as separate species.
Gynacantha nigripes Martin, 1909 appears to be a junior synonym of G. khasiaca (e.g. Fraser 1936).
Two subspecies are recognised: Echo m. margarita and E. m. tripartita. Both have been reported from Meghalaya, suggesting that teir relationship needs to be re-examined.
This species is known only from the type series collected more than 80 years ago.
The subspecies M. pinratani vietnamica Asahina, 1996 is included in this assessment.

Bayadera melanopteryx Ris, 1912 has wing tips which are coloured dark blackish-brown from the mid-point in some populations and the apical third from a point near the pterostigma in others. Within each region the extent of the colouration is consistent in both hind wing and fore wings for males and females (Wilson and Reels 2003). Wilson and Reels (2003) postulated that: "With more information on the distribution of melanopteryx throughout China the western form may prove to be a separate taxon at species level". Wilson and Xu (2007) provided good colour photographs of the two forms. Davies and Yang (1996) and Hämäläinen (2004) treated Bayadera melania Navás 1934 as a junior synonym of  Bayadera melanopteryx and this treatment is accepted by Schorr et al. (2009) and the Odonata on-line database managed by the Naturalis Museum Leiden.

For separation of Philoganga vetusta from its close congener Philoganga robusta Navás see Chao (1953b) and Wilson and Reels (2001).

Please note the correct family name for Philoganga Kirby is Diphlebiidae not Lestoideidae. The Australian genus Lestoidea Tillyard is the only genus in the family Lestoideidae (Theischinger and Hawking 2006). The family-group name for Philoganga and Diphlebia Sélys is Diphlebiidae. The genus Philoganga has benn moved between families recently, and it is hoped the taxonomic status of this genus will be resolved shortly. It is placed within family Lestoideidae based on its original description.

Chao (1995) reviewed records of Davidius trox and described a new species, Davidius zhoui, based on a male and female collected from Luku, Yunnan Province, which Zhou (1986) had previously identified as Davidius trox. Davies and Yang (1993) also identified material from Yangbi County, Yunnan, as trox, which according to Chao (1995) also belongs to Davidius zhoui.

Agriomorpha fusca has different colour pattern in Hainan (Wilson and Reels 2001) and western Guangdong (Wilson and Reels 2003) when compared with material from Hong Kong but no structural differences. Agriomorpha is a monotypic genus.

Karube and Kosterin (2018) described the genus Mattigomphus, to include two species: tamdaoensis (formerly Merogomphus tamdaoensis Karube, 2001) and pinratanai (formerly Anisogomphus pinratani Hämäläinen, 1991).
This species is known from males only.
More research is needed on its differentiation from Orolestes selysi MacLachlan, 1895.
The species may be a form of Anotogaster sieboldii (K. Wilson pers. comm. 2010).
The species was described as Asiagomphus xanthenatus acco and whilst it is almost certainly a distinct species it has not yet been published as such (but see Do et al. 2011).
This species was described only from a single female specimen.
Laidlaw (1917) and Fraser (1923, 1933) treated this species under the name I. kempi, which now considered a synonym of I. orang.
Originally described under the genus Libellula (Linnaeus) and subsequently became the genotype for Pseudothemis Kirby (1889). Chao (1962) synonymised Orthetrum zonale Navás with Pseudothemis zonata.

Records of this species from Thailand and Malaysia have proved to actually be A. minima, suggesting that the relationship of these two species needs to be re-examined, at the very least records of A. dabreui from Lao PDR and Viet Nam must be checked; it seems likely that these records actually refer to A. minima.
This species is very similar to Planaeschna chiengmaiensis Asahina, 1981 and might eventually prove to be a junior synonym (Karube 1999).
The male has not yet been described (Fraser 1919).

The species, known only from the type series from Tam Dao in northern Viet Nam (Asahina 1997), is almost certainly a junior synonym of Coeliccia cyanomelas Ris, 1912, a species that certainly occurs in Viet Nam. The original description and illustrations of C. onoi are inadequate, and the type series does not appear to be available for study.

The Ischnura rufostigma-group consists of four structurally distinct taxa: rufostigma ssp.; annandalei; mildredae and carpentieri. Vick (1986) proposed to consider them as separate species rather than subspecies as the differences in the male appendages and dorsal tubercle are considerable. Asahina (1991) in a thoroughly confusing piece of work appears to come to the opposite conclusion to that of Vick, but then to express doubts over his own conclusion. The whole species group is treated as one taxa for the purposes of this assessment, but the issue is still open. Further work is required to resolve this species complex.
A subspecies E. v. bellicosa is known from Myanmar, Thailand and Lao PDR.
It is described from a single female, and there is doubt that this is a good species.
Some populations in mainland Asia differ in colouration from typical L. hyalina and might represent distinct taxa (A.G. Orr, pers. comm. 2010).

As pointed out by Wilson and Reels (2001) there are unresolved problems of synonymy associated with Macromia berlandi. Lieftinck (1941) described M. berlandi from a Tonkinese male specimen identified by Martin (1907) as Macromia borneensis Krüger, 1899; the latter taxon is now recognised as a synonym of  Macromia cincta Rambur, 1842. M. pyramidalis Martin 1907 was also described from male and female specimens collected in Tonkin. The male specimen, Martin described as M. pyramidalis, has the characteristics of Macromia moorei malayana Laidlaw 1928 and is certainly synonymous with it, but the female specimen is identical to Macromia berlandi Lieftinck, 1941, which was described for the first time by Wilson and Reels (2001) from a Hong Kong specimen. Note Lieftinck (1929) considered  Macromia moorei malayana was synonymous with Macromia moorei fumata Krüger, 1899. In essence Martin (1907) examined two males and one female Macromia speciemens collected from Tonkin in the Selys collection; (i) a male he misidentified as Macromia borneensis (= holotype M. berlandi), (ii) a second male (type M. pyramidalis = M. moorei malayana = M. moorei fumata) and (iii) a female (type M. pyramidalis = M. berlandi).

There are two courses of corrective action possible: (1) Designate the male specimen, described by Martin (1907) as M. pyramidalis, as the holotype pyramidalis specimen. M. pyramidalis would then become a junior synonym of Macromia moorei Selys, 1874 and the new combination Macromia moorei pyramidalis Martin, 1907 would become a junior synonym of Macromia moorei fumata (= M. moorei malayana). (2) Designate the female specimen, described by Martin (1907) as M. pyramidalis, as the type-specimen. M. pyramidalis Martin, 1907 would become a valid taxon and Macromia berlandi Lieftinck, 1941 would be a junior synonym. The first course of action is strongly favoured by the assessor, which would have the least impact on current nomenclature and render Macromia berlandi a valid species.
Originally described as a species of Somatochlora Sélys, 1871.
Lieftinck (1984) divided Calicnemia into two main groups; those with a finely divided penile organ and those with a broadly divide tip. Calicnemia haksik belongs to the latter group.
Chao (1990) synonymised Davidius miaotaiziensis Zhu, Yan & Li (1988) with chaoi.
Originally described under the genus Gomphus Leach. Chao (1954) transferred intinctus to Burmagomphus.
Hämäläinen (2004) distinguished clear-winged venusta from orange-winged Vestalis smaragdina Sélys, 1879 based on its hyaline wings and structure of the superior appendages.

Originally described and identified as B. vermicularis (Martin) by Williamson in 1922 from three males collected in Burma by R.A. Earnshaw. Fraser (1926) realised it was a distinct species but described it under the name willliamsoni, which was not an available name as Förster (1914) had already described Burmagomphus williamsoni from Pahang, Peninsula Malaysia. Lieftinck (1940) realised the error and established a new name Burmagomphus arboreus.
Originally described under the genus Gomphus Leach and transferred to Paragomphus by Chao (1954).

Asahina (1997) described the species from Tam Dao, Viet Nam. In this description Asahina (1997) pointed out that the venation of ambigua was not consistent with the genus Coeliccia Kirby but with the genus Indocnemis Laidlaw. In Indocnemis the anal crossing ends on the anal bridge vein and not on the wing margin except in one of four specimens examined by Asahina (1997). As pointed out by Wilson and Reels (2003) another characteristic of the genus Indocnemis is the presence of four cells between the discoidal cell and the oblique vein, whereas Coeliccia has just three cells. Coeliccia ambigua has three cells consistent with the genus Coeliccia. Not including ambigua currently there is only one species recognised in the genus Indocnemis which is I. orang (Förster in Laidlaw, 1907).
This is a western Africa species and further taxonomic work is needed to confirm its occurrence within the southern Africa region.
Chao (1995) synonymised Nihonogomphus zhejiangensis Chao & Zhou (1990) with shaowuensis.

Lieftinck et al. (1984) considers Euphaea compar McLachlan, 1870 is probable synonym of formosa based Campion (1924) who compared both types and considered formosa and compar were synonyms. Based on variability of wing colouration Hämäläinen (2004) agreed with Campion's view.

Originally described as species of Coenagrion Kirby it was transferred to "Cercion Navás" when this genus was generally recognised. Recently Weekers and Dumont (2004) completed a molecular study which sunk "Cercion" and established Paracercion Weekers & Dumont, 2004, to replace it.

Asahina (1956) proposed the synonymy of Coenagrion barbatum Needham with v-nigrum.
Previously placed in Allorrhizucha (Dijkstra and Vick 2006).

Davies and Tobin (1985) listed both Burmagomphus sowerbyi Needham and Burmagomphus collaris Needham as synonyms of Burmagomphus campestris Needham. Chao (1990) synonymised campestris with collaris but recognised sowerbyi as a distinct species.

Asahina (1978) described Boyeria sinensis from a single male from ‘Chengtu’, Sichuan, which he described as, ‘not very mature’. When comparing other Asian species of Boyeria it is apparent there are clear structural differences to differentiate sinensis from Boyeria maclachani (Sélys, 1883) but there are no overt structural differences to distinguish Boyeria karubei Yokoi, 2002 from maclachani. The face of karubei is paler than maclachani and the abdominal yellow colour pattern is more developed in karubei than maclachani (Wilson & Xu, in prep.)

Closely allied to A. gregoryi Fraser which is also known from Yunnan. Zhou (1998) pointed out several differences related to colour maculation when compared to gregoryi but none of a structural nature.
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

Chlorogomphus montanus was described by Chao (1999) under the genus Sinorogomphus, which was established by Carle (1995) for chlorogompids with yellow dorsal thoracic stripes expanded into ovals at upper ends. The genus Sinorogomphus was treated as a subgenus by Wilson (2002). Chao (1999) followed Carle (1995) and described montanus under Sinorogomphus. Carle (1999) established a new family of chlorogomphids (Chloropetalidae) and many new subfamilies including Sinorogomphinae. Wilson and others accept ‘Chloropetalidae’ as a subfamily (i.e. Chloropetalinae) and ‘Sinorogomphinae’ as a subgenus. Therefore Chao’s Sinorogomphus becomes Chlorogomphus i.e. Chlorogomphus (Sinorogomphus) montanus.

Zhou et al. (1994) considered macula to be very closely related to hamifera, which was synonymised with Macroma clio by Wilson and Reels (2001). One of the features used by Zhou et al. Liu (1994) to differentiate macula from hamifera was the presence of dorsal and lateral yellow spots on the fronds. This feature was noted in Macromia clio specimens obtained from Hainan (Wilson and Reels 2001).

Closely related to Macromia moorei group (sensu Lieftinck, 1929). Amongst other features the male, known only from the type, is distinguished by its yellow face and yellow caudal appendages, hence its name 'icterica' (= jaundiced or yellow).
Navás (1936) described rubripes under the genus Taolestes Needham, which is a junior synonym of Rhipidolestes Ris.

Lohmann (1993) considered McLachlan's (1896) material from Peking and Sichuan, described by McLachlan as the subspecies Cordulegaster luniferus pekinensis, belonged to Neallogaster lunifera pekinensis. G. van Pelt showed part of this material (Sichuan) belonged to Cordulegaster lunifera Sélys and part to Cordulegaster pekinensis McLachlan.

Zhou and Wilson (2001) established the genus Priscagrion, under the subfamily Megapodagrioninae Tillyard, to receive two new species from southern China, including Priscagrion kiautai the type species. The generic characters of Priscagrion Zhou and Wilson 2001 were reviewed by De Marmels (2002) who considered the genus is closely related with the Australo-Papuan 'Argiolestinae' and with the South American 'Megapodagrion-complex'.

The type species for the genus Aeschnophlebia Sélys is optata, which Asahina (1957) examined and considered may be an incomplete specimen of Planaeschna milnei Sélys. If this is the case then Aeschnophlebia would be equivalent to Planaeschna McLachlan; the latter being the junior synonym.

According to Tsuda (2000) Aeschnophlebia kolthoffi Sjöstedt, 1925, described from 'Kiangsu', China, is a synonym of Aeschnophlebia longistigma.
Originally described under the genus Gomphus Leach. In 1988 Sui and Sun transferred endicotti to Stylurus (Chao, 1990)

Lieftinck (1968) split the genus Oligoaeschna Sélys, 1889 into two groups 'pryeri' and 'poeciloptera' based on well defined morphological characters. Karube and Yeh (2001) established the new genus Sarasaeschna to receive members of the pryeri-group and tsaopiensis was transferred to the new genus.

Originally described by Sélys (1883) from Yokohama, Japan under the genus Trithemis Brauer. Kirby (1889) subsequently described fasciata under a new genus Deielia. Deielia fasciata is now considered a synonym of phaon. Chao (1962) synonymised Leucorrhinia nebulifera Navás, 1932 with Deilia phaeon (Sélys).
Described under the genus Gomphus Leach. Transferred to Asiagomphus (Asahina, 1985).

Described from a single female from Guangxi by Needham (1930) as Gomphus dolus. Needham (1941) transferred dolus to the genus Burmagomphus. Chao (1990) established the onychogomphine genus Melligomphus and transferred dolus to this new genus based on a study of the type (collection notes: "C.U. 954.1").

The only know specimen, the type female, was originally described as a species of Gomphus Leach by Asahina (1966) who considered the female belong to the 'melanops' group of gomphines, which became included in Asiagomphus Asahina (1985). Chao (1990) transferred takashii to Stylurus Needham.
Described by Needham (1941) under the genus Gomphurus Needham 1901. Needham (1948) transferred gideon to Stylurus Needham 1897.

The genus Sinogomphus was established by May (1935) with Sinogomphus nigrofasciatus as the type species. Chao (1990) considers nigrofasciatus is a synonym of Sinogomphus scissus. Klots (1947) first pointed out the probably synonymy of edax with scissus. Sinogomphus shennongianus Liu (1989) described from Hubei was synonymised by Chao (1990).

Described under the genus Anisogomphus Sélys. Transferred to Asiagomphus (Asahina, 1989). Lee (2001) considers it is necessary to review whether melanopsoides is a subspecies of Asaigomphus melanops (Sélys), which is common and widespread throughout central and southern Japan.
Chao recorded first male from Jiangfengling as Leptogomphus hainanensis, which he later synonymised with celebratus (Chao, 1990).
Described under the genus Gomphus Leach. Transferred to Asiagomphus (Asahina, 1985).
Rhinagrion yokoii Sasamoto, 2003 is a junior synonym of this species (Kalkman and Villanueva 2011).

Male Paragomphus capricornis (Förster) can be easily misidentified as Paragomphus pardalinus (Wilson and Reels 2001, Wilson 2005). Wilson and Reels (2001) consider that Paragomphus wuzishanensis Liu (1988) may be a synonym of pardalinus.
Wilson (2004) reported the three females collected from Diding, western Guangxi may represent a separate, closely related new species.
Asahina (1974) reviewed the status of M. gregoryi and considered maclachlani and semiopaca were races of gregoryi.
Originally described under the genus Hagenius Sélys, 1854.
Recently Karube & Yeh (2001) established the new genus Sarasaeschna and new combination for this species.

Japanese Mnais species are taxonomically very difficult and have been split up into four species. Recent DNA study has shown that it is best to regard them as two separate species and this opinion was provided under morphological evidence (Hayashi et al 2004.). The two accepted Japanese Mnais species are:
- Mnais pruinosa Selys, 1853
- Mnais costalis Selys, 1869
Only the male of Rhipidolestes malaisei has been collected.
The male of Onychogomphus maclachlani is not known.
Macromia cingulata is similar to M. bellicosa, however absence of yellow markings behind eyes and shape of genitalia distinguishes these species.
Megalogomphus bicornutus is known only from a single female collected prior to 1922.

The genus Hylaeothemis has four species, of this 3 are found within Indian subcontinent and the fourth one in widely distributed in southeast Asia. Some authors (Mitra, 2002 and Lahiri, 1985) have probably considered H. gardeneri erroneously as H. frushtorferi apicalis.

Male: Abdomen 38mm. Hindwing 33mm. Labium dirty yellow, labrum black, with a large yellow basal spot on each side. Eyes emerald green above. Thorax black, with  yellow interrupted collar anteriorly and two oblique yellow spots below the collar. A narrow yellow line laterally and under side is yellow. Legs black, femora yellow on inner side. Wings hyaline, pterostigma blackish-brown, covering 3-4 cells. Abdomen black marked with yellow. Anal appendages bright yellow, narrowly black at base. Female: Unknown.
The male of Chlorogomphus schmidti is not known.
The female of Platygomphus feae is not known.
Gynacantha rotundata was described from, and is only known from, a female specimen; most Odonata described by Navás have proved to be synonyms.
Asahina (1984) noted that this species may well be a form of the widespread S. striolatum.
No male Paragomphus frontalis specimens have been collected.

Indolestes peregrinus (Ris, 1916), known from Japan, Korea and China, was described as a subspecies of I. gracilis, and is still treated as such by some authorities, but is considered to be a separate species for the purposes of this assessment. Indolestes gracilis is known only from Sri Lanka (and from some records in southern India; Kerala and Tamil Nadu; D. Allen pers.); Indolestes gracilis birmanus (Selys, 1891) was described from Myanmar as a distinct species, and is also known from parts of India; it may be distinct from gracilis.
A subspecies C. d. carminea is known from Nepal.

Williamson (1907) mentions a "female collected by Earnshaw", but Fraser (1934), in full knowledge of Williamson's work, stated that the female is unknown. In this assessment we follow Fraser in considering that the female of this species is not known. Fraser also noted that O. annularis may merely be a form of O. saundersi Selys, 1854.
The male of this species is not known.
This species appears to be rather similar to I. yolanda, and might possibly prove to be a junior synonym of that species.
The female of Ceriagrion nigroflavum is unknown.
The male of this species is unknown. It is likely to be a junior synonym of some other Gomphidia species.
Most Odonata described by   Navás have proved to be synonyms when subjected to expert scrutiny; there is no reason to believe that this species is an exception.
Macromia aculeata is only known from the male holotype.
The male of this species is not known.
Only the female of this species is known, and is said to be “not quite typical of” Burmagomphus (Fraser 1926).

The status of this species is extremely dubious, the authority who described it created numerous synonyms, often misidentifying common species as new taxa not even placed in the correct family. It is most likely to be a synonym of H. exclamationis.

Coeliccia loringae is often considered to be a synonym or a subspecies of C. didyma (e.g. Asahina 1985). Its true status will not be resolved without a revision of the regional representatives of the genus, a task that is severely hindered by a lack of material and legal barriers to the collection of fresh material. If C. loringae is in fact a species distinct from C. didyma, then there are likely to be additional specimens in collections misidentified as C. didyma.
The male of Gynacantha apicalis is not known.
The female of Macromia sombui is not known.

The female of Macrogomphus robustus is not known. Macrogomphus seductus Fraser, 1926, the type series of which was treated by Laidlaw (1922) as M. robustus, is extremely similar to M. robustus, and might be a junior synonym.
The male of Leptogomphus inclitus is unknown. Of four female specimens known, only one from Moolai in Myanmar can be considered to certainly belong to this species (see under Geographic Range).
Chlorogomphus speciosus is only known from the female holotype.
Pelt (1996) feared that the holotype is already lost due to poor preservation.

Onychogomphus meghalayanus is known from a single female collected in 1973 (Lahiri 1987). As many Onychogomphus species are poorly known, until the male of this species becomes known, doubts must remain over the validity of this species.
The female of Paragomphus risi is unknown.

Taxonomic limits of Umma and Sapho must be reassessed, but this species belongs to the genus Sapho (Dijkstra, unpubl.). Status relative to S. fumosa unclear, but most likely is synonym of S. fumosa and currently regarded as such. Not conspecific according to Legrand (2003).

This species appears not to belong in Pseudagrion. Carfi and D'Andrea (1994) suggested to place it in Aciagrion by describing the synonym A. walteri, but this is probably not right either (Dijkstra unpubl.)
This species appears not to belong in Pseudagrion. Gambles (unpubl.) suggested to place it in Teinobasis, but this is probably not right either (Dijkstra unpubl.)
Similar to P. schoutedeni of central Africa, further comparisons required.
The only known specimens deserve study: perhaps pertain to P. funicularioides or P. melania.
Previously confused with central and east African species P. aureozona, P. caneri and P. insignis.

All earlier records of other Diastatomma species in western Africa probably pertain to this species, although poorly preserved specimens of possibly other species have been seen from Sierra Leone and Togo (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Known only from holotype, which is so damaged that its identity cannot be properly established.
Only known from females. Taxonomic identity therefore remains unclear.
Only known from the female holotype, may be the female of another species.
P. bartolozzii and P. helenae are possible synonyms of P. moundi..
The status of the species is uncertain, and is based on unseen records.
Records from east of the Dahomey Gap (Nigeria, etc.) are treated as T. tropicana.
This species is unique in the world by the extreme length of the male cerci, almost 30% of the abdomen length and 5 to 6 times as long as epiproct.
All listed names treated as synonyms by Carfi & D'Andrea (1994). Legrand (2003) raised Chlorocnemis rossii to species level, but the basis is suspect.
This species was known as M. andamanicus prior to 1990.
This species has been confused with P. guttatus (Vianna 1986).
This species continues to be confused with S. brasiliensis (Rathbun 1906), due to their similar colour patterns and locally sympatric distributions (Tavares et al. 2009).

There are two recognized subspecies for the species. Panulirus argus argus is found north of the equator and Panulirus argus westonii is found south of the equator in Brazil, however this is an invalid name (Sarver, Silberman and Walsh, 1998).
Fischer and Bianchi (1984) mention that this species may possibly be synonymous with N. stewarti, however no other authors have confirmed this.
This species was previously known as one species (Thenus orientalis), but now has been split into five separate species (Burton and Davie 2007).
Homarus capensis as described by Herbst (1792) has been changed to Homarinus capensis (Kornfield et al. 1995).
FAO states that this species was not formally distinguished from P. antarcticus (Holthuis 1991).

In Hawaii this species has many common names including: Royal Slipper Lobster, King's Hawaiian Lobster, Shovel-nosed Lobster, Spanish Lobster and Ula-papapa (Holthuis 1991).

This species very closely resembles A. guineensis, and at one time they were believed to be conspecific (Holthuis 2006).

There are three sub-species: P. homarus homarus found throughout the range; P. homarus megasculpta is known only from the northern Arabian Sea; and P. homarus rubellus is found southern East Africa, from Mozambique to Natal and southeast Madagascar (Holthuis 1991).
Before 1991, specimens of this species were considered to belong to M. japonicus (Holthuis 1991).
Justitia japonica is now known as Nupalirus japonicus (Chan 2010).
This species was once synonymized by Holthuis (1966) with Puerulus angulatus but this was shown to be incorrect by Berry (1969) (Holthuis 1991).

Chan et al. (2009) recently showed that the banded and non-banded forms of Metanephrops thomsoni were widely, genetically divergent. The banded (widespread) form is now treated as a distinct species and named after a recent fossil, Wongastacia taiwanica Hu, 1983, while the non-banded (Philippines) form remains M. thomsoni (see also Tshudy et al. 2007).
This species was split into two species. Past records referring to I. ciliatus south of the Philippines are now I. pubescens, although both species occur in the Philippines (Chan, 1997).
Holthuis (1991) states that this species has previously been confused with P. antarcticus.
This species is also known as the slipper lobster (Boyko 2003).
The species has often been confused with N. atlantica and most, if not all, records of N. atlantica from the Indo-West Pacific region refer to the present species (Holthuis 1991).
The Australian stock was previously known as Jasus novaehollandiae.
Justitia mauritiana is now a synonym of this species.

Although originally classified as Panulirus femoristriga (von Martens, 1872), this species was later included within P. longipes (Milne-Edwards, 1868) as a subspecies, P. l. femoristriga. Recent morphological and allozyme analysis showed that in fact there were two cryptic forms of P. l. femoristriga, and assigned a new species P. albiflagellum Chan & Chu, 1996 to one of them. Later work (Chan and Ng 2001) revealed that P. albiflagellum is conspecific with the holotype of P. femoristriga, and P. l. femoristriga was synonymized with P. longipes bispinosus Borradaile, 1899. Further molecular work supports this distinction based on nucleotide sequence divergence (Ravago and Juinio-Meñez 2002, Chow et al. 2006a).

In Australia this species is known by many local names including: Red Flapjack, Squat Crayfish, Southern Shovel-nosed Cray, South-eastern Shovel-nosed Crayfish and South-eastern Squat Crayfish.

In New Zealand this species is known locally as the Spanish Lobster (Holthuis 1991).
This species is comprised of two subspecies: Palinurus longipes longipes and Palinurus longipes bispinosus (Chan and Ng 2001).
This species is regarded as a living fossil, with very similar fossils dating from the Jurassic period. There is a debate on whether it is part of the coral lobsters or the spiny lobsters.

This species is extremely similar to Gynacantha dohrni Krüger, 1899, and may fall within the limits of variation of that species. Its status as a distinct species is considered doubtful here. A revision of the Asian Gynacantha is badly needed.
The species was described from a single male from northern Viet Nam (Martin 1904) and has not been recorded subsequently. The original description is inadequate and unillustrated.
The species is known from one male and one female, taken at separate locations, so that some doubt as to the correct association of the sexes must remain.

Nazari & Sperling (2007) reported significant genetic divergence between populations of this species from Palestine and Turkey, suggesting that there might be more species in this complex than what was previously reported.At present, there are X subspecies recognised: the nominate subspecies apollinus; A. apollinus forsteri Koçak, 1977; A. a. nikodemusi Stüning & Wagener, 1989; A. a. drusicus de Freina & Leestmans, 2003;
The taxonomy of the Azores-graylings is still under debate. At this moment only H. miguelensis is considered a separate species.
This species was recently split from Spanish Brassy Ringlet (E. hispania).
The Canary Brimstone used to be considered a subspecies of the Cleopatra (G. cleopatra).
Euchloe grancanariensis was formerly considered a subspecies of the Green-striped White (E. belemia).

This species was first assessed under the name P. bellieri. However, as descriptions of both Syrichtus alveus f. foulquieri and Syrichtus alveus f. bellieri were published simultaneously by Oberthür in 1910, the name used by the first reviser (i.e. Rebel in 1914), Pyrgus foulquieri, should be used in accordance with ICZN (Wiemer et al. 2018).
Thymelicus christi was formerly considered a subspecies of the Lulworth Skipper (T. acteon).
The taxonomic status of this taxon and its relationship to C. leander, C. arcania, and C. gardetta are unclear and require further research.

Euchloe eversi was considered a subspecies of the Green-striped White (E. belemia). Based on studies in molecular biology, it has been separated from the nominate species (Back et al. 2008) , but recent studies put this conclusion again under discussion (Suarez et al. 2009).
This butterfly used to be considered a subspecies of the Furry Blue (P. dolus), but there is a clear difference in the number of chromosomes of each species.

The species was described, and remains known from, a single teneral (freshly emerged) male (Fraser 1933). The original description is unillustrated and according to Lieftinck (1969) the superior appendages of the type (in the Paris Museum) are missing, making comparison with any fresh specimens that become available problematic.
The female of this species has not yet been described.

Zhang et al. (2010) pointed out that according to the rules of International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, the correct spelling of the specific epithet of this species is silbergliedi, not silvergliedi. However, the World Odonata List (Schorr et al. 2010) considers Indocypha silvergliedi as a valid name.
The female of this species is undescribed.
The species was described from a single female specimen (de Selys-Longchamps1877).
Prior to its description in 1949 the species was misidentified as A. melanocyana (Selys, 1877).
The female of the species is not yet described.

Macromia pyramidalis Martin, 1907 was described from male and female specimens collected in Tonkin. Wilson and Reels (2001) raised a number of issues concerning the Macromia pyramidalis type specimens. The male specimen Martin described as M. pyramidalis, has the characteristics of Macromia moorei malayana Laidlaw 1928 and is almost certainly synonymous with it, but the female specimen is identical to Macromia berlandi Lieftinck, 1941. Martin's (1907) describes the type male with tenth abdominal segment as having a bump, which forms a not very pointed pyramid (M. berlandi has a very sharply pointed or spine-like pyramidal process). An examination of the M. pyramidalis types, if they could be found (Martin commented that the male and female types were not in the Selys collection, but the actual location was not given), would likely reveal the female to be synonymous with M. berlandi and the male synonymous with M. moorei fumata  Krüger, 1899. Note Lieftinck (1929) considered  Macromia moorei malayana was synonymous with Macromia moorei fumata.

Lieftinck (1941) described M. berlandi from a Tonkinese male specimen identified by Martin (1907) as Macromia borneensis Krüger, 1899; the latter taxon is now recognised as a synonym of Macromia cincta Rambur, 1842. Wilson & Reels (2001) described the first female specimen of M. berlandi from a Hong Kong specimen. In summary Martin (1907) examined two males and one female Macromia speciemens collected from Tonkin in the Selys collection. These three specimens represent: (i) a male he misidentified as Macromia borneensis (= holotype M. berlandi male), (ii) a second male (type M. pyramidalis male = M. moorei malayana = M. moorei fumata) and (iii) a female (type M. pyramidalis = M. berlandi female).

There are two courses of corrective action possible: (1) Designate the male specimen, described by Martin (1907) as M. pyramidalis, as the holotype pyramidalis specimen. M. pyramidalis would then become a junior synonym of Macromia moorei Selys, 1874 and  the new combination Macromia moorei pyramidalis Martin, 1907 would become a junior synonym of Macromia moorei fumata (= M. moorei malayana). (2) Designate the female specimen as the holotype. M. pyramidalis Martin, 1907 would remain a valid taxon and Macromia berlandi Lieftinck, 1941 would be a junior synonym. The assessor strongly favours the first course of action which would have the least impact on current nomenclature and render Macromia berlandi a valid species.
The species is often confused with  Agriocnemis pygmaea due to the close similarity in morphological features.
The species was originally described as Idiophya nilgiriensis. However, the species was later placed under the genus Idionyx (Fraser, 1924).
Microgomphus souteri is distinguished by black labrum marked with two large triangular greenish spots and characteristic shape of the anal appendages.
The subspecies Onychogomphus nilgiriensis annaimallaicus could actually qualify for a species status, however further taxonomic research is required.
Macromia irata can be distinguished from other Macromia sp. by twin diamond shaped saddle markings on second abdominal segment.

Platyops sterreri is a stygobitic mysid, endemic to anchialine caves in Bermuda and the only species in the genus. Size 2-3 mm; rectangular eyes, strongly dorso-ventrally flattened with tiny corneal side in lateral external position; pereiopod I bulky; pereiopod II almost 3 times longer and thin; telson vaguely linguiform with 3 lateral spines in distal 1/4,  2 long lateral spines and 2 shorter median ones on aptical side; pleopods small and similar (Bacescu and Iliffe, 1986).
This newly described species was discovered in 2005. It is the single representative of the family Symphytognathidae in Europe with its closest relatives occurring in Cote D’Ivoire.
Generic name was entered incorrectly in 1996 as Antriscopia.

Chlorocnemis maccleeryi Pinhey, 1969 was described as a subspecies of C. montana St. Quentin, 1942. It differs substantially in coloration and size. Moreover the appendages are more like those of C. abbotti (Calvert, 1892) than C. montana. The differences are sufficient to regard the taxon as a good species (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer in press).

Largest museum collection of this species is held at the University of Michigan under the supervision of Dr Theodore Cohn (tcohn@sunstroke.sdsu.edu). Still undescribed, but genus is currently under revision.
The NatureServe NatureExplorer database lists this as Procambarus conus.

This species is one of several troglobitic species in the subgenus Ortmannicus. It is highly distinctive, and its closest affinities are with Procambarus delicatus, which appears to be on a line leading to Troglocambarus (J. Cordeiro, T. Jones and R. Thoma pers. comm. 2009).
Additional taxonomic study is needed to better differentiate this species from the similar Procambarus spiculifer, which occurs in the drainage immediately adjacent (GA DNR, pers. comm., 2009).

From a study conducted by Buhay and Crandall (2009) Procambarus pecki has been transferred from the subgenus Remoticambarus of the genus Procambarus, to the subgenus Aviticambarus of the genus Cambarus. This has been based on genetic studies which more accurately reflect its evolutionary history.

This crayfish is very closely related to Procambarus regalis and the two may be synonymous. The only differences noted by Hobbs are slight differences in the symmetry of the gonopods and differences in tuberculation of the annulus ventralis (D. Johnson pers. comm. 2010).
Very similar to rare but earlier described P. aequatorialis: all records of latter should be reassessed.
P. bredoi and P. xanthus are synonyms (Dijkstra unpubl.). This species is very similar to P. cognatus (Rambur, 1842).
N. anaci and N. verschuereni, from north-east and west Congo-Kinshasa respectively, are synonyms (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Often considered a subspecies of T. africana.
L. erythra is synonymous (Parr 1974).
Confused with P. sophia by Gambles (1979).
Subspecies radix of C. glauca was raised to species level by Dijkstra (2003).
Might be confused with Elattoneura lliba (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Complex taxonomy: considered synonym of A. bequaerti, but that is incorrect (Dijkstra unpubl.), while Sleuthemis diplacoides and Monardithemis leonensis do appear synonymous.
Subspecies couturieri is based on a single female from Tai Forest in Cote d'Ivoire, and may be just a variation.
Formerly treated as A. biordinata, but pertains to a new species.
See Dijkstra (2003) about synonymy of Pseudagrion coeruleiceps.
This species is very similar to the more common but more recently described P. hervei: all records should be reassessed.
Isomecocnemis is a synonym of Chlorocnemis (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Genus has been revised recently (Cammaerts 2004).
The validity of Z. occidentis and its generic placement is demonstrated by Dijkstra et al. (2006).
Possibly con-specific with N. uelensis.
Similar to P. cognatus and P. serrulatus, and the taxonomy is therefore confused.
Synonymy is discussed by Dijkstra et al. (2006).
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.
May have been transferred to the genus Typhlocypris.

This species is extremely similar to N. rosea, with the relative position of the gastric tubercle on the carapace being the only difference to separate them (Chan 1997).

Watabe and Iizuka (1999) state that more specimens need to be examined to determine if this is a valid species or not.

Some specimens of this species were incorrectly labelled as Scyllarus martensii (Holthuis 2002).

This species is referred to as Scyllarus modestus in Holthuis (1991).
This species had been assigned as Scyllarus paradoxus (Miers, 1881). More recently, Forest (1963) showed it to be a new species (Holthuis 2002).
This species is named Justita chani by Poupin 1994, but is now accepted as Nupalirus chani (Chan 2010).

This species has previously been confused with T. orientalis, which is now regarded as not occurring in Australia. The species are very difficult to separate using morphological characters (Burton and Davie 2007).

From morphological analyses the two subspecies, Chelarctus cultrifer cultrifer and C. cultrifer meridionalis (Holthuis, 1960) have been abandoned in favour of a single species (Chan 1997, Holthuis 2002).
Synonyms: Arctus depressus (S.I. Smith, 1881); S. nearctus (Holthuis, 1960).
Synonyms: Arctus americanus (S.I. Smith, 1869), Scyllarus gundlachi (Von Martens, 1872).
This species is named Justita vericeli by Poupin (1994), but is now accepted as Nupalirus vericeli (Chan 2010).
This species includes Scyllarides tumidus of Colin & Arneson (1995).
Synonyms: Scyllarus (Arctus) arctus paradoxus (Miers, 1881).
This species was split by Holthuis 1960 into S. chacei and S. americanus, as previous specimens have had some confusion between these two species.

Chan et al. (2009) recently showed that the banded and non-banded forms of Metanephrops thomsoni were widely genetically divergent. The banded (widespread) form is now treated as a distinct species and named after a recent fossil, Wongastacia taiwanica Hu, 1983 (see also Tshudy et al. 2007).
This species is very similar to N. stewarti and they often occur together (Chan 1997).
Named Allophaea ochracea by some authors.

The species was described in Onychogomphus, later treated as an Acrogomphus by Laidlaw, and then placed in Orientogomphus by Chao in 1990.
The female of this species is not known.

Described under the genus Gomphus Leach by Williamson (1907) from four males sent to him by Mr. R.A. Earnshaw who collected the specimens in Myanmar. No specific details of the type locality were provided by Williamson but Fraser (1934) states the type material was collected from the Toungoo and Karen districts. Fraser (1934) treated G. xanthenatus as a junior synonym of G. personatus Selys, 1873. The mesepimeron of G. xanthenatus is predominately black with three isolated yellow spots located centrally and the synthoracic antehumeral stripe is reduced to a small yellow spot situated below the wing base. Fraser (1934) studied G. personatus specimens collected from the type locality at Khasi Hills, Shillong and specimens collected from Maymyo, Myanmar. He was of the opinion that: "Mr. Williamson's specimens grade almost imperceptibly through the Maymyo specimens into the Shillong ones, the only real point of difference being the lateral sutural black lines, which are complete in Burmese material but invariably broken in Assam specimens." Following the establishment of Asiagomphus by Asahina (1985), Chao (1990) transferred all Chinese gomphines possessing distinctive and characteristic secondary genitalia, as described by Asahina, to the Asiagomphus genus. Carle (1986) established the subgenus Anatogomphurus to receive gomphines related to G. personatus Selys group but had overlooked Asahina's creation of Asiagomphus genus the previous year. Anatogomphurus is a synonym of Asiagomphus. The Japanese species Asiagomphus melaenops (Selys), 1854 is the type-species for the Asiagomphus genus. Since the original description A. xanthenatus and notwithstanding Fraser's (1934) records of A. personatus and treatment of  A. xanthenatus as a junior synonym of  A. personatus, no new records of A. xanthenatus were documented until Asahina's description of Asiagomphus xanthenatus acco Asahina (1996) from Cuc Phuong, Gia Vien, Ninh Binh Province, Viet Nam. Asiagomphus xanthenatus acco has an entirely black mesepimeron and lacks an antehumeral stripe. Wilson (2005) subsequently recorded this latter taxon from Chunxiu, Guangxi but considered it unlikely that A. x. acco belonged to A. xanthenatus.

Wilson (2005) stated: "If Asahina’s (1996) description of acco is compared with Williamson’s (1907) original description and drawings of xanthenatus it would appear unlikely that acco belongs to this taxon. The superior appendages of nominate subspecies are very different in style and do not possess a stout ventral spine. In addition the yellow pattern on the thorax and abdomen is more extensive than acco." The on-line Odonata database (odonata.info) managed by the Naturalis Museum Leiden treats acco as a good species. However until a direct comparison has been undertaken as stated by Wilson (2005): "Rather than elevate acco to species status subjectively it would be prudent to carry out a direct comparison with xanthenatus".

Two female records of A. x. xanthenatus from Thailand were documented by Hämäläinen and Pinratana (1999) although Asahina (1986) who originally documented these specimens did not feel confident in identifying them as A. x. xanthenatus in the absence of male specimens.

The species was described in Acrogomphus (Laidlaw 1931) and records have appeared with the species placed in Onychogomphus. Wilson (2008) transferred the species to Orientogomphus and summarised all taxonomic and distributional information on it.
This species differentiation from Drepanosticta sharpi has not been clearly demonstrated.

Protosticta robusta was described, and is still only known, from a single female specimen (Fraser 1933) collected in 1932. The main feature given to distinguish the species from other Protosticta species was its high nodal index, a wing venational character of doubtful taxonomic value.
The female of the species is not known.

Somatochlora dido Needham, 1930 was described from Sichuan. Wilson (2005) reported a male from Maoershan, Guangxi and synonymised Somatochlora taiwana Inoue and Yokota (2001), which was described from Yuan Yang Lake, Taiwan, with S. dido. Inoue and Yokata (2001) considered S. taiwana different from S. dido in a number of respects, principally (1) distance between the base of superior appendages and basal spine is one-third of total length in S. dido and one-sixth in S. taiwana and (2) broadest part of superiors situated distally in S. dido and centrally in S. taiwana. Wilson (2005) showed that specimens from Guangxi, southern China were intermediate between Sichuan and Taiwan and considered it rational to treat S. taiwana and S. dido as a single species.

Boonsoong and Chainthong (2014) described the female and larva of Microgomphus thailandicus, which provided information that clarified the generic and specific identity of this species; this allowed Makbun and Fleck (2018) to confirm M. thailandicus Asahina, 1981 as a junior synonym of M. svihleri (Asahina, 1970).
The status of this species, when compared with M. borikhanensis Fraser, 1933, is uncertain.
Until recently Rhipidolestes pallidistigma was placed in its own genus Calilestes Fraser, 1926. Kalkman and Wilson (2010) showed that the species in fact belongs in Rhipidolestes.
The species description is based on male specimens.
The female of the species is not known.

Three subspecies of Burmagomphus williamsoni are sometimes recognised: B. w. williamsoni, B. w. javicus and B. w. austrosundanus. The distribution of the subspecies is somewhat puzzling; the whole complex should be re-examined.
The taxonomic position of the species should be reviewed. When Asahina (1986) described it, he himself questioned the genus he was placing it in.
This species is described only from the male (Hämäläinen and Pinratana 1999, Hämäläinen 2003).

The species was described from a single teneral (freshly emerged) male (Xu 2006), which lacks any strong diagnostic structural characters. It is difficult to verify records from other locations by comparison with the description.
The species was described, and remains known from, a single female specimen.
The female of this species is undescribed.

Lestes angularis is known from a single male, and is said to be very similar to both Lestes elatus Hagen in Selys, 1862 and Lestes viridulus Rambur, 1842 (Fraser 1929, 1933). The status of this species should be re-examined.

Asahina (1970) considered Ceriagrion chaoi to be a junior synonym of C. auranticum Fraser 1922. However Hämäläinen (1987) showed convincingly that C. chaoi is a separate species. Individuals from Singapore identified as C. chaoi differ quite noticeably in colouration from those from further north.

According to Dow (unpublished), Prodasineura doisuthepensis Hoess, 2007 is possibly a junior synonym of this species, which both occur at the same locality. The only difference between the two species, at least that is apparent from the description and discussion in Hoess (2007) appears to be in the colour of their pale markings: blue in doisuthepensis but yellow in auricolor. Examples are already known in the Asian Protoneuridae of species which typically have orange or yellow pale markings, but which in some populations have pale markings blue in individuals that are not fully mature (Orr 2001, Dow 2008, Lieftinck 1937), such individuals can even be reproductively active.

The species apparently differs from the widespread Zygonyx iris, a species with a number of subspecies, in details of colouration and wing venation only. It is known from only two males and may ultimately prove to be a junior synonym or a subspecies of Z. iris.

The only certain records of this species are that of the type male from “Cochinchine” (Selys 1878) and a recent unpublished record from Khan Hoa province in southern Viet Nam (a male specimen was collected by M. Hämäläinen at Ba Ho falls [12° 23’ 22’’ N, 109° 08’ 14’’ E; alt. 25 m ] in 2009. The specimen is presently in Coll. Karube.).

Förster (1905) regarded the species as a synonym of M. smithii (Selys, 1854), a Himalayan species, but it is not clear if his assessment is correct.

Although the original spelling of the species name is 'pavici', in literature most later authors have used the spelling 'paviei', since it is evident that the species was named in honour of Auguste Pavie. However, the spelling 'pavici' may actually have been based on the latinized form of the surname - Pavicius (J. van Tol, in litt.). Therefore, in agreement with the usage of this taxon name in Catalogue of Life (2011) the original spelling 'pavici' is used here."

Karube and Kosterin (2018) described the genus Mattigomphus, to include two species: tamdaoensis (formerly Merogomphus tamdaoensis Karube, 2001) and pinratanai (formerly Anisogomphus pinratani Hämäläinen, 1991). Merogomphus chaoi Yang & Davies, 1993 is also now recognised as a junior synonym of Mattigomphus pinratani (Karube and Kosterin 2018).

The species is known only from the female type, which is apparently lost (Fraser 1934). From the description given by de Selys (1878) it is not possible to know even what genus it belongs to with any certainty.
There was some historical dispute over the presence of this species in Viet Nam but recently specimens have been confirmed in northern Viet Nam.
This species was previously misidentified as Galearctus kitanoviriosus (T-.Y. Chan pers. comm. 2011).

The species was described in 2011 base on male specimens collected in 2008 and 2009. The female of the species was observed and photographed, but not collected.

Do et al. (2012) described the female of the species, also from Huu Lien Nature Reserve, Lang Son Province.
There are two subspecies; R. alpina alpina which is relatively widespread from Spain to Turkey and R. alpina syriaca which is a relict subspecies of the southeastern Turkish population.
Anthene janna is now considered a subspecies of A. opalina and treated as such. This taxonomic arrangement was put forward by Larsen (1991) and is supported by Libert in his recent revision.
S. acuminata was in the 1996, 2000 and 2002 IUCN Red Lists. Now confirmed that it is a synonym of S. daguerrei.
Incorrectly spelt in Red Lists prior to 2008 as S. mundaus.
Should possibly be placed in the family Archaeobalanidae (see ITIS).
There are four known subspecies: the nominate subspecies imperialis; imperatrix (de Niceville, 1899); gillesi (Turlin, 1991); and behludinii (Pen, 1936).
A monotypic genus and some put this in a monotypic family. However, it is a near relative of several species of Paraphlebia from Mexico to Nicaragua.
Astacus astacus is comprised of three subspecies: Astacus astacus astacus, Astacus astacus balcanicus, Astacus astacus colchicus.

This species is part of the coon species group which was considered part of the Atrophaneura by Hancock (1988); the group occurs from Assam and Hainan in the north to the Andaman Islands and Sumatra in the south (Hancock 1988). This species was previously thought to be a subspecies of Atrophaneura coon by some authors (e.g. Tsukada and Nishiyama 1982), but it is now considered a full species as per Hancock (1984). Other authorities elevated the subgenus Losaria to full genus level (Häuser et al. 2017), and we follow this treatment here

Some consider Austropotamobius pallipes as a species complex comprised of two genetically distinct species; A. pallipes and an Italian species for which the name is being discussed. The Italian species is thought to be comprised of a number of subspecies, though this depends on the author. Both the Italian form and A. pallipes can be found in Spain, France, Italy and Switzerland. It is also suggested that there are two subspecies of A. pallipes: A. pallipes pallipes which exists in France, the British Isles, Spain, Switzerland, and Germany, and A. p. subsp. nov. which is known from Liguria in Italy and the Alpes Maritimes region of France. There still exists some debate as to whether the Italian form should be raised to species level, though recent genetic work (Grandjean et al. 2000a, Fratini et al. 2005, Bertocchi et al. 2008) would support a separate species, Austropotamobius italicus with 4 subspecies.
Appeared on Red Lists prior to 2008 as Bayadera brevicauda ishigakiana.
The specific epithet was incorrectly spelt in the 1996 Red List as verticornis according to the Odonata Specialist Group.
See Dijkstra (2003) about the synonymy of Pseudagrion angelicum.
Originally described under Diaphlebia. A monotypic genus.

This taxon is regarded as a subspecies of splendens Harris, 1782 by several authors (Schmidt 1938, 1954; Buchholtz 1955; Rueppell et al. 2005; Kalkman 2006). Calopteryx syriaca is an endemic of the southern Levant (Schneider 1986, Dumont 1991) and overlaps in its northernmost range with Calopteryx hyalina Martin, 1909. In their area of sympatry both taxa exhibit 'character displacement', which is another reason to give them full specific rank (Schneider 1986).
This species is allopatric with Cambarus aculabrum and C. setosus. It was originally identified as C. setosus.

Populations of this species in North and South Carolina have tentatively been identified as this species, but further taxonomic study is necessary before a final determination is made on the identification of these populations (J. Cooper, pers. comm. 2006).
Following J. Marshall (Natural History Museum, London) Neduba longipennis was transferred to Aglaothorax longipennis.
Following J. Marshall (Natural History Museum, London) Conocephaloides remotus was transferred to Euconocephalus remotus.
Should be Allancastria (Bollini and Racheli 2012).
This species is considered as a subspecies of Pieris brassicae by some authors.
Note correction to scientific spelling of Pantagenia to Pentagenia.
Orthographic error in specific name in the 1996 Red List (was in as 'oculta'). Generic name Parapheidole is a synonym of Pheidole.

The southern subpopulations (from Greece and Macedonia) belonging to the subspecies Stenobothrus eurasius macedonicus are likely to represent a unique species (D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015) or a subspecies of S. croaticus and are therefore ignored here. In addition, the status of S. eurasius hyalosuperficies needs to be studied (V. Savitsky and V. Vedenina pers. comm. 2015).
Was in the 1996 IUCN Red List as Spharagemon superbum. Was accidentally spelt as Eximacxris in the 2001-2002 IUCN Red Lists.

The species status is well accepted, but there was a debate concerning different subspecies. Löbl and Smetana (2010)  listed a number of described subspecies and species synonyms, but regarded all of them as C. cerdo cerdo. The only accepted subspecies C. cerdo mirbeckii is known from Northern Africa (Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia). Whether the subspecies C. cerdo mirbeckii is also present on the Iberian Pensinsula is unclear (Vives 2000, Sama 2002).

Both Conomyrma medeis and Conomyrma reginicula were in the 1996, 2000 and 2002 Red Lists: Both are synonyms of D. insanus.
Other Synonym = Conomyrma (Biconomyrma) wheeleri.
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).

A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

The earlier Cape records (Pinhey 1984) are doubtful and are probably Pseudagrion hageni hageni (Samways 2006).

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata armata. Coulter (1991) treated it as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata. The revisions by Cumberlidge (1997, 1999) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), revived the genus Platythelphusa, and referred this species to Platythelphusa armata. Cumberlidge (1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata conculcata. Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) conculcata. The revisions by Cumberlidge (1997, 1999) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), revived the genus Platythelphusa, and referred this species to Platythelphusa conculcata. Cumberlidge(1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) echinata. Cumberlidge (1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) tuberculata. This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) aloysiisabaudiae. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) treated it as Potamonautes aloysiisabaudiae and reported on new material from the DR Congo and western Uganda.

This genus was formerly assigned to the family Deckeniidae Ortmann, 1897. The genus Deckenia is now assigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckenini: Deckenina (Cumberlidge et al. 2007). This species was described by Ng et al. (1995) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006), and its distribution was updated by Marijnissen et al. (2005).

This genus was formerly assigned to the family Deckeniidae Ortmann, 1897. The genus Deckenia is now assigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckenini: Deckenina (Cumberlidge et al. 2007). This species was described by Ng et al. (1995) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006), and its distribution was updated by Marijnissen et al. (2005).

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) armata armata. Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) maculata. Cumberlidge (1999), Cumberlidge et al. (1999) and Marijnissen et al. (2004) recognised nine species in the genus, all of which are endemic to Lake Tanganyika. This genus was formerly assigned to the Platythelphusidae (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004). It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) polita. This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) berardi berardi (Audouin, 1826) with one subspecies. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) treated this species as Potamonautes berardi with no subspecies.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) didieri. It is listed here as Potamonautes didieri.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Lobopotamonautes) perparvus gonocristatus Bott, 1955. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes gonocristatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamon (Geothelphsua) granviki Colosi, 1924. It is recognised here as Potamonautes idjiwiensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) berardi ignestii. Cumberlidge (1998) treated it as the valid species Potamonautes ignestii.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonutes) infravallatus. Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes infravallatus.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangapotamonautes) johnstoni johnstoni. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes johnstoni.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Tripotamonautes) loveridgei. Cumberlidge (1998) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes loveridgei.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) neumanni. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) referred to this species as Potamonautes neumanni.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) pilosus. Cumberlidge (1997) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes pilosus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangopotamonautes) johnstoni platycentron.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) platynotus. Cumberlidge (1998) and Cumberlidge et al. (1999), and Reed & Cumberlidge (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes platynotus.
Cumberlidge & Vannini (2004) described this interesting species from a number of localities in Tanzania and Kenya.
This species is known from a single report in 2001.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) johnstoni unisulcatus. Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) recognised this taxon as the valid species Potamonautes unisulcatus.

Coulter (1991) treated this taxon as Potamonautes (Platythelphusa) denticulata. Cumberlidge et al. (1999) considered this taxon to be a possible junior synonym of P. armata. This taxon was revived by Marijnissen et al. (2004) following the reexaminaton of the type specimen and the collection of more material. This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This genus was formerly assigned (Cumberlidge 1999, Cumberlidge et al. 1999, Marijnissen et al. 2004) to the Platythelphusidae. It was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Potamonautinae by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).
This species is closely related to the Taiwanese species Chlorogomphus risi.
Appeared on the Red List prior to 2008 under the name Chlorogomphus brevistigmata okinawanus.
Synonyms = Cordulegaster insignis mzymtae; Sonjagaster (insignis) mzymtae.

Changed from Aethiothemis watulikii Pinhey, 1962 to A. basilewskyi Fraser, 1954 for 2005 Red List. A. watulikii was described on the basis of minor colour differences to A. basilewskyi, which do not support an own species status (Dijkstra 2007). Both basilewskyi and watulikii pertain to a slender, dark Aethiothemis species, known from limited material from the Congo basin.
Atoconeura aethiopica was formerly considered a subspecies of A. biordinata, but it is now regarded as a valid species (Dijkstra in prep.).
The species is only known from the original description might turn out to be conspecific with C. pulchellum.
Complex taxonomy: Anectothemis and Porpacithemis are synonyms of Congothemis (Dijkstra, unpubl.).

Pseudagrion quadrioculatum is conspecific with P. superbum. The latter was regarded synonymous with P. serrulatum by (Pinhey 1964), from which it only differs in minor details of markings (Dijkstra in prep).

Fraser (1960) stated that of C. abyssinicus "only two females and a male are known. The former came from Abyssinia, the latter from Uganda and is regarded as the correct male […] only on supposition". He added "Uganda, swampy borders of Lake Victoria" as the species’ habitat. The male – now the allotype (Natural History Museum, London) – is labelled "E. abyssinia". Presumably Fraser was in error, misleading later authors such as Pinhey (1962) who stated "Uganda (teste Fraser, ex Carpenter)" for C. abyssinicus. C. abyssinicus is not known from outside Ethiopia.
This is the Erythrodiplax sp. of Laessle (1961)
There is some confusion over recent taxonomic changes for this species.
Prior to 2008, the generic name was incorrectly spelt on the IUCN Red List.
Monotypic genus.
This is a sibling species of Lestes virens, discriminated through breeding phenology and genetics (Samraoui et al. 2003).

According to the New World Orthoptera Hypolestes clara should be transferred to Ortholestes clara. However, Paulson and von Ellenrieder (2005 submissions) note that this should be Hypolestes clara: originally described as Ortholestes clara. There is confusion about whether any Hispaniolan populations are this species, H. trinitatis of Cuba, or a third unnamed species (Dunkle 1991). Hypolestes occupies a somewhat isolated position in its family, and other family placement has been suggested, even a family of its own. It may be a sister group to most other modern damselflies (Rehn 2003).

According to the New World Orthoptera Hypolestes trinitatis should be transferred to Ortholestes trinitatis. However, according to Paulson and von Ellenrieder (2005 Red List submission), this should be Hypoletes: there is confusion about whether any Hispaniolan populations are this species, H. clara of Jamaica, or a third undescribed species (Dunkle 1991). Hispaniolan populations are usually listed with H. trinitatis, but penis structure is different (and this is often used to separate similar species). Hypolestes occupies a somewhat isolated position in its family, and other family placement has been suggested, even a family of its own. It may be a sister group to most other modern damselflies (Rehn 2003).
Senior synonym of Neoneura palustris Hagen, 1867.
Monotypic genus.
Originally described under genus Eurypetalia; von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is currently reviewing taxonomy of South American austropetaliids.
Originally described under genus Eurypetalia; von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is currently reviewing taxonomy of South American austropetaliids.

Synonyms: Ophiopetalia auregaster Carle, 1996; Ophiopetalia araucana Carle, 1996; Ophiopetalia diana Carle, 1996 (von Ellenrieder in prep.).

The taxonomy of South American austropetaliids is currently being reviewed by von Ellenrieder. Carle (1996) created genus Ophiopetalia to include this species, and described three new species; von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is synonymyzing them.

Taxonomy of South American austropetaliids is currently
being reviewed by von Ellenrieder.

This species was introduced as "Gomphus ruppeli" (after Eduard Rüppell) by Selys-Longchamps (1858). The name has been spelt in several ways since, mainly to correct for the vowel mutation and the missing consonant.

Originally described as Disparoneura cellularis Grünberg, 1902. It was "referred with some doubt to Isomecocnemis" by Cowley (1936) (Dijkstra 2007). Pinhey (1962a) considered the species as belonging to Elattoneura. Dijkstra (2007) confirms that the species belongs to Elattoneura. The male holotype is held at ZMH, Berlin.
The dark form, P. impedita, occurs in the highlands of Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe.
The species is the smallest of the four of the genus within the assessment area. A key to separate them is given by Schneider (1986).
Synonyms = Phyllogomphus selysi sensu Fraser, 1957; P. dundomajoricus Fraser, 1957; P. dundominusculus Fraser, 1957.
Very recently comparing the types in the Bulawayo museum Dijkstra synomynised M. mozambicensis. This is still unpublished.
Originally described as Micromacromia, but moved to Neodythemis (Dijkstra and Vick 2006). Synonymy and generic placement is discussed by Dijkstra and Vick (2006).
Previously placed in Allorrhizucha (Dijkstra and Vick 2006).
Possible synonym = Phyllomacromia onerata (Martin, 1907).
The larger subspecies N. malawiensis in Malawi (Mulanje) is likely to be transferred to a new genus: Mastigogomphus.
N. meruensis is a synonym to N. kilimanjaricus (not yet published).
Synonym = Olpogastra fraseri.
The taxonomy of Onychogomphus near O. supinus is extremely difficult and all records of similar taxa are combined here, including Legrand's (2003) O. quirkii.
Paragomphus bredoi (Schouteden, 1934) is most likely a synonym of P. serrulatus (Dijkstra unpub. data).
Some questions over the status of the species (very similar to Paragomphus elpidius).

This Pemba Island species is nearly identical to some species of the Malagasy radiation of Platycnemis, but distant from the Guineo-Congolian species that have tropical Asian affinities. The species is likely to be a long-distance wind-borne arrival from Madagascar, which survived due to favourable climatic conditions on Pemba (Dijkstra et al. 2007).

Trithemis imitata Pinhey, 1961 and T. monardi Ris, 1931 are very similar species, with rather relative differences in markings. Their taxonomy needs to be resolved in a geographic perspective. Most T. imitata and T. monardi records appear to be from North and South of the Equator respectively (see also Dijkstra 2007). For the time being T. imitata is regarded as a synonym to T. monardi.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. assegaii is a B-group species.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". Pseudagrion coelestis is a B-group species.
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
Some records were misidentifications. The taxonomic confusion was recently solved by Dijkstra (in prep.).
Microneura is a monotypic genus.
Formerly often considered as a subspecies of Libellula fulva.

Coenagrion intermedium Lohmann 1990 from Crete is regarded either as a full species or a subspecies of C. ponticum. Full species rank is retained here for both taxa. This assessment is for C. ponticum sensu stricto, from the South Caucasus area.

This species has been described almost simultaneously from Northern Zambia (aequalis) and the Okavango Delta (falconis). K.D. Dijkstra (pers. comm.) who compared material of both did not find relevant differences.
A monotypic genus.
Originally considered E. paulsoni Belle, 1981.
Closest relative is West African Pentaphlebia (De Marmels 1996, De Marmels et al. 1996).

This species was introduced as Gomphus ruppeli (after Eduard Rüppell) by Selys-Longchamps (1858). The name has been spelt in several ways since, mainly to correct for the vowel mutation and the missing consonant.

First described as a subspecies of Coenagrion puella (Linnaeus, 1758) (in the genus Agrion) from Palestine, this is now widely accepted as a valid species, endemic to the Levant and southern Turkey (Dumont 1977; Schneider and Moubayed 1985; Schneider 1986; Battin 1993; Kalkman 2006; Kalkman and van Pelt 2006a,b). Dumont (1991) placed it again in the synonymy of Coenagrion puella.

This east Mediterranean endemic is morphologically well distinct from other regional Gomphus species. The syntype series came from Iskenderun, Beirut and Damascus (Selys 1887). St. Quentin's (1965) record from Izmir (= Smyrna) is certainly a misidentification of G. schneiderii and therefore correctly not listed by Kalkman and van Pelt (2006); the same holds true for the specimens reported by St. Quentin (1994, 1995) and by Asahina (1973) from northern Iraq. Most likely both refer to Gomphus kinzelbachi (Schneider, 1984).

Ris (1919) described Orthetrum poecilops poecilops from Guangdong. The subspecies Orthetrum poecilops miyajimaense Yuki & Doi, 1938 was described, originally as separate species, from Miyajima, a small island near Hiroshima, southern Honshu, Japan. Asahina and Sawano (1957) synonymised the two taxa but later Asahina (1970) reinstated miyajimaense at subspecies level, based principally on its smaller size. Wilson (2001) considers the two taxa are probably synonyms. Nevertheless the Japanese population represents a distinct and isolated (fragmented) population.
Similar to D. selysi of Congo Basin, but probably distinct (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Previously placed in Allorrhizucha (Dijkstra and Vick 2006).

Pastilla dacuna appeared incorrectly as Pastilla ruhuna in Bahir et al. (2005), and subsequently was entered into the 2007 IUCN Red List as P. ruhuna. Pastilla is a monotypic genus. Bott (1970) included this species in Ceylonthelphusa. This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).
