Two former sub species, Orconectes australis australis and O. a. packardi have recently been elevated to species level (Buhay & Crandall 2008).
This species is known to be made up of two sub species, Orconectes inermis inermis Cope, 1872 and Orconectes inermis testii (Hay 1891).
Two subspecies of this species are recognised; Meek's Short Pointed Crayfish Orconectes meeki brevis Williams, 1952 and Meek's Crayfish Orconectes meeki meeki (Faxon 1898).

This species is a species complex consisting of Procambarus lucifugus lucifugus (Florida Cave Crayfish, Hobbs 1940b) and Procambarus lucifugus alachua (Vampire Crayfish Hobbs 1940b). Ongoing genetic work has found little genetic differentiation among P. lucifugus alachua, P. lucifugus "intergrades", P. erythrops, and P. leitheuseri, whereas P. l. lucifugus is distinct from all of those.  Hence, P. l. lucifugus may prove to be a separate species known from only two localities (Hobbs 1942), the location of one of which is unknown. Procambarus l. lucifugus is characterized by a lack of eyespots.  Three miles away from the cave at which  P. l. lucifugus is found is a cave with crayfish possessing very distinct eyespots, which is genetically indistinguishable from P. l. alachua. Further investigation is required to clarify this discrepancy as it may affect the threat status of Procambarus lucifugus (P. Moler pers. comm. 2010).

This is a species complex:
Procambarus rogersi rogersi (Seepage crayfish, Hobbs 1938)
Procambarus rogersi campestris: Field Crayfish (Hobbs 1942)
Procambarus rogersi expletus: Perfect Crayfish (Hobbs and Hart 1959)
Procambarus rogersi ochlocknensis: Ochlockonee Crayfish  (Hobbs 1942)

This is a species complex that needs taxonomic revision.

Described from female collected from Taiwan by Oguma (1926).  Chen (1950) described first male from Miao-Li, Hsin-Chu Hsien, and provided details of five more specimens collected from Doba, Taipeh Hsien, Taiwan. Asahina (1961) designated a lectotype from Hoppo (Peipu).

The type locality of Planaeschna risi risi Asahina (1964) is Kussha, Taiheizan, Taiwan. Planaeschna risi sakishimana Asahina, 1964 was described (in the same paper describing the nominate subspecies) from the island of Omoto-dake, Ishigaki-Shima, Ryukyus of Japan near Taiwan. Lieftinck et al. (1984) consider that Planaeschna ishigakiana Asahina (1951), also described from southwestern parts of Ryukyus, is not sufficiently characterised and differentiated from P. r. sakishimana.

Two forms previously treated as subspecies or synonyms of M. basilaris are currently recognised as distinct species: M. nigripectus (Sélys, 1879) and M. kricheldorffi (Karsch, 1891); however there is not universal agreement that these should be treated as distinct species, although they are treated as such here. A subspecies M. b. japonica (Förster, 1897) occurs in Japan.

Ris (1912) described Coeliccia flavicauda flavicauda from Tainan, southwest Taiwan where it is probably endemic. The single subspecies Coeliccia flavicauda masakii Asahina, 1951 was described from Isigaki-Shima, southwest Ryukyus Islands, Japan.

Martin (1909) described this taxon as a subspecies of Calopteryx splendens (Harris, 1782) and was followed by several authors (Morton 1924, Schmidt 1954, Buchholtz 1955). Bartenef (1912) regarded it as a subspecies of Calopteryx syriaca Rambur, 1842. Although already Dumont (1975, 1977) treated the taxon - with some doubts - as a valid species, it was Schneider (1986) who could show conclusively that C. hyalina merits full specific rank: C. hyalina and C. syriaca are sympatric but never syntopic. In addition to sympatry (upper Orontes, Nahr al-Kabir (S), Litani, Lake Hula) they exhibit reproductive character displacement. Where C. hyalina comes into contact with C. intermedia Selys, 1887 (lower Orontes, Nahr al-Kabir (S)) hybrids occur, and these were described by Buchholtz (1955) as Calopteryx splendens "pseudosyriaca".

Will become Aethiothemis coryndoni (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Taxonomic work is needed for the genus Onychogomphus and it may be discovered rossii is not a valid species.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. makabusiense is an A-group species. The taxonomy of the species is likely to requires reform.
B-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
The African genus Phaon seems to be the closest relative of the Iridictyon (De Marmels et al. 1996).
The African genus Phaon seems to be the closest relative of the Iridictyon (De Marmels et al. 1996).
Nearest relatives in Australia and New Zealand.
Taxonomy of South American austropetaliids currently being reviewed by von Ellenrieder. Carle (1996) created genus Rheopetalia to include this species, von Ellenrieder (in prep.) is synonymyzing it.
Taxonomy of South American austropetaliids currently being reviewed by von Ellenrieder. Carle (1996) created genus Odontopetalia to include this species, von Ellenrieder (in prep.) synonymyzed it.

In 2004, Andrew Smith discovered a new species Poecilotheria hanumavilasumica from a sacred grove of the Hanumavilasum Temple on Rameshwaram Island. This species was earlier misidentified by Simon (1885), and Annandale (1907), as Poecilotheria fasciata from the Island and later Gravely (1915) misidentified this as Poecilotheria striata from Pamban on Rameshwaram Island.
It closely resembles Poecilotheria miranda, P. formosa and P. fasciata.
Populations occurring in Eastern Ghats and Western Ghats could be two different species but this needs taxonomic confirmation.
May belong to the genus Thrigmopoeus. The description of the species is based only on the female.

The description of the species is based only on female specimens and the male is yet to be discovered and described. Taxonomy of this species is not very clear due to lack of information from recent reports.

Gravely (1915) reported this species from Pamban on Rameshwaram Island. However, Smith (2004) described the spider on Rameshwaram Island as P. hanumavilasumica. There is some confusion in identification of P. striata and P. formosa. Further studies are required to resolve this.There is also some confusion between the maxillary lyra patterns between P. regalis and P. striata, In one instance two spiderlings collected from the same burrow matured into two species, P. regalis and P. striata, identified based on the presence and absence of the epigastric pinkish/rufous/yellow band.
It closely resembles Poecilotheria miranda.

There is some confusion between Thrigmopoeus truculentus and T. insignis since the two have overlapping distribution. Taxonomically, the difference is noticeable in size, colour, chelicerae and maxillary lyra under a stereomicroscope.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as the subspecies Potamonautes (Obesopotamonautes) obesus calcaratus (Gordon, 1929). Reed and Cumberlidge (2004) redescribed this species as Potamonautes calcaratus.

Bott (1955) treated this taxon as the subspecies Potamonautes (Potamonautes) bayonianus dubius. Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) argued that this taxon should properly be referred to as the valid species Potamonautes dubius.
Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) described the distribution and habitat of this species which is known only from the holotype from Angola.
Gouws, Stewart, & Reavell (2001), and Gouws and Stewart (2001) provide details of the distribution and habitat of this species.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Isopotamonautes) macrobrachii. Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) referred to this species as Potamonautes macrobrachii.
Found only in high mountain streams in the Western Cape Province of South Africa. Similar to P. brincki in size, habitat, and distribution.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) perlatus. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998), Daniels, Gibbons, and Stewart (1999), and Daniels, Stewart, and Gibbons (1999) refer to this species as Potamonautes perlatus; both of these latter works summarize the distribution of this species in Western Cape Province, South Africa. The distribution of P. perlatus in its entire range was described by Barnard (1935, 1950). This is one of the first species of freshwater crabs to be described from Africa.

This species was treated by Bott (1955) as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) sidneyi. Cumberlidge (1998) and Gouws and Stewart (2001) referred to this species as Potamonautes sidneyi and the latter workers described its distribution and habitat.
Daniels, Stewart, Ridgway and Florence (2001) described the distribution of P. unispinus in detail.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) warreni. Daniels, Stewart, Ridgway, and Florence (2001) referred to this species as Potamonautes warreni and described its distribution in detail, updating that provided by Barnard (1935).
This species was originally placed in the genus Procambarus, subgenus Distocambarus (Hobbs 1981). However, in 1983 Distocambarus was elevated to a generic rank (Hobbs and Carlson 1983).
This species incorrectly spelled yongineri in Wilson (1989).

Marincek, M. 1978. Eoleptestheria spinosa, a new species of Conchostraca (Phyllopoda) dicovered in Yugoslavia. Bulletin du Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle de Belgrade B 33: 103-118.

Marincek, M. and Valvajter, B. 1982. Eoleptestheria spinosa magna, a new subspecies of Conchostraca (Crustacea). Bulletin du Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle de Belgrade, B 37: 63-72.

It is possible that more than one species is included in this taxon, as a specimen from Oaxaca in the Paulson collection is considered to be this species (Donnelly 1989) but differs in morphology from the type series from Nayarit.
Listed from Veracruz in the original description. This population was later described as E. sulcatistyla Donnelly, 1989.
The Epiophlebiidae are the only extant family in the suborder Anisozygoptera, which holds just two species. They are relict species of a once widespread group.
This species was previously placed in the genus Cambarus (K. Crandall pers. comm. 2009).
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).
The Red Wood Ants include species from the Formica rufa group in Eurasia (including F. aquilonia, F. lugubris, F. polyctena, F. pratensis, F. rufa, and F. uralensis) (D. Agosti pers. comm. 1995).
There are no known subspecies of this species.
There are no subspecies of Graphium levassori.
This species is very similar to Graphium doson, but is considered a valid species by D’Abrera (1982), Tsukada and Nishiyama (1982) and Robinson (1975-76).
Probably does not belong in this genus; of uncertain position, but more closely related to Rhionaeschna and Andaeshna than to Aeshna (von Ellenrieder 2003).
Synonym = Diacyclops hypogeus Kiefer, 1930.

This ill-defined taxon was described as a subspecies of Crocothemis erythraea by Morton (1920). Waterston and Pittaway (1991) considered it as a good species, but few constant structural criteria allow the separation of both taxa (Morton 1920, Asahina 1973, Schneider 1985). Criteria used are structural ones, colour differences, a smaller size and minor venational characters. A taxonomic revision of the C. erythraea-complex over its whole range is urgently needed.

The taxonomic status of C. tardus is uncertain. The species has only been found in the Ukraine and is only known from old records from 1929. However, no specimens have been found in museum collections that could help to clarify the situation.
Dasypoda iberica is only from the male. Female of this species is still undescribed.
This species was first described as subspecies - Pseudagrion inconspicuum arabicum Waterston, 1980 - but is now regarded as a good species.
Lindenia inkiti described from the south Caucasus area by Bartenef falls in the variability of the species and thus is a synonym of L. tetraphylla.

The African Orthetrum kollmannspergeri is the western counterpart/sister taxon of the Asian O. taeniolatum, with which it was often confused in Africa and western Arabia. Both differ by details in their genital structure although their general appearance is similar (Clausnitzer and  Dijkstra, 2005; Dumont and Verschuren, 2005).

Libellula gracilis Albarda in Selys, 1887 is according to Ris (1910) a synonym of L. ransonnetii Brauer, 1865.

This is a well defined species which is however poorly known and is not easy to identify using the existing keys for Middle Eastern species (Dumont 1991, Kalkman 2006, Schneider 1986), although using the figures of the species’ genitalia provided in these publications makes identification easy. In North Africa, the key by Jacquemin and Boudot (1999) works well.

The taxonomic history of the "pale" Sympetrum is complex. The holotype of S. sinaiticum Dumont, 1977 was described from Tunisia and was based on an aberrant specimen (in its genitalia structure). As a consequence the subspecies S. s. tarraconense Jödicke, 1994 was subsequently synonymized with the nominotypical form, which ranges from the southern Levant (including the extreme north of Saudi Arabia) to Morocco and eastern Spain. Its Asiatic counterpart, Sympetrum arenicolor Jödicke, 1994, initially considered as a subspecies of S. sinaiticum, is now considered as a true species due to significant differences in the larvae and exuviae features, with S. deserti Jödicke, 1994 as a junior synonym. The name S. decoloratum Selys, 1884, now denotes a pale Asiatic subspecies of S. vulgatum, previously recorded as S. vulgatum flavum Bartenef, 1915.

This name applies to the former records of Trithemis donaldsoni from western Africa and Yemen (Dijkstra, 2007). The exact distributional ranges of the closely related species T. dejouxi and T. donaldsoni is unclear and needs further studies. Genetic analysis shows they are sister taxa with recent separation (Damm et al., 2010).
Aeschna yemenensis is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011).

Aeshna ellioti is now placed in the genus Zosteraeschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011). Peters and Theischinger (2011) also proposed that the subspecies usambarica be retuned to species level as Z. usambarica.
The genus Eozubovskya has been synonymised by Storozhenko et al. (2015) with Zubovskya and currently the species is assigned to the latter.

Previous IUCN Red Lists had the genus name spelled as Acanthaeshna; this was corrected in 2005 to Acanthaeschna. See Theischinger and Endersby (2009) for an account of the taxonomic history of this species.
Northern populations previously treated as Austrophlebia costalis were separated as Austrophlebia subcostalis by Theischinger (1996).
Original description was Caliaeschna conspersa, by Tillyard (1907) and for latter taxonomic changes see Houston and Watson (1988).
Original description (Tillyard 1909). A detailed account on taxonomic history is provided by Watson (1991).
The adult of Austrogomphus pusillus is only known from the holotype male, which “It is somewhat teneral, and is now much broken:” Watson (1991)

Austrolestes minjerriba Watson 1979, is often mistakenly written as Austrolestes minjerriba Watson & Moulds, 1979, after the paper which the description was published in; see Watson and Moulds, (1979).
The identity of this species is uncertain, the four specimens collected may be immature. Its generic placement is questionable.
Prionotropis hystrix subsp. azami Uvarov, 1923 was raised to species level by Massa and Ünal (2015).
Ischnura fountainei Morton, 1905 is an incorrect original spelling in the sense of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN), which had been emended according to Article 31.1.2.

This small species of Orthetrum is mainly Asian in distribution and is replaced in Africa and southwestern Arabia by its sister taxon Orthetrum kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959. According to Dumont and Veschuren (2005) and Clausnitzer and Dijkstra (2005), all African and west-Arabian records of O. taeniolatum should be ascribed to O. kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959. Unfortunately the name kollmannspergeri Buchholz, 1959 will fall into synonymy of an earlier available name (Ober in prep.).

The species consists of two subspecies, Caridina babaulti babaulti distributed in India, but poorly known, and Caridina babaulti basrensis distributed in Iran and Iraq. Currently it is not known if both subspecies could represent valid species or if a single, variable species is involved.

Four subspecies are currently recognised within this species, with the nominotypical subspecies being widespread in central and southern China.  The other three subspecies are currently only known from their type material.
Two subspecies are currently recognised, both of which are poorly known and their identities need resolving.

The species consists of two subspecies, one (subsp. idella) distributed in Tanzania and Madagascar, the other (subsp. georgii) in Kerala (India).  It appears very likely that both taxa should be elevated to species level.
The species comprises three subspecies, one of which is widely distributed in Asia, the other two are only known from their type material and are of doubtful taxonomic status.
The species comprises six distinct evolutionary lineages, which have been formally recognised as subspecies (Sket and Zaksek 2009, Jugovic et al. 2012).

In Europe three subspecies could be recoginsed. The subspecies O. f. forcipatus occurs in most of Europe. The subspecies O. f. unguiculatus (Vander Linden, 1823) is confined to Iberia, Italy and the southeastern part of France. The third  subspecies O. f. albotibiualis is in Europe confined to the eastern Mediterranean Greek islands and Cyprus. Genetic studies failed to find any genetic differentiation between these three subspecies (Ferreira et al. 2014).

The Baltic populations were formerly regarded as a distinct taxon, namely A. osiliensis or A. serrata osiliensis Mierzejewski, 1913. The characters separating these two taxa are however weak and are now considered insignificant, reflecting at most more genetic variability than true speciation. Here A. osiliensis is regarded as a synonym of A. serrata.
Coenagrion vanbrinkae Lohmann, 1993 is considerd a junior synonym of C. ornatum (Kosterin and Ahmad 2018).

Several subspecies - Coenagrion pulchellum mediterraneum Schmidt, 1964, C. p. interruptum (Charpentier, 1840) and C. p. saisanicum (Belyshev, 1964), have been described in the past. They were mostly based on variations in melanism and in size. As both characters are highly variable within a given region, these subspecies are no longer recognized as valid.
The subspecies Erythromma viridulum orientale Schmidt, 1960 doesn't differ statistically from many European populations and cannot be validated (Boudot and Jacquemin 1988)

No valid subspecies is known, as P. elisabethae matches the full species rank (Kalkman & Lopau 2006). The populations in Morocco are structurally identical to P. nymphula but genetically closer to P. elisabethae (Guan et al. 2013).

The overall taxonomy of Cordulegaster insignis Schneider, 1845 is much more complex than previously believed. Many local forms of this polytypic species do not fit the so-called "specific" criteria of the populations from the type locality. A recent taxonomical revision of the Cordulegaster of the eastern part of the Western Palearctic using molecular phylogeny and morphological tried to solve the problem (Schneider et al. 2021). They considered Cordulegaster coronata Morton, 1915 (Central Asia) and C. mzymtae Bartenef, 1929 (southern Caucasus and NE Anatolia) as good species and no longer as being part of C. insignis. They further consider C. charpentieri as a good species (southern Caucasus, eastern Turkey and Iran) and proposed C. cilicia as a new species (Anatolia, eastern Turkey and the Levant).  
It is not unlikely that more systematic surveys of southwest Asia might lead to new insights in the taxonomy of the Cordulegaster species present in the area.

Cordulegaster picta is a very variable taxon in colour pattern which shows several morphs. Some populations are very yellow and resemble C. heros or some forms of C. insignis and C. helladica in colour pattern, others are very black and resemble C. bidentata, C. b. boltonii, C. trinacriae or even C. vanbrinkae with respect to their general colour. The black forms seem to be localized in the western Rhodopes mountains between Greece and Bulgaria, in European Turkey and in northern Anatolia. The yellowest forms are known from the Eastern Rhodopes, from some East Aegean islands and from western and southern Anatolia. Intermediate populations are known as well. No subspecific differentiation is possible between these forms, as none show a proper geographic range. Only the examination of the abdominal appendages is needed for a correct identification of this species and all its morphs.

There is some debate over whether Somatochlora meridionalis is a valid species or only a subspecies of S. metallica. In this assessment, both taxa will be treated as full species. Some old records dealing with S. metallica in the Balkans may refer to S. meridionalis.
The family name Euphaeidae should be replaced by the name Epallagidae Needham, 1903 in strict application of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature

The Asiatic Gomphus ubadschii Schmidt 1953, considered as a subspecies of G. flavipes for a long time, is now placed at the full species rank. The so-called subspecies Gomphus flavipes sibirica Bartenev, 1909 is not different from the European taxon and has not been validated

Formerly considered as a subspecies of Gomphus flavipes under the invalid homonym Gomphus flavipes lineatus (Bartenef 1929).Until recently this species and its close relative S. flavipes were considered to belong to the genus Gomphus but recent molecular analysis (Ware et al. 2017) confirmed the placement of both species in the predominantly Nearctic genus Stylurus.

Gomphus vulgatissimus is rather similar to G. schneiderii and the latter is sometimes considered as a subspecies of the former, with which it can be easily confused. Both taxa either overlap and hybridize or are connected through clinal variation by intermediate forms, so that the geographic limit between them cannot be traced with certainty. Some intermediates have even been described under G. schneideri helladicus Buchholz, 1954. Due to this complexity, information on distribution in parts of the Balkan Peninsula is unclear and genetic studies will be needed to clarify the situation in this area.

The species (as Lestes parvidens) was previously considered a subspecies of Lestes viridis. 

Both L. viridis and L. parvidens were moved to the genus Chalcolestes Kennedy, 1920, based on genetic analysis (Dumont pers. comm. 2007, Schorr and Paulson 2015).

This species is assessed without any subspecies distinction.
Two subspecies are currently recognized, namely Lestes virens virens (Charpentier, 1825) in the west Mediterranean area, and L. virens vestalis Rambur, 1842 in the rest of Europe. Distribution and identification of both subspecies is not clear. The distinction of these two spp. in their contact zone is sometimes not possible (for example in parts of France). The precise identity of the Anatolian member of L. virens is still unclear.

This species is known under different names, which were, until recently, frequently used. Jödicke (1997) showed that the name Sympecma paedisca has priority over the names annulata, braueri and striata. The latter three names are still sometimes used for subspecies occurring in the southeast of its range. These subspecies are largely based on the reduced dark pattern on the thorax. This character is however merely correlated with the hot climate of Central Asia where specimens become gradually paler over a large area. Due to this it is not possible to distinguish clearly definable subspecies and the subspecies should be considered invalid.
In some literature, this species has been assigned to the genera Platetrum or Ladona (Schmidt 1987) but presently most authors use the Libellula as genus name.

The southwest Asian Libellula pontica was until recently considered to be a subspecies of L. fulva. In some literature, this species has been assigned to the genus Ladona. Here it is assessed as Libellula.

In northern Spain, subspecies ibericum occurs, which requires further taxonomic study. Sympetrum decoloratum, which occurs in Asian Turkey and further east is considered to be a valid species, and not a subspecies of S. vulgatum. In eastern Asia several other subspecies have been described.
The species was formerly considered as a subspecies of O. cecilia. It is regarded now as a good species.

In Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002), the species is named Andrena roscipes Alfken, 1933. The correct name is A. roseipes, not A. roscipes. In the original description the name indeed is spelled A. roscipes, but this was a printer's error. It is obvious, that in choosing the species name Alfken refers to the red colour of the hind legs, thus according to ICZN § 32.5.1 the name A. roseipes is valid.

Although Andrena sagittaria has been considered a subspecies of Andrena sinuatta, for the purposes of the assessment the criteria of Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002) will be followed, regarding it as a species on its own.
The genus has been revised by Grunshaw (1996), who described this species based upon museum material.
Subpopulations of this species from different mountain ranges vary in morphology and need to be re-examined to clarify if they all represent the same species.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
The species was formerly mixed with H. canariensis and H. hohmanni (Dathe 1993).
The species was formerly mixed with H. ater and H. hohmanni (Dathe 1993).
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
This species replaces possibly H. communis at its southern and eastern distribution edges (see Dathe 2000). A taxonomic state of subspecies is discussed.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The species was formerly confused with H. ater and H. canariensis (Dathe 1993).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood.
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
This species belongs to a highly diverse taxonomic group, which is not yet fully understood. It is probably a local variant only and is closely related to Hylaeus hyalinatus.
The taxon is a member of the H. nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 1977, 2000).
The taxonomic situation of the species of the Hylaeus conformis group was formerly unclear (Dathe 2006).
The taxonomy of the Hylaeus gibbus group was recently revisited (Straka and Bogusch 2011). A series of problems occurred and the first suggestions to solve them were given.
The taxon is a member of the Hylaeus nivalis group (Dathe 2000).
The taxon was originally described as a local subspecies, but this does not fit to its distribution pattern.
The genus Tomogonus d’Orbigny 1904 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where it currently comprises three valid species (ScarabNet 2009).
The genus Tomogonus d’Orbigny 1904 is restricted to the Afrotropical region where it currently comprises three valid species (ScarabNet 2009).

The genus Proagoderus van Lansberge 1883 shows a wide biogeographical distribution across the Afrotropical and Oriental regions and is currently represented by 107 species in the Afrotropical region. These are divided into nine species groups (Palestrini 1992). The taxonomy of the P. brucei complex has been recently revised. It is now represented by three subspecies, P. brucei brucei (Reiche 1849), P. brucei cyanostolus (d’Orbigny 1902), and the recently described P. brucei njombeensis Moretto 2004. Of several other species names formerly placed in synonymy with P. brucei, two have been reinstated as valid species, P. chalcostolus (d’Orbigny 1902) and P. cyanopterus (d’Orbigny 1904). Two further species in the complex have also been described in recent years, P. werneri Moretto & Nicolas 2002 and P. freyi Moretto 2004.
Only the males of this species have been observed and described. Further research needs to conducted to describe the females of this species.
Warncke (1977) considered Dioxys atlanticus as a subspecies of Dioxys cinctus (Jurine, 1807).
The species was described from a single specimen, a male, collected in 1987 (Tkalců 2001).

Pseudoanthidium canariense is a species belonging to the subgenus Pseudoanthidium Friese, 1898 (Warncke 1980, Michener 2007, Ascher and Pickering 2012).


Warncke (1980) stated that Pseudoanthidium canariense should be the subspecies Anthidium lituratum canariense.
This species was described as a subspecies of S. phaeoptera (Kirby, 1802). Warncke (1992) still thought it was a synonym of the former. It belongs to the nominate subgenus.

The taxonomic status of Ammobates handlirschi (Friese, 1895), a close north African relative to A. dusmeti, needs to be confirmed by more comprehensive study, especially by methods of population biology based on DNA.

The taxonomic status of Ammobatoides okalii is uncertain (J. Straka pers. obs. 2013). This species was described from a single specimen and it was never found again. This problematic species needs to be studied in the future and its validity resolved.
Once treated as a subspecies of Eucera vidua, which lives in the north-west Mediterranean part of Africa (J. Ortiz pers. comm. 2013).
The Sphecodes species from the Canary Islands are very poorly known and their taxonomy is likely to be changed in future studies (P. Bogusch pers. comm. 2013).
Only females have been discovered and described, further surveys are required to catch the male of the species.
Osmia tenuispina in Stanek (1964) and Hoplitis tenuispina in Tkalcu (1977c, 2000a) are misidentifications of Hoplitis mazzuccoi (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002), see Schwarz et al. (2005).

At least four species of the subgenus Thoracobombus from Central and South America have many individuals for which the pubescence is almost entirely black. The genitalia of the males are quite distinctive, but association of the conspecific females with these males has caused problems (Williams 1998).

The single known female of B. abditus was described as originating from 'Rep. de Guinée Beyla' (equatorial Africa). However, it is indistinguishable from B. brevivillus according to Sakagami (1976:427) and probably represents an introduced or mislabelled individual (Michener 1979, Williams 1998). This specimen was also examined by P.H. Williams (pers. comm. 2016), and his assessment agreed with that of Sakagmai

Bombus butteli is closely similar to B. ecuadoris. They have been considered separated species (e.g., Franklin 1913, Milliron 1973b) although Franklin conceded that B. butteli might be ´only a variety of subspecies´ of B. ecuadorius. However, B. ecuadorius females are very rare in collections and only five specimens are known. Of these only one was a male, and is labelled 'Bolivia/?Peru', whereas the rest of Milliron's B. ecuadorius are from Ecuador, with the exception of one queen from 'Peru' with no specific locality data. This putative male also differs from the females in having yellow hairs intermixed on the front and rear of the thorax, what was not mentioned in the original description of this male (under the name B. nigrothoracicus) by Friese (1904), which Franklin (1923) then used as the sole basis for associating the male with B. ecuadorius. Another possible interpretation views the male holotype of B. nigrothoracicus instead as a semi melanic male of B. melaleucus, which might explain the difference in colour pattern and distribution from other B. ecuadorius. However, a consequence of this interpretation would be that the only remaining known difference between B. ecuadorius and B. butteli would be in colour pattern, because the main morphological justification for regarding them as a separate species (the broader apical process of the gonostylus of the putative male B. ecuadorius, now B. melaleucus in the broad sense) would have been removed. Further evidence is awaited (Paul Williams http://www.nhm.ac.uk/NHMUK 2013).

This species is currently in revision. As of now, it is recognized as Bombus ephippiatus with a distribution from Northwest Mexico to Panama (Abrahamovich et al. 2004, Labougle 1990). The currently recognized Bombus ephippiatus and its sister species Bombus wilmattae are in the process of being described as 4 separate species (Duennes et al. 2012). One species ranges from Chihuahua to southern Veracruz and Oaxaca in Mexico. Two species are sympatric from Chiapas, Mexico through northern Nicaragua. One of the species from Chiapas, Mexico through northern Nicaragua includes B. wilmattae; unpublished research by Duennes et al. has demonstrated that B. wilmattae is a colour variant of a species within B. ephippiatus sensu lato. Because of this, B. wilmattae is included in this assessment of B. ephippiatus. The fourth species occurs in Costa Rica and Panama.

This species is synonymous with B. californicus, based on the lack of differentiation in DNA barcodes between individuals with this color pattern and those with the B. fervidus s. str. color pattern (Williams et al. 2014).
Bombus robustus and B. hortulatus have been considered both as conspecific (e.g., Franklin 1913, Frison 1925a) and as separate species (e.g. Milliron 1973b, Asperen de Boer 2007).

Williams (1998) and Williams et al. (2014) consider that Bombus intrudens, B. variabilis, B. sololensis, B. guatemalensis, and B. mysticus might all be parts of one species based on morphological evidence, noting the lack of any documented reason (other than differences in colour pattern) why these five taxa should not be considered conspecific. Further study is hampered by a lack of fresh material of North American B. variabilis for analysis of genetic relationships. Although B. intrudens is the oldest available name for this species, the name B. variabilis has been in common use for the species since 1950, and it could be argued that the latter name be used in the interest of stability (Williams 1998).

Several of these nominal taxa placed in synonymy have been treated as separate species. Bombus volucelloides is closely similar to B. melaleucus, but has been considered to be a separate species (e.g. Milliron 1973b, Asperen de Boer 2007). There is very little material available of the males in this group from South America, but the males of B. vogti are distinctly different in the morphology of the genitalia. B. nigrothoracicus seems more likely to be conspecific with B. vogti than with B. ecuadoris. Thus B. melaleucus is interpreted here in a broad sense, to include such variation that is not yet well understood. While awaiting more evidence from critical studies of patters of variation, they are treated initially as parts of a single variable species.For this species, the oldest available known name is B. melaleucus, which becomes the valid name. The name volucelloides has been in most common use for just a part of this species. However, it seems premature to conserve B. volucelloides by suppressing B. melaleucus until the taxa are better understood, because the name B. melaleucus might yet be required for a separate species (http://www.nhm.ac.uk/bombus, Williams 2013).
Williams 1998 and Cameron et al. 2007 upheld the species status as unique.

Williams (2014) provides a detailed review of the taxonomic status of this species. In short, a number of authors have regarded this species as conspecific with B. auricomus, while other authors have treated them as separate. Williams (2014) and Williams et al. (2014) considers them separate based on morphological and colour patterns (Williams 1998), allozymes (Scholl et al. 1992), and DNA sequence data (Cameron et al. 2007, and more recent unpublished work).

Recent DNA barcodes support that Bombus sonorus is conspecific with B. pensylvanicus (Williams et al. 2014). A population from the south of Mexico (state of Chiapas) is morphologically and genetically distinct from the rest of North America, and could be a separate undescribed species. Further sampling is needed to clarify the situation.

Bombus pullatus Franklin was first described by Franklin (1913). Bombus niger is a synonym for this species, however Williams (1998) stated that the lectotype of B. niger is conspecific with B. pullatus (as suggested by Labougle, 1990, see also Milliron, 1962, Williams/NHMUK 2013).
Cross mis-identifications with B. atratus Franklin (1913) are common in many collections, and molecular analyses are required to separate clearly the two species.

Bombus robustus is closely similar in morphology to B. vogti, but has been considered a separate species (e.g., Milliron 1973b, Asperen de Boear 2007). Bombus vogti and B. robustus are usually separated using colour. Although B. rosbustus is variable in colour, the name is applied to individuals with extensive yellow bands, whereas the name B. vogti is used for individuals that lack yellow bands and are often most completely black. There is still very little material available about males of these species, although there are slight differences in the morphology of the genitalia. While awaiting more evidence from critical studies of patterns of variation, these species are treated separately (http://www.nhm.ac.uk/bombus, Williams 2013).

Bombus funebris and B. rohweri have been regarded both as conspecific (Milliron 1962) and as separate species (Frison 1925a, Asperen de Boer 1993a, Williams 1998). They have been distinguished with reference to subtle morphological characters as well as to the consistently and strongly differing color patterns. Both Asperen de Boer (1993a) and G. Chavarría (pers comm.) found that they co-occur at some localities without intermediate colour patterns. Further evidence is awaited (http://www.nhm.ac.uk/bombus, Williams 2013).

This specimen was collected at least 180 years ago and possibly more than 200 years ago. Given the high level of survey effort applied to bumblebees in general and the knowledge that there is only one other bumble bee species (among ca. 250 species) known from a single specimen, it seems reasonable to infer from available information that B. rubriventris is likely to be extinct. However, the location of the type locality remains uncertain. Although there is no reason to challenge the original description placing the type locality in Brazil, there are reasons to doubt whether a label“St. Domingue.” (interpreted by later authors as placing the type locality either in Goiás or in the Dominican Republic) originally belonged to the specimen. Indirect evidence from morphology and from the historical biogeography of bumble bees supports a South American type locality, with the Brazilian Atlantic Forest as a likely candidate (Williams 2014).

The orthography of Olivier (1789) and Fabricius (1798) employs a long 's' (similar to 'f' or 'f'), a common practice of the period. This convention has since changed and recent authors have consistently used 's'. (Williams 1998).

Bombus trinominatus was recorded in Mexico, but some years later this species was recorded in Guatemala as well. There is doubt as to whether both are the same species, since there are some slight differences in morphological characteristics and colour pattern, and further evidence is needed. The name of the other potential species would be Bombus xelajuensis, but for now they are considered synonyms (Natural History Museum 2013).

Bombus vogti is closely similar in morphology to B. robustus, but has been considered to be a separate species (e.g., Milliron 1973b, Asperen de Boear 2007). Bombus vogti and B. robustus are usually separated using colour. Although B. robustus is variable in colour, the name is applied to individuals with extensive yellow bands, whereas the name B. vogti is used for individuals that lack yellow bands and are often most completely black. There is still very little material available of the males, but the males of B. vogti are most only subtly different in the morphology of the genitalia. While awaiting more evidence from critical studies of patters of variation, it is treated as a separate species (http://www.nhm.ac.uk/bombus, Williams 2013).

Taxonomic issues regarding the position of Andrena fimbriata within the Andrena labialis group are treated by Schönitzer et al. (1995).

Warncke (1967) examined the type of this species. Most previous records belong to A. forsterella, A. variabilis or other species of the subgenus Holandrena.

While Warncke considers Andrena fulvata as a subspecies of A. angustior, Andrena angustior fulvata Stöckhert, 1930, almost all the other authors after him recognize Andrena fulvata as a distinct species (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014), and this will be the criteria applied for the purposes of this assessment.

Since Pascoe’s 1877 description, Hadramphus tuberculatus has been included in three genera and is synonymous with two names in the literature. Pascoe originally placed Hadramphus tuberculatus in the genus Lyperobius (Pascoe 1877), but in Kuschel’s 1971 revision the species was moved to Hadramphus Broun (Kuschel 1971). Kuschel later erected the genus Karocolens to include the type species K.  pittospori (a Molytine weevil from the Poor Knights Islands, NZ) (Kuschel 1987).  In 1999 however, Craw re-instated Karocolens  pittospori within Hadramphus (Craw 1999) and Karocolens is now synonymised with Hadramphus.

Originally described as a full species, this taxon was downgraded to a subspecies of L. riparia by Kirby (1904). The taxon was reinstated as a valid species by Brindle (1970) and synonymised with L. loveridgei Zeuner, 1962 which had been described from subfossil forceps.

This species was originally described as Campsicnemus mirabilis. However, C. mirabilis (Grimshaw, 1902) takes precedence of this name. Dyte (1980), therefore provided an alternative name for this concept, which is C. atlanticus.
This species was previously listed incorrectly as Tasmanophlebia lacus-coerulei, instead of Tasmanophlebi lacuscoerulei.

This taxon was considered until recently as a synonym of Habropoda tarsata (e.g., Friese 1896, Brooks 1988). It has been revised as a valid species only very recently by Schwarz and Gusenleitner (2001).

The genus Cyptochirus Lesne, 1900 was recently revalidated from synonymy with Drepanocerus. It is currently considered to comprise four closely related Afrotropical species (ScarabNet 2009). However, there may be some confusion in the taxonomy of these described taxa.
The genus Epirinus currently comprises 29 species (ScarabNet 2009) with a combined distribution restricted primarily to the coolest climates of South Africa.
The genus Heteronitis Gillet 1911 is restricted to the savannas of Africa where it currently comprises five valid species (ScarabNet 2009).

Megalonitis Janssens 1937 is a fairly distinctive, very large-bodied genus that is restricted to southern Africa. Although two species have been described (ScarabNet 2009), it is possible that M. bohemani is a junior synonym of M. gigas (Bertolini 1855). This needs to be determined by comparison of the type and other museum material.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 17, which has radiated throughout the savannas of inter-tropical Africa and is taxonomically difficult. Although O. tanzaniensis currently has taxonomic validity, this assessor considers it to be a synonym of O. proximus Ferreira 1977, which is the preceding species (pp 192-195) in the same publication in which O. tanzaniensis was described. In this 1977 publication, the type locality of O. proximus was described as Amboseli N.P. [National Park] (14 kms W of Ol Tukai). However, in a review of the genus in 1978, the type locality was erroneously cited as Marsabit (also in Kenya).

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to Onitis Group 18, which is widespread throughout lowland to upland drier savannas of the Afrotropical region on both deep sands and finer-grained soils.

The genus Sarophorus Erichson 1847 currently comprises nine species with a distribution in the southeast and southwest of Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species belongs to a group of four species restricted to South Africa, three of them centred within the area influenced by winter rainfall.
The status of this taxon remains unclear.
Westrich (1993) does not provide a subgenus for this species, but indicates that it is close to A. scopippes, a north African species, in the subgenus Pyganthophora.
<span lang="EN-US">The taxonomic status of this species remains confusing. Westrich (1993) did not assign the species to any known subgenus.

This species belongs to the group of rogenhoferi species group, where the species relationships are not yet clarified. However, within this group, A. sichelii is the only one that shows a golden to reddish colour pattern instead of a grey one, making it a species that is easy to identify.
The status of this species is still unclear. It belongs to the A. persica group, whose species relationships remain unsettled.
The status of this species is unclear. It could be a synonym of either A. affinis or A. mucida.

The genus Onitis Fabricius 1798 is widespread in the Afrotropical, Oriental and Palaearctic regions. It is divided into 20 species groups of which 13 groups and 130 species are represented in Africa (ScarabNet 2009). This species is in Onitis Group 12 that comprises only two species. O. parainflaticollis was only described in 1977, possibly due to its rarity.

The genus Sisyphus Latreille is biogeographically widespread across the Afrotropical, Palaearctic and Oriental regions with a restricted occurrence in the Central American part of the Neotropical region. It is currently represented by 18 species in the Afrotropical region but is in urgent need of revision. S. ocellatus is held to be represented by two subspecies by some sources, S. ocellatus ocellatus (Reiche 1847) and S. ocellatus nanniscus (Péringuey 1901). However, an unpublished revision of the southern African species indicates that S. nanniscus is, in fact, a synonym of S. seminulum Gerstaecker, a species that is currently erroneously classified as a synonym of S. costatus Thunberg 1818.
One of a group of very closely related sibling species including A. barbareae, A. cineraria and A. danuvia. The taxonomic status of these taxa is uncertain.

In the original description Selys (1887) placed this taxon as a 'race' (= subspecies) of his P. praetextatum Selys, 1876 which is a synonym of Agrion kersteni Gerstäcker, 1969 (Ris and Schmidt 1936). In fact, it is closely related to the latter species but deserves full specific status (Dumont 1974; Schneider 1986, 1987).

Marinov and Seidenbusch (2007) place this taxon in a new monotypic genus, Corduliochlora. We refrain from using Corduliochlora as long as no overall phylogenetic study of the Corduliidae has been undertaken.

Both Lestes viridis and L. parvidens were moved to the genus Chalcolestes Kennedy, 1920, based on genetic analysis (Dumont pers. comm. 2007, Schorr and Paulson 2015).

Until ten years ago Chalcolestes parvidens was considered a subspecies of Chalcolestes viridis, but there is now a wide consensus that they should be considered separate species.

Canthonella was described by Chapin in 1930. Halffter and Martínez (1977) synonymized Ipselissus under Canthonella. There are currently very few species described from South America, but there are likely to be many more to be described.
There are no taxonomic problems known at present.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds and Zidek (2012). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.). Subspecies lydiae is considered by Edmonds and Zidek (2012) to be a colour variant of the species.

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds (1994). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.).

Phanaeus pyrois in particular, has two different morpho-types. According to Arnauld (2002), these morpho-types correspond to two subspecies (P. pyrois malyi Arnauld and P. pyrois olsoufieffi Balthasar). However, this assessment is based on the Phanaeus pyrois, combining the subspecies information.

Scatonomus is a small genus, containing only eight described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. The genus is known from Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, and its species are distributed throughout “Cerrado”, “Pampa” and Atlantic forest.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa. This assessment is based on the two subspecies Sulcophanaeus miyashitai miyashitai and Sulcophanaeus miyashitai metallescens.

Andrena fulica Warncke, 1974 is considered here a subspecies of Andrena astrella, Andrena astrella ssp. fulica Warncke, 1974, following Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002).

The taxonomic review of Wood et al. (2020) found that the taxon Andrena astrella Warncke 1975 is a junior synonym of Andrena fulica Warncke 1974.

Andrena nitidula and A. distinguenda have been considered as one species for a long time. The observation of A. nitidula and A. distinguenda in the same locality was the cause for clarifying the unclear taxonomic status of these two taxa. The examination of material of the A. distinguenda group occurring in Europe and north Africa revealed that A. distinguenda and A. nitidula are two good species. A. distinguenda turned out to occur in south eastern Europe whereas A. nitidula has a western distribution. The distribution areas of the two species broadly overlap along the Mediterranean coast from Spain to Italy and from the Provence around the Alps to southern Germany.
The summer generation could possibly be a distinct species (Westrich 1990).
This is a valid species, and was described in a peer-reviewed journal publication (Taylor and Moir 2009).
The species was described in the genus Rhophitoides but it was later moved to Rophites. Review by Pesenko and Astafurova (2006) resulted in epiroticus being moved back to Rhophitoides.
There are four subspecies: ssp. viride (Brullé, 1839); ssp. cabrerai (Warncke, 1975); ssp. palmae Ebmer, 1993; and ssp. unicolor (Brullé, 1840).
The species is closely related to Lasioglossum minutulum.
The subspecies Lasioglossum bavaricum olympicum (Warncke, 1982) is found in the mountains of Greece. The nominal subspecies is found throughout the rest of it's distribution.

There are three subspecies on the Canary Islands: L. a. glandarium (Warncke, 1975) is found on El Hierro and La Palma; L. a. optatum is found on Gran Canaria (Warncke, 1975); and the nominal subspecies is found on Tenerife.

This assessment includes the Canarian subspecies Andrena chalcogastra gomera Warncke, 1968 (from La Gomera), Andrena chalcogastra palmaensis Warncke, 1968 (from La Palma), Andrena chalcogastra extrema Warncke, 1993 (from Gran Canaria), and Andrena chalcogastra chalcogastra Brullé, 1839 (from Tenerife).

Dylewska (1987) and Schmid-Egger and Scheuchl (1997) accept A. pauxilla as a distinct species. Besides, H. Schwenninger (pers. comm. 2014) examined the type of A. curtula and stated that A. curtula and A. pauxilla are clearly distinct species.
According to Blank and Kraus (1994), the type specimens of Andrena (Chlorandrena) damara are labelled Andrena sagittaria ssp. damara.
The subgeneric attribution of Andrena ebmerella is uncertain.
This species was originally described by Warncke as Andrena abrupta ssp. elata Warncke, 1975.

Warncke described this taxon using the name Andrena truncatilabris ssp. española. The usage of diacritic marks is forbidden by Article 27 ICZN, 1985. The name has had to be corrected to espanola. Following Warncke and Gusenleitner, Ortiz-Sanchez (2011) regards Andrena (Truncandrena) espanola as a subspecies of Andrena (Truncandrena) truncatilabris Morawitz, 1877. While the disparities between A. truncatilabris and A. espanola females are minimal, the differences between the male genitalia, especially the penis valves, are so different that both taxa are considered different species by E. Scheuchl (pers. comm. 2014), and this will be the criteria followed for the purposes of this assessment.
Andrena (Cnemidandrena) freygessneri was first considered as subspecies of Andrena simillima Smith, 1851, but it is clearly a distinct species according to Ebmer (2001).

There are taxonomic uncertainties regarding the status of this taxon and A. boyerella (qv). Both A. leucolippa and A. boyerella are regarded as a valid names by Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002). However, in the maps provided by Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002), A. boyerella and A. leucolippa appear together in the same map since A. leucolippa was regarded as a subspecies by Warncke. After further examination, it seems that A. leucolippa occurs in Europe and A. boyerella occurs in North Africa (and the records from Sicily and Italy probably belong to it as well) (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).

While A. maderensis fratella Warncke, 1968 was described from Morocco, it seems that A. maderensis is endemic to the main island of Madeira and A. fratella is a distinct species (E. Scheuchl pers. comm. 2014).

The two subspecies Andrena montarca andina Warncke, 1974, and Andrena montarca parva Warncke, 1974 are certainly distinct species (Gusenleitner and Schwarz 2002). A. montarca is an Iberian endemic species, while A. parva and A. andina are north African species.

This species appears to have two subspecies, but the assessment is made at the species level. Additional taxonomic studies might reveal that this taxon is two different species or only two races of one species.

There are three different subspecies that occur in different countries: D. angustissimus angustissimus is found in Turkey, D. angustissimus liviae is found in Rhodes (Greece), and D. angustissimus troodi is found in Cyprus and Lebanon (Löbl and Smetana 2010).
Also known as Aleurostictus decempunctatus.

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
There has been some confusion on whether A. corsicus and A. quercicola are the same species. According to Platia (1994) A. corsicus is a valid species and it is endemic to Corsica.

The species status for this species is doubtful. It seems to be published only in the original description by Pic 1930 and in the old italian fauna of Porta. Is a taxon name valid for Fauna Europaea. However the taxon is not included in any of the recent taxonomic reviews.

Dolin (1988) considers this species as A. apicalis Reitter, 1889. This species was at first described as Elater pulcher v. apicalis. Then quoted as E. pulcher Baudi (Gurieva, 1957); E. pulcher v. apicalis (Yacobson, 1913); E. pulcher Baudi (Pliginskii, 1916). According to Lobl and Smetana (2007) there are two separate species: Ampedus pulcher (occurs in Cyprus, Turkey) and A. apicalis (occurs in in Ukraine, Greece).

More research is needed on the taxonomy.
Two subspecies are known: Callimenus macrogaster macrogaster and C. m. longicollis, defined on mostly subtle differences in the female subgenital plate.
Two subspecies occur in the Mediterranean: P. desfontainii ssp., in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and Crete (Greece) and P. d. inhumeralis in Greece, Turkey, Jordan, Israel and Syria.
Described in 1993 as one of four species identified within a species complex (with P. budensis, P. caucasicus and other). Delimitation and distributional ranges are not yet clear.
This species might be a complex of several hitherto undescribed species (P. Fontana, pers. comm. 2015).

Bombus ashtoni Cresson, 1864 from North America was previously considered to be a species separate from B. bohemicus, but Cameron et al. (2007) suggested it may be conspecific and this was supported by Williams et al. (2014).

Evidence from a global study of DNA barcodes supports the North American population as part of a species widespread in Europe and Asia (Williams et al. 2012, 2014).

Bombus cryptarum is difficult to identify and has been generally accepted as a valid species only recently. This explains why it has been explicitly dealt with in rather few articles (Rasmont et al. 2014).

This species has only recently been discvoered in North America (Williams & Thomas 2005, Sheffield and Williams 2011). Populations in different parts of the range show especially strong genetic differentiation in COI barcodes (Williams et al. 2011).

Morphological and genetic evidence support a close relationship between B. fernaldae from North America and B. flavidus from Europe and Asia (Cameron et al. 2007, Williams et al. 2014). As such, Williams et al. (2014) treat them as conspecific. Rasmont (1988) reports that the Pyrenean population of B. flavidus in the Spain-France region is morphometrically distinct from the disjunct Scandinavian population; nevertheless, he continues to treat them as conspecific, as does Williams (2014).

This species has been separated from Bombus pyrrhopygus as evidenced by gene coalescents by Williams et al. (2015). Bombus pyrrhopygus is restricted to the European and Asian continents, and Bombus polaris is restricted to North America and Greenland.
Previously considered conspecific with B. nevadensis, this species is now considered separate (Williams et al. 2014).

This taxon as usually understood is now interpreted as a composite of two cryptic species with overlapping distributions (Williams et al. 2015). Clarification of the situation is currently under investigation and should be available by the end of 2016.

DNA evidence (divergence in COI-barcode sequences) supports Bombus occidentalis as a valid species, separate from B. terricola (Williams et al. 2012). COI-barcode divergence also suggests that B. occidentalis can be divided into northern (including Alaska, Yukon Territory, and northern British Columbia) and southern (including the western contiguous United States and southern British Columbia) populations, each of which have distinctive haplotype groups (Williams et al. 2012). These distinct haplotypes correspond with morphological differences; specifically, shorter pile (hair) has been noted in the southern populations and longer pile in the northern populations (Williams et al. 2012; Williams et al. 2014). Taxonomic work is in progress to formally distinguish two subspecies of B. occidentalis (C. Sheffield pers. comm. May 2013 in Jepsen and Foltz Jordan 2013).

While there has been some debate over whether this species is conspecific with Bombus occidentalis (e.g. Cameron et al. 2007), recent morphological and molecular work (e.g. Bertsch et al. 2010, Williams et al. 2012, Owen and Whidden 2013) support the separate taxa.

Although the oldest available name for this species is B. pleuralis Nylander, the name B. flavifrons has been in common use for this species since 1950, while only one publication is known to use the name B. pleuralis (Williams et al. 2014, Williams 2014). Thus, for stability, it is suggested that use of name B. flavifrons be continued (Williams et al. 2014). 

DNA barcodes support as part of the same species individuals with metasomal T3-4 red (named flavifrons, from Alaska and British Columbia south to Utah) and those with T3-4 black (named dimidiatus, predominant in California, Oregon, and Washington) (Williams et al. 2014).

Evidence from DNA barcodes supports B. centralis and B. flavifrons as separate species (Williams et al. 2014).

Bombus sylvicola is morphologically closely similar to B. lapponicus, and it has been suggested repeatedly that they are conspecific (reviewed in Williams 2014). Evidence from comparisons of DNA sequences from the 16S gene is not strong, but is consistent with the two taxa being separate species (Cameron et al. 2007). Until more evidence to the contrary is available from critical studies of patterns of variation, these two species should be treated as separate (Williams 1998, Williams 2014, Williams et al. 2014).

Evidence from DNA barcodes supports a close relationship between B. vagans and B. bolsteri, with only minor differences, as what can be considered parts of a single species. The two are considered synonymous by Williams et al. (2014). 

Bombus cockerelli is very similar to B. vagans (particularly in female morphology), but so far it has not been possible to obtain DNA barcodes of B. cockerelli from which to assess whether it is conspecific (Williams et al. 2014). The synonymy is considered possible but unconfirmed.

The extensively yellow female color pattern from Washington and northern Oregon was described in 1970 with the name cascadensis, however, this name is now known to be a junior synonym of B. vandykei (Williams et al. 2014, Williams 2014).

There is what is believed to be a predominantly yellow colour form of this species found near Corvallis and Ashland, Oregon, but so far there have been no molecular assessments of the status of this variation (Williams et al. 2011).
This species is also known as Aleurostictus baborensis (Bedel, 1919) (Tauzin 2004).

= A. algerinus Bedel, 1867.This species is, strangely, not cited in the world catalog of Erotylidae of Chûjô & Chûjô (1989) nor Fauna Europaea. It only appear in the catalog of palaeartic coleoptera (Wegrzynowicz et al. 2007).

The original description is Triplax syriaca Escalera, 1925

The name have been changed by De la Escalera few months after because T. syriaca was preoccupyed by a different species described by Pic in 1908.
Kocher (1956) considered this species as a subspecies of Litargus connexus Geoffroy. This statement was not followed by subsequent authors.
There haven’t been taxonomic changes at least since 1911.
There have not been taxonomic changes at least since 2010.

authority: Bahillo de la Puebla et al., 2003
taxonomicNotes: There have not been taxonomic changes at least since 2003.

Cucujus tulliae is clearly related to the cinnaberinus–haematodes species group, its distribution seems to be restricted to the mountains of Calabrian peninsula.The closest taxon could be C. haematodes, from which it can easily be distinguished by the less prominent postgenae, the arrow head shaped prosternal apophysis, the smaller and less spiny pronotum, the typical median lobe of the aedeagus and the larval morphology, that is apparently unique because of its slender body and occipital furrows (Bonacci et. al. 2012).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain as it might be a synonym of Petaloptila andreinii, which is also present in the same cave.
This species appears to have two different subspecies; C. gratiosus gratiosus (Syria, Lebanon, Israel) and C. gratiosus sparsus (Turkey).
Originally condidered a subspecies of the North African population Poecilium glabratum (Charpentier), but is now considered a seperate species.
Some authors (Bense 1995) treat this species as a subspecies of Semanotus russicus (Fabricius, 1777).
The taxonomic status of this species requires further investigation.
Currently its species status needs revision because often considered as a synonym of Thymalus limbatus (H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
Prionotropis hystrix subsp. rhodanica Uvarov, 1923 was raised to species level by Massa and Ünal (2015).
The subspecies Anonconotus baracunensis occidentalis Carron and Wermeille, 2002 is now considered a valid species (Eames et al. 2015).
Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the relationship of Tessellana lagrecai and Tessellana tessellata.
It was previously described as a subspecies of S. marginatus but it is thought to be a separate species (Bogusch and Straka in prep.).
Revision of material collected in Sardinia, presented by Warncke (1992) showed that the species was mis-identified. Therefore the species does not occur in Sardinia (P. Bogusch pers. comm. 2013).
For taxonomic and nomenclature history of the genus Ahermodontus Báguena, 1930, see Dellacasa et al. (2002).

This is a polytypic species with two subspecies (siculus siculus and siculus buturensis).

This species was described by Clément (1981) on a couple of exemplars (male and female, type locality: “Taza”, Morocco) with weak differential traits of other species of the subgenus Alocoderus, mainly Aphodius (Alocoderus) hydrochaeris (Fabricius, 1798). Baraud (1985) expressed doubts about the validity of the species.

Esymus sesquivittatus is currently placed in the subgenus Volinus Mulsant & Rey, 1870 (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) in the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III.

This species was described as Heptaulacus atlantis Peyerimhoff, 1925 and subsequently transferred to genus Euheptaulacus Dellacasa, 1983 (see Dellacasa 1983, Hollande et al. 1998). Heptaulacus peyerimhoffi was described exclusively on the larva (Paulian and Villiers 1939) and two years later Paulian and Villiers (1941) described the adult.
This species was described as Heptaulacus nemethi Théry, 1925 and subsequently transferred to genus Euheptaulacus Dellacasa, 1983 (see Dellacasa 1983, 1998).

This species was described as Paracoptochirus dellacasai Petrovitz, 1970. Branco and Baraud (1988) transferred it to their new genus Osmanius (type-species: Paracoptochirus balthasari Petrovitz, 1963; see Branco and Baraud 1988, Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006).

The status of the taxon is not yet well defined as sometimes it has been recorded as a subspecies of Bodiloides ictericus (Laicharting, 1781). A thorough study of both taxa from the whole distribution area is needed to define the correct taxonomic level.

Recently, Dellacasa and Dellacasa (2008), has elevated Chelotrupes to the genus rank. Moreover they propose Typhaeus matutinalis (first considered as synonymous of hiostius) as a valid species. Given that both proposed taxa occurs in sympatry in the majority of their ranges and that genus Chelotrupes have high morphological variability (Verdú pers. obs.), on a precautionary basis and pending further molecular analysis that verify such status, Typhaeus will be considered as genus and T. matutinalis as a synonym of T. hiostius in this assessment.
The taxonomy of this species is well known (Zunino 1973, 1984; Löbl and Smetana 2006; Ziani et al. 2006)
The genus group name Stereopyge was established for Geotrupes douei. Some authors consider Stereopyge at generic rank and others at subgeneric rank.
The taxonomy of this species is well known (Löbl and Smetana 2006, Nikolajev 2003).

After Hiller et al. (2012) this species could belong to different species or subspecies. However, it is necessary a revision based on molecular data to verify the taxonomic status of all subpopulations.
After Martín-Piera and López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to the genus Jekelius López-Colón, 1989. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
