The taxonomy of this species is well known (López-Colón 2000).

After Martín-Piera and López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to the genus Silphotrupes Jekel, 1866. However, it is necessary to have a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status. After Verdú and Galante (2000) this species have two well defined subspecies: T. (S.) escorialensis and T. (S.) petrovitzi.

The taxonomy and phylogeny of this species is well known (López-Colón, 1989, 1996, 2000; Löbl & Smetana, 2006; Palmer M. & Cambefort Y. 1997; Zunino M., 1984; Angus, 2011). However, López-Colón (1989) on the basis of a comparative analysis of males genital characters, inserted this species within the new subgenus Silphotrupes. In the 1996, the same author (López-Colón, 1996) creates the new genus Baraudia specifically for this species, which was called Baraudia geminata. In conservative terms, since there is no agreement (Branco & Ziani, 2006; 2007; López-Colón & Alonso-Zarazaga, 2006) on the new classification proposed by López-Colón (1989; 1996), we decided to follow the traditional approach that ascribes the species to the genus Thorectes.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.

The taxonomy and phylogeny of this species is well known (Muller 1938; Zunino 1984; Löbl and Smetana 2006; Baraud, 1965, 1966a, 1966b; Lopez-Colon 1988, 1989, 1992, 1996; Palmer and Cambefort 1997). However, López-Colón (1989) on the basis of a comparative analysis of males genital characters, inserted this species within the newly-designated subgenus Jekelius. The same author (López-Colón 1996), raised Jekelius to the genus rank and named this species as Jekelius (Jekelius) intermedius. In conservative terms, since there is no agreement (Branco and Ziani 2006, 2007; López-Colón and Alonso-Zarazaga 2006) on the new classification proposed by López-Colón (1989, 1996), we decided to follow the traditional approach that ascribes the species to the genus Thorectes.

Thorectes intermedius has been interpreted in different ways, so several records could be erroneous.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
In general the taxonomy is well known (Baraud 1985). However, the possible existence of several subspecies or species is at present under revision using molecular data (Lobo et al. pers. comm.).

The taxonomy of this species is well known and studied (Löbl and Smetana 2006; Zunino 1984; Baraud, 1965, 1966, 1985, 1992; Palmer and Cambefort 1997). However, López-Colón (1989) on the basis of a comparative analysis of males genital characters, inserted this species within the newly-designated subgenus Jekelius. The same author (López-Colón 1996), raised Jekelius to the genus rank and creates, for marginatus, the subgenus Petrovitzia. However, being the subgenus Petrovitzia preoccupied by an Asian Cetoniinae, Rey and López-Colón (2003) brought the “nomen novum” Rudolfpetrovitzia in place of preoccupied Petrovitzia. In conservative terms, since there is no agreement (Branco and Ziani 2006, 2007; López-Colón and Alonso-Zarazaga 2006) on the new classification proposed by López-Colón (1989, 1996), we decided to follow the traditional approach that ascribes the species to the genus Thorectes.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.

This species could belong to the genus Silphotrupes Jekel, 1866. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status. For its correct identification see Verdú and Galante (2000).
After Martín-Piera and López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to the genus Silphotrupes Jekel, 1866. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.
After Martín-Piera & López-Colón (2000) this species could belong to Jekelius López-Colón 1989 genus. However, it is necessary a new revision based on molecular data to verify this status.

The taxonomy and phylogeny of this species are well known (Baraud 1966, Löbl and Smetana 2006, Palmer and Cambefort 1997, Zunino, 1984). However, López-Colón (1989) on the basis of a comparative analysis of males genital characters, inserted this species within the subgenus Jekelius. The same author (López-Colón, 1996), raised Jekelius to the genus rank and named this species as Jekelius (Jekelius) sardous. In conservative terms, since there is no agreement (Branco and Ziani 2006, 2007; López-Colón and Alonso-Zarazaga 2006) on the new classification proposed by López-Colón (1989, 1996), we decided to follow the traditional approach that ascribes the species to the genus Thorectes.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear and is currently under revision. Using molecular tools, several entities of uncertain status (incertae sedis) were highlighted (Lobo pers. comm. 2014)
Previously considered as a subspecies of B. bubalus (Oliv). It was separated from B. bubalus by Janssens in 1938.
Bubas bubaloides (Janssens 1938) was previously considered a subspecies of Bubas bubalus (Olivier 1811).
This is a vicariant species of C. lunaris in the Maghreb region.
Zunino (1971) established the synonymy of E. tissoni with E. hannas (Sahlberg 1908).

One specimen, designed by Zunino (1976) as a paralectotype male of O. furciceps Marseul, 1869 (in Marseul collection MHNH) from the Bekaa valley, Lebanon, is actually a specimen of O.bytinskii (Ziani and Gudenzi 2006).
Onthophagus circulator is, according to Zunino (1978), nomen inquirendum (Reitter 1891, Ziani and Gudenzi 2001).

This species belongs to the ovatus group and this group of species is characterised by similar external morphology. Only the study of laminae of the internal sac of the aedeagus enables the identification of the species. Thus, many old records from the species from the ovatus group could be attributed to the species O. dellacasai.

Martin-Piera and Zunino (1986) incorrectly synonymized O. hermonensis with O. ruficapillus Brullé, 1832. Pittino (2004) agreed with Ziani and Gudenzi (2001) who considered O. hermonensis as a valid and separate species.

This species belongs to the ovatus group and this group of species is characterized by similar external morphology. Only the study of laminae of the internal sac of the aedeagus enables the identification of the species.

Falahee and Angus (2010), using a chromosomal approach, considered O. massai as a valid species and not a synonym of O. fracticornis. Pizzo et al. (2011), using a combination of geometric morphometric and genetic approaches, argued that there was not sufficient evidence to vindicate the species status for O. massai, which should more likely be considered a small-sized form of O. fracticornis.

Onthophagus opacicollis and O. similis are considered close species. The genetic distances between O. opacicollis and O. similis populations as a function of the biogeographic scenery (allopatry vs. sympatry) indicate that these taxa are not completely reproductively isolated across their entire geographic range, thus suggesting a still unfinished speciation process in sympatric areas and a fully realised speciation by means of ecological segregation in allopatry (Pizzo et al. 2013). In Spain, both the existence of some gene flow between O. opacicollis and O. similis in one place (El Barraco, Central Spain) and isolation in others (Sierra Nevada, southeast Spain) was demonstrated. Geographic areas hosting populations of both taxa with intermediate genetic distances (Doñana, southwest Spain) also exist in the Iberian Peninsula (Martín-Piera and Boto 1999). However, a chromosomal analysis showed no evidence of hybridization between O. similis and O. opacicollis where they occur together in central Spain (Angus 2008).

Onthophagus punctatus  (Ill.) was previously confounded with O. emarginatus (Mul.) . The subgenus Parentius was created to include O. punctatus (Ill.) as type species, O. nigellus (Ill.), O. atricapillus d’Orb. and O. punctator Reitt (Zunino 1979). In 1981, O. emarginatus was restored to the status of good species (Branco 1981).

 

In a revision of the Paleartic species of the subgenus Parentius Zunino, 1979, Martín-Piera (1986) recorded Onthophagus (Parentius) punctatus ab. cupreolus Reitter, 1894, as a synonym of O. (Parentius) punctatus.

 

The synonymy between O. cupreolus Reitter, 1894, currently deemed a synonym of Onthophagus (Parentius) punctatus (Illiger,1803), and Onthophagus (Parentius) emarginatus Mulsant, 1842 is established  (Branco, 2003).

Onthophagus strabo Reitter, 1892 was considered as a dubitative junior synonym of O. kindermanni Harold (Gillet and Boucomont, 1927, Winkler 1929, Panin 1957). Pittino (2004) considered O. strabo as a good species, closely allied but distinct from O. kindermanni and O. rodentium.

The species-group name was dedicated to Turk Yilmaz Sürmeli (Petrovitz 1963). According to Bezděk and Hájek (2013), its original spelling ‘sürmelii’ should be corrected to ‘surmelii’ (ICZN 1999: Art. 32.5.2) and not to ‘suermelii’ as applied by Baraud (1992), Kabakov (2006), Martín-Piera and Zunino (1985, 1986), Lobl et al. (2006) and Ziani et al. (2011).
Krell (1990) reintroduced the name Onthophagus (Palaeonthophagus) muelleri Novak, 1921 and placed the replaced name Onthophagus novaki Gillet & Boucomont, 1927 as a synonym.

Matthews (1962) recognized two subspecies: C. k. klugi found in Aguascalientes, Guerrero, Mexico, Michoacan, Morelos, Oaxaca, Puebal, Veracruz, and C. k. sierrensis. However, López-Guerro et al. (2009), conducted a study of the internal genitalic characters of males and females of Copris klugi klugi Harold and Copris klugi sierrensis Matthews, and they decided that C. klugi Harold and C. sierrensis Matthews are two distinct species.
Ammobates melectoides is often understood as a subspecies of A. oraniensis. Taxonomy of this species needs to be studied in detail in the future.

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue to be published in 2015, all the subgenera will be upgraded to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

Ziani pers. comm. 2014). Its specific validity has been recently confirmed by Dellacasa et al. (2002).

The taxonomy between H. aurora and H. duplex is not settled.

This species has previously been confused with H. aurora (W. Mauffray pers. comm. 2014) and was considered to be the same species (Garrison, 1990). Bota-Sierra has collected specimens in Colombia that could prove, after further study, that the two are distinct (C. Bota-Sierra, pers. comm. 2014).
Lozano et al. 2017 has stated that Acanthagrion peruvianum is a subjective synonym of A. floridense. The assessment of A. floridense includes previous records of A. peruvianum
This species should be considered as part of the genus Oxyagrion (Von Ellenrieder) (assessors to provide reference)

The species Acanthagrion cuyabae was considered a junior synonym of A. lancea until 2010 (Souza et al. 2010). A. cuyabae is distributed in northern Amazon region, for this reason, several records from literature recording A. lancea in the northern Amazon were not included, since they probably are A. cuyabae.
Misspelled - should b A. fraudratriculata
This species was though to be synonym of A. cupraurea, but Garrison and von Ellenrieder ( 2017), revealed that it is a distinct species.

The taxonomy of several species of the genus Argia is currently under revision, and Argia rosseri would seem to represent pale violaceous specimens of the more southerly Argia jujuya Ris, 1913, as there are specimens of Argia jujuya from NW Argentina that are intermediate between A. jujuya and A. rosseri (R. Garrison and N. von Ellenrieder pers. comm. 2015).
This species is possibly a synonym of I. indivisa (Bota-Sierra and Tennessen pers. obs October 2014); research is pending.
The validity of this species is under question, and it is quite possibly synonymous with I. chingaza (E. Realpe pers. comms.).
This species is known only from a nymph, which was not fully grown, meaning that is not possible to be sure that this is even a distinct and valid species.
Taxonomic confusion surrounds both this species and L. pallidus, which have both been purported as synonyms of each other. It is also possible that L. apollinaris is the same species as well.
"Micrathyria romani seems to be a distinct species, different from M. coropinae, to which it is related in possessing one row of cells in the discoidal space in the fore wings." Geijskes, 1963.

Hoffman (2009) listed this species in Southern Peru in the Amazon region, this record was considered erroneous since the species is pretty conspicuous when present and it has not been recorded in the Amazon regions of Colombia, Ecuador or Venezuela.
P. cerasina is considered a synonym of P. tenuissima (Garrison, 2004).

In 2011, von Ellenrieder stated that "Based on observed morphological variability of the diagnostic characters traditionally used to identify species of Microstigma, the three specific names currently used might represent only intraspecific variability", thus Microstigma species may all be M. anomalum synonym.
Peters and Theischinger (2011) proposed reinstating the species status of Aeschna ellioti usambarica and placing the species in the genus Zosteraeschna.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is considered as a subspecies of M. parietina by some authors (e.g., Benoist 1940).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. This species is possibly a junior synonym of M. pyrenaica (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimens (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).

It is not clear if it is a distinct species from M. hungarica (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
It is unclear if it is distinct from H. albonotata (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The specific status of the species is considered doubtful, it may be a subspecies of P. pylaon.
The taxon was first described as Agriades coridon race caelestissima by Verity (1921).
Some authors consider this species should be split in P. dolus (France and NW Italy) and P. virgilia (Central Italy). For this Red List we follow Vila et al. (2010).
Due to the recent split of T. taygetica and T. endymion the knowledge on the distribution of each species is limited to the specimens which have so far been examined (Coutsis 2005).
Real´s Wood White has recently been separated from the Wood White (L. sinapis). However, in the field the species cannot be distinguished from each other.
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear.

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. For long it was considered a subspecies of E. variegatus but recently it has been elevated to a separate species. However, its true taxonomic status is in need of revision.

Trithemis morrisoni and T. palustris were discovered in the course of a population genetic study of the common and widespread T. stictica. Trithemis parasticta, currently considered as synonym to T. stictica, might also a valid species. All of these species are difficult to identify in the field or on morphological characteristics.

Trithemis morrisoni and T. palustris were discovered in the course of a population genetic study of the common and widespread T. stictica. Trithemis parasticta, currently considered as synonym to T. stictica, might also a valid species. All of these species are difficult to identify in the field or on morphological characteristics.
Originally described as belonging to the genus Poecilium Fairmaire 1864 (Sama and Rapuzzi 1999), however currently belongs to Phymatodes Mulsant, 1839 (Sama and Löbl 2010).

Formerly Acisoma panorpoides was thought to occur in Africa, Madagascar and Asia. Recent taxonomic and genetic studies showed, that in Asia the true A. panorpoides occurs, while two different species each occur in Madagascar and continental Africa. The latter are separated in A. variegatum and in A. inflatum, both of them being described long ago and neglected since (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer 2014).

Formerly Acisoma panorpoides was thought to occur in Africa, Madagascar and Asia. Recent taxonomic and genetic studies showed, that in Asia the true A. panorpoides occurs, while two different species each occur in Madagascar and continental Africa. The latter are separated in A. variegatum and in A. inflatum, both of them being described long ago and neglected since (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer 2014).
Taxonomic revision of this species is pending, and awaiting publication.
The larva described as Aeshna peralta from Brazil (Santos 1966) corresponds to a different species (Rhionaeschna brasiliensis, von Ellenrieder and Costa 2002).
Bombus mucidus was considered formerly as a distinct subgenus (Mucidobombus).

This species may be conspecific with B. hortorum but the taxonomic status is uncertain. No-one has a sufficiently broad analysis of this complex at present to conclude this authoritatively(P. Williams pers. comm. 2015).

Araneus hortensis has not been found since its description in 1859 (Blackwall 1859). Given the usually easy sampling of similar species, being relatively large orb weavers, and the fact that the single known specimen was captured in a garden, this may be due to either it being a synonym of another, potentially common, species or an species that has been introduced to Madeira.
Not recorded since original description from Madeira with uncertain locality (Kulczyński 1899).

Possible junior synonym of Centromerus sexoculatus Wunderlich, 1992
(Reboleira et al. 2011) which if true could considerably impact the species extinction risk
assessment.

Possible senior synonymy with Centromerus anoculus Wunderlich,
1995 (Reboleira et al. 2011)

Despite intensive searches during the last decade it was not possible to find this species recently described from undetermined locality in the island of Porto Santo (Wunderlich 1992). It probably is a junior synonym of Hogna insularum.

Hogna ingens was described in 1857 by John Blackwall (1857). Despite several taxonomic redescriptions from pioneer arachnologists (Blackwall 1867, Kulczynski 1899, Roewer 1960, Denis 1962 and later Wunderlich 1992), every other aspect of this remarkable species remained unknown until recently (Crespo et al. 2014).
The species is not found since 1962 and needs taxonomic clarification (Denis 1962).
The species belongs in the Theridion sexpunctatum group.
Possible junior synonym of Steatoda paykulliana (Walckenaer, 1806), a widespread palearctic species (Denis 1962).
This species was described based on males only.
Seychellum mahefregate is a cryptic species recognized mainly on the basis of genetic evidence with an overall morphology that is identical to that described for S. alluaudi.

Seychellum alluaudi s.s. is now only believed to occur on two islands (Praslin and La Digue). This species was re-described by Ng et al. (1995) and was updated by Cumberlidge and Daniels (2014). Two other species of Seychellum are now recognised: S. mahefregate Cumberlidge and Daniels, 2014 and S. silhouette Cumberlidge and Daniels, 2014.
Dromoaeschna weiskei was previously placed in Austroaeschna.
This species was described as Austroaeschna parvistigma flavomaculata Tillyard, 1916.

Martin (1909) described what he regarded as the male of Austroaeschna unicornis, but it was not. In the same work Tillyard described pulchra as a new race of A. unicornis. However pulchra differs from unicornis so much that Tillyard’s (1909) specimen does not warrant subspecific rank. Theischinger (1982) corrected the erroneous use of A. unicornis, recognising these specimens as Austroaeschna pulchra.
Considered to be a subspecies of A. unicornis by some authorities.
This species was treated as Austrophlebia costalis until it was separated as Austrophlebia subcostalis by Theischinger (1996).
See Endersby and Fliedner (2015: 149) for a brief summary of prior taxonomy for this species.
This species was described as Telephlebia godefrroyi brevicauda Tillyard, 1916
This species was described as Telephlebia godeffroyi cyclops Tillyard, 1916.
Originally described as Telephlebia godeffroyi tillyardi Campion in Tillyard, 1916.

Southern populations of Austropetalia, originally treated as A. patricia, were separated as A. tonyana by Theischinger (1995). A single female from Barrington Tops was treated as A. patricia until it was recognised as a separate species Austropetalia anneliese (Theischinger 2013).
Southern populations of Austropetalia, originally treated as A. patricia, were separated as A. tonyana by Theischinger (1995).
Theischinger (1999) described a subspecies, A. r. jurzitzai, from the southern part of the range of the species, occurring as far north as the Bellinger catchment.
This species was originally described as Diphlebia euphaeiodes coerulescens Tillyard, 1913
This species was originally described as a subspecies Antipodogomphus neophytus hodgkini Watson, 1969.
Austroepigomphus melaleucae (Tillyard, 1909) is a junior synonym of Austroepigomphus praeruptus.
This species was originally described as Ictinogomphus australis dobsoni Watson, 1969.
A subspecies Neosticta canescens dorrigoensis Tillyard, 1913 has been recognized by some authorities.

The species is not considered a valid species by the World Bee Checklist (ITIS 2014), and Brooks (1988) synonymised A. gallica with A. quadricolor (Erichson, 1840), and indeed these two taxa look superficially similar. There are nevertheless several very significant differences and the taxa differ conspicuously in their colour patterns and, in males, by the shape of the hind metatarsus and genitalia. For the purposes of this assessment, Friese (1897) will be followed, therefore separating A. gallica from A. quadricolor.

This species was erroneously synonymised with A. balneorum Lepeletier, 1841 by Brooks (1988). However, these species are conspicuously different (Rasmont et al. 1995). Furthermore, while A. balneorum is a montane species, A. nigrovittata only lives near the sea level (P. Rasmont pers. comm. 2014).
This skipper used to be considered a subspecies of the Red-underwing Skipper (S. sertorius).
Until recently the Iberian Sooty Copper was regarded as a subspecies of Lycaena tityrus (Casulo et al., 1989).
Recently the subpopulations in the Sierra de la Sagra (formerly described as Polyommatus sagratrox) have been assigned to this species.
Following Vila et al. (2010), the taxon subbaeticus (from the Sierras de Cazorla y Segura and Sierra de la Sagra) is treated as a subspecies of P. violetae.
C. c. elbana is considered specifically distinct by some authors.
The populations in the Pyrenees are by some authors treated as distinct species (E. rondoui).
Some authors regard H. senthes a subspecies of H. aristaeus.
This butterfly species used to be considered a sub-species of the Wall Brown (L. megera)
Considered by some authors as a subspecies of M. occitanica.
Should be Allancastria (see Bollini and Racheli 2012).

No taxonomic problems with the species. The species is of special interest as it is the only one of the genus Eostemmiulus, itself phyletically very isolated in the Southeast Asian fauna (Golovatch et al. 2010).

Although Sympetrum janeae Carle, 1993, has never been formally synonymized with S. internum, most odonatologists in North America do not recognize the species as distinct. Populations in southeastern Canada and northeastern United States do show some differences from populations farther west, but a thorough analysis of the geographic variation has not been conducted.

Unofficial suggestions have been made by T. W. Donnelly (2005) that this species is conspecific with Amphiagrion abbreviatum (Selys, 1876) of western North America, connected by intermediate populations across the Great Plains. This synonymy has not been made official, and there is not universal acceptance of it among North American odonatologists.
Several described subspecies, none of them very well defined.
Two fairly well-marked subspecies, an eastern Aeshna umbrosa umbrosa and a western A. u. occidentalis; both common and widespread.
Two subspecies discussed in literature were formerly considered different species: Cordulegaster obliqua obliqua and C. o. fasciata.

The nominate subspecies occurs in Northern America. In Europe and Asia A. subarctica elisabethae is found. Two types of A. subarctica elisabethae occur in Europe which mainly differ in the amount of yellow pattern in the thorax. It seems that in cooler climates the darker type prevails while in the lowland of central Europe the paler type is more common. These types can be found together and are at least partly determined by climatological circumstances and are therefore not considered to be subspecies.

Bartenev (1930) described Aeshna juncea americana for New World populations of this species, but the name is not in general use. Several subspecies have been presented on the basis on the differences in patterns, but none are so far commonly recognized.
In the past, this species was placed in a distinct monotypic genus (Anomalagrion Selys, 1857)
Once consider a subspecies of the Eurasian A. caerulea (Ström, 1783).
This species is now in the genus Phanogomphus.

Up until 2005, Enallagma annexum was included within E. cyathigerum. However Turgeon et al. (2005) demonstrated that the Nearctic and Palearctic populations of E. cyathigerum were really two species: E. cyathigerum (occurring in the Palearctic) and E. annexum (occurring in the Nearctic).

Pérez (1902: 174-175) described A. batava from the Netherlands. Stöckhert (1930: 923-924; 962-963) produced a key with detailed information on separating A. apicata and A. batava. Warncke (1967: 255) synonymized A. batava with A. apicata and was followed by some authors. However, Schmid-Egger and Scheuchl (1997: 53-54, 102-103), examined copious material of both taxa, reaching the conclusion that they are distinct species.

Originally described as A. gelriae ssp. gredana Warncke, 1975. In the description, Warncke pointed out the differences between the male genitalia of A. gelriae ssp. gelriae and A. gelriae ssp. gredana, and the latter was raised to a full species on the basis of these differences.

Gusenleitner and Schwarz (2002: 313) state that possibly all three of Warncke’s subspecies of A. gelriae (gredana, producta and vocifera) are distinct species.
The validity of this species has been questioned by Garrison (Tennessen pers. comm. with Garrison).
Neuragrion mysticum Karsch, 1891 is a junior synonym of Heteropodagrion sanguinipes Selys 1885 (Garrison & von Ellenrieder 2005).
A monotypic genus.

This species was originally identified from Daegu, Republic of Korea, under the name of Gomphus coreanus Doi & Okumura, 1937. It was later recombined as Anisogomphus coreanus Doi & Okumura, 1943 and again recombined as Asiagomphus coreanus Asahina, 1985 (Bae and Lee 2012).

The evolutionary phylogeny of the Armadillidae requires further study. As presently defined, the genus Pseudolaureola Kwon, Ferrara & Taiti is comprised of just four species with a remarkably disjunct distribution across humid forests of the tropical Afro-Australasian zone; In addition to the Atlantic outpost occupied by P. atlantica, the other taxa are found in Madagascar, New Caledonia and western Australia (Schmalfuss, 2003). Related genera (e.g. Laureola Barnard) have a predominantly southern African distribution but extend as far as south-east Asia.

This rare moth was only discovered in 2009 (Arenberger et al., 2012). Previously, only a single Agdistis species was known from St Helena (the locally much more widespread endemic, A. sanctaehelenae Wollaston), although some taxonomic confusion remains over the genus and it is possible that further St Helena species await recognition. Agdistis marionae is superficially close to its more common sister taxon and the adults are distinguished on relatively subtle morphological characters, but the larvae presumably display strong physical and behavioural differences. Agdistis sanctaehelenae occurs in many habitats and is thus assumed to be less host-specific.
Trioza barrettae has recently been described (Taylor and Moir 2014) and was previously known as Trioza sp. 03 (Moir et al. 2012a).

E. Scheuchl and A. Kratochwil (pers. comm. 2014) are working on the clarification of the confused taxonomic and nomenclatural situation in the subgenus Suandrena. While the work is not finished yet, it is already clear that Andrena fratella and Andrena notata are distinct species, rather than subspecies as Warncke regarded them. Andrena fratella does not occur in Europe, while A. notata occurs in Fuerteventura and Lanzarote (Canary Islands, Spain) and A. cyanomicans occurs in Spain, Portugal, Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia.

Dylewska (1987) and Schmid-Egger and Scheuchl (1997) accept A. pauxilla as a distinct species. Besides, H. Schwenninger (pers. comm. 2014) examined the type of A. curtula and stated that A. curtula and A. pauxilla are clearly distinct species.
Pseudococcus markharveyi has recently been described (Gullan et al. 2013) and has been previously referred to as Pseudococcus sp. 15 in Moir et al. (2012).
Acizzia mccarthyi has recently been described (Taylor & Moir, 2014). No other names exist for the species and the taxonomy has not been questioned.

The species concept of B. melanopygus is now considered to include B. edwardsii, the latter of which was formerly treated as a unique and morphologically distinct species from California and Oregon, but is now considered conspecific with B. melanopygus based on genetic similarity (Williams et al. 2014, Owen et al. 2010). Specifically, Owen & Plow (1980) found that these two morphs differ by a single pair of alleles at one locus controlling the color of the pubescens on gastral terga II-III. According to Owen et al. (2010), there can be little doubt that the two are conspecific.

Due to several major color pattern polymorphisms and evidence of genetic structuring among regional populations, the taxonomic status of regional populations of this species has been the subject of debate (Lozier et al. 2013). According to Williams et al. (2014), evidence from DNA barcodes supports a close relationship between two divergent groups with different color patterns and distributions, B. bifarius bifarius and B. bifarius nearcticus. At present, these two groups are treated as the nominant and nearcticus color patterns of the same species, although the potential need for taxonomic revision is currently under examination (Lozier 2014, pers. comm.).
Evidence from DNA barcodes supports B. centralis and B. flavifrons as distinct species, despite their close genetic relationship (Williams et al. 2014).

Some records previously treated as this species (e.g., from southern Appalachians) are now considered Bombus sandersoni, often determined as Bombus frigidus sandersoni (NatureServe 2014). It is now recognized that the two species are separate (Williams et al., 2014).

See Williams (2014) for a discussion of the taxonomic status of this species. In short, B. praticola (Kirby 1837) is considered a synonym based on Kirby's original descriptions (there is no type material of this species). Since B. praticola appears to be the oldest available name for this species, that name (the senior homonym) would typically take precedence. However, since the name B. mixtus has been in common use for the species since 1950, Williams (2014) suggests that, in the interests of stability, an application be made to ICZN to suppress the senior homonym. At present, B. mixtus continues to be the widely-accepted name for this species (Williams 2014; Williams et al. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear as the species is only known from the type specimen (C. Praz pers. comm. 2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is considered conspecific with M. lefebvrei by some authors.

Recent studies re-organized the binotatus group within the genus Chorthippus (Defaut 2011). This revision proposes two species: C. binotatus and C. saulcyi.

Five sub-species are currently recognized : 

*Chorthippus saulcyi saulcyi (Krauss, 1888), which is widespread on the eastern Pyrenees both on the French side (in the Pyrénée-Orientale department) and on Spanish side (east of the Cerdagne). 

*Chorthippus saulcyi vicdessossi Defaut, 2011, which is widespread in the French Pyrenees (in the Ariège, Haute-Garonne and Hautes-Pyrénées departments).

*Chorthippus saulcyi moralesi Uvarov, 1954, which is widespread in the Catalonian Pyrenees (mainly in Spain, in Aragon and Catalonia, but also in France in Cerdagne).

*Chorthippus saulcyi algoaldensis Chopard 1952, which is widespread in the South Massif Central (Gard, Hérault, Ardèche, Lozère, Aveyron and Tarn Departments).

*Chorthippus saulcyi daimei (Azam, 1893), which is widespread in the French South Alps (in the Alpes-Maritimes, Var and Alpes-de-Haute-Provence departments, but probably not in the Hautes-Alpes Department, where former records exist) and in Italy (in the peaks of Alpi Maritime).

The description of Chorthippus smardai lacks clear diagnosis and its distinction from Pseudochorthippus tatrae is problematic. According to its taxonomic affinity, C. smardai should be related to the genus Pseudochorthippus (A. Kristin pers. comm. 2015).
It was previously thought that the taxon authority of this species was (Rungs, 1952). However, Barat (2012) recently indicated that that the correct authority is (Ebner, 1938).
Bolívar (1897-1899) doubted the validity of this species.
There are two subspecies: Ocnerodes brunneri brunneri (Bolívar, 1876) and Ocnerodes brunneri cyanipes Bolívar, 1902.
This species is in need of a taxonomic study as it is quite similar to P. bosphoricus and P. bidens (D. Sirin pers. comm. 2015).
This species was formerly recorded from Corsica under several different names, including E. magnifica (Costa, 1863), E. schmidti (Fieber, 1961) and E. chabrieri (Charpentier, 1825)
Ramme (1939) described this species as Rhacocleis silvestrii, named after Prof. F. Silvestri-Portici, but it is often cited as Rhacocleis sylvestrii.

The taxonomic status of this species is a matter of debate (Gorochov 2009, 2012). It may be a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina but this issue has not been definitely settled yet. The taxon was described as Gryllomorpha cretensis by Ramme (1927), however Eades et al. (2014) place the taxon as a subspecies of Gryllomorpha dalmatina Ramme, 1927. Gorochov and Ünal (2012) mentions G. cretensis in the context of G. dalmatina (p.54-55) but the text there states: "The first taxon [i.e. Gryllomorpha cretensis] is insufficiently studied, and its belonging to G. dalmatina is not evident; however, a single female from Crete I., recently studied by us, is similar to Ramme’s description and distinguished from the above-mentioned Turkish specimens as well as from the other Greek and Montenegro specimens by the smaller body size and transversally banded (not spotted) colouration of abdominal dorsum; this is probably a separate subspecies." In addition, the paper itself does not make the new combination. Although future studies may indeed prove this to be a subspecies of G. dalmatina, at present we retain G. cretensis as a species (L. Willemse pers. comm. 2015).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).
The species was recently moved into the genus Pseudochorthippus by Defaut (2012). It is often referred to as Chorthippus tatrae.

The genus Capraiuscola was previously considered a sub-genus of Miramella, but it was upgraded to genus in 2014. This change was made without a clear statement to revise the status of this taxon. The authors (Chintauan-Marquier et al. 2014) compared a small sample of the sub-tribe Miramellina and the speciation of Capraiuscola is mentioned in comparison with Podisma. Thus, for the purposes of this assessment, the species is currently regarded here within the genus Miramella.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear, as it may possibly be a synonym of Odontopodisma fallax (J. Skejo pers. comm. 2016).
This species most probably represents a senior synonym of Demirsoyus salmani Sirin and Ciplak, 2004 in Yalim et al. (2004) (F. Willemse pers. comm. 2005).

P. nagyi has been described on the basis of small differences with P. fieberi and P. transilvanica in the male aedeagus. Nagy et al. (2010) suggest that it may be a synonym (or subspecies) of P. fieberi.

Some records from localities outside Hvar island were thought to belong to B. kaltenbachi, however the females are not distinguishable from B. yersini at the moment and research on their identity is needed. Until then, records outside of Hvar that are based only on females are disregarded here.
The western subpopulation of this species needs to be compared with the eastern subpopulation to verify if they are conspecific.

Future taxonomic and faunistic research on the Poecilimon elegans species complex (including P. albolineatus) would help to clarify the distribution and ecology of this taxon, which was formerly regarded as P. elegans.

The great variation and genetic similarity (Kaya et al. 2012, D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015) suggest close relationships of P. tauricus and P. pliginskii and their possible infraspecific relationships. Kaya et al. (2012) consider Poecilimon boldyrevi to be a synonym of P. pliginskii.
The taxonomic status of Poecilimon ukrainicus and Poecilimon fussi needs further study.
This species possibly includes more than one sibling taxa (J. Skejo pers. comm. 2015). All records of D. palpata from the western Balkans and the Adriatic coast belong to this species.
This species is considered to possibly represent a local form of C. dorsalis by Willemse (1984). Taxonomic research is necessary to clarify the status of this species.
This species should be compared with M. karnyana, because according to the analyses performed so far they seem quite similar.
This species should be compared with M. hoermanni because according to the analyses performed so far they seem quite similar.

The large gap between the northern and southern subpopulations and the high degree of long-term isolation in different mountain ranges suggest a considerable infraspecific variability which requires detailed taxonomic research.
This species is very poorly known from a description based on three specimens. Thus, its systematics and distribution are in need of thorough research.
This species is closely related to Pholidoptera stankoi Karaman, and they are probably synonymous (D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is still uncertain (Chobanov 2011) and needs further investigation.

The Horrid Ground-weaver (Nothophantes horridus Merrett & Stevens, 1995) is a recently described species of small linyphiid spider (total body length of just 2.5 mm). It is also the only known representative of the genus.
The taxonomic status of Sphingonotus crivellarii is not clear. Whether it is indeed a distinct species or not still needs to be confirmed.

There have been three species of Desert Grasshoppers described from Cyprus, all three of them endemic to Cyprus. The distinction between the three species is not clear which makes an assessment of these species impossible. Consequently, the assessment for all three species of Xerohippus will be Data Deficient on taxonomic grounds.

There have been three species of Desert Grasshoppers described from Cyprus, all three of them endemic to Cyprus. The distinction between the three species is not clear which makes an assessment of these species impossible. Consequently, the assessment for all three species of Xerohippus will be Data Deficient on taxonomic grounds.

There have been three species of Desert Grasshoppers described from Cyprus, all three of them endemic to Cyprus. The distinction between the three species is not clear which makes an assessment of these species impossible. Consequently, the assessment for all three species of Xerohippus will be Data Deficient on taxonomic grounds.

This species was described from the eastern Aegean island of Kos (Baccetti 1992). Baccetti described this species on the basis of the studies of Krimbas (1956a, 1956b, 1960), who found two Gryllotalpa species with different chromosome numbers in Greece. G. krimbasi has 19 chromosomes and Baccetti considered his specimen as typical for this form which was found by Krimbas in many places of the Greek mainland (see map 109a in Willemse 1984). Ingrisch et al. (2006) present further morphological details of krimbasi after material from Fthiotis, Central Greece, with a chromosome number of about 19

Acrometopa cretensis is a species with two subspecies: A. cretensis cretensis and A. cretensis daedali; see also the Orthoptera Species File (orthoptera.speciesfile.org/). This assessment is based on (distribution) data of the species.

The species needs taxonomic revision. It has been synonymized with V. oblongicollis by Willemse (1977) but reestablished as a species by Massa and Fontana (2011). According to the variation observed by Willemse (1977, 1984) the synonymy of Vichetia knipperi and V. oblongicollis is very probable.
This species needs further taxonomic research to identify the differences with M. nonveilleri (the only difference stated so far is its colour).

Zeuner (1941) described Parnassiana tymphrestos from Mt.Timfristos (= Mt. Veluchi, compare Ramme, 1931). Ramme (1951) discussed the possible synonymy of P. tymphrestos and P. coracis but, not being aware that Mt. Korax is close to Mt. Timfristos, and by lack of material of P. tymphrestos, did not solve it, and the matter remains unsolved. For the time being, the material from Mt. Vardhousia recorded under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1980 & 1984) should be transferred to Platycleis (Parnassiana) coracis Ramme, 1920. Likewise a re-evaluation of the population of Mt. Oiti, also arranged under P. tymphrestos in F. Willemse (1973 & 1980) appears necessary.

The identity of Rhacocleis agiostratica is not beyond doubt as the description has been based on juvenile specimens. Adult material is required to compare it with other Rhacocleis species in particular Rhacocleis distinguenda.
The genus Acrida is in need of taxonomic revision.

This identification of this species of Gryllotalpa can only be certain on the basis of the chromosome number (Ortiz 1958). As a result, the known distribution of this species may be doubtful, as in known recordings the chromosome number has only rarely been counted.

According to several authors (e.g. Massa et al. 2012, Ragge and Reynolds 1998) this species is considered a junior synonym of C. cialancensis. However, other authors such as Morichon and Morin (2010) consider these two to be two distinct species. For the purposes of this assessment, both C. cialancensis and C. sampeyrensis are considered as distinct species.
The Authority for this taxon is given as (Obenberger, 1926), because although Puschnig (1910) named the species for the first time, he did not give a valid description.
The species is only known from the first description and its taxonomic status is probably doubtful.

Several endemic Corsican grasshoppers were previously described (Omocestus corsicus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus corsicus montanus Chopard, 1924; Omocestus pascuorum Chopard, 1924; Stauroderus incertus Chopard, 1924; Chorthippus chopardi Harz, 1971) and are now considered to belong to Chorthippus corsicus (Defaut 1999), with two subspecies: C. c. corsicus (Chopard, 1924) and C. c. pascuorum (Chopard, 1924). Both taxa overlap in distribution (Braud et al. 2002). In the same way, the morphological distinction is not always easy or possible due to the substantial intra-populational variability.
The identification of Corsican Dolichopoda can be difficult sometimes since some specimens seem to be intermediary between D. bormansi and D. cyrnensis.
The identification of Corsican Dolichopoda can be difficult sometimes as some specimens seem to be intermediary between Dolichopoda bormansi and Dolichopoda cyrnensis.

The status of this taxon is uncertain. Several previous records of this species have recently been assigned to Ephippigerida diluta and the remaining records need to be checked, but may also be misidentifications of this taxon (Barat and Correas 2015).
The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied and compared with other Platycleis species. It is currently not clear whether it represents a synonym or a unique species.
The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied as recent findings suggest that the species is in fact three distinct species (P. Fontana pers. comm 2015).
More research is needed into the taxonomy of this species, since the two  subspecies might represent separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm.  2015).
The two distinct subpopulations of this species are currently considered two subspecies but they may actually be two separate species (P. Fontana pers. comm. 2015).

The confusion surrounding the identities of the freshwater crabs from western Kenya arises from a number of sources, including long-standing opinions on species synonymies, some that have proved to be in error (Bott 1955), the confusion of two different species (Williams 1991), and the lack of understanding of the morphological changes that accompany growth in these species (Reed and Cumberlidge 2006, Cumberlidge and Clark 2009).

Aeshna wittei Fraser, 1955 is a synonym to A. scotias (Peters and Theischinger 2011). The paraphyletic genus Aeshna was split by Peters and Theischinger (2011) and A. scotias assigned to the monotypic Afroaeschna.
Four subspecies have been reported for this species: O. chevrolati chevrolati, O. chevrolati longicarinatus, O. chevrolati omiltemi, and O. chevrolati retusus.

This species is often placed in the genus Anaciaeschna without any published evidence. The species appears distinct from both genera, but is retained in Aeshna until the issue is resolved (K.D. Djikstra pers. comm. 2018).
This species, formerly included in the genus Hemianax, is increasingly included in the genus Anax. As no genetic investigation is available, this remains controversial.
Gynacantha flavipes and G. sevastopuloi are synonyms to G. nigeriensis (Dijkstra 2005).
Gynacantha zuluensis (Balinsky, 1961) is a synonym of Gynacantha usambarica Sjöstedt, 1909 (Djikstra 2005).
Heliaeschna libyana is synonym to H. fuliginosa (Dijkstra 2004).
Discussed as H. longfieldae by Dijkstra (2005), but that name is predated by the synonymous H. sembe (Dijkstra, unpubl.)
Heliaeschna ukerewensis Pinhey, 1961 is a synonym of H. trinervulata.
Aeschnna meruensis is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011).

Aeschna moori is now placed in the genus Pinheyscha (Peters and Theischinger 2011). Species status confirmed by Dijkstra (2007), close to P. meruensis Sjöstedt, 1909 and especially to P. yemenensis Waterston, 1985 and an unnamed relative from Ethiopia.

Aeschna rileyi is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theoschinger 2011). Pinheyschna moori (Pinhey, 1980), described from a single poorly preserved male from Zambia, is most likely a synonym of P. rileyi (Dijkstra and Clausnitzer in prep.).
Aeschna subpupillata is now placed in the genus Pinheyschna (Peters and Theischinger 2011).
Subfamily Pseudothelphusinae; tribe Hypolobocerini, Subgenus Hypolobocera.
The status of the two subspecies needs to be studied as these may represent unique species.

Recent molecular evidence (unpublished data, A. Hochkirch pers. comm. 2016) suggests that at least three different genetic lineages exist on the islands of Tenerife, Gran Canaria and La Gomera. Their taxonomic status needs to be studied as they well might represent unique species.
Tartarogryllus sandanski is likely to be a synonym of Tartarogryllus tartarus (Chobanov 2009)
The status of the subspecies Asiotmethis t. steppensis and A. t. flavipes needs to be studied.
The former French subspecies Prionotropis hystrix rhodanica and Prionotropis hystrix azami are now considered valid species (Massa et al. 2015).
A recent study by López et al. (2013) showed that the former records from North Lanzarote and Montaña Clara belong to a different species, Purpuraria magna.
The Italian subspecies Poecilimon jonicus superbus is sometimes considered a unique species (Massa et al. 2012).
Recent genetic evidence suggests that unique species may occur on La Gomera and El Hierro (H. López pers. comm. 2015).

The status of this species and its relationship with Canariola willemsei needs to be studied. Both species are flightless, but overlapping ranges have been documented. Canariola willemsei has even been documented from two islands (La Gomera and Tenerife).

The taxonomy of the Eupholidoptera chabrieri group has recently been studied and the status of some taxa (E.g. Eupholidoptera schmidti) has sometimes been moved to subspecies level or even synonymy of Eupholidoptera chabrieri (e.g. Ciplak et al. 2009). However, a recent molecular study shows that the species status of these taxa is probably valid (Allegrucci et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes considered a synonym of Eupholidoptera megastyla (Ciplak et al. 2009). However, recent molecular evidence supports the species rank (Allegrucci et al. 2013).

The species has long been considered as subspecies or even synonym of Eupholidoptera chabrieri (e.g. Ciplak et al. 2009). However, recent genetic evidence supports its species rank (Allegrucci et al. 2013).

No differences have been found in morphology or bioacustics of this quite variable species between Pholidoptera dalmatica brachynota, P. dalmatica maritima, P. dalmatica cvrstnicensis, P. dalmatica dalmatica - all of them seem to be just local forms without taxonomic value and there is no regularity of subspecies in different distribution areas.
This species is likely to be a synonym of Pholidoptera ebneri (Lemmonier-Darcemont et al. 2014).

A female record from Troglav Mountain is quite similar to what is regarded as R. buchichii in the literature. However, the true identity is uncertain as far as the subpopulation from Troglav and the subpopulations from islands are not compared morphologically on both sexes and bioacoustically, both on song characters and stridulatory area morphology.
The taxonomic status of Roeseliana ambitiosa is under debate. A taxonomic revision of the genus Roeseliana is needed (Chobanov and Mihajlova 2010).

Saga gracilis was considered a subspecies of S. campbelli for a long time, but currently it is treated as a separate species. Further taxonomic research is required to clarify its status (M. Lemonnier-Darcemont pers. comm. 2015).
This species shows very similar morphology and song to L. punctatissima, which needs clarification on its taxonomic situation (G. Szovenyi pers. comm. 2016).
Subspecies occasi occurs in Italy and France, and subspecies asturica occurs in Spain.
This species is probably a synonym of Chorthippus binotatus (Charpentier, 1825) (Presa et al. 2007).
This species is probably a synonym of Chorthippus jacobsi Harz, 1975 (Presa et al. 2007).
There are two subspecies: Podisma carpetana ignatii Morales-Agacino, 1950, and Podisma carpetana carpetana.
This species has been moved from the genus Jacobsiella Harz, 1975 to the genus Sphingonotus Fieber, 1852 by Husemann et al. (2013).

This species changed its taxonomic status from subspecies to valid species and was moved to a different genus (Husemann et al. 2013). It was formerly known as Leptopternis candidus lusitanicus Ebner, 1941.
Taxonomic limits of Umma and Sapho must be reassessed, but this species is closer to Sapho (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Includes Umma distincta (Djikstra in prep.).
The synonymy of A. greyi and A. ntaali with each other is indisputed, but that of both with A. lacuselephantum requires futher study (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Chlorocypha hintzi (Grünberg, 1915) is a synonym of C. cancellata (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Kipping et al. (2017) transferred the blue Chlorocypha species endemic to Angola to the genus Platycypha.
The taxonomic status of Chlorocypha dahli has not been fully resolved.
Previously mistaken for C. wittei; could be a form of C. curta with wholly red abdomen (Dijkstra 2007).

In the Lokutu area of central Congo (Kinshasa), Dijkstra (2007) found populations of a species with features intermediate between C. ghesquierei, C. trifaria and C. cyanifrons. C. trifaria is widespread east of Lokutu, while C. ghesquierei and C. cyanifrons are sympatric to the west at Eala. Because of the latter sympatry, the Lokutu populations can only represent a character gradient either from C. trifaria to C. ghesquierei or to C. cyanifrons, or a discrete species. Without material from intermittent area and with only slight differences in the configuration and (partly age-related) extent of markings their status must remain unsettled for now.

Pinhey (1967) regarded C. hasta Pinhey, 1960 as a subspecies of C. molindica Fraser, 1948. Dijkstra (2007) considers C. hasta as a good species and as closely related to C. tenuis Longfield, 1936, of which it might even be a synonym.
Confused with C. consueta of southern Africa; taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2003).
The closeness of the slender red Chlorocypha species is demonstrated by two hybrid males C. molindica x tenuis discovered in south west Uganda (Dijkstra, Kisakye unpubl.).
All records under this name require comparison with the type material.
Confused with C. dispar; taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2003).
Subspecies radix of C. glauca was raised to species level by Dijkstra (2003).
May include a second species with blue head markings in eastern Nigeria (Dijkstra, unpubl.).
Subspecies C. nigeriensis Gambles, 1975 is not more than a pale variety.
Dijkstra (2007) considers Chlorocypha basilewskyi as a junior synonym of C. tenuis.
A specimen from the shores of Lake Malawi may be a new species.
Separation of subspecies lucalaensis from Angola probably invalid (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Aciagrion congoense is a synonym to A. africanum (Dijkstra 2007).
Western Africa records of this and the similar A. hamoni must be reviewed.
Although this is a recognised species, it may belong in a different genus. The genus Aciagrion is in need of further taxonomic work.
A. balachowskyi, from northeastern Gabon, might be a synonym of this species. If this is the case, it will be widespread (Dijktra pers. comm.).
A dark form, abercornensis, occurs in northern Zambia.
Previously confused with A. dondoense (Dijkstra 2007).
Often confused with A. sinuatum.
Africallagma pseudelongatum was treated as a synonym of A. elongatum for a long time.

A. malawi specimen, described as Africallagma sinuatum f. fugax (Pinhey, 1962), differs significantly from A. sinuatum (Ris, 1921) and is expected to become a good species (May and Dijkstra in prep.).
Includes sub-species A. angolensis spatulatum.
Female was recently described by Terzani and Marconi (2003).
This species is often confused with A. victoria.
D'Andrea and Carfi (1997) made Agriocnemis aligulae Pinhey, 1974 a synonym of A. maclachlani Selys, 1877.
There are two subspecies: Eumigus cucullatus almeriensis Bolívar, 1912 and Eumigus cucullatus cucullatus (Bolívar, 1878).
The specific name should be monticola (Llorente del Moral & Presa Asensio, 1997).

There are three subspecies:

  • Eumigus punctatus punctatus (Bolívar, 1902)
  • E. p. calarensis Presa, Llorente del Moral & García, 2000
  • E. p. templadoi Llorente del Moral & Presa, 1986
The species has been moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
There are two subspecies: ruberrima Balinsky, 1961 and albifrons Balinsky, 1961. Further taxonomic work is required as A. ruberrima may be split into two separate species.
There is a subspecies: Canariola emarginata paynei Llucià Pomares & Quiñones, 2013

authority: (Gomez Ladrón de Guevara, Pardo & Llorente del Moral, 1998)
taxonomicNotes: Barat (2012) changed the species from Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Coracinotus.
This species was changed from Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Coracinotus by Barat (2012).
This species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Conacinotus by Barat (2012).

Agriocnemis sania Nielsen, 1959 was made a subspecies of A. pygmaea (Rambur 1942) by Pinhey (1974). Dumont (1974) redescribed the taxon and elaborated on the differences between A. sania and A. pygmaea, the latter being very abundant and widespread in Asia. Though more taxonomic work is needed, both species are currently considered as good species, with A. sania occurring in northeastern Africa and A. pygmea being widespread in southern Asia
Ephippigerida marceti is probably a synonym of E. asella or of E. areolaria (Barat 2012, Olmo 2006, Poniatowski et al. 2010)
This species is probably synonymous with Ephippigerida asella Navás, 1907 or Ephippigerida areolaria (Bolívar, 1877) (Olmo 2006, Poniatowski et al. 2010, Barat 2012).

Taxonomic research is needed in the group of species composed by Lluciapomaresius anapaulae, L. asturiensis and L. nobrei to clearly identify their taxonomic status and the characteristics that distinguish these entities. Lluciapomaredius anapaulae and L. asturiensis are very similar in morphology and bioacustics, while it is not possible to distinguish L. asturiensis from L. nobrei (Pfau and Pfau 2015).

Taxonomic research is needed in the group of species composed by Lluciapomaresius asturiensis,  L. anapaulae, and L. nobrei to clearly identify their taxonomic status and the characteristics that distinguish these entities. It is not possible to distinguish L. asturiensis from L. nobrei regarding bioacustics, while distinctness between Lluciapomaresius anapaulae and L. asturiensis  is limited (Pfau and Pfau 2015).

Research is needed to ascertain the validity of this species and its distinction from Lluciapomaresius asturiensis. Available information shows no differentiation between the male songs of both species and a hypothesis for the synonymy of L. asturiensis and L. nobrei exists (Barat, pers. comm. in Pfau and Pfau 2015).
The species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Lluciapomaresius by Barat (2012).
This species was changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Lluciapomaresius by Barat (2012).
This species is often confused with A. forcipata.
This species has been changed from the genus Steropleurus Bolívar, 1878 to the new genus Lluciapomaresius by Barat (2012).
This species was moved from the genus Platycleis Fieber, 1853 to the new genus Montana by Eades et al. (2010).
This species was moved from the genus Callicrania Bolivar, 1898 to Neocallicrania by Barat (2007).
This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).

There are two subspecies: Parasteropleurus martorelli martorelli (Bolívar, 1878) and Parasteropleurus martorelli angulatus (Bolívar, 1908). This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
This species was moved from the genus Ephippiger Berthold, 1827 by Barat (2012).
The taxonomic status of this species was revised recently (Barranco and Gutierrez-Rodríguez 2010).

There are several subspecies:
  • Pterolepis spoliata kaltenbachi Galvagni, 1981
  • P. s. llorenteae Galvagni, 1981
  • P. s. minor Bolívar, 1900
  • P. s. nadigi Galvagni, 1981
  • P. s. nevdensis Galvagni, 1981
  • P. s. pascuali Galvagni, 1981
  • P. s. raggei Galvagni, 1981
Pycnogaster gurriae Pinedo, 1987 is considered a junior synonym of P. algericensis. Some authors have proposed this species as a subspecies of Pycnogaster finoti (Pinedo and Llorente 1986).
Two subspecies of this species are known: Pycnogaster (Bradygaster) sanchezgomezi sanchezgomezi Bolívar, 1897 and Pycnogaster (Bradygaster) sanchezgomezi constricta Bolívar, 1926.
The species was moved from the genus Ephippigerida Bolívar, 1903 by Barat (2012),
This species was moved from the genus Ephippigerida Bolívar, 1903 by Barat (2012),
There are two subspecies: Steropleurus andalusius andalusius (Rambur, 1838) Steropleurus andalusius levantinus (Bolívar, 1908).
This species needs to be taxonomically reassessed in the light of current knowledge of the tribe Ephippigerini (Barat 2012).
This is probably a misidentification of an exceptionally large specimen of S. brunerii (J.R. Correas pers. comm. 2016).
This species was moved from the genus Callicrania Bolívar, 1898 by Barat (2007).
This species potentially requires further investigation as there are discontinuities in habitat and behaviour across its range.
Enallagma vansomereni is a synonym.
Previously listed as Argiocnemis umbargae Pinhey 1970, which is a synonym of the widespread Ceriagrion annulatum (Dijkstra unpublished).
Taxonomy is clarified by Dijkstra (2005).
Taxonomy is clarified by Dijkstra (2005).
Suspected synonimized with C. suave (Dijkstra).
Ceriagrion moorei and C. hamoni may be synonymous with C. suave (Dijkstra 2005) and are treated as such here.
Ischnura hilli was collected from the same locality as I. abyssinica. Full credit to the new synonymy is given in Clausnitzer and Dijkstra (2005).

A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

This species has often been confused with P. hageni tropicanum.
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".
This is the only member of this otherwise Neotropical family in Africa.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. inopinatum is an A-group species.
A-group. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B".

Examination of the holotype shows that Cornigomphus guineensis is probably a species of Tragogomphus, a taxonomically unresolved genus. However, listing of any Tragogomphus species is premature (Dijkstra unpublished).
Transferred to Onychogomphus by Legrand (2003).

The Maghrebian populations of Gomphus simillimus are ascribed to a weakly differentiated subspecies, Gomphus simillimus marocannus Lieftinck 1966. Its overall heterogeneity is much more marked than expected in the original description, however, so that this taxon is probably more a local form than a true subspecies.
The group requires taxonomic revision, as it may belong to the genus Tragogomphus.

From Dijkstra (2007): "Pinhey (1961b) noted that T. mamfei “has a remarkable superficial resemblance to a Uganda species of Gomphid, now under publication as an aberrant Onychogomphus”. This O. bwambae Pinhey, 1961 may indeed belong to the complex also, as could O. emiliae Legrand, 1992. The species differ only subtily in relative features of size, markings, dorsal profile of S10 and appendages. The T. mamfei holotype is rather teneral and belongs to a small species (Hw 24.7 mm), which has also recently been collected in southwest Cameroon (G.S. Vick in litt.). All species currently classified in Tragogomphus must be revised, including the possible distinction of additional genera in the complex (Cornigomphus, Libyogomphus)."
Possibly synonymous with P. nigroviridis, but the holotype is badly damaged and the name P. machadoi has priority.
Very similar to P. bispina from east Africa and P. bicristulata and P. villiersi from central Africa: requires revision.
Identity deserves study.
Further taxonomic studies are necessary, as this species might belong to P. bispina (Fraser, 1954) or another more widespread and variable taxon (Dijkstra 2007).
Sometimes considered as synonym to Aethiothemis solitaria Martin, 1908, but is a distinct species (Dijkstra unpubl.).
It was in the genus Porpacithemis and has recently been revised by Djikstra and Vick (2005).
Previously placed in its own genus Mesumbethemis Vick, 2000 (Dijkstra and Vick 2005).
Most likely a synonym of C. apicalis (C. trithemoides) (Dijsktra unpubl.).
Formerly placed in Porpacithemis.
The species is close to T. aurivilii, requiring further work.
known from both sexes, illustrated.
The taxonomy of the species needs to be verified.
Morgan (1997) named the species "in respect of Ellen Clark’s pioneering parastacid studies".

The species was identified by Ng (2002) after it was realized that the type series of crabs described as Karstama emdi (Ng and Whitten 1995) contained this additional species. The species was reassigned from Sesarmoides to Karstama by Davie and Ng (2007).

The species was redefined by Ng (2002) when a second species, K. balicum, was recognized from within the original type material, and the species was reassigned from genus Sesarmoides to Karstama by Davie and Ng (2007).

Wood's (2008) definition of M. jeanneli has been split into several different species. The M. jeanneli syntypes include two females that cannot be confidently distinguished. However, the type locality of “La Mandraka” is an area about 40 kilometers east of Antananarivo, and Wood and Scharff (2018) propose that the female syntypes are conspecific to the males found in this area. The male and female specimens that were described and illustrated as M. jeanneli in Wood (2008) are considered as M. lotzi (Wood and Scharff 2018).
Originally named Eriauchenius workmanni by Pickard-Cambridge in 1881, but subsequently referred to as E. workmani (Wood and Scharff 2018).
Revised by Kuntner (2007), known from both sexes, illustrated.
'Halambohitra' means 'mountain spider' in Malagasy (Wood 2008).
This species was formerly considered as a subspecies of Crocothemis erythraea, but structural features (Lohmann 1981, Schneider 1985) support its full species rank.
This species is thought by most workers to include Cordulegaster godmani, usually considered a distinct subspecies.
This species is presently in the genus Gomphurus.
This species is now in the genus Phanogomphus.
Confused with and by some authors as it was considered a subspecies of Anax longipes until 1960s.
This species is now in the genus Hylogomphus.
This species is now considered in the genus Stenogomphurus.
This species is now in the genus Gomphurus.
This species is now in the genus Gomphurus.
This species is now in the genus Phanogomphus.
This species is now in the genus Phanogomphus.
This species is now in the genus Gomphurus.
Garrison (1995) considered O. alleghaniensis a possible synonym of O. incurvatus.
A number of subspecies of Neurothemis ramburii are recognised: N. r. martinii Krüger, 1903; N. r. oceanis Lieftinck, 1948.

A subspecies Neurothemis stigmatizans bramina (Guérin, 1838) is recognised. Another species, N. manadensis (Boisduval, 1835) formerly treated as a subspecies of N. stigmatizans, was raised to specific rank by Seehausen and Dow (2016). However, hybridisation between N. manadensis and N. stigmatizans bramina may occur in parts of the Moluccas and Western New Guinea.

Kalkman and Orr (2014) reviewed records and re-examined specimens of Rhodothemis from east of the Wallace Line and concluded that all records of R. rufa from east of the Wallace line actually refer to R. nigripes.

In New Guinea, two closely allied forms have developed, one in the mountain Valley of the Baliem River, central north New Guinea (I. aurora viduata Lieftinck, 1949) and the other in the Arfak Mountains of the Vogelkop of west New Guinea (I. aurora rhodosoma Lieftinck, 1959) (Armstrong 1973).

There are strong differences in DNA between the Asian forms of the species and specimens from the Pacific (R. Rowe pers. comm. 2012).

Massive habitat modification throughout New Zealand (particularly the North Island) since c.1820 has created new selection pressures on this genus, that has affected distribution, morphology and genetics, possibly leading to positive hybridisation. This species has suspiciously variable morphology, and its taxonomy needs to be studied in greater detail (R. Rowe pers. comm. 2011). Despite the recent recognition of several species, it is probable that several more or less isolated taxonomic groups remain 'undiscovered' in this species (Rowe 1987).

Marinov and McHugh (2010) suppose a possible subspecific status of this species and suggest a DNA-analysis to clear this problem. Earlier work by Nolan et al. (2007) found a 7% difference between a specimen from South Chatham Island from material from the open country in the North where Marinov and McHugh undertook their later work.

Individuals from the Chatham Island population have more black area on the thorax than South Island populations (Marinov and McHugh 2010) and differing DNA analysis (Nolan et al. 2007), and may prove to be a different subspecies.

Both forms, D. bipunctata bipunctata and D. b. novaezealandiae (described from a female), occur in New Zealand. The former has been collected from Northland and Raglan on the Waikato coast and the latter from Maramarua in inland Waikato, Rotorua, Feilding, and Paekakariki. D. b. novaezealandiae may be no more than an environmentally induced variant and therefore not worthy of the subspecific status indicated by its name, but firm conclusions must await breeding experiments and rearing under controlled conditions (Rowe 1987).
The generic status is not clear and needs to be confirmed after revision of all pacific genera.

Wolfe (1953) expressed doubt over the species status - it may be a subspecies of Uropetala carovei (White, 1846), however this was rejected by Rowe (1987), and it has been considered a valid species by several subsequent authors (e.g., Schorr and Paulson 2012).
There is a possibility that Australian populations treated as Agyrtacantha dirupta are not actually that species (G. Theischinger, pers. comm.), this needs further investigation.
The original description was by Watson (1984), with holotype from Cooktown, Queensland. Further taxonomic information provided Houston and Watson (1988).
The species was described by White (White and Doubleday 1846) and the type material is held in the British Natural History Museum (Rowe 1987).

A number of subspecies have been recognized for L. asiatica. Lathrecista a. festa occurs in northern Australia, New Guinea, the Tanimbar Islands, the Aru Islands, Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands and New Caledonia. Lathrecista a. interposita occurs in New Guinea, whilst L. a. pectoralis has been recorded from Papua New Guinea, the Moluccas (the type is from Seram) and northern Sulawesi. Lathrecista a. simulans has only been recorded from the Palawan region of the Philippines. The nominate subspecies has been recorded from India to the Philippines and Moluccas. The current taxonomic situation appears chaotic. Research is needed to determine if any of the subspecies are actually separate species, or better treated as junior synonyms rather than subspecies.

Dijkstra et al. (2014) suggested that Amorphostigma armstrongi should be transferred to Ischnura. However, this has not been fully justified. More recent molecular studies are in favour of Amorphostigma retaining a separate generic status based on morphology (Marinov, M., pers. comm.)

A number of subspecies of Agrionoptera insignis are recognised: A. i. insignis occurs in mainland southeast Asia and throughout Sundaland; A. i. allogenes Tillyard, 1908 occurs in Australia, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and possibly New Caledonia; A. i. chalcochiton Ris, 1915 is known from Simalur and the Mentawai Islands; A. i. insularis Kirby, 1889 was described from the Solomon Islands; A. i. lifuana Kimmins, 1953 was described from New Caledonia; A. i. nereis Lieftinck, 1948 is known from Enggano; A. i. nicobarica Brauer, 1865 is known from the Nicobar Islands;  A. i. papuensis is known from the New Guinea region. Hämälänen and Müller (1997) left the issue of the subspecific status of material from the Philippines open. A. i. dorothea Fraser, 1927 from west Bengal in India is sometimes considered as a distinct species, and sometimes as a subspecies or junior synonym, it is left out of consideration for the purposes of this assessment. Considerable confusion persists over the status of some of these subspecies and of other closely related species of Agrionoptera; the whole complex needs to be critically re-examined.

Agriocnemis sania Nielsen, 1959 was made a subspecies of A. pygmaea (Rambur 1942) by Pinhey (1974). Dumont (1974) redescribed the taxon and elaborated on the differences between A. sania and A. pygmaea, the latter being very abundant and widespread in Asia. Though more taxonomic work is needed, both species are currently considered as good species, with A. sania occurring in northeastern Africa and A. pygmea being widespread in southern Asia.

Dijkstra et al. (2014) suggested that Amorphostigma auricolor should be transferred to Ischnura. However, this has not been fully justified. More recent molecular studies are in favour of Amorphostigma retaining a separate generic status based on morphology (Marinov, M., pers. comm.)
Houston & Watson (1988) give the synonym Cordulia (Hemicordulia) tau, since the incorrect spelling of Hermicordulia was given in the original description.

The type locality for Tramea transmarina transmarina Brauer, 1867 is Fiji. There are several subspecies T. t. euryale Selys, 1878, T. t. intersecta Lieftinck, 1975, T .t. propinqua Lieftinck, 1942 and T. t. yayeyamana Asahina, 1964. The various subspecies vary in the amount of colouration at the basal hind wing, with T. t. euryale possessing a small dark marking from base to anal crossing (Ac). In T. t. propinqua the hindwings have a small dark brown marking which extends from middle of 1st and 2nd antenodal veins to distal margin of arc. The hindwing basal dark marking of T. t. yayeyamana are even more extensive than T. t. propinqua.  T. t. intersecta has an isolated almost pair-shaped spot in the hindwing anal field (Lieftinck 1975). Lieftinck (1975) confirmed that there can be no doubt that T. t. intersecta and other Oriental forms of the limbata-group having a more western distribution (i.e. euryale and propinqua) are subspecies of transmarina. Whether all of these forms represent synonyms or subspecies is a taxonomic minefield. In the Philippines T. transmarina has been recorded by Needham and Gyger (1937) as Tramea limbata.

Trapezostigma loewii (Kaup, 1866), a species widespread in northern and eastern coastal areas of Australia, has recently been reconsigned as a synonym of Tramea transmarina (Rowe et al. 2011).
A subspecies, P. m. stainbergerorum Marinov, 2012 is known from the Kingdom of Tonga.
Ischnura torresiana Tillyard, 1913 was synonymised with I. heterosticta by Watson (1976). A subspecies I. h. tasmanica Tillyard, 1913 is recognized from Tasmania.

A subspecies Orthetrum sabina viduatum Lieftinck, 1942, has been described from the highlands of central New Guinea. It is sometimes regarded as a synonym of O. sabina (Drury, 1773) (http://www.pugetsound.edu/academics/academic-resources/slater-museum/biodiversity-resources/dragonflies/world-odonata-list/). A genetic study of the species throughout its huge range is needed to understand its variability and possible subspeciation.

A number of subspecies of Rhinocypha tincta are usually recognised: R.t. adusta Lieftinck, 1949, R.t. amanda Lieftinck, 1938, R.t. dentiplaga Lieftinck, 1938, R.t. retrograda Lieftinck, 1938, R.t. sagitta Lieftinck, 1938 and R.t. semitincta Selys, 1869 as well as R.t. tincta.
Known only from the description of two males and a doubtfully conspecific female.
Often regarded as a subspecies of Agrionoptera insignis. The taxonomy of the different subspecies and their distribution is poorly known.
Family Synthemistidae is sometimes treated as a subfamily of Corduliidae.

Described as Coenagrion interruptum by Needham (1932), but that name was preoccupied. Polhemus et al. (2000) suggested that the genus Bedfordia should be reinstated for this species, together with Pseudagrion demorsum, but they made no formal proposal to do that. If these two species are in a genus endemic to the Marquesas, it gives them higher conservation status.
Family Synthemistidae is sometimes treated as a subfamily of Corduliidae.
Xanthagrion was first introduced as Sous-genre 14 of the genus Agrion thus causing Houston and Watson (1988) to bracket the citation of Xanthagrion erythroneurum (Selys, 1876)
This species is sometimes placed in Trapezostigma, which should be treated as a synonym of Tramea (Dijkstra et al. 2005).

Many subspecies of R. phyllis have been recognised at various times and places: R. p. apicalis Kirby, 1889, R. p. beatricis Lieftinck, 1942, R. p. chloe Kirby, 1894, R. p. dispar Brauer, 1867, R. p. ixias Lieftinck, 1953, R. p. marginata Ris, 1913, R. p. obscura Selys 1878, R. p. snelleni Selys, 1878, R. p. subphyllis Selys, 1882, R. p. vitellina Brauer, 1868; the whole complex needs revision.
Besides the nominate subspecies, two other subspecies are recognised, R. v. arria from China and Vietnam, and R. v. imperatrix from Japan.
A subspecies of Tramea eurybia, T. e. monticola Lieftinck, 1942 is known from altitudes above 1,600 m in central New Guinea.
The record of this species under Coenagrion castellanii from Morocco is definitely incorrect and is due to a confusion of either C. scitulum or C. caerulescens with C. mercuriale.
Genetic studies are in need for confirmation of the conspecificity of the Omanian (U. thomasi) and Somalian (U. t. aethiopica) populations.
The solitaria complex includes carpenteri, discrepans and mediofasciata. The taxonomy for this complex is not clear.
The species name is often misspelt as Diplacodes lefebvrei.
This species has been confused in the past with Lestes ochraceus and L. ictericus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
In Africa it is often confused with Orthetrum camerunense.
The paler subspecies falsum occurs in East Africa and parts of Southern Africa.
Subpopulations from Iraq and Kuwait have been ascribed to a poorly defined subspecies, Orthetrum trinacria igarashii Asahina, 1973. Its taxonomic status needs clarification.

Melanic insular subpopulations from the Anjouan island have been described as a distinct subspecies, Paragomphus genei ndzuaniensis Levasseur, 2007.
