As similar subpopulations are known in mainland Africa, more genetic research should be done before validating such subspecific division, which was done based on very weak criteria and without taking the variability of other subpopulations into account.
This widely distributed and abundant species is often misidentified and confused with similar taxa.

The small dark form, rusingae, occurs on the northern shores and islands of Lake Victoria.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group B.

The nominal subspecies is distributed in Africa south of the Sahara, the Nile Valley and in Sinai. A paler subspecies, Pseudagrion torridum hulae Dumont, 1974, is said to be restricted to the upper Jordan Valley (Dumont 1974, Dumont 1979, Schneider 1986, Schneider 1987). The only difference to specimens from the Nile and Sinai is their paler colouration, a variation also found in sub-Saharan subpopulations. As there are also no morphological differences, the Levantine subpopulations are no longer regarded as a distinct subspecies.

The nominotypical subspecies is restricted to Mauritius Islands and is defined by small dark patches at the base of the forewings and the dark area of the hindwings reaching the nodus. The subspecies Rhyothemis semihyalina separata (Selys, 1849) extends over the whole continental African and Arabian range of the species and is defined by forewings lacking dark patches at base (totally hyaline) and the dark area of the hindwings not reaching the nodus.

Another subspecies, R. s. syriaca (Selys, 1849) was described from the Jordan Valley, where it was supposedly endemic (and is now extinct), and was defined by a dark area at the base of hindwings which do not reach the nodus and where the last row of cells on the posterior wing margin remains hyaline.

Such criteria used for subspecific separation are very weak and lack of true statistical basis, and there is some evidences that individuals from Gabon, Namibia and Madagascar may show a dark patch at the base of forewings and a dark area in hindwings reaching or not the nodus (i.e. <http://www.africa-dragonfly.net/pics/a488/P1010356.jpg>, Pinhey 1962, Suhling and Martens 2007). That suggests a stronger intraspecific variability than initially expected. 

Therefore, most researchers do not retain this subspecific splitting, which is unlikely in such nomadic species, and further genetic study throughout this species range is needed.
This species is sometimes placed in Trapezostigma, which is a synonym of Tramea.

Libellula haematina Rambur, 1842, described from Senegal and Madagascar, and claimed to be occurring in La Réunion, Mauritius and Sicily, represents the infraspecific variability and cannot be accepted as a valid taxon despite the treatment published by Ris (1912).
Trithemis jacksoni is a synonym (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The occurrence of Trithemis furva in west Africa is uncertain due to possible confusion with T. pruinata, which appears commoner in the west but rarer in the east and south Africa.

The former splitting into a nominotypical form and a subspecies Trithemis kirbyi ardens (Gerstäcker, 1891) is currently challenged because of different opinions on biogeographic interpretation in the distribution of phenotypes.

The subspecies Urothemis edwardsii hulae Dumont, 1975, described from the upper Jordan Valley, falls within the variation range of the African and Arabian subpopulations (Samraoui et al. 1993) and is no longer recognized as valid.

It is occasionally misspelt as Zygonyx torrida, from its former name, Pseudomacromia torrida.

Specimens from Mauritius have been described as a distinct subspecies, Zygonyx torridus insulanus (sub Z. torrida insulana) by Pinhey (1981), based on their smaller size and the occurrence of a yellow tinge on all wings in three males only. However, Jacquemin and Boudot (1999) specified that two males from Mauritius and a third from La Réunion islands agree perfectly in size and wing colour (fully hyaline) with the nominotypical subspecies. Similarly, specimens from India, which have been doubtfully ascribed to a distinct subspecies, Zygonyx torridus isis (sub Zygonyx isis, then Z. torrida isis) by Fraser (1924, 1926) on the basis of their faint yellow suffused wings in six males and without any comparison with the African subpopulations. This poorly defined taxon is in need of re-evaluation.
Sympetrum nigrifemur (from the Canaries and Madeira) is considered a subspecies of S. striolatum.

Until 2004, Erythromma lindenii was placed in the genus Cercion although Heidemann and Seidenbusch (1993) had already suggested that the species should be placed in Erythromma based on larval characters. It was not until Weekers and Dumont (2004) confirmed this idea with a DNA-study that this was widely accepted.
Sometimes the subspecies kocheri is recognised.
Locally hybridizes with Ischnura elegans.
Philonomon luminans is junior synonym to Diplacodes luminans (Dijkstra 2006).

Brachythemis leucosticta (Burmeister, 1839) was recently split in two distinct cryptic species (Dijkstra and Matushkina 2009), with B. impartita (Karsch, 1890) occurring from the south of Europe and northern Africa to central Africa, and the true B. leucosticta from the Sahel to South Africa. Both species overlap over a large part of central Africa.
Pinhey (1969) made superba Schmidt, 1951 a subspecies of marshalli Ris, 1921. Recently Dijkstra and Clausnitzer (in prep.) treat superba as a valid species again.
Bott (1955) treated this taxon as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) didieri (Rathbun, 1904). It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes amalerensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) emini emini. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) treated this species as Potamonautes emini.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Gerdalopotamonautes) gerdalensis. Cumberlidge (1998) and Reed and Cumberlidge (2006) referred to it as Potamonautes gerdalensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) emini emini. It is treated here as the valid species Potamonautes mutandensis.

Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Acanthothelphusa) niloticus (H. Milne Edwards, 1837). This species is treated here as Potamonautes niloticus following the opinion of by Cumberlidge (1997, 1998).

The former Brachythemis leucosticta (Burmeister, 1839) was split in two distinct cryptic species (Dijkstra and Matushkina 2009), with B. impartita (Karsch, 1890) occurring from the south of Europe and northern Africa to central Africa, and the true B. leucosticta from the Sahel to South Africa. Both species overlap over a large part of central Africa.
Previously confused with numerous Platycnemis species.
Platycnemis nyansana Förster, 1916 and P. xanthopus Navás, 1924 are possible synonyms.
Gomphidia balii Fraser, 1949 is possibly a synonym.
Anonconotus occidentalis Carron and Wermeille, 2002 was previously considered a subspecies of Anonconotus baracunensis (Eames et al. 2015).

Crocothemis sanguinolenta was first recorded from the Dead Sea by Morton (1924), based on three males in Ris' collection. Based on these specimens and new records, Schneider (1982) described the subspecies arabica. With more material at hand Dijkstra and Dingemanse (2000) found out that characters used to separate Levantine subpopulations fall within the variation of the nominal (African) form and concluded that arabica is not a valid subspecies.
Diplacodes okavangoensis is a synonym to D. deminuta (Dijkstra 2007).
This species was previously often confused with G. villosa (see Dijkstra 2005).
The name of this species is often misspelt as P. subfurcatum.

Former records of Kenya correspond to P. niloticum. Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group B.
Subspecies bicoerulans is in central Kenya, elgonensi is in west Kenya and east Uganda, and kilimanjaricus is in north Tanzania.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.
The holotype of P. glaucum pertains to the species known as P. basicornu (Dijkstra unpubl.).

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.
Kenyan records have formerly been confused with Pseudagrion massaicum.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group B.
Pseudagrion risi rufocinctum is a synonym.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species is part of group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". P. sjoetedti is a B-group species.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group A.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". Pseudagrion sudanicum is a B group species.
Gomphidia madi is considered as a pale variation of G. bredoi (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Regarded as Hemicordulia asiatica Selys, 1878 but according to Dijkstra (pers. comm.) this is a separate species. There are major taxonomic uncertainties around this taxon.
This species has been confused in the past with Lestes ochraceus and L. pallidus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
Confused in the past with L. ictericus and L. pallidus (Gambles 1976) and records must be revised carefully.
This species is often mixed up with L. africanus, of which the systematic status remains unclear.

The whole genus Microgomphus is very elusive and this is why only a few specimens have ever been collected. The taxonomy is still not settled and Microgomphus schoutedeni might pertain to M. nyassicus, which will become the nominate species.
Notogomphus speciosus (Sjöstedt, 1909) is a possible synonym.
The species was assigned to the genus Roeseliana (from Metrioptera) by Song et al. (2015).

Owing to its poor description, the true identity of Paragomphus alluaudi (Martin, 1915) has remained unclear. Dijkstra & Clausnitzer (in prep.) consider a species occurring in the border region of Kenya and Tanzania as the true P. alluaudi.
A dark form, P. nguelicus, occurs in southern Africa. The taxonomy of the cognatus group of Paragomphus is unresolved and in urgent need of a throughout revision.
Phyllogomphus orientalis Fraser, 1957 is a possible synonym.

According to J. Marshall (NHM) Gryllotalpa major should be transferred to Neocurtilla major. But this has not been adopted in the USA and is not accepted on the Orthoptera World List. So changed back again to Gryllotalpa (was under Neocurtilla for the 2000-2002 Red Lists).
The name is often misspelt as H. albipuncta.

Malgassophlebia bispina is in central, eastern and southern Africa, and subspecies M. longistipes is in north Zambia. In western Africa it is widespread, somewhat variable and rarely collected. Therefore, several synonyms exist and no subspecies should be recognised (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The paler subspecies N. auricolor occurs in Uganda.
This species is seriously confused with O. stemmale.
This species is often confused with O. caffrum.
This species is seriously confused with O. brachiale.
The Ugandan specimen seems to be a new species.
Palpopleura portia, often considered a form of P. lucia, was proven to be a good species (Mitchell and Samways 2005).
Palpopleura portia, often considered a form or subspecies of P. lucia, was proven to be a good species (Mitchell and Samways 2005).
Dijkstra (2003) discusses the synonymy.

The confusing taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2005). Phyllomacromia nyanzana (Grünberg, 1911); ?P. bifasciata Martin, 1912. The female holotype seems to be miss-matched to the male holotype contumax, so melania may be something distinct (funicularia-like), while "contumax" takes priority over the whole nyanzana-bifasciata-complex.
The complex synonymy is discussed by Dijkstra (2005).
This is often treated as a subspecies of Rhyothemis notata, but the two occur alongside each other in western Africa.
Rhyothemis fenestrina is a good species and not a subspecies of R. notata (Dijkstra unpubl.).
The shape of the epiproct varies and this species therefore has two synonyms (Dijkstra 2007).

Lieftinck (1969) reported Thermochoria jeanneli disjunctly from Katanga, and Ris (1919) recorded “form b” of T. equivocata, which clearly refers to latter population. Under T. equivocata (Pinhey 1984) called “Ris forma “b” […] locally common in Malawi, Zambia and Shaba”. These records must refer to T. jeanneli. Specimens from West Tanzania in RMNH published by Pinhey and Pinhey (1984) as T. equivocata indeed pertain to T. jeanneli.

The records of Trithemis donaldsoni from western Africa and Yemen have been recently ascribed to T. dejouxi Pinhey, 1978 (Dijkstra 2007), which is its sister species (Dijkstra et al. 2010). Both species may be easily confounded and their respective range is still unclear and needs further studies.

The subspecies T. grouti atra is from central Africa. Trithemis grouti has priority over T. atra by two months (Pinhey 1984). This correction has sometimes been overlooked (e.g., Legrand 2003). All records of T. nuptialis in western Africa probably pertain to this species.

Trithemis imitata Pinhey, 1961 and T. monardi Ris, 1931 are very similar species, with rather relative differences in markings. Their taxonomy needs to be resolved in a geographic perspective. Most T. imitata and T. monardi records appear to be from north and south of the equator, respectively.
Records from western Africa probably follow confusion with T. grouti. This has been confirmed by V. Clausnitzer for the records from Sierra Leone.
This species is easily confused with T. furva, which appears more common in the east and south but rarer in the west of Africa.
Subpopulations in the northern Kalahari basin that have been formerly identified as T. stictica are now known as a separate species.
This genus was recently revised: Sympetrum navasi is junior synonym to Tritherum navasi (Dijkstra and Pilgrimm 2007).

This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Saga campbelli by Kaltenbach (1967) and it was later established as a distinct species based on genetic markers by Kolics et al.(2012). According to M. Lemonnier-Darcemont pers. comm. 2015, there is proof of the synonymy between S. gracilis and S. campbelli.

Pseudagrion is likely to be split into two genera at some point. Until this taxonomic split occurs, the candidates for these two groups are highlighted by "group A" and "group B". This species belongs to group B.
This genus has been object of taxonomic changes: Olpogastra fuelleborni is junior synonym to Zygonoides fuelleborni (Dijkstra et al. 2006).

The taxonomy of Zygonyx fallax (Schouteden, 1934) and Z. flavicosta (Sjöstedt, 1900) is problematic, in part because the Z. fallax holotype (MRAC) is a female. Specimens from west Uganda differ slightly from typical Z. flavicosta, most clearly by the relative length of the epiproct, and have traditionally been identified as Z. fallax. Zygonyx fallax is treated as synonym to Z. flavicosta (not yet published).
Zygonyx ikomae is a synonym (Dijkstra unpubl.).
Zygonyx pretentiosus Fraser, 1957 and Z. chrysobaphes umbrosus Fraser, 1957 are possible synonyms.

Alosterna pauli Pesarini, Rapuzzi & Sabbadini, 2004 was described in the group of species related to A. anatolica Adlbauer, 1992 and A. tabacicolor (De Geer, 1775) (Adlbauer 1992, Pesarini and Sabbadini 2004). It differs from them on the basis of strong elements while the description paper gives precise drawings. Some mistakes remain in the documentation, like in Fauna Europaea where the description date is 2003 (De Jong et al. 2014) or wrong bibliographic reference for the description (Tavakilian and Chevillotte 2012).

Xestoleptura nigroflava (Fuss, 1852) is very close to the related Siberian species X. rufiventris (Gebler, 1830). For its original descriptions, Fuss (1852) probably did not know this species and did not provide a differential diagnosis (Kadlec and Hajek 2005). Therefore, many subsequent authors have considered the description to be a misinterpretation of another species: Evodinus borealis (Gyllenhal, 1827), Brachyta variabilis (Gebler, 1817), Brachyta borni (Ganglbauer, 1903) or Xestoleptura rufiventris. This last synonymy was largely accepted until now. However, Kadlec and Hajek (2005) collected a male near the Type locality, and have compared it with the Type specimen and with Siberian specimens of X. rufiventris. This has made it possible to strongly establish the true specific identity of X. nigroflava. This opinion is accepted by Danilevsky (2015).

Fabricius’ Entomologia systematica dedicated to Cerambycidae (first tome), was published in two parts with the date 1792 indicated on the title page of the first part. The second part was published in 1793 (Gaedike et al. 2012), not in 1792 as listed by authors. The correct name is Pidonia lurida (Fabricius, 1793: 343) (Danilevsky 2016).

The taxonomic position of the genus Schurmannia is unclear but is most probably a synonym of Alocerus, as Švácha and Danilevsky (1987) first confirmed the strong similarity between the larvae of A. moesiacus and S. sicula. Then Holzschuh (1995), proposed a new combination, Alocerus siculus, but this was not considered by subsequent authors.

Xylosteus caucasicola Plavilstshikov, 1936 is considered by Sama and Rapuzzi (1999), Sama (2002), and Löbl and Smetana (2010), as a subspecies of X. spinolae, while according to Miroshnikov (1998, pers. comm. 2016), and to Danilevsky (2016) this taxonomic transfer is unacceptable. Based on the review of dozens of specimens, Miroshnikov (1998) showed clear distinctive characters between the two taxa and confirmed the specific status of X. caucasicola. Sama and Rapuzzi (1999) replied that not enough specimens have been studied, especially specimens from south-eastern Europe that are viewed as transitional forms between spinolae and caucasicola. Here, X. caucasicola is considered as a good species, endemic to the Caucasus and the Krasnodar mountains. In Turkey, Miroshnikov (2000), described X. kadleci that could be a subspecies of X. caucasicola but more specimens are needed from Anatolia to confirm this hypothesis.
As this species is only known from the holotype, taxonomical work is required to confirm the status of this species.

Corticeus krueperi is only known by the type specimen and recorded only from Greece, without any locality (Obenberger 1922). It has not been recorded since and the type specimen hasn't been examined. This species could be a synonym of another European Corticeus species or could correspond to a foreign species due to mislabelling.

Corticeus rufithorax is probably a very rare Mediterranean form of Corticeus linearis. Described from Greece, without precision, the species has been recorded in the Balearic Islands. Among specimens of C. linearis living on Pinus halepensis collected in the French Mediterranean  and in Spain, some specimens could correspond to Corticeus rufithorax, and there seem to be intermediate specimens between both taxa in Spain (Espanol 1967). 

In spite of this, C. rufithorax Pic, 1903 has not been officially put in synonymy with C. linearis, including type examination and is considered as a valid species in Löbl et al. (2008), and we retain C. rufithorax as a valid species (F. Soldati, pers. comm. 2015).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The first edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III (Löbl and Smetana 2006) considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

The current edition of the Catalogue of Palaearctic Coleoptera Volume III considers all the genus-group names of Aphodiinae (Dellacasa and Dellacasa 2006) at subgenus rank. In the next edition of the Catalogue in prep., all the subgenera will be raised to genus rank (M. Dellacasa and S. Ziani pers. comm. 2014).

A number of taxa, originally described as separate species, are generally treated as subspecies or junior synonyms of A. rubescens, for instance: A.intermedia Selys, 1877, A. lunulata Selys, 1877, A. nigricans Selys, 1877, A. obscura Laidlaw, 1914, A. rubeola Selys, 1877. It is likely that some of the subspecies and supposed junior synonyms will ultimately prove to be distinct species.
This species was described as a new species by Theischinger and O’Farrell (1986) from material previously placed under Austroargiolestes alpinus (Tillyard) by Fraser (1960).
Dromoaeschna forcipata was previously placed in Austroaeschna.
Macromia amymone Lieftinck, 1952, described from New Guinea (Lieftinck 1952) is now considered a junior synonym of Macromia viridescens (Moulds 1979).
Nososticta pilbara was originally described as a subspecies of N. solida in Watson (1969) and later elevated to a full species in Watson (1974).
The species was recognized and described by Theischinger (1999), from material attributed to Petalura gigantea.

The status of Petalura pulcherrima as a species distinct from P. ingentissima Tillyard has been questioned; for instance see Theischinger and Endersby (2009: 249-250). To-date molecular studies (e.g. Ware et al. 2014) have, if anything, made the situation less clear and it is difficult to determine whether many specimens are best treated as P. pulcherrima, P. ingentissima or even as some other as-yet-unnamed species.

Two subspecies of Rhyothemis princeps have been recognised, the nominate subspecies is known from Australia, with a few records from the south of New Guinea. Rhyothemis princeps irene is known only from New Guinea. Additionally there are some records where the subspecies, or even species, is not clear. Kaize and Kalkman (2011) list R. princeps from Vriendschap is Asmat district in south Papua, Indonesia; presumably this record refers to R. p. princeps since that subspecies was already recorded from Asmat, but this is not stated. Kaize and Kalkman (2009) recorded R. princeps/R. regia from other locations in southern Papua; I do not know to which species these records actually refer.

A number of subspecies of Tetrathemis irregularis are recognised. The nominate subspecies occurs in the Philippines and Sulawesi, T. i. cladophila Tillyard, 1908 occurs in Queensland and has been recorded in the Aru Islands, T. i. dives Ris, 1913 and T. i. papuensis Lieftinck, 1942 occur in New Guinea and T. irregularis hyalina Kirby 1889 occurs in Sundaland and mainland Asia. T.i. dives has also been recorded in the Torres Straits Islands between New Guinea and Australia (but politically part of Australia). Gassmann & Richards 2011 recorded T. i. ?irregularis from East New Britain, it seems unlikely that T. i. irregularis is actually present in the Bismarck Islands, but it is not known which, if any, of the recognised subspecies that this record actually refers to.
Of the subspecies, T. i. hyalina is almost certainly a separate species, but it has not yet been formally separated from T. irregularis so they are treated together here. Some or all of the others may actually be separate species as well.
Austroargiolestes icteromelas is considered to fall into two subspecies, A. i. icteromelas from the southern part of the species range, and A. i. nigrolabiatus from the northern part.
This species was described as Argiolestes griseus albescens Tillyard, 1913
This species was described as Argiolestes griseus eboracus Tillyard, 1913
This species was described as Argiolestes griseus intermedius Tillyard, 1913.
Agriocnemis thoracalis was described from a single imperfect specimen and it is not known if it is the same as some other species described before or since.

Hemicordulia novaehollandiae was inadequately described from a specimen from “Nouvelle-Hollande” said to be in the Museum of St. Petersburg, and never subsequently examined or interpreted. Tillyard (1911: 371) stated that “nothing certain can be gathered about this species (unless, indeed, as seems very probable, H. continentalis Martin, is synonymous with it)”.
In older literature Urothemis aliena is often referred to as a subspecies of U. signata (Rambur, 1842).
Two subspecies have been recognised, aside from the nominate one: Synlestes w. nigrescens Tillyard, 1917 and S. w. tillyardi Fraser, 1948.
A subspecies (Eusynthemis brevistyla subjuncta) Tillyard, 1913 is recognized by some authorities.
Tillyard (1913) described a subspecies Eusynthemis guttata aurolineata Tillyard, 1913, this is now recognized as a full species E. aurolineata.

Doubts about the identity of material from South Australia and from the Grampians in Victoria previously considered to be S. eustalacta have been raised and need further investigation (G. Thesischinger pers. comm).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This species was originally described as Boreas uglowi Cumberlidge & Sternberg, 2002. However, this genus name proved to be occupied, so the taxon was given the replacement name of Boreathelphusa uglowi (Cumberlidge & Sternberg, 2002) by Cumberlidge (2010).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Hydrothelphusinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Hydrothelphusa goudoti H. Milne-Edwards, 1853. It is now valid in the genus Foza (Cumberlidge and Meyer 2009).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).
This genus was recently transferred to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Hydrothelphusini by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

This species was originally identified from Jeongseon, Republic of Korea, under the name of Galloisiana biryongensis Namkung, 1974. It was later recombined as Namkungia biryongensis Storozhenko & Park, 2002.
This species was originally identified from Jeongseon, Republic of Korea, under the name of Galloisiana magnus Namkung, 1986. It was later recombined as Namkungia magnus by Kim and Lee (2006).

In 1985, Sláma described Brachyleptura martini from Crete. However, the name was preoccupied by Leptura semirufula var. martini (Pic, 1945) described from Madrid, and thereafter synonym of Stictoleptura trisignata (Fairmaire, 1852). So, when Brachyleptura was included in the new genus Stictoleptura, the species of Sláma was changed to S. slamai Sama, 2010.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
The genus Tatocnemis needs revision.
The genus Nesolestes needs revision.

Leptorhabdium illyricum was described by Kraatz in 1871 based on specimens coming from the central Balkans, without precise localities. For a long time, the species remained mysterious and hidden since the literature only discussed taxonomy, without adding information about localities or biology. In 1986, Ohbayashi and Shimomura gave precise drawings for all those species. Then, Sama (1993) confirmed taxonomical choices after a study of the type specimens in Pic and Kraatz's collections. Therefore, he fixed the taxonomy among the European Leptorhabdium-Xylosteus group. That taxonomy is followed here.

The status of this species has been uncertain ever since it was described, with authors going backwards and forwards frequently on whether it is part of B. balteatus or a separate species. This species was recently split from Bombus balteatus as evidenced by gene coalescents by Williams et al. (2015). Bombus balteatus is restricted to the European and Asian continents, and Bombus kirbiellus is restricted to North America. Thorp et al. (1983) treated the California population of this species as B. balteatus.

This species has been separated from Bombus hyperboreus as evidenced by gene coalescents by Williams et al. (2015). Bombus hyperboreus is restricted to the European and Asian continents, and Bombus natvigi is restricted to North America and Greenland.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.There are currently at least five recognised subspecies: the nominate subspecies tithonus; subspecies waigeuensis Rothschild, 1897; misresiana (Joicey & Noakes, 1916); misoolana (Deslisle, 1985); and dominici Schäffler, 2001. There are another two possible subspecies, cytherea (Kobayashi & Koiwaya, 1980) and makikoae Morita, 1998 (in Schaeffler 2001). Subspecies cytherea was also recognised by Ohya (2001) as a subspecies of O. tithonus.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

The correct year of description for S. hybridula is 1902. In the indicated publication of 1901, for example, as given in Löbl and Smetana (2010), Reitter did not mention this species. It was described by him in the volume two of the Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift 1901, published in January 1902 (Danilevsky 2012, Özdikmen 2013).

Recently Rössner and Fery (2014) in their revision of Biralus species had redefined the distribution of B. mahunkaorum, thus the western localities formerly ascribed to B. satellitius could be referred to B. mahounkaorum and need to be checked.
Genus Lokia is most likely a synonym to Aethiothemis (Dijkstra unpublished).
Ceriagrioni platystigma was removed from synonymy with C. varians by Dijkstra et al. (2015).
Dijkstra et al. (2015) revalidated Gynacantha victoriae as a separate species, removing it from synonymy with G. bullata.
Very likely some of the subpopulations will have to be treated as new species in the future.
known from both sexes, illustrated.
Known from both sexes, illustrated.
Modern taxonomical research should reevaluate the potential species status of a population from Fiji and neighbour islands called Nephila tetragnathoides, here deemed as conspecific with N. plumides.
Originally, Elattoneura lindleyi was described as a wholly black subspecies of the reddish E. acuta, but now it is considered a good species.

Anonyxmolytes lilliput is the only species of the genus Anonyxmolytes, which is restricted to the Hon Chong limestone hills (Meregalli and Osella 2007), possibly extending into nearby areas in Cambodia (Deharveng pers. comm). It is well characterized within the subfamily Molytinae, and unique among Curculionidae by the extreme reduction of its tarsi. It is a blind species of low vagility, associated with deep soil, and highly specialized, probably very sensitive to change in the habitat conditions (deforestation, changes in the water-content of the soil, etc.). It is possibly related to a Japanese genus, and appears to be a relict taxon of high phylogenetic and biogeographic interest (Meregalli, Pers. Comm.).

The genus Delamarephorura contains few species and occurs in Africa and in Viet Nam (Janion et al. 2013). Delamarephorura tami is one of the two Vietnamese species of the genus in Viet Nam, the other one being a littoral form described known from Binh Chau beach. The genus has so far not provided other species from Viet Nam, contrary to several other Tullbergiidae genera.
Eustra honchongensis belongs to a genus including species which are all rare and narrowly endemic in Southeast Asia (Deuve, 1996).

Lepidonella lecongkieti is the only species of the tropical genus Lepidonella known to be cave-restricted. It exhibits clear troglomorphic traits and is the only cave Paronellidae known from Viet Nam so far (Deharveng & Bedos, 1995).

Eutrichodesmus griseus belongs to a genus that includes a large number of species in Southeast Asia, mostly in caves and all narrow endemics. It is unusual morphologically compared to its congeners, because of its greyish coloration. E. griseus is the only species of the genus in the Hon Chong region (Golovatch et al., 2009).

Gnomulus bedoharvengorum is a species of the large Indo-Malayan genus Gnomulus. The Hon Chong species is biologically of interest because of its occurrence in caves and rarer occurrence in surface litter under bushes, while most other species of the genus live in rainforest litter. It appears as a relictual form in this respect.

Isometrus deharvengi belongs to the rather large genus Isometrus, which is known from Vietnam and surrounding countries by several species (Lourenço & Duhem, 2010). All species of the genus except one have reduced distribution areas. The presence of I. deharvengi in caves is unusual for the genus Isometrus, though the species is not troglomorphic.

Folsomides sp. nov. 'HC - blind' is a new undescribed species of Isotomidae Collembola. The genus Folsomides is poorly diversified in the tropics, but its three widespread are possibly the most abundant pantropical Collembola. The presence of a blind and well characterized species in a cave of Hon Chong was quite unexpected.


Species under description by Louis Deharveng and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (3 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris

Microblattellus lecongmani is a remarkable species, the only species of the genus Microblattellus. The new tribe Falsocossyphini was erected to accomodate it together with two other monospecific genera (Ferrer 2006). The unusual morphology of those species casts doubts on the monophyly of this tribe, but not on the originality of the species it includes (Bremer & Lillig 2014). It has therefore to be considered as one of the most remarkable endemic species of Hon Chong, and a major issue regarding biodiversity conservation, though the species is less strongly threatened than many others from the Hon Chong-Kampot karst.

Species under description by Louis Deharveng, Marko Lukic and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (6 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris.

Acrocyrtus sp. nov. 'HC - blind' is a new undescribed species of Entomobryidae Collembola provisionally assigned to the genus Acrocyrtus. This genus is widespread and well diversified in Southeast Asia, and has several new species in the Hon Chong area. A. sp. nov. 'HC - blind' would be the only blind and the only troglobitic species of the genus
The species is the first representative of the genus Sumatrillo outside Sumatra from where two species are known, and the only troglomorphic species of Oniscidea (blind and unpigmented) in Hon Chong.
Blasconura batai is the only known Vietnamese species of the large Southeast Asian genus Blasconura (Bedos & Deharveng, 2000).

scientificName: Burmoniscus sp. nov. 'HC - first segment white'
taxonomicNotes: Species under description by Stefano Taiti and Giovanna Monticelli Cardoso (May 2016), vouchers in Firenze (1 specimen), and 2 specimens to be deposited in MNHN Paris (Taiti 2016, pers. comm.).

Species under description by Louis Deharveng and Anne Bedos, vouchers in MNHN Paris (6 specimens), to be deposited in Ho Chi Minh City University and MNHN Paris.

Ceratophysella sp. nov. 'HC' is a new undescribed species of Hypogastruridae Collembola, assumed to be related to temperate region species of the genus. Its is a remarkable relict restricted to one cave of the Hon Chong hills, and the only non-guanobitic cave Hypogastruridae known from the tropics.
Plusioglyphiulus boutini belongs to a genus that includes a large number of species in Southeast Asia, living mostly on bat guano in caves. Most species are narrow endemics (Golovatch et al. 2009).
This species was described as Synthemis macrostigma occidentalis Tillyard, 1910.
This species was described as Synthemis macrostigma orientalis Tillyard, 1910.
Austropetalia anneliese is known from a single female specimen, and was treated as A. patricia until it was recognised as a separate species (Theischinger 2013).
Placed within the subgenus Petrochilosina. The species name was erroneously spelled 'octhoniai' in the title, abstract and discussion of the describing paper (Alexiou et al. 2015).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.
The species was previously considered a subspecies of O. paradisea, due to morphological similarities (D'Abrera 2003). This species currently has two valid subspecies: the nominate subspecies meridionalis and subspecies tarunggarensis (Joicey & Talbot, 1927). Subspecies tarunggarensis has sometimes been considered as a subspecies of paradisea instead of meridionalis, based on external characters such as wing patterns (Hancock 1982, 1991); however, on basis of genitalia, the subspecies is thought to belong to meridionalis (Darby 1985).

Previous authors considered between two and nine potential subspecies of this species: Rothschild (1904) considered two subspecies (goliath and procus) while Szent-Ivany (1975) considered nine subspecies or races in total. However, D'Abrera (1975a) noted the evidence for a cline in female morphology in the species and synonymised seven subspecies with O. goliath  as a result. We accept this here as correct, although there has been suggestion that at least one of these taxa may require more research to establish its status.
This species currently has six recognised subspecies: the nominate subspecies goliath Oberthür, 1888; subspecies procus Rothschild, 1914; subspecies atlas Rothschild, 1908; subspecies samson (Niepelt, 1913); subspecies supremus Röber, 1896; and subspecies ukihidei Hanafusa, 1994. A sixth subspecies, sorongensis Morita & Sugiyama, 1998, is likely a junior synonym of subspecies atlas.

The taxonomy of this species is complex. Authors list between 14 and 19 distinct subspecies for this species (e.g. Common and Waterhouse 1972, Matsuka 2001). For the purpose of this assessment, we treat the following 13 taxa as valid subspecies of this species: admiralitatis;  arruana; boisduvali; bornemanni; caelestis; demophanes; hecuba; macalpinei; miokensis; poseidon; priamus; pronomus; and urvillianus.
Some authors (e.g. Parsons 1999) suggest Ornithoptera croesus to be a distinctive subspecies of O. primaus, for example based on the extreme similarity between early life stages of the two taxa (Igarashi 1979, Parsons 1999). Here, we treat Ornithoptera croesus as a separate species following Parrot and Schmid (1984) and Hancock (1991). Similarly, some authors treat the Richmond birdwing Ornithoptera richmondia as a subspecies of Ornithoptera priamus; however, we treat the Richmond birdwing a separate species, again following Hancock (1991). Additionally, Ornithoptera euphorion has been argued to be a subspecies of this species; however, both Ornithoptera richmondia and O. euphorion appear to be closer phylogenetically to Ornithoptera croesus than to Ornithoptera priamus (Hancock 1991). This evidence is the basis for us treating O. euphorion  as a distinct species as discussed by a number of authors (e.g. Hancock 1983, Hancock and Orr 1997, Kondo et al. 2003). Other authors recognise additional subspecies, e.g. subspecies leucrus from Biak Island, which we treat here as part of the subspecies poseidon. Subspecies urvillianus was formerly regarded as a separate species, but is here also treated as a subspecies of Ornithoptera priamus.

During the 1985 Swallowtail assessment, the taxonomic status of this species was uncertain as it was previously regarded as a subspecies of O. priamus (McCubbin 1971, Common and Waterhouse 1972, Haugum and Low 1979). The species was assessed, however, on the grounds that Hancock (1983) considered it to be a distinct species. Uncertainty continues, with some authorities placing the species under O. priamus (e.g. Matsuka 2001), while others treat it as a distinct species (Common and Waterhouse 1981, Braby 2000).

There are six (Haugum and Low 1979) to eight subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies victoriae; regis Rothschild, 1895; archeri (Calderara, 1984); isabellae (Rothschild & Jordan, 1901); reginae (Salvin, 1888); rubianus Rothschild, 1904; epiphanes (Schmid, 1970, in Schaeffler 2001); and maramasikensis Morita, 2000 (in Schaeffler 2001).

Haugum and Low (1982) recognise five subspecies: albescens (Malay Peninsula north to Thailand and Myanmar), trogon (Sumatra and adjacent islands, and Johor), cardinaali (Lingga Islands), natunensis (Natuna Islands), and the nominate subspecies brookiana (Borneo). Another subspecies, mollumar, is cited by some authors but is considered to be subspecies trogon by others (Kirton 2014).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species.

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species. Troides dohertyi is sometimes treated as a subspecies of T. rhadamantus: separation of the two taxa is based on differences in coloration and may not be justified (Matsuka 2001, in Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).

Two subspecies are known for this species: the nominate subspecies criton; and subspecies critonides (Fruhstorfer, 1903). Additional subspecies sometimes reported from the Sulawesi region (celebensis and selayarensis) are considered to be hybrids of Troides helena x T. haliphron (in Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).
There are three subspecies currently reported for this species (Ohya 2001): the nominate subspecies cuneifera; subspecies sumatranus (Hagen, 1894); and subspecies paeninsulae (Pendlebury, 1936).

There are between twelve and fourteen recognised subspecies for this species (e.g., Matsuka 2001, Ohya 2001): here we consider the nominate subspecies haliphron; subspecies naias (Doherty, 1891); subspecies pallens (Oberthür, 1897); subpecies pistor Rothschild, 1896; subspecies purahu Kobayashi, 1987; subspecies bellwoni Neukirchen, 1993, subspecies ariadne, subspecies heptanonius (considered by some authors to be part of ariadne); subspecies rikyu, subspecies iris, and subspecies ikarus. 
The local from socrates from Timor Island is considered at the subspecific level by some authors (e.g. Ohya 2001). We follow Haeuser et al. 2012 and treat subspecies staudingeri as a full species (assessed as Troides staudingeri).

This species was previously treated under its own genus, Ripponia, by Haugum and Low (1982). However, both adults and early stages show no major morphologcial differences from the other Troides, to which it now belongs. Haugum and Low (1982) considered three subspecies, although now up to five subspecies are accepted (Collins and Morris 1985, Matsuka 2001, Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003): the nominate subspecies hypolitus; subspecies antiopa Rothschild, 1908; subspecies cellularis Rothschild, 1895; subspecies sulaensis (Staudinger, 1895); and subspecies caelicola Haugum & Low, 1982. Ohya (2001) only recognised four subspecies: cellularis, sulaensis, antiopa, and hypolitus. Morisode (2005) reported the description of a new subspecies, sangirensis from Sangir Islands in Indonesia; however this is not consistently recognized in taxonomic databases, and is here considered to be likely subspecies cellularis.
There are two subspecies reported for this species: the nominate subspecies magellanus, and subspecies sonani (Matsumura, 1931).
There are three subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies miranda; subspecies neomiranda (Fruhstorfer, 1903); and subspecies hayamii Kobayashi, 1991.

Between five and eight subspecies are reported for this species, depending on author: five are listed by Zeuner (1943), seven by Haugum and Low (1985) and eight by Rumbucher and von Knoetgen (including subspecies ilonae Schäffler, 1999 and subspecies cyclop (Rumbucher & Schäffler, 2005)). Here, we recognise six subspecies: the nominate subspecies oblongomaculatus; subspecies hanno Fruhstorfer, 1904; subspecies bouruensis (Wallace, 1865); papuensis (Wallace, 1865); thestius (Staudinger, 1896); and subspecies bandensis Pagenstecher, 1904. A rare form of the species found in Sulawesi is sometimes reported by some authors (e.g. Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003); this may be a form of T. helena affected by introgression from T. haliphron (Hancock 1983b) or a relict race of uncertain status (Haugum and Low 1983) and is not considered here, since there appears to be much consensus that the species does in fact not exist on Sulawesi (e.g. Vane-Wright and De Jong 2003).
On LepIndex, the species is listed under the name Troides oblongomaculus.
This species is sometimes considered to be a subspecies of Troides haliphron; however, based on study of its genitalia, Haugum and Low (1983) consider this to be a good species.
Troides plateni is considered by some to be a subspecies of T. rhadamantus (Ohya 2001); however, here we follow Haeuser et al. (2012) and consider T. plateni as a good species in its own right.

This species is sometimes listed as a subspecies of Troides hypolitus (e.g. Ohya 2001). Here, we follow Haeuser et al. (2012) and consider Troides staudingeri as a good species.
This species consists of six subspecies: Troides staudingeri staudingeri (Röber, 1888), T. s. iris (Röber, 1888), T. s. ariadne Rothschild, 1908, T. s. heptanonius (Fruhstorfer, 1913), T. s. ikarus Fruhstorfer, 1904 and T. s. rikyu Arima & Morimoto, 1991.
This species consists of three subspecies: Troides vandepolli vandepolli (Snellen, 1890); T. v. honrathiana (Martin, [1893]); T. v. parrottei Deslisle, 1989.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List under the incorrect name of Procambarus riojai. It has now been corrected to Procambarus riojae. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this change.
This species was moved from the genus Procambarus to Fallicambarus following Ainscough et al. (2013).

This species appeared on the IUCN Red List until 2016 as Geocharax gracilis Clark, 1936. The name has been updated to Geocharax tasmanicus (Erichson, 1846) as this takes priority. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this change.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List under the incorrect name of Astacoides madagascariensis. It has now been corrected to Astacoides madagascarensis. An updated Red List assessment has been created to reflect this change.

The genus Nesolestes may be a synonym of Neurolestes (Gambles 1970). Similar specimens from adjacent Cameroon may pertain to another species (Vick unpubl). The original 2009 Red List assessment included this species in Nesolestes. In 2017, it was moved to genus Neurolestes.

The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful. It is known from the dubious female type only, collected in 1818 on Rodrigues. A second Argiocnemis record from 1918 without identification to the species level is reported by Campion (1923).
Brock (1999) placed the species in the monospecific genus of Pseudobactricia of which it is the type species.
The species Zeuneriana amplipennis occurs in the eastern Balkans. As the species is morphologically quite similar to Z. marmorata, the status of both species needs to be studied.

Harvengia vietnamita is a remarkable blind species, very isolated phyletically, for which the genus Harvengia and the subtribe Harvengina has been erected (Ferrer 2004). It has therefore to be considered as one of the most remarkable endemic species of Hon Chong, and a major issue regarding biodiversity conservation. Further taxonomic analyses are needed to decide if the subpopulation in the northern hills are distinct of those from the southern hill from where holotype was described. For now they are considered the same species.

Redman et al. (2003) described two species groups for Zinophora: munda group (brevilobata, diplodonta, junodi, munda, laminata, sabulosa and similis); and gracilis group (brevispina, gracilis, slotowi, levis, mudenensis, ochropygialis, pearlae, punctata and thukela).

Cryptotettix macrophthalmus probably belongs to the genus Rhynchotettix (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).
Holocerus taurus is probably a junior synonym of H. lucifer. The data for H. taurus is therefore considered in this assessment.
Holocerus taurus is probably a junior synonym of H. lucifer. The data for H. taurus is therefore considered in the assessment of H. lucifer.

The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied and compared with other Pterotettix species. It is currently not clear whether it represents a synonym or a unique species (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).

The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied and compared with other Pterotettix species. It is currently not clear whether it represents a synonym or a unique species (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).

The taxonomy of this species needs to be studied and compared with other Pterotettix species. It is currently not clear whether it represents a synonym or a unique species (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).

This species was originally described in Epitadas. Günther (1939) placed it in Oxytettix, mentioning that there is only one character distinguishing both genera: being apterous against being macropterous. Devriese found more differences between both used the name Epitadas arius, but without discussion (Devriese 1991, H. Devriese pers. comm. 2016).

The Osmoderma species complex is here treated as five separate species (barnabita, eremita, cristinae, italica and lassallei), following Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). Distribution limits of these different forms remain poorly resolved, but for the purpose of these assessments we follow the approximate distribution limits outlined in Audisio et al. (2007, 2008). There is ongoing debate as to whether or not these forms constitute valid species, but for the purpose of this assessment we are assessing each form separately.
Catailopus klaptoczi Karny, 1917 is likely to be a synonym of this species (Mestre and Chiffaud 2006).

Two subspecies of this species are known: Chorthippus changbaishanensis changbaishanensis and Chorthippus changbaishanensis longipennis (Lu et al. 2012). The latter is likely to be the macropterous morph of the former subspecies.
Several authors have stated that this species is likely to belong in a different genus, including Bhowmik (1986).
This species is likely to be a synonym of Trachyrhachys kiowa or Mestobregma plattei (D. Lightfoot and D. Fergusan pers. comm. 2018). A comparison of the type material is necessary.

The species is only known from a singly type specimen, so that information on intraspecific variability is missing. A thorough study of more specimens from the type locality and comparison with other Pseudoceles species, particularly P. ledereri and P. ebneri, is required to clarify its status.
This species needs to be taxonomically studied and compared with material of other Australian grasshoppers (D. Rentz, pers. comm. 2018).
The species consists of numerous subspecies. The taxonomy is in need of revision to clarify species delimitation and validity of subspecies.
The taxonomy of this species has not been studied in recent years. A detailed taxonomic study is needed to test whether it consists of several species (Macfarlane et al. 2010).

The species may belong to another genus (Gorochov 2016). As the record from Mt. Kalulong is based upon a female specimen (which are more difficult to distinguish), confirmation of its presence should be confirmed based upon a male specimen.
A proper taxonomic revision of the African Nemobiinae is needed. It is likely that there are many undescribed species occurring in Africa.

The genus Saussurella is in need of a taxonomic revision as the intraspecific variability in some traits that have been used in species descriptions is not well documented. It is possible that Saussurella acuticornis is a junior synonym of Saussurella decurva (J. Skejo, pers. comm. 2018).
The species is likely to belong in another genus (J. Skejo, pers. comm. 2018).
This species might belong to the genus Liara, subgenus Acanthocoryphus (S. Ingrisch 2018, pers. comm.).
This species may represent a species complex (D. Rentz, pers. comm. 2018). Therefore, more taxonomic work is needed.

This species has three subspecies, L. philippina ceramica from Seram Island, L. philippina mindanica from Mindanao and L. philippina philippina. Karny (1926) indicates that L. p. ceramica may represent a unique species. The genus is in need of taxonomic revision (M.K. Tan, pers. comm 2018).

The genus Ruspolia is in need of taxonomic revision. Ruspolia flavovirens has been described based upon a female, while it is likely that the male song is the best character to distinguish species of the genus. Genetic analyses of the genus are also lacking. Currently, it is likely that the species will become a nomina dubia unless the type specimen is sequenced and matched with males and their song recordings (P. Naskrecki, pers. comm. 2018).
The genus Torbia is in need of revision. It needs to be clarified whether T. costulata represents a synonym of another species or a good species (D. Rentz, pers. comm. 2018).
The genus Acrida is in need of taxonomic revision.
The genus Criotettix is in need of taxonomic revision.
According to Robillard and Desutter-Grandcolas (2013) this species does probably belong in another genus.
The genus Formosatettixoides is in need of taxonomic revision.
H. mauritiana from Mauritius may represent a synonym of this species (S. Hugel, pers. comm. 2019).
The taxonomic status of this species needs to be studied when males become available (Otte 1985).
As the type specimen is lost, the taxonomic status of the species is not clear.

Specimens from the Sahel differ morphologically slightly from those from the Congo. A DNA analysis is thus recommended to clarify the taxonomic status of these subpopulations (H. Devriese pers. comm. 2018).
Research should be undertaken to clarify the taxonomic status of the two disjunct subpopulations in Venezuela and Colombia, which differ slightly in morphology (Carbonell 2000).

The genus Quilta includes three species all occurring in the Indomalayan region. Q. oryzae and Q. mitrata are quite similar and have overlapping distribution areas. A taxonomic revision of Quilta would hep to clarify the exact status of both species.
The status of Sphingonotus arenarius has often been debated and Defaut (2005) suggested that it may represent a subspecies of Sphingonotus azurescens.
This species has two subspecies Staleochlora arcuata arcuata and Staleochlora arcuata iguazuensis.
This species is likely to belong to another genus (e.g. Crimisus) as the genus Tetrix is largely restricted to the Old World (J. Skejo, pers. comm. 2018).

It is not clear whether this species represents a single species or a species complex. Taxonomic research (using also molecular methods) is required to clarify this question (D. Rentz pers. comm. 2018).
In order to confirm its species status, a male needs to be collected and compared to those of other Typophyllum species as it might represent a synonym.

The female of D. penicillata was described from a single teneral (freshly emerged) female collected at a different site, albeit close to the site where the males were collected (van Tol 2007), at a significantly lower altitude; in these circumstances its association with the males cannot be considered to be completely definite.

Van Tol (2000) states “Not similar to any of the other Sulawesi platystictids here assigned to Protosticta. As indicated elsewhere, the correct generic assignment of this species has to await a generic revision of the Platystictidae. The general appearance is more similar to Drepanosticta, but its structural details studied so far are too generalized to postulate another generic position than Protosticta.”

Libellago celebensis is currently considered to have four subspecies: L. c. celebensis from the western part of Central Sulawesi, L. c. anoa from the north eastern part of South Sulawesi, L. c. dorsonigra from the north eastern part of South Sulawesi, and L. c. orientalis from the extreme eastern part of South Sulawesi, eastern part of Central Sulawesi and Southeast Sulawesi (van Tol 2007). Van Tol (2007) noted that “specimens collected around Lake Poso are distinctly intermediate between L. c. celebensis and L. c. orientalis. Further studies are needed to judge the status of these populations”. The same author also stated that L. c. anoa has “Superficially the same range as L. celebensis dorsonigra, but not recorded from the same sites”; this suggests that at least these two subspecies might be better treated as species distinct from each other.
A subspecies Diplacina militaris dumogae is recognised from the north of Sulawesi (van Tol 1987).
This species has not been seen since its original description.
According to Rosser Garrison, this species is a synonym of Argia tinctipennis.
This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but was reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 by Klaus et al. (2006) in the subfamily Parathelphusinae (see Klaus et al. 2010).
This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but was reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 by Klaus et al. (2006) in the subfamily Parathelphusinae (see Klaus et al. 2010).
This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but was reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 by Klaus et al. (2006) in the subfamily Parathelphusinae (see Klaus et al. 2010).
This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but was reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 by Klaus et al. (2006) in the subfamily Parathelphusinae (see Klaus et al. 2010).
This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae, but was reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae Rathbun, 1904 by Klaus et al. (2006) in the subfamily Parathelphusinae (see Klaus et al. 2010).

Seehausen and Günther (2016) comment on possible relationships between Neurothemis nesaea and species of the N. intermedia-group, noting that it is possible that at least one of N. intermedia atalanta Ris, 1913 and N. intermedia excelsa Lieftinck, 1934 might be junior synonyms of N. nesaea.

There are currently five subspecies recognised: the nominate subspecies philenor; subspecies insularis (Vázquez, 1957); subspecies hirsuta (Skinner, 1908); subspecies acauda (Oberthür, 1879); and subspecies orsua (Godman & Salvin, 1889).

There are currently 20 subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies polydamas; subspecies lucayus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cubensis (Dufrane, 1946); subspecies jamaicensis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies polycrates (Hopffer, 1865); subspecies thyamus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies antiquus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies christopheranus (A. Hall, 1936); subspecies neodamas (Lucas, 1852); subspecies dominicus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cebriones (Dalman, 1823); subspecies lucianus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies vincentius (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies grenadensis (A. Hall, 1930); subspecies streckerianus (Honrath, 1884); subspecies peruanus (Fuchs, 1954); subspecies atahualpa T. Racheli & Pischedda, 1987; subspecies weyrauchi Lamas, 1998; subspecies renani Lamas, 1998; and subspecies psittacus (J. Molina, 1782).

There are currently seven known subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies dolicaon; subspecies septentrionalis K. Brown, 1994; subspecies hebreus K. Brown & Lamas, 1994; subspecies tromes (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cauraensis Möhn, 2002; subspecies deileon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1865); and subspecies deicoon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1864).

There are three subspecies: P. a. andraemon (Hübner 1823); P. a. bonhotei (Sharpe 1990); and P. a. tailori (Rothschild and Jordan 1906).


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

Five subspecies have been described for this species: the nominate subspecies aristodemus and subspecies temenes (Godart, 1819); ponceanus (Schaus, 1911); bjorndalae (Clench, 1978); and majasi (Miller, 1987). 


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

This species belongs to the subfamily Papilioninae (Tyler et al. 1994, Zakharov et al. 2004). Based on mitochondrial and nuclear DNA analysis, it has been suggested that it is closely related to the “Troilus” group (Zakharov et al. 2004).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).
There are three recognised subspecies: P. m. multicaudata (Kirby 1884); P. m. pusillus (Austin and Emmel 1998); P. m. grandiosus (Austin and Emmel 1988).

There are four recognised subspecies (Warren et al. 2016): the nominate subspecies pelaus (Fabricius, 1775); subspecies imerius (Godart, 1819); subspecies atkinsi (Bates, 1935); and subspecies puertoricoensis (Möhn, 1999).


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

There are several recognised subspecies: P. p. polyxenes Fabricius, 1775; P. p. asterius Stoll 1782; P. p. coloro Wright 1905; P. p. stabilis Rothschild & Jordan 1906; P. p. americus Kollar 1850; P. p. gerardi Bollino and Vitale 2002; P. p. costarum Orellana, 2009; and P. p. sadalus Lucas 1852.

Subspecies of this butterfly include the nominate subspecies zelicaon (Lucas 1852) and nitra (Edwards 1883). Subspecies nitra is however considered a synonym of zelicaon by some (Pelham 2008), albeit it is also considered to be an eastern subspecies of zelicaon (Opler and Warren 2002, Fisher 1977) containing only rare dark individuals; representing possible introgression with P. polyxenes (NatureServe, 2019). P. gothica (Remington 1968) (occurring across Canada, western USA, and Mexico) is also regarded as a biological race or subspecies of P. zelicaon, or possibly as the yellow form of P. nitra (Collins and Morris 1985).

There are currently twenty subspecies known for this species, according to Warren et al. (2010): the nominate subspecies anchises; subspecies nephalion (Godart, 1819); subspecies stilbon (Kollar, 1839); subspecies alyattes (C. & R. Felder, 1865); subspecies cymochles (Doubleday, 1844); subspecies etias (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies serapis (Boisduval, 1836); subspecies thelios (Gray, [1853]); subspecies humaita D'Abrera, 1981; subspecies osyris (C. & R. Felder, 1861); subspecies drucei (Butler, 1874); subspecies orbignyanus (Lucas, 1852); subspecies foetterlei (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies orinocensis (Rousseau-Decelle, 1960); subspecies marinae Racheli, 1981; subspecies koenigi Racheli, 1989; subspecies bukuti Brévignon, 1998; subspecies farfan Brown, 1994; subspecies marthilia Maza, 1999 and subspecies zygma Lamas, 2001.

There are currently four subspecies reported for this species, following the treatment by  Racheli (2006): the nominate subspecies sesostris; subspecies tarquinius (Boisduval, 1836); susbpecies zestos (Gray, [1853]); and subspecies trinitensis Brown, 1994. Another taxon, zischkai, has been considered a fifth subspecies of this species (Warren et al. 2013), but is considered a synonym of the nominate subspecies by Racheli (2006).

There are several subspecies recognised for this species, including subspecies vosnessenski Ménétriés, [1850]; subspecies thor H. Edwards, 1881; subspecies septentrionalis Verity, 1911; subspecies maui Bryk, 1914; and subspecies daisetsuzana Matsumura, 1926. Subspecies felderi is considered a separate species by some authors, with maui and litoreus as subspecies of P. felderi (e.g. Weiss 1999). Here, we follow the view that felderi, maui, and lacinia are subspecies of Parnassius eversmanni (Beccaloni et al. 2003).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

Some sources list this species under genus Neographium (e.g. Butterflies of America; https://www.butterfliesofamerica.com/L/Papilionidae.htm), however, here we follow Tyler et al. (1994) and retain this species under genus Protographium.

Kaya et al. (2012) suggested that this species may represent a synonym of Poecilimon sureyanus, but Ünal (2012) argued that the morphological differences are distinct and re-established the species. Chobanov et al. (2015) suggested to await a genetic analysis to finally clarify its status.
According to Djikstra et al. (2013) Paraphlebia is part of the family Thaumatoneuridae as sister group of the Central American genus Thaumatoneura.

This species was described from Danyang, Republic of Korea, under the name of Galloisiana kosuensis Namkung, 1974.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Lirrangopotamonautes) lirrangensis lirrangensis. Cumberlidge (1998) referred to this species as Potamonautes lirrangensis.

The name Malawi Blue Crab is used only for the subpopulations of this species found in Lake Malawi, and not for subpopulations from other parts of the range of this species.

Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Obesopotamonautes) obesus obesus (A. Milne-Edwards, 1868). This species is treated here as Potamonautes obesus following the opinions of Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) and Reed & Cumberlidge (2004).
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Arcopotamonautes) suprasulcatus suprasulcatus. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) referred to this species as Potamonautes suprasulcatus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Orthopotamonautes) depressus dybowskii. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes choloensis.
Bott (1955) treated this species as a junior synonym of Potamonautes (Lirrangapotamonautes) johnstoni johnstoni. It is recognised here as the valid species Potamonautes montivagus.

Individuals from the northern part of Namibia differ morphologically and further studies are needed to clarify if they represent a unique subspecies or even species (Naskrecki 1995).
The taxonomy and phylogeny are well known (Zunino 1984, Löbl and Smetana 2006, Baraud 1966a, Lopez-Colon 1989, 1995d; Palmer and Cambefort 1997).

This species was formerly included in the Parathelphusidae but has recently been reassigned to the Gecarcinucidae; Parathelphusidae is now regarded as a junior synonym of Gecarcinucidae (Klause et al. in press).

authority: Korn, Machado, Cristo & Cancela da Fonseca, 2010

taxonomicNotes:
There are between 22 and 27 subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies helena, subspecies hephaestus (Felder, 1865), subspecies cerberus (C. & R. Felder, 1865), subspecies heliconoides (Moore, 1877), subspecies nereis (Doherty, 1891), subspecies propinquus Rothschild, 1895, subspecies sagittatus (Fruhstorfer, 1896), subspecies nereides Fruhstorfer, 1906, subspecies antileuca Rothschild, 1908, subspecies typhaon Rothschild, 1908, subspecies isara Rothschild, 1908, subspecies spilotia Rothschild, 1908, subspecies mosychlus (Fruhstorfer, 1913), subspecies euthycrates (Fruhstorfer, 1913), subspecies ferrari Tytler, 1926, subspecies bunguranensis Ohya, 1982, subspecies hermes Hayami, 1991, subspecies venus Hayami, 1991, subspecies rayae Deslisle, 1991, subspecies orientis Parrott, 1991, subspecies sugimotoi Hanafusa, 1992, and subspecies dempoensis Deslisle, 1993. Additional subspecies listed by some authors are: subspecies neoris Rothschild, 1908, subspecies mopaRothschild, 1908, subspecies demeter (Rumbucher & Schäffler, 2005) , subspecies hypnos (Rumbucher & Schäffler, 2005) and subspecies hahneli (Rumbucher & Schäffler, 2005). Troides helena cerberus f. eumagos (Jordon, 1908) has so far been reported only from the Sankhuwa Sabha District of East Nepal (NRDB, 1995). 
Regarding sub-species occurring in Vietnam and following the concept offered by Haugum and Low (1978-85), type specimens of subspecies euthycrates (N. Vietnam) are rather distinctive and may be distinguished from subspecies cerberus (S. Vietnam) based on larger size, darker abdomen laterally and dorsally, and pattern of spots on the hind wing (the latter in the case of females); in essence, females from southern populations have more oval spots while in the specimens from Northern and  northern Central Vietnam spots are more elongated and pointed (Monastyrskii 2007).

Acanthagrion franciscoi fits none of the species groups defined by Leonard (1977). It keys out to
couplet 7 in Leonard’s key that leads to the viridescens, adustum and chararum groups. It differs
from the species of the viridescens group by having the modifications of genital ligula segment
3 not visible in ectal view. It differs from the species of the adustum group because the distal
part of genital ligula segment 3 is not incised. From the species of the chararum group it differs
by having the cercus slanting forward relative to the paraprocts from base to apex. A. franciscoi
differs from all known species of Acanthagrion by its small size (Rw 13.0 mm, Abd 17 mm),
a character it shares only with A. minutum Leonard, 1977, regarded by Leonard (1977) as the
smallest species of Acanthagrion.
Erythrodiplax ana fits in Borror’s Basalis Group.
Oxyagrion franciscoi is easily distinguished from all other congeners by its dominantly blue colours, a character it shares only with Oxyagrion ablutum (Calvert, 1909).

In 2011, von Ellenrieder stated that "Based on observed morphological variability of the diagnostic characters traditionally used to identify species of Microstigma, the three specific names currently used might represent only intraspecific variability", thus Microstigma species may all be M. anomalum synonym.

This relict species is known as probably the oldest extant butterfly linage, commonly referred to as a “Living Fossil” (Collins and Morris 1985), estimated to have evolved between 65 and 75 million years ago (Covarrubias-Camarillo et al. 2016). The subfamily Baroniinae contains only this species, and on the basis of morphology, it has been suggested to be the sister lineage to all other Papilionidae (Léon-Cortés et al. 2004). While the position of Baronia as the basal lineage within the Papilionidae family seemed assured (Munroe 1961, Hancock 1983), comprehensive morphological analysis of butterfly phylogeny by De Jong et al. (1996) has suggested that Parnassius might instead occupy this position. Baronia does, however, resemble one of the oldest known fossil butterflies, Praepapilio colorado, which occurred during the Eocene, some 48 million years ago (Durden and Rose 1978). The resemblance offers no evidence of its phylogenetic placement (Caterino et al. 2001), yet the phylogenetic position of this species has important implications for understanding butterfly evolution, such as whether the use of a leguminous host represents the "original" butterfly condition (Scott 1986).

Due to the geographical isolation between the main populations and the Chiapas population, it had been suggested that there are two subspecies: the nominal B. brevicornis (Vázquez and Pérez-Ruiz 1961) and B. brevicornis rufodiscalis within Chiapas, Mexcio (De la Maza et al. 1987, Machkour-M’Rabet et al. 2014).

Hong Kong and Guangdong specimens possess a pair of yellow lateral spots on the otherwise black labium and the superior appendages are slightly divaricate. Chao (1990) uses an all black labium as a keying character in his key to the Chinese Euthygomphus despite the fact that Asahina (1968) illustrated female E. koxingai from Taiwan with a pair of yellow lateral spots. All the male specimens Wilson and Xu (2009) examined from Hong Kong, Guangxi and Guangdong possessed slightly divaricate superior appendages whereas E. koxingai from Taiwan is figured with parallel superior appendages. According to Wilson and Xu (2009) it is most likely that Euthygomphuss fujianensis Zhou and Wu (1992) is a junior synonym.
.

M. kerri is reported from the Peninsular Thailand while the Malaysian part of the Malay Peninsula is considered as occupied by a related species Microgomphus quadratus (Orr, 2005), differing in the shape of the antehumeral patches (Asahina, 1986). It is still to clarify if these species co-occur somewhere in the peninsula, or are geographically isolated, or there is a transitional zone which would indicate their subspecific status.

The specimens from Gia Lai Province have certain differences in the abdominal pattern from those from the type locality in Lam Dong Province (both provinces in the southern Vietnam), the taxonomical value of which is unclear (Kompier, 2017).

According to the molecular phylogenetic analysis by Sánchez-Guillén et al. (2018), Ischnura foylei forms a tight cluster together with two Neotropical species, Ischnura fluviatilis Selys, 1876 and I. ramburii (Selys in Sagra, 1857), and indeed, these species share some similarity in the abdominal colour pattern. Occurrence of a representative of a Neotropical lineage in the Indo-Malayan Biogeographical Realm, but only at one crater lake in Sumatra, is striking. It may be hypothesized that after the crater lake was formed and became suitable for Odonata it  was by chance colonised by an American damselfly arrived across the Pacific as aeroplancton.

The Cambodian and Laotian specimens differ in the extent of the yellow pattern (Kosterin & Yokoi, 2016), which may be environmental modification or reflect genetic differences, while the Vietnamese specimens are not yet characterised in detail. The main diagnostic character of this species is a conspicuous lobe between the male cerci (Kosterin & Yokoi, 2016) which hints to a considerable divergence from the rest of the genus. It may well happen that there exist a number of closely related species with such lobe than one unique species. Further research are needed to clarify this issue.
