Conspecificity of the two only known specimens, the holotype and paratype, is not beyond doubt (Kosterin, 2016).
Biogeographically, the record of R. dohrni (Krueger, 1902) (a Sondaic species) for Vietnam (Asahina 1969) must have been referred to this species but the specimen were not examined to prove this.

While males if this species are conspicuous and unmistakable females, as to the current state of knowledge, cannot be distinguished by external characters from its widespread congener Onychargia atrocyana Selys, 1865. Males from North Thailand were identified by photos and were not examined morphologically.

A blue-marked male specimen from North Vietnam identified as Prodasineura verticalis (Selys, 1860) (a red-marked species!) by Asahina (1997) could probably be this species but other options are possible. The same refers to a male specimen from the northern Laos depicted, as ‘Prodasineura sp.1’, by Yokoi & Souphanthong (2014)

Argia plana Calvert, 1902 is considered a junior synonym of Argia funebris (Hagen, 1861), so the A. funebris before considered a tropical species now reaches Oklahoma and northern Texas in the middle of the USA (Rosser W. Garrison pers. comn.).
Originally described as Leptobasis costalimai Santos 1957. Later was included in the genus Tuberculobasis by Machado (2009).

About the taxonomic similarities between Heteragrion silvarum Sjöstedt 1918 and Heteragrion melanurum Williamson 1919, Lencioni (2013) stated as follows: "...Other material from Manaus (paratype of H. melanurum) is close to H. silvarum, as noted by De Marmels (1987). All comparisons with the morphology of the appendages was based on Sjöstedt's figures, as the appendages were missing when De Marmels examined the holotype in 1987. Based on his examination, Garrison agrees with De Marmels that H. melanurum = H. silvarum but acknowledges that this species is wide-ranging and variable as to color. The specimen in the Lencioni collection from Porto Velho includes a note from R. Garrison: "specimens darker than normal H. silvarum but agree with appendage morphology to topotypical material."

Astacus leptodactylus is referred to as a species complex. In the 1950s this species was believed to belong to the subgenus Astacus (Potastacus) along with A. (P.) pachypus, A. (P.) pylzowi and A. (P.) kessleri.The following four subspecies were attributed to A. (P.) leptodactylus: eichwaldi, cubanicus, salinus, and leptodactylus. Karaman (1962, 1963) however does not acknowledge A. (P.) cubanicus as a subspecies. In the 1970s, Pontastacus was raised to generic level. In the 1980s, Brodskij made a number of revisions within Pontastacus but the number of taxa varied within papers. In the mid 1990s Starobogatov (1995) split Pontastacus into two genera: Pontastacus - P. angulosus (Rathke, 1837); P. cubanicus (Birstein & Winogradow, 1934); P. danubialis (Brodskij, 1967); P. eichwaldi (Bott, 1950); P. intermedius (Bott, 1950); P. kessleri (Schimkewitsch, 1886); P. pyzlowi (Skorikov, 1911); P. salinus (Nordmann, 1942), and Caspiastacus with two species. However, there is great deal of criticism over the recent revision in taxonomy made by Ukranian and Russian taxonomists as it appears to be based on little evidence.
In line with a new publication: Crandall, K.A. & S. De Grave. (2017). An updated classification of the freshwater crayfishes (Decapoda: Astacidea) of the world, with a complete species list. Journal of Crustacean Biology. This species formally under the genus Astacus has been moved to Pontastacus.

In the 1950's this species was thought to belong to a different sub-genus from Astacus i.e. was thought to belong to A. (Pontastacus) pachypus along with the species pylzowi, kessleri and leptodactylus. The sub-genus Pontastacus has since been elevated to generic level, and then to a new genus (Caspiastacus) in 1995 by Starobogatov (Souty-Grosset et al. 2006).

The taxonomy of Eurasian crayfish is questionable as there appears to be little validity for revisions to existing taxonomy. There is considerable morphological variation across the Eurasian species, and it is thought that there is hybridisation between A. pachypus and A. leptodactylus. The only way to truly delineate the precise range of each species, is to conduct comparative molecular genetic studies. At the present time A. pachypus is considered to be present in the Black, Azov and Caspian Seas (Souty-Grosset et al. 2006).
In line with Crandall, K.A. & S. De Grave. (2017). An updated classification of the freshwater crayfishes (Decapoda: Astacidea) of the world, with a complete species list. Journal of Crustacean Biology this species has been laterally moved from the genus Astacus to Pontastacus, no change in taxonomic concept has occurred, so there was no need for reassessment.
Three subspecies are known: Austropotamobius torrentium torrentium, A. t. danubicus, and A. t. macedonicus.
This species was previously regarded as Boninagrion ezoin, but this genus has been regarded as synonymous with Ischnura since 2012 (Karube et al. 2012).
The female of Argiolestes amphistylus has not been described.
The female of Argiolestes celebensis is not known.
The female of Argiolestes foja is not known.
The female of Argiolestes pallidistylus is not known.
The female of Argiolestes roon is not known.
The female of Metagrion convergens is unknown.

Dysphaea lugens is very similar in general appearance to the other two Dysphaea species that occur in Borneo and until the revision of Hämäläinen et al. (2015) had frequently been confused with them, because of this many records of this species in the literature prior to 2015 actually refer to other species.
Dysphaea ulu is very similar in general appearance to the other two Dysphaea species that occur in Borneo and until its description (Hämäläinen et al. 2015) had been misidentified as D. dimidiata.
Until recently Dysphaea vanida was considered to be a northern variant of D. dimidiata but it was shown to be a distinct species by Hämäläinen et al. 2015.

Euphaea inouei was described from specimens from southern Vietnam (Asahina 1977) as a subspecies of E. guerini Rambur, 1842, and has also been treated as a subspecies of E. masoni Selys, 1879 and as a good species. The issue of the relationship of E, inouei to E. masoni has never been properly resolved (M. Hämäläinen personal communication 2018) and, for instance, Phan et al. (2018) did not attempt to separate their Vietnamese material into E. masoni and E. inouei. For assessment purposes only the type specimens of E. guerini inouei and other material from the holotype site (Thac Bobla in Lam Dong Province) is treated as belonging to E. inouei and all other material is left out of consideration until the taxonomic issues are resolved; this is not a judgement on other records, but a Red List assessment is not the place to attempt to solve the taxonomic issues surrounding this taxa and any other course of action would be premature and likely to add further to the confusion surrounding this taxon.
Two subspecies of Euphaea lara are recognised, E. l. lara from Sumba and E. l. lombockensis known from others of the Lesser Sunda Islands.

Two subspecies of Leptogomphus lansbergei are recognised, the nominate subspecies from Java and L. l. assimilis Krüger 1898 from Sumatra. Ris (1927) noted that the anal appendages of the two subspecies differ, as noted in Dow et al. (2017), if this is true then probably they should be treated as distinct species. However for the purposes of assessment they are treated as a single species until the matter has been investigated more closely.
Only known from the male holotype.

A population in southern Papua New Guinea might be this species (S. Richards pers. comm. 2017), however since there is some uncertainty on this at present and this population would represent a very large range extension, it is left out of the current assessment.
The male of Selysioneura venilia is not known.
Kosterin & Poggi (2015) clarified that Indolestes birmanus is a distinct species, not a subspecies of I. gracilis.
The female of Akrothemis risi is associated with the male only by (reasonable) supposition. This species was placed in Risiophlebia until recently (see Theischinger and Richards 2012)
The female of Chalybeothemis pruinosa is not known.
Three subspecies of Diplacina phoebe are recognised. The nominate subspecies is recorded from Buru and Seram, D. p. amoena is known from Bacan, Halmahera and Obi and D. p. phyrne from Ambon.

Huonia rheophila is known from Halmahera and from Biak off the coast of New Guinea, there are no records from locations in between and in these circumstances there is some doubt over whether the records from Biak really refer to the same species.
This species has traditionally been ranked as subspecies Matrona basilaris japonica, but now it is ranked as good species since 2011 (e.g., Hamalainen et al. 2011,Ozono et al. 2012).

This species was previously considered part of the genus Atrophaneura (Hancock 1988). This species is very similar to Atrophaneura priapus and there were some doubts about its taxonomic status in the past (Collins and Morris 1985). Racheli and Cotton (2010) have now placed this species in the priapus group, alongside Atrophaneura priapus, A. hageni, and A. sycorax.

This species was considered part of the polydorus species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs in Indo-Australia (Hancock 1988). However, since then the subgenus Pachliopta has been elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here.

This species has two subspecies; P. s. schadenbergi and P. s. micholitzi (Collins and Morris 1985, Treadaway 1995, Danielsen and Treadaway 2004).

There is some debate about the subspecies recognised for this species. Here, we follow Bollino and Racheli (2012) in recognising the nominate subspecies thaidina; subspecies hoenei Bryk,1938; and subspecies melli Bryk, 1938. The latter may be synonymised in future, although further examination of material is required, specifically in terms of melanic appearance. Other authorities recognize subspecies chonjiangensis Li 1994; however, here this is considered a synonym of hoenei (Bollino and Racheli 2012).

There are three subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies garleppi; subspecies interruptus (Staudinger, 1892); and subspecies lecerfi Brown & Lamas, 1994. It has been suggested in the past that P. garleppi could possibly be a hybrid between P. torquatus and P. astyalus, two sympatric species (Collins and Morris 1985). However, more recent studies treat it is a distinct species (e.g. Lewis 2010).
This species, previously under genus Papilio, is now considered under genus Chilasa (Tennent 2006).

In Europe, there are many different subspecies, forms and aberrations noted for this species, presumably because of the very divided nature of the distribution area and as a consequence, large isolation of populations. Separated by mountains, the populations develop independently of one another, so that quite marked differences arise. However, it has been argued that “colour and pattern variation, including polymorphism, is quite common in butterflies, and its taxonomic value has been severely disputed, as it may, at least in part, result from phenotypic plasticity” (Todisco et al. 2010). The same paper highlights that in several instances, populations from different subspecies share similar or identical mtDNA, so have either recently diverged or are not different from one another (Todisco et al. 2010).
There are four subspecies of Papilio desmondi (Williams, 2019): the nominate subspecies; P. d. magdae Gifford, 1961; P. d. teita van Someren, 1960; and P. d. usambaraensis (Koçak, 1980).

The nominate subspecies dorcus occurs in northern Sulawesi; subspecies ventus Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980, and subspecies butungensis Hanafusa, 1997, were described from central Sulawesi and Buton Island respectively.

Fourteen subspecies have been described, listed below. It should be noted that ssp. zoroastres is isolated in Bioko and the Cameroon highlands: it was described as a distinct species and given the huge disjunction may actually deserve species status, but most authors presently treat it as subspecies.

Papilio echerioides ssp. oscari, Rothschild, 1902

Papilio echerioides ssp. zoroastres, Druce, 1878

Papilio echerioides ssp. wertheri, Karsch, 1898,

Papilio echerioides ssp. shirensis, Hancock, 1987,

Papilio echerioides ssp. pseudowertheri, Kielland, 1990,

Papilio echerioides ssp. nyiro, Carcasson, 1962,

Papilio echerioides ssp. leucospilus, Rothschild, 1902,

Papilio echerioides ssp. nioka, Hancock, 1989,

Papilio echerioides ssp. kiellandi, Clifton & Collins, 1997,

Papilio echerioides ssp. joiceyi, Gabriel, 1945,

Papilio echerioides ssp. homeyeri, Plötz, 1880,

Papilio echerioides ssp. ambangulu, Clifton & Collins, 1997,

Papilio echerioides ssp. chirindanus, van Son, 1956,

Papilio echerioides ssp. echerioides, Trimen, 1868.

Two or three subspecies are recognised for this species. The nominate subspecies occurs on Sulawesi, Halmahera, Bacan and Ternate (Indonesia), and subspecies marabuntana (Detani, 1983), is restricted to Kepulauan Banggai (Peleng). There is some difference of opinion as to whether felixi (Joicey & Noakes, 1915) (Biak) belongs with this species (as the third subspecies), with Graphium thule (Wallace, 1865) (Hancock 1980, Parsons 1998, Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003) or with G. leucadion (previously considered a subspecies of deucalion) as a separate species (Jan Moonen 2019, pers. comm.). C. Muller (pers. comm. 2010) states that it is closer, both geographically and phenotypically, to G. thule than to G. deucalion. This different classification does not affect the assessment as both G. thule and G. deucalion separately classify as Least Concern, irrespective of the assignment of felixi.

There are two subspecies of this butterfly. The nominate occurs on the main island of Sulawesi and the island of Buton and Kepulauan Banggai (Peleng) while extremum Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980 was described from Kepulauan Sula (Sanana) (Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).

This species was considered to belong to the genus Atrophaneura (Hancock 1988). The subgenus Pachliopta has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; LepIndex; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this here.
There are four distinct subspecies: B. l. laodamas (Rothschild and Jordan 1906), B. l. copanae (Reakirt 1863), B. l. iopas (Godman and Salvin 1897) and B. l. rhipidus (Rothschild and Jordan 1906).

This species is sometimes considered a subspecies of Atrophaneura (Pachliopta) aristolochiae, however in 1995 it was separated from Atrophaneura aristolochiae Fabricius by Page and Treadaway (Moonen 2016). The subgenus Pachliopta was elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this is followed here.There are nine subspecies recognised for this species (Jan Moonen pers. comm. February 2019): the nominate subspecies adamas; subspecies probus Fruhstorfer, 1911; subspecies antissa Jordan, 1908; subspecies agricola Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980; subspecies balinus Fruhstorfer, 1908; subspecies lombockensis Rothschild, 1896; subspecies sapientia Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980; subspecies austrosundanus Rothschild, 1895; and subspecies floresianus Rothschild, 1908

This species was previously treated as Atrophaneura adamsoni (Hancock 1988), however, subgenus Byasa was elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. LepIndex, GLoBIS, Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here.

Uehara (2006) identifies takakoae as a subspecies.

This species was not assessed in a global status assessment of swallowtails in 1985 by Collins and Morris, as it was still considered at this point a subspecies of Atrophaneura (Pachliopta) aristolochiae. Hancock (1988) considered the species under the genus Atrophaneura. The subgenus Pachliopta was elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this is followed here.There are five subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies antiphus; subspecies antiphulus; subspecies acuta Druce, 1873; subspecies yoshikoae Okano, 1988; and subspecies elioti Page & Treadaway, 1995 (Danielsen and Treadaway 2004, J. Moonen pers. comm. 2019).

This species is part of the nox species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs from northern India and Taiwan in the north to Bali and Sulawesi in the south (Hancock 1988, Racheli and Cotton 2010).

This species has previously been considered a subspecies of Atrophaneura nox.

This species was considered within the Atrophaneura (Hancock 1988). However, since then, the subgenus Pachliopta has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; LepIndex; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this here.

This species was previously considered conspecific with Pachliopta aristolochiae (for example Hancock 1983, as Atrophaneura), however it was separated by Hiura and Alagar in 1971 and it is now widely considered its own species (for example Collins and Morris 1985, Tsukada and Nishiyama 1982). There are thought to be six different subspecies, each occupying different islands or different parts of an island. P. k. kotzebuea is found in west and central Luzon, P. k. philippus in Samar, Leyte, Dinagar, Mindanao, Panaon, Camiguin de Mindanao, Siargao, Homonhon and Sarangani, P. k. tindongana in north-east Luzon and Babuyanes, P. k. mataconga in south Luzon, P. k. deseileus in Mindoro, Marinduque, Masbate, Ticao, Panay, Negros and the Sibuyan islands and P. k. bilara in Bohol and Cebu (Treadaway 1995, Jan Moonen pers. comm. February 2019).

This species was considered part of the Atrophaneura, which occur in Indo-Australia (Hancock 1988). However, since then, subgenus Pachliopta was elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and here we follow this new treatment.

This species has three subspecies: P. m. mariae, P. m. almae and P. m. camarines (Treadaway 1995). These are each found in different regions of the Philippines.

This species is part of the nox species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs from northern India and Taiwan in the north to Bali and Sulawesi in the south (Hancock 1988, Racheli and Cotton 2010).

There are around fourteen subspecies known for this species, classed based on wing pattern and geographical range into four subspecies groups (Hirata and Miyagawa 2006): the nox subspecies group (consisting of subspecies nox and nyx); the smedleyi subspecies group (consisting of subspecies smedleyi, and mirifica); the erebus subspecies group (consisting of subspecies erebus, henricus, tungensis, solokanus, petronius and the relatively recently described hirokae); and the noctis subspecies group (consisting of subspecies noctis, noctula, banjermasinus, and miekoae). 

A. n. tungensis was previously thought to be its own species, however it is now considered a subspecies of A. nox. Females of the species Papilio memnon may mimic females of  A. nox (Barlow 1988). Both species of the sympatric Papilio acheron are thought to mimic this species (Collins and Morris 1985).

This species was considered part of the polydorus species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs in Indo-Australia (Hancock 1988). The subgenus Pachliopta has since been elevated to full genus level (e.g. GLoBIS; Page and Treadaway 2004).Treadaway (1995) listed three subspecies for this Phlippine endemic: the nominate subspecies phlegon, subspecies strandi and subspecies splendida. However, subspecies strandi has since been elevated to species level, with splendida a subspecies of Pachliopta strandi (Page and Treadaway 2004).

The genus Pachliopta, to which this species belongs, was previously thought to be a subgenus of Atrophaneura (Hancock 1988), however it is now known to constitute its own genus. Several subspecies have been reported for this widespread species: the nominate subspecies polydorus; subspecies polypemon (Mathew, 1887); subspecies godartianus (Lucas, 1852); subspecies leodamas (Wallace, 1865); subspecies polydaemon (Mathew, 1887); subspecies thessalia (Swinhoe, 1893); subspecies tenimberensis (Rothschild, 1895); subspecies queenslandicus (Rothschild, 1895); subspecies septentrionalis (Rothschild, 1895); subspecies novobritannicus (Rothschild, 1895); subspecies dampierensis (Hagen, 1897); subspecies utuanensis (Ribbe, 1898); subspecies aignanus (Rothschild, 1898); subspecies kajelanus (Fruhstorfer, 1899); subspecies asinius (Fruhstorfer, 1904); subspecies varus (Fruhstorfer, 1906); subspecies orinomus (Rothschild, 1908); subspecies meforanus (Rothschild, 1908); subspecies humboldti (Rothschild, 1908); subspecies aphnitis (Fruhstorfer, 1913); subspecies lascarus (Fruhstorfer, 1913); subspecies naissus (Fruhstorfer, 1908); subspecies vulcanicus (Rothschild, 1915); subspecies alboplagatus (Joicey & Talbot, 1922); subspecies manus (Talbot, 1932); subspecies auster (van Eecke, 1915); subspecies ceramites (Fruhstorfer, 1916); subspecies schoutensis (Joicey & Talbot, 1924); and subspecies wangaarensis (Joicey & Talbot, 1924). There is another potential subspecies, mamberanus, which requires confirmation.

Hancock (1988) considered the species under the genus Atrophaneura. The subgenus Pachliopta was elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this is followed here.

There are currently at least four recognised subspecies: the nominate subspecies polyphontes (Boisduval 1836); subspecies rosea (Oberthür 1879); subspecies aipytos (Fruhstorfer 1908) and subspecies sejanus (Frushstorfer 1908). Subspecies bugius is known to be synonymous with the nominate (Ney 1911) (Collins and Morris 1985, Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003, Häuser et al. 2017).
There are two known subspecies: priapus and dilutus.

This species has three subspecies: the nominate subspecies sycorax; subspecies egertoni (Distant, 1886); and subspecies carolinae Toxopeus, 1936 (subspecies pariwononis Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1979 is a synonym of carolinae (J. Moonen pers. comm. February 2019).

The following subspecies are currently known for this species: the nominate subspecies madyes; subspecies adloni (Ehrmann, 1926); subspecies philetas (Hewitson, 1869); subspecies lojaensis Möhn, 1999; subspecies magnimacula (Joicey & Talbot, 1925); subspecies plinius (Weymer, 1890); subspecies buechei Lamas, 1998; subspecies callangaensis Möhn, 2001; subspecies chlorodamas (Guenée, 1872); subspecies montebanus (Dyar, 1913); subspecies crispatus Lamas, 2001; and subspecies tucumanus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906).
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies polystictus and subspecies galenus (Fruhstorfer, 1907).

This is a monotypic genus from Australasia and considered closely related to Euryades (Collins and Morris 1985). There are four subspecies described for this species: the nominate subspecies cressida; subspecies insularis (Fruhstorfer, 1909); subspecies cassandra (Waterhouse & Lyell, 1914); and subspecies troilus (Butler, 1876).
There are two subspecies recorded for this species: subspecies angolanus and subspecies baronis (Ungemach, 1932).

There are thought to be at least four subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies delesserti (Guérin-Méneville, 1839); subspecies palawanus (Staudinger, 1889), subspecies hyalinus (Fruhstorfer, 1901) and subspecies verbigenus (Fruhstorfer, 1911) (Beccaloni et al. 2003, Savela 2010).

This species is listed by some taxonomic sources as a subspecies of Graphium codrus (e.g. Beccaloni et al. 2003), however it is treated here it as a separate species in its own right. Subspecies for this species include; the nominate subspecies empedovana (Corbet, 1941), subspecies eremicola (Watanabe, 1987), subspecies tanjungpandana (Watanabe, 1987), subspecies honorabilis (Tsukada, 1987), subspecies subdebilis (Tsukada, 1987) and subspecies subiensis (Hanafusa, 1990) (Hancock 1982). Some taxonomic sources list additional subspecies however some may require additional confirmation.

There are at least seven subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies euphrates (C. & R. Felder, 1862);  subspecies domaranus (Fruhstorfer, 1903); subspecies cuyoensis (Medicielo & Hanafusa, 1994);  subspecies buhisanus (Page, 1987); subspecies boholensis (Page, 1987); subspecies ornatus (Rothschild, 1895); and subspecies elegantia (Tsukada & Nishiyama, 1980).

There are thought to be several different subspecies reported for this species, however the numbers vary depending on the source from which the information is taken. The following subspecies are most commonly reported: the nominate subspecies codrus (Cramer, 1779); subspecies melanthus (C. & R. Felder, 1862); subspecies medon (C. & R. Felder, 1864); subspecies gilolensis (Wallace, 1865); subspecies segonax (Godman & Salvin, 1878); subspecies pisidice (Godman & Salvin, 1888), sometimes referred to as subspecies gabriellae; subspecies tenebrionis (Rothschild, 1895); subspecies auratus (Rothschild, 1898); subspecies toealensis (Rothschild, 1896); subspecies stiris (Jordan, 1909); subspecies taloranus (Jordan, 1909); subspecies schoutensis (Talbot & Joicey, 1916); subspecies christobalus (Jordan, 1909) (Savela 2010, Hauser et al. 1997, Beccaloni et al. 2004, Tennent, 2002). Other subspecies include: subspecies celebensis (Wallace, 1865); subspecies noeli (Page & Treadway, 2003) and subspecies yayoeae (Nihara & Kawamura, 1986).

This species was relatively recently described as a separate species, but closely related to G. weiskei (Müller & Tennent 1999); some taxonomic sources retain this taxon under G. weiskei due to its allopatric distribution (Haeuser et al. 2012), but here we treat it as a separate species.

Four subspecies have been described for this species: the nominate subspecies macfarlanei; subspecies seminigra (Butler, 1882); subspecies cestius (Fruhstorfer, 1903); and subspecies admiralia (Rothschild, 1915).
The following subspecies were described for this species: the nominate subspecies porthaon; subspecies tanganyikae Kielland, 1978; subspecies mackiei Collins & Larsen, 1991.

There are currently four recognised subspecies: the nominate subspecies rhesus (Boisduval 1836); and subspecies rhesulus (Fruhstorfer 1902), rhaphia (Jordan 1908), and parvimacula (Joicey and Talbot 1922) (Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).

There are three subspecies of this butterfly: the nominate subspecies astyalus (Godart, 1819); subspecies hippomedon (Felder & Felder, 1859); and subspecies phanias (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906) (Warren et al. 2016).  


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

There are four subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies chiansiades; subspecies maroni Moreau, 1923; subspecies dospassosi Rütimeyer, 1969; and subspecies mossi (Brown, 1994). This latter subspecies, mossi (Brown, 1994), has a consistent geographic range, morphology and type with that of the nominate subspecies and is by some authors considered to be a likely synonym of subspecies chiansides (Lewis 2010).
The following subspecies have been described: the nominate subspecies constantinus; subspecies mweruanus Joicey & Talbot, 1927; subspecies lecerfi Koçak, 1996.

Several subspecies have been described for this species: the nominate subspecies dardanus; subspecies sulfurea Palisot de Beauvois, 1806; subspecies antinorii Oberthür, 1883; subspecies byatti Poulton, 1926; subspecies cenea Stoll, [1790]; subspecies figinii Storace, 1962; subspecies flavicornis Carpenter, 1947; subspecies humbloti Oberthür, 1888; subspecies meriones C. & R. Felder, 1865; subspecies meseres Carpenter, 1948; subspecies ochraceana Vane-Wright 1995; subspecies tibullus Kirby, 1880; subspecies polytrophus Rothschild & Jordan, 1903.
The following subspecies have been recorded: the nominate subspecies demodocus and subspecies bennetti Dixey, 1898.

The species has three subspecies: the nominate subspecies nireus; subspecies pseudonireus; and subspecies lyaeus (Williams 2020). Some taxonomic databases list Papilio aristophontes, endemic to Anjouan, Moheli and Grande Comore, Comoros Islands, and Papilio wilsoni, endemic to Ethiopia, as a subspecies of Papilio nireus (Savela 2010), but we follow Williams (2020) in the treatment of this species.

The following subspecies have been recorded for this species: the nominate subspecies ophidicephalus; subspecies phalusco Suffert, 1904; subspecies chirinda van Son, 1939; subspecies entabeni van Son, 1939; subspecies transvaalensis van Son, 1939; subspecies ayresi van Son, 1939; subspecies zuluensis van Son, 1939; subspecies cottrelli van Son, 1966; subspecies mkuwadzi Gifford, 1961; subspecies niassicola Storace, 1955.

This species was recently proposed, following the discovery that southwestern and eastern populations of Heraclides cresphontes differed both genetically and in wing patterning (Shiraiwa et al. 2014). Described as part of the genus Heraclides, but now part of the genus Papilio, of which Heraclides is a subgenus (see below).

Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

There are 13 subspecies reported for this species, according to Warren et al. (2010): the nominate subspecies aeneas; subspecies bolivar (Hewitson, 1850); subspecies opalinus (Butler, 1877); subspecies damis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies locris (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies gabrielensis (Bryk, 1953); subspecies marcius (Hübner, [1816]); subspecies huallaga Racheli, 1988; subspecies lamasi Racheli, 1988; subspecies tucha Racheli, 1988; subspecies linoides Brown & Lamas, 1994; subspecies lucasi Brown & Lamas, 1994; and subspecies didas Brown & Lamas, 1994.

There are currently six subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies bunichus; subspecies chamissonia (Eschscholtz, 1821); subspecies damocrates (Guenée, 1872); subspecies diodorus (Hopffer, 1866); subspecies perrhebus (Boisduval, 1836), and the recently described subspecies almas Casagrande & Mielke, 2007.

There are currently four subspecies known for this species (Racheli 2006): the nominate subspecies chabrias; subspecies ygdrasilla Hemming, 1935; subspecies mithras (Grose-Smith, 1902) and subspecies marajoara (Brown, 1994).

There are currently four subspecies recognised for this species, according to Warren et al. 2010): the nominate subspecies echemon; subspecies ergeteles (Gray, [1853]); subspecies empistocles Küppers, 1975; and subspecies pisander (C. & R. Felder, 1865).

According to Tyler et al. (1994) and Warren et al. (2013) there are seven subspecies: the nominate subspecies neophilus; subspecies anaximenes (C. & R. Felder, 1862); subspecies consus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies ecbolius (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies eurybates (Gray, [1853]); subspecies parianus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); and subspecies olivencius (Bates, 1861).

Based on the information in Racheli (2006), there are currently six subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies panthonus (Cramer, 1780), subspecies barbotini Brévignon, 1998, subspecies ecaudatus (Joicey & Talbot, 1924), subspecies castilhoi (d'Almeida, 1967), subspecies callicles (Bates 1861) and subspecies aglaope (Gray 1853). According to Warren et al. (2013) there are currently only two subspecies: the nominate subspecies panthonus; and subspecies phylarchus (Hopffer, 1866); however, no basis is provided to support this arrangement. A previous status assessment of the world's swallowtails in 1985 referred to numa which is now considered a synonym of P. burchellanus (Tyler et al. 1994), a taxon that could be conspecific with P. panthonus (Silva-Brandão et al. 2008). Parides aglaope has been considered as a separate species (Warren et al. 2013, see above); however, for this assessment, we stand by the information given in Racheli (2006).
There are two subspecies reported for this species: the nominate subspecies phalaecus; and subspecies nieva Möhn, 1999.

There are currently five subspecies reported for this species (Tyler et al, 1994, Racheli 2006, Warren et al. 2013): the nominate subspecies phosphorus; subspecies gratianus (Hewitson, 1861); susbpecies vavi Racheli, 1992; subspecies zopyron Lamas, 1998; and subspecies laurae Bollino & Costa, 2004.
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies quadratus; and subspecies spoliatus (Staudinger, 1898) (Tyler et al. 1994, Racheli 2006, Warren et al. 2013).
There are currently two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies tros; and subspecies danunciae Mielke, Casagrande & Mielke, 2000 (Warren et al. 2013).

There are currently nine subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies vertumnus; subspecies cutora (Gray, [1853]); subspecies diceros (Gray, [1853]); subspecies bogotanus (C. & R. Felder, 1864); subspecies autumnus (Staudinger, 1898); subspecies yuracares (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies pseudobogotanus (Krüger, 1926); subspecies pyrophanus (Zikán, 1937) and subspecies astorius (Zikán, 1940) (Tyler et al. 1994, Warren et al. 2013).
There are currently two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies zacynthus; and subspecies polymetus (Godart, 1819) (Tyler et al. 1994, Warren et al. 2013).

This species belongs to the subgenus Kailasius. There are several subspecies recognised for this species, such as subspecies anjuta Stshetkin & Kaabak, 1985; amabilis Bryk & Eisner, 1932; basharianus Eisner, 1969; corporaali Bryk, 1935; deckerti Verity, 1907; ducalis Boullet & Le Cerf, 1912; eisnerianus Bryk & Eisner, 1931; ella Bryk, 1932; flaugeri Eisner, 1978; kabiri Eisner & Naumann, 1980; katheruthae Bryk, 1935; ljudmilae Lesin & Kaabak, 1991; mistericus Kaabak, Sotshivko & Titov; naimus Eisner & Naumann, 1980; nuristanus Eisner & Naumann, 1980; otto Bryk & Eisner, 1932; robertjan Eisner, 1959; romanovi Grum-Grshimailo, 1885; sakai Eisner, 1978; serenissimus Bryk, 1932; vaporosus Avinov, 1913; voigti Bang-Haas, 1927; and wernickei Kotzsch, 1936.
Parnassius delphius consist of two major subspecies: P. delphius delphius and P. delphius maximinus Staudinger, 1891 (often considered as two different species) (Lukhtanov et al. 2016).

Several subspecies have been described for this species, including subspecies afghanistanus Eisner, 1940; subspecies alburnus Stichel, 1907; subspecies ernesti Bryk, 1932; subspecies pseudoalburnus Eisner, 1954 (Beccaloni et al. 2003).
Parnassius hide is sometimes considered to be a subspecies of this species (Häuser et al. 2012)

Several subspecies have been reported for this species, including the nominate subspecies tenedius; subspecies britae Bryk, 1932; subspecies kleinschmidti Bryk, 1950; subspecies scepticus Bryk & Eisner, 1932; and subspecies vulcanus Bryk & Eisner, 1932 (Beccaloni et al. 2003).
Common and Waterhouse (1981) recognized two subspecies in Australia: the nominate subspecies leosthenes in eastern Australia; and subspecies geimbia from the Northern Territory.
There are two subspecies of Papilio antimachus: the nominate subspecies and P. a. parva Jackson, 1956.
Papilio sjoestedti Aurivillius, 1908 has two subspecies (Smith et al. 2008): the nominate subspecies and P. s. atavus Le Cerf, 1912.
The genus Acrida is in need of revision.
The genus Heliocypha Fraser is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Heliocypha Fraser is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

All the names listed as synonyms here have sometimes been treated as subspecies. Of these, R. abbreviata, from the Khasi Hills in Meghalya, might possibly deserve sub-specific or even full species status (Hämäläinen pers. comm. 2007).

The genus Heliocypha Fraser is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

Needham (1930) records cuneata from Guangxi and Tibet but the Guangxi records are misidentifications of Heliocypha fenestrella Rambur (Bridges 1994, Wilson and Reels 2003). Rhinocypha adamantina Foerster, 1903 is a synonym, and this species was previously known by its original name of Rhinocypha cuneata.

The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

A subspecies, Aristocypha hilaryae miaoa Lahiri & Sinha, 1991, has been described from Arunachal Pradesh. It is not clear whether this form really merits subspecific status, or merely represents and extreme of geographical variation.

The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Aristocypha Laidlaw, 1950 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenus of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

Heliocypha angusta is currently considered to have two subspecies: Heliocypha angusta angusta (Hagen in Seys, 1853) from Sumatera and Nias; and Heliocypha angusta oceanis (Lieftinck, 1947) from Enggano Island. It cannot be ruled out that H. a. oceanis deserves a species status (cf. Hämäläinen 2016). Lieftinck (1954) noted: "The Nias form is inseparable from typical angusta". Taking into account the existence of a separate taxon oceanis from Enggano and the newly described species H. vantoli Hämäläinen, 2016 from Siberut, the taxonomic status of the subpopulation from Nias should be verified.

The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenus of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

Heliocypha fenestrata is currently considered to have two subspecies (Hämäläinen 2016): Heliocypha fenestrata fenstrata (Burmeister, 1839) from Java; and Heliocypha fenestrata cornelii (Lieftinck, 1947) from Bali.
The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenus of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenus of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.
The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenus of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2017) treat it as a valid genus.

Lieftinck (1955) distinguished populations from Central and South Sulawesi from those inhabiting the northern Minahasa Peninsula and named the southern form Neurobasis kaupi pavo. Currently they are considered to represent a single taxon owing to widespread intergradation with clinal variation (Günther 2006). Orr and Hämäläinen (2007) have ranked the subspecies pavo as a synonym.

Melanocypha snellemanni is currently considered to have two subspecies (Hämäläinen 2016): Melanocypha snellemanni snellemanni (Albarda in Selys, 1879) from Sumatera; and Melanocypha snellemanni javana (Laidlaw, 1950) from Java. The taxonomic status of the subspecies is unclear and perhaps both may soon be regarded as separate species (Orr 2004).
The taxonomy of Rhinocypha in Sulawesi is still poorly understood. Some of the “geographically recognizable forms” of Rhinocypha frontalis probably will be recognised as separate taxa in future.

The taxonomy of Rhinocypha in Sulawesi is still inadequately studied and poorly understood (cf. Lieftinck 1938, van Tol 2007). Rhinocypha monochroa includes some “geographically recognizable forms” which may represent separate taxa.

The species aorund Guizhaphaenops lipsorum are remarkably variable in several morphological characters (Ueno 2000, Ueno 2006, Deuve & Tian 2016). Guizhaphaenops baiyinensis Deuve 1999 is considered synonym of G. lipsorum Deuve 1999 by Ueno (2006).
The genus Pilosaphaenops is considered as a synonym of Uenotrechus and P. pilosulus as a synonym of Uenotrechus hybridiformis by Uéno (2009).
The genus Pilosaphaenops is considered as a synonym of Uenotrechus by Uéno (2009).

Coeliccia erici has had a confused taxonomic history. The situation surrounding it is clarified in Dow et al. 2018; C. kimurai Asahina is a junior synonym of C. erici and some records of C. erici actually refer to a separate species, C. sameerae Dow et al. 2018.

Dow (2010) revised the Coeliccia borneensis-group of species, including Coeliccia borneensis. The holotype of C. borneensis is a female specimen from somewhere in the Sandakan area on the east side of Sabah, there are some small differences between the holotype and all other female specimens available, but the species appears to exhibit a relatively large degree of variation across its range. It is possible that a number of different species are currently being treated under this name, but the evidence available at present is inconclusive, and it may simply be a variable species, it is treated as such for the purposes of this assessment, where populations treated as, for instance, Coeliccia cf borneensis in the literature are included under C. borneensis.

Hylaeothemis clementia was described from West Kalimantan (Ris 1909) and is known with certainty from Borneo and Peninsular Malaysia; specimens from further north differ consistently in colouration and markings and are likely to represent a separate species.

A subspecies of Coeliccia poungyi, C. p. dasha Kosterin 2016 has been described from Cambodia (Kosterin 2016) and is also known from the south of Vietnam. It is likely that C. p. dasha will ultimately prove to be a separate species.

In Borneo two colour forms occur in males of Lyriothemis biappendiculata. One has a predominantly red thorax when mature, the other a predominantly white thorax when mature. Only one form appears to occur in any given population but there is no clear geographic pattern to the occurrence of the forms or obvious difference in habitat and the available evidence (including some molecular data) does not provide support for the idea that they are separate species. The form occurring in Peninsular Malaysia differs again, having a darker thorax in mature males than any of the Bornean populations; the status of this form requires further investigation, but in the absence of strong evidence that it is a distinct species it is treated as belonging to Lyriothemis biappendiculata for assessment purposes.
Only the female of Lanthanusa cyclopica is known.

A subspecies, Coeliccia membranipes nereis Lieftinck, 1948, is known from Enggano off the west coast of Sumatera, it is likely that this is actually a distinct species and the Enggano population is treated as presence uncertain for assessment purposes.

Coeliccia nemoricola was described from the vicinity of Mount Batu Lawi in the area often referred to as the Kelabit Highlands (including the Tama Abu Range) and other specimens from this area are in good agreement with the type. Specimens that have been treated as C. nemoricola from other locations in Sarawak fall into two categories: (a) a taxon that occurs in the lowlands, and up to over 1,000 m asl away from the Kelabit Highlands and that appears to be a separate species; (b) various higher altitude forms whose status is uncertain at present. Similarly most specimens from elsewhere in Borneo that have been treated as C. nemoricola appear to actually not belong to this species, however specimens from around 1,000 m asl in the Crocker Range and on Mount Kinabalu appear morphologically identical to the true C. nemoricola but diverge from it in the mitochondrial DNA marker COI (see  Figure 4 in Merckx et al. 2015) while a population from the Long Pasia area, adjacent to the border with Sarawak and almost contiguous with the Kelabit Highlands also appears to belong to C. nemoricola, but molecular data are not available for this population. For the purposes of assessment only the populations from the Tama Abu Range and surrounds, Long Pasia, the Crocker Range and Mount Kinabalu are considered to belong to C. nemoricola. Although the Crocker Range and Mount Kinabalu populations might eventually prove to be distinct from C. nemoricola, it seems equally likely that the differences currently seen in the (often very variable) COI marker between these populations and the Kelabit Highlands population will become blurred when data for the Long Pasia population and other, as-yet-undiscovered populations between this and the known Crocker Range population becomes available.

Coeliccia resecta Lieftinck, 1953 has been considered likely to be a junior synonym of C. nigrohamata, however this matter is not settled and it remains possible that C. resecta is a separate, albeit very similar, species to C. nigrohamata. For the purposes of assessment, C. resecta is considered as only known from the type series and all other populations to belong to C. nigrohamata (following most authorities in recent decades); if however C. resecta eventually proves to definitely be a distinct species, then many populations of C. nigrohamata (all those east of the Lupar River in Sarawak) are probably actually C. resecta and both species will need to be reassessed.

Coeliccia resecta has been considered likely to be a junior synonym of C. nigrohamata Laidlaw, 1918, however this matter is not settled and it remains possible that C. resecta is a separate, albeit very similar, species to C. nigrohamata. For the purposes of this assessment, C. resecta, following most authorities in recent decades, is considered as only known from the type series and unpublished specimens from the same location and time; if however it eventually proves to be a distinct species, then many populations of C. nigrohamata (all those east of the Lupar River in Sarawak) are probably actually C. resecta and both species will need to be reassessed.

Coeliccia simillima was described from Bukit Besar (Laidlaw 1917), a location in southern Thailand. Later Laidlaw (1931) discussed a specimen of C. didyma (Selys, 1863), a species described from “Thibet” (Selys 1863; it is likely that these specimens were not actually from Tibet) and listed C. simillima (implicitly) as a junior synonym of C. didyma. After this the name C. simillima almost disappeared from the literature, but Lieftinck (1954: 47, footnote 1) stated that “I am not all convinced that C. simillima Laidlaw should not be specifically distinct from didyma”. The name C. simillima has persisted in world Odonata lists to this day and indeed it was never formally synonymised with C. didyma, but the only record is of the type series. However there are small morphological differences between C. didyma from Peninsular Malaysia and southern Thailand on the one hand, and specimens from, for instance, north west Thailand on the other; the limited molecular data available (Naturalis Biodiversity Center, unpublished) also shows what may be significant differences. If the southern C. didyma should eventually prove to be a distinct species from C. didyma, it is very likely that it will actually be the same as C. simillima. Since these issues are not resolved, C. simillima is treated as known only from the type series for the purposes of assessment.
The female of Drepanosticta asahinai is not known.

Drepanosticta barbatula is closely related to D. simuni Dow & Orr, 2012 which is known from a single specimen from Sarawak. Rosser Garrison (personal communication) has seen a specimen from the Crocker Range in Sabah that might be intermediate between D. barbatula and D. simuni; I have not seen this specimen and it is not known if it represents a distinct species, one of D. barbatula or D. simuni, or provides evidence that D. simuni is a junior synonym of D. barbatula. This specimen is left out of consideration in this assessment. The female of this species is not known.
The female of Drepanosticta batanta is not known.
Only the male of Drepanosticta bicornuta has been described.
Drepanosticta bispina is known from a single female specimen; the male has never been described.
The female of this species is not known.

Drepanosticta crenitis is known from the type series collected on Gunung Poteng near Singkawang, in West Kalimantan in 1932 (Lieftinck 1933). Related forms are widespread in Sarawak, Brunei and Sabah, but differ consistently in the colour of the prothorax from the type series, while the limited molecular data available (not including any from the type series) shows very extensive variation in mitochondrial markers between different populations, although little morphological difference is apparent. Further investigation is required into the status of all populations known from Sarawak, Sabah and Brunei; there may be a number of cryptic and near cryptic species involved. Until more is known only the type series can be regarded as definitely belonging to this species, and other populations are left out of consideration for assessment purposes.

Drepanosticta dentifera is known from the type series (Kimmins 1936) collected on Mount Dulit on the border of Miri and Kapit Divisions in Sarawak and later records from the same mountain (Dow, Reels & Butler 2013). Closely related forms are widespread in Sarawak (e.g. Dow et al. 2015a, Dow & Ngiam 2014, 2015) and Brunei (Dow & Choong, unpublished), but differ in small details, while the limited molecular data available (not including any from the type series) shows very extensive variation in mitochondrial markers between different populations. Further investigation is required into the status of all populations known from Sarawak and Brunei; there may be a number of cryptic and near cryptic species involved. Until more is known only the Mount Dulit population can be regarded as definitely belonging to this species, and other populations are left out of consideration for assessment purposes.

Drepanosticta sharpi was described from the south of Thailand (Laidlaw and Förster 1907), unfortunately the original description and illustrations are inadequate and the type series appears to be lost (Dow et al. 2017). It appears likely that two species are currently being lumped under this name (Dow unpublished) but for the purposes of this assessment all are treated as D. sharpi; however ongoing taxonomic work may eventually result in the splitting of this species and a change to the Red List assessment. The situation is further complicated by the fact that both Drepanosticta viridis Fraser, 1922 from the Mergui Islands of lower Burma and Drepanosticta khaochongensis Asahina, 1984 from Thailand may be junior synonyms of D. sharpi (Dow et al. 2017, Hämäläinen and Pinratana (1999: note 16)); until the situation is clarified, these two taxa are considered as separate species for assessment purposes. The species of the Drepanosticta quadrata (Selys, 1860) group of species, to which D. sharpi belongs, are all similar in general appearance and may be variable in their markings. For these reasons some published records of D. sharpi are likely to be misidentifications of other species from the quadrata-group and conversely some published records of other species may really refer to D. sharpi.

Drepanosticta pan was described from three females and a male from a location in Perak (Laidlaw 1931). Later Lieftinck (1965) recorded a male from a location in Pahang, and a teneral (freshly emerged) female from Perak (probably from the same location as the type series); however Lieftinck’s male differs in significant details from the lectotype of D. pan and may well not be the same species. Subsequently Choong (2013) recorded D. pan from a location in Kelantan, but again the specimens differ in significant details from the lectotype (Choong personal communication) and are likely to be a different species. Only the type series is considered to represent the true D. pan for assessment purposes.

Drepanosticta hamadryas is known with certainty only from the holotype male from Kuala Tahan in Pahang (Laidlaw 1931), and another male from the same area in the collection of the Natural History Museum, London. The holotype is missing the terminal segments of the abdomen but otherwise agrees well with the second male. Allied forms have recently been collected in Terengganu (Choong, Ng & Dow 2012 as Drepanosticta species), Selangor and Negeri Sembilan (Dow unpublished), but these differ in markings and some details of the anal appendages; it is not clear at this time if these specimens represent variation in D. hamadryas or are a separate species. For assessment purposes only the specimens from the Kuala Tahan area are considered to be true D. hamadryas.

Drepanosticta fontinalis is rather variable in its markings, and the species of the D. quadrata (Selys, 1860) group of species, to which D. fontinalis belongs, are all similar in general appearance. For these reasons some published records of D. fontinalis are likely to be misidentifications of other species from the quadrata-group and conversely some published records of other species may really refer to D. fontinalis. Additionally it is possible that some of the apparent variation in D. fontinalis in fact represents additional, almost cryptic, species. Taxonomic work is ongoing on this group; in this assessment most populations are considered to represent D. fontinalis but a form known from some sites in Selangor and Negeri Sembilan and that shows the largest structural differences from typical D. fontinalis is excluded from consideration. A subspecies, D. f. wheeleri Fraser, 1942 was described from the mainland of Penang (Fraser 1942) but Lieftinck (1965) considered this to fall within the variation seen in typical D. fontinalis; the Assessor agrees with this view.

The original description of Drepanosticta vietnamica in Asahina (1997) is inadequate and poorly illustrated, more over the holotype appears to be lost and the surviving paratype disagrees in many respects with the published description (Dow, Kompier & Phan 2018).

Drepanosticta viridis is very similar to D. sharpi (Laidlaw, 1907) and may be junior synonym of that species, however two species may be being treated under D. sharpi currently, so it is equally possible that D. viridis will prove to be a valid species. The female of D. viridis is not definitely known: the only specimen recorded was teneral and Fraser (1922: 39) merely states “most probably related to the two males”.
Only the male of Drepanosticta halmahera is known.

Kaize and Kalkman 2010 recorded a “Drepanosticta spec (near inconspicua)” from Mois Waar Island off the coast of New Guinea in Indonesia’s Papua Barat Province. This taxon is excluded from the assessment.
Although Donnelly (1998) recorded a female of this species, the female has not been described.

Drepanosticta monoceros, only known from two specimens, is very similar to the widespread (in Borneo) Protosticta versicolor Laidlaw, 1913, a rather variable species (especially in wing venation, which is why it is sometimes placed in Drepanosticta and sometimes in Protosticta), and may ultimately prove to be a junior synonym of it.

The type of Drepanosticta pytho is from a location in West Sumatra (Lieftinck 1937). Later Tsuda & Kitagawa (1988) recorded the species from a location in West Sumatra and Sasamoto & Karube (2007) recorded it from three locations in North Sumatra and West Sumatra, and gave the first description of the supposed female, based on a mature female from West Sumatra and a teneral female from North Sumatra. However Toan et al. (2018) have now determined that the male reported from North Sumatra in Sasamoto & Karube (2007) belong to a different species and therefore the identity of the female specimen from North Sumatra is questionable. Therefore only the holotype male and the series reported in Tsuda & Kitagawa (1988), are regarded as definitely belonging to this species in this assessment; the female from West Sumatra may well actually be that of D. pytho, but this cannot be regarded as certain.

Drepanosticta quadrata was described from Singapore. Individuals identified as this species that the Assessor has seen from Johor agree well with examples from Singapore, but records from further north in Peninsular Malaysia are more problematic. The species of the D. quadrata (Selys, 1860) group of species are all similar in general appearance and may be variable in their markings. For these reasons some published records of D. quadrata are likely to be misidentifications of other species from the quadrata-group and conversely some published records of other species may really refer to D. quadrata. Additionally it is possible that some of the apparent variation in D. quadrata in fact represents additional, almost cryptic, species. Taxonomic work is ongoing on this group; for assessment purposes populations from Singapore and Johor are considered to represent D. quadrata but populations from further north are treated as of uncertain identity.

Drepanosticta robusta was described from a single male and female, as van Tol (2007: 274) notes the male “is teneral, incomplete (missing abdominal segments 7-10) and in poor condition”. The female is “presumably conspecific” according to van Tol (2007: 274) but thus assumption does not appear very secure.
The female of Drepanosticta sembilanensis is not known.
The female of Drepanosticta sumatrana is not known.
The female of Drepanosticta watuwilensis is not known.

Drepanosticta simuni is closely related to D. barbatula Lieftinck, 1940 which is known from a few specimens from the east of Borneo. Rosser Garrison (personal communication) has seen a specimen from the Crocker Range in Sabah that might be intermediate between D. barbatula and D. simuni; the assessor has not seen this specimen and it is not known if it represents a distinct species, one of D. barbatula or D. simuni, or provides evidence that D. simuni is a junior synonym of D. barbatula. This specimen is left out of consideration for assessment purposes.

Protosticta curiosa was described from Myanmar. Fraser (1934) noted its similarity to P. foersteri Laidlaw, 1902 and it is possible that the two are synonyms since they differ chiefly in markings and size; this is a subject of ongoing investigation. If the two species eventually prove to be synonymous, P. foersteri takes precedence. Protosticta zhengi Yu and Bu 2009 and P. albifrons Kompier, 2016 are junior synonyms of P. curiosa (Kompier pers. comm. 2017).

Protosticta versicolor was transferred to Drepanosticta by Orr (2001) on the basis of the wing venation of male specimens from Brunei. However this species has either Protosticta or Drepanosticta wing venation in different populations, and in reality is not likely to belong in either genus. Therefore it is best left in Protosticta until the issue of its placement is resolved.

Protosticta satoi was described as a subspecies of P. khaosoidaoensis Asahina, 1984 (Asahina, 1997) from a single female from Tam Dao in Viet Nam. Later van Tol (2008) raised satoi to a full species but considered other material from Tam Dao to belong to a different form, the so-called dark form of P. satoi. All subsequent records from Tam Dao appear to refer to the dark form. Kompier (2016) separated the dark form as P. nigra Kompier, 2016, based on small but apparently consistent differences from P. satoi.

It is possible that Protosticta foersteri is merely a southern form of the widespread P. curiosa, which is structurally similar but differs somewhat in colouration and size. However, until this issue is clarified it is treated as a separate species for assessment purposes.
The female of Protosticta maurenbrecheri is not known.
The female of Protosticta ponmudiensis is not known.
The female of Protosticta reslae is not known.
The female of Telosticta janeus has not been described.
Zwick (2011) removed Perlodes mortoni from synonymy with P. microcephalus.
Possible junior synonym of Parapelecopsis nemoralioides (O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1884) (Wunderlich 1992)
Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Rotundopotamonautes) granviki. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998) and Ng et al. (2008)  referred this species to Potamonautes loveni.
Description (Santos 1965) does not fit with generic diagnosis of Acanthagrion - taxonomic revision needed (von Ellenrieder and Garrison 2007).
Meurgey (2016) treats Brechmorhoga grenadensis as a subspecies of B. praecox.

Described on the basis of a single female from the Sierra de Perija this species has neverbeen found since. De Marmels (1999) examined the type and concluded that B. innupta is a probable synonym of B. flavopunctata (Martin, 1897), a species known from Bolivia to Colombia. However, also, in this case, fresh material from Venezuela, especially males, should be examined before a final conclusion can be drawn (De Marmels 1999).

Tillyard originally described as Alloneura solitaris (Tillyard 1906), and in 1913 (Tillyard 1913) corrected the spelling of the specific name. Additional information (Watson and Theischinger 1984, Houston and Watson 1988).
Transferred from the genus Hylogomphus to Gomphus as the former is now a subgenus.
The female of Argiolestes zane is not known.
Populations previously reported as Nososticta selysi (Förster, 1896) from Timor all appear to belong to Nososticta impercepta (Seehausen & Theischinger 2017).

Drepanosticta forficula is a poorly known species, and at least one closely related but distinct species occurs in northern Borneo. The true identity of specimens from all locations except Mount Dulit (the type locality) is uncertain, so for the purposes of this assessment only the population from Mount Dulit is considered.
There are two sub-species recognized: a northern, univoltine species (Anatrytone logan lagus) and a southern, bivoltine species (Anatrytone logan logan) (Pelham 2021).
The name is noted to be frequently misspelled in literature, usually as “Ancyloxipha” (Warren et al. 2021).

Two subspecies, Atrytone arogos arogos and Atrytone arogos iowa, have been identified. Distribution and ecology for the taxa are quite different, however, morphological differences are subtle (NatureServe 2010).
There are no currently recognized subspecies (Selby 2005).

The genera Metagrion (type species Argiolestes postnodalis) and Wahnesia (type species Argiolestes kirbyi) were not in use for over 70 years, but were reinstated by Kalkman and Theischinger in 2013, resulting in Argiolestes simplex now becoming Wahnesia simplex (Kalkman and Theischinger 2013).

This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. See Lieftinck (1968) for an account of the confused history of this species. The type specimen, a female, has been lost, and the only known male was described as Aeshna nigripes, which Fraser later regarded as a junior synonym of S. martini.
This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. The female of S. pramoti is unknown.
The female is unknown. This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001.
This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. Only the female is known.
This species was transferred to Sarasaeschna by Karube and Yeh in 2001. The female is unknown.

The genera Metagrion (type species Argiolestes postnodalis) and Wahnesia (type species Argiolestes kirbyi)were not in use for over 70 years, but were reinstated by Kalkman and Theischinger in 2013, resulting in Argiolestes connectens now becoming Metagrion connectens (Kalkman and Theischinger 2013).
The genera Metagrion (type species Argiolestes postnodalis) and Wahnesia (type species Argiolestes kirbyi) were not in use for over 70 years, but were reinstated by Kalkman and Theischinger in 2013.

The genera Metagrion (type species Argiolestes postnodalis) and Wahnesia (type species Argiolestes kirbyi) were not in use for over 70 years, but were reinstated by Kalkman and Theischinger in 2013, resulting in Argiolestes luteipes now becoming Wahnesia luteipes (Kalkman and Theischinger 2013).

This species was described as Archiargiolestes pusillissimus (Kennedy 1925). Further taxonomic history is provided by Watson (1977), Houston and Watson (1988), Theischinger and Hawking (2006), and Kalkman and Theischinger (2013).

This species was described as Argiolestes mimimus pusillus (Tillyard 1908) and raised to species rank (Kennedy 1925). A more complete taxonomic history is provided by Watson (1977) and Houston and Watson (1988). Theischinger (1998) transferred this species to Archiargiolestes.

Kalkman and Theischinger (2013) described four new genera: Eoargiolestes (New Caledonia, type species Sympecma ochracea Montrouzier, 1864), Luzonargiolestes (Philippines, type species Argiolestes realensis Gapud & Recuenco, 1993), Solomonargiolestes (Bougainville, Papua New Guinea and Malaita, Solomon Islands, type species Argiolestes bougainville Kalkman, 2008) and Pyrrhargiolestes (Papua New Guinea, type species Argiolestes sidonia Martin, 1909).
Hämäläinen (2005) considered Calopteryx grandaeva Sélys, 1853 must be treated as a synonym of Atrocalopteryx atrata (Sélys, 1853). Chao (1962) synonymised Vestalis tristis Navás with atrata.
Hämäläinen (2014) transferred Calopteryx coomani to Atrocalopteryx.
Hämäläinen (2014) transferred Calopteryx laosica to Atrocalopteryx.
Hämäläinen (2014) transferred Calopteryx melli to Atrocalopteryx.

Hämäläinen (2014) transferred Calopteryx oberthuri to Atrocalopteryx. Calopteryx grahami (Needham, 1930) is a junior synonym of A. oberthueri. Both names are still in use in Chinese literature (for instance Hua 2000; Wang 2007), although C. grahami was synonymized by Asahina (1977). In some publications and world odonate lists A. oberthueri has been erronously placed in the genus Matrona. The wrong combination Matrona oberthueri originates from an error by Fraser (1924), who misidentified a (still unnamed) Matrona taxon as Calopteryx oberthueri.
Pinhey (1972) described the Ugandan record as subspecies karamoja.

Machado (2005) erected the genus Schizocordulia for this species, based on its cleft male epiproct, long inner branch of hamule, pilose plate on male sternum 7 and large vulvar lamina. Garrison et al. (2006) regarded these differences as specific rather than generic.
Weekers and Dumont (2004) transferred all eastern Asian Cercion species to Paracercion.
Weekers and Dumont (2004) transferred all eastern Asian Cercion species to Paracercion.

This species appeared on the IUCN Red List until 2016 as Chlorocypha crocea ssp. bambtoni. However, the correct spelling of the name was Chlorocypha crocea ssp. bamptoni. The subspecies was also promoted to species level. Kipping et al. (2017) transferred the blue Chlorocypha species endemic to Angola to the genus Platycypha.
Kipping et al. (2017) transferred the blue Chlorocypha species endemic to Angola to the genus Platycypha.

The original description was based on a pair, collected from Gisborne, Victoria (Tillyard 1913). Later taxonomic information is provided by Houston and Watson (1988). Dijkstra et al. (2014) transferred this species from Coenagrion to Austrocoenagrion.

This species was originally described from Shanghai under the genus Psilocnemis Sélys, but the Psilocnemis name was preoccupied, and Kirby (1890) subsequently replaced it with Copera. A number of southern Chinese records of annulata have been misidentifications of the similar Copera ciliata Sélys (now Pseudocopera ciliata), described from Malacca and Sumatra, which was treated as a synonym until Asahina (1984) clarified the difference between the two species. Dijkstra et al. (2014) transferred this species from Copera to Pseudocopera.

Asahina (1984) separated Copera ciliata from C. annulata (Selys, 1863). Prior to this it had been regarded as a form of C. annulata. Dijkstra et al. (2014) transferred both C. annulata and C. ciliata from Copera to Pseudocopera.
Dijkstra et al. (2014) transferred this species from Copera to Pseudocopera.
A review of the type material is required to confirm that this is a good species and not a synonym of other close taxa within the genus (D. Azar pers. comm. 2016).
See Dijkstra (2006) for taxonomy.

authority: De Grave, Piscart, Tuekam Kayo & Anker, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species is one of only four species in the genus that belong to a rare group of freshwater crabs endemic to Sierra Leone, West Africa. This genus was recently transferred from the Gecarcinucidae and reassigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckeniini: Globonautina by Cumberlidge et al. (2008).

This species was described by Bott (1969) as Afrithelphusa gerhildae. This species is one of only four species in the genus that belong to a rare group of freshwater crabs endemic to the upper Guinea forest block of West Africa. This genus was recently transferred from the Gecarcinucidae and reassigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckeniini: Globonautina by Cumberlidge et al. (2008).

This species was described by Cumberlidge (1987) as Globonautes leonensis, and was later transferred to the genus Afrithelphusa by Cumberlidge (1999). This species is one of only four species in the genus hat belong to a rare group of freshwater crabs endemic to the upper guinea forest block of West Africa. This genus was recently transferred from the Gecarcinucidae and reassigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckeniini: Globonautina by Cumberlidge et al. (2008).

Bott (1959) described this species as Globonautes monodosus. Cumberlidge (1999) transferred this species to the genus Afrithelphusa Bott, 1969. This species is one of only four species in the genus that belong to a rare group of freshwater crabs endemic to the upper Guinea forest block of West Africa. This genus was recently transferred from the Gecarcinucidae and reassigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckeniini: Globonautina by Cumberlidge et al. (2007).

Bott (1959) treated this taxon as Globonautes macropus macropus, while Cumberlidge (1996, 1999) regarded Globonautes to be a monotypic genus and treated this taxon as Globonautes macropus. This species is one of only five species in two genera that belong to a rare group of freshwater crabs endemic to the upper Guinea forest block of West Africa. This genus was recently transferred from the Gecarcinucidae and reassigned to the Potamonautidae: Deckeniinae: Deckeniini: Globonautina by Cumberlidge et al. (2007). The species is very poorly sampled and a surveys are needed to understand the extent of the species.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) africanus chaperi. Cumberlidge (1985, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this species, transferred it to the genus Liberonautes Bott, 1955, and treated it as the valid species Liberonautes chaperi.
The only published account of this species is Cumberlidge (1999).

Bott (1955) treated this species as Liberonautes latidactylus latidactylus. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this species and regarded it as the valid species Liberonautes latidactylus.
The only published account of this species is Cumberlidge (1999).

Cumberlidge and Sachs (1989) described this species as Liberonautes latidactylus nanoides. Cumberlidge (1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon and treated it as the valid species Liberonautes nanoides.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1999), and additional localities and ecological notes were provided by Cumberlidge and Huguet (2003).

Cumberlidge and Sachs (1989) described this species as Liberonautes latidactylus paludicolis. Cumberlidge (1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon and treated it as the valid species Liberonautes paludicolis. Additional localities and ecological notes were provided by Cumberlidge and Huguet (2003).

Cumberlidge and Sachs (1989) described this species as Liberonautes latidactylus rubigimanus. Cumberlidge (1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon and treated it as the valid species Liberonautes rubigimanus. Additional localities and ecological notes were provided by Cumberlidge and Huguet (2003).
Bott (1955) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) ecorssei. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999) treated this species as Potamonautes ecorssei.
The only published account of this species is Cumberlidge (1999).
Bott (1970) placed this species in the subgenus Isopotamonautes, but Cumberlidge (1999) did not recognize this subgenus category and treated this taxon as Potamonautes senegalensis.
Bott (1959) referred to this taxon as Potamonautes (Platypotamonautes) triangulus. Cumberlidge (1997, 1999) treated this species as Potamonautes triangulus.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) africanus africanus. Cumberlidge (1995, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes africanus.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) aubryi aubryi. Cumberlidge (1994, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes aubryi.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) aubryi floweri. Cumberlidge (1995, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes floweri.

Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) decazei granulatus, a junior synonym of Sudanonautes (Sudanonautes) decazei decazei. Cumberlidge (1993, 1997, 1998, 1999) revised the taxonomy of this taxon as the valid species Sudanonautes granulatus.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1991) with additional localities and ecological notes provided by Cumberlidge (1999).
The only published account of this species is Cumberlidge (1999).

The genus Heliocypha Fraser, 1949 is considered by some taxonomists as a subgenera of Rhinocypha Rambur, 1842; Schorr and Paulson (2018) treat it as a valid genus. Heliocypha biseriata is likely to eventually prove to be synonymous with the widespread H. biforata.
The miss-association of females with males in the original description (Laidlaw 1915) of R. moultoni is discussed by Hämäläinen (2009).

Females and atypical males that might or might not be of this species are known from various locations in Sarawak, but in the assessor's view they are more likely to represent one or more additional species and are excluded from the assessment.

The only record of Archibasis oscillans from Vietnam of which the assessor is aware is on the http://odonatavietnam.blogspot.my website, where it is noted that the anal appendages of the Vietnamese species are not an exact match for A. oscillans and therefore it may not really be that species. For assessment purposes the presence of the species in Vietnam is regarded as in need of confirmation. A subspecies, A. oscillans hanwellanensis, is recognised from Sri Lanka.
The female of Archibasis rebeccae has not been described.

Amphicnemis dactylostyla (described from Central Kalimantan) and A. martini Lieftinck, 1953 (described from West Kalimantan) are closely related species, differing mainly in details of the superior anal appendages of the males. Forms resembling both species occur in Sarawak and Brunei, as well as similar forms differing in their anal appendage morphology. At present it is not clear how many species are present in the group, and it is even possible that all available specimens merely represent a single, variable species, although the distribution of the different forms seems to rule out simple klinal variation. Until taxonomic progress is made with the group it is best to treat both A. dactylostyla and A. martini as only known from the area of their type localities, to prevent possible vast over estimates of their ranges; this course is followed for assessment purposes here.

Amphicnemis dactylostyla (described from Central Kalimantan) and A. martini Ris, 1911 (described from West Kalimantan) are closely related species, differing mainly in details of the superior anal appendages of the males. Forms resembling both species occur in Sarawak and Brunei, as well as similar forms differing in their anal appendage morphology. At present it is not clear how many species are present in the group, and it is even possible that all available specimens merely represent a single, variable species, although the distribution of the different forms seems to rule out simple klinal variation. Until taxonomic progress is made with the group it is best to treat both A. dactylostyla and A. martini as only known from the area of their type localities, to prevent possible vast over estimates of their ranges; this course is followed for assessment purposes here.

In addition to confirmed A. wallacii, at least two closely allied forms occur in north Borneo. Although it is possible that one or more of these forms actually represent distinct species, in the assessor’s opinion it is much more like that they merely represent geographical variation in a single species and all are treated as A. wallacii for assessment purposes.

Teinobasis gracillima is only known from the holotype male (Fraser 1926). Lieftinck (1934: 451) states that it is identical with Teinobasis superba (Selys), but the name has persisted in lists of Odonata and Lieftinck’s statement requires confirmation.

It is possible that Teinobasis kirbyi is the same species as Teinobasis laidlawi Kimmins, 1936. It is also possible (but unlikely) that only the holotype is the true T. kirbyi and the second record (Wilson & Gibert 2005) is another species. These issues are discussed in detail in Dow (2010).
