It is possible that Teinobasis laidlawi is a junior synonym of Teinobasis kirbyi Laidlaw, 1902. This issue is discussed in detail in Dow (2010).

Elattoneura coomansi has been recorded from India, the first mention of the species from India appears to be that in Prasad & Varshney (1995: 394) who cite Lieftinck (1937) as giving “India” in its range. However Lieftinck (1937) does not mention India in the range of this species, the only mention made of India is (Lieftinck 1937: 80) “By its sombre colours this new species comes closest to E. tetrica (Laid.) and E. nigerrima (Laid.) from Peninsular India”. Subsequently the species has been reported from Nagaland by Joshi & Kunte (2014) but the photograph provided (Image 6g) whilst not adequate for definite identification, shows colour and patterns unlike E. coomansi from Sundaland. It is not clear what species is being reported from Nagaland but in the opinion of the assessor it is very unlikely to be E. coomansi and it is not considered to be E. coomansi for the purposes of assessment.

Dow and Silvius (2014) recorded unusually small individuals of this species, with reduced and atypical pale markings, at three peat swamp forest sites in Central Kalimantan. They also recorded typical individuals at a stream and individuals that were possibly intermediate between the two forms in a habitat that was intermediate. It is not clear whether the atypical form is merely due phenotypic plasticity in E. longispina or represents a distinct species or speciation in process. In the assessors opinion phenotypic plasticity is the most likely explanation, however individuals from peat swamp forest in Sarawak are normal. For the purposes of assessment all are treated as E. longispina, but with uncertainty over the peat swamp forest form.

Prodasineura flammula was described (Lieftinck 1948) from a single male from East Kalimantan, and stated to differ from P. dorsalis by an orange band between the eyes, deeper orange markings on the thorax and slightly different anal appendages. However the first two characters vary from east to west in P. dorsalis, with specimens from the east of Sarawak and further east identical to P. flammula and the third character, in the assessor’s opinion, is almost certainly due to distortion or a slight rotation of the anal appendages compared with the typical state. However the holotype of P. flammula must be checked before this can be confirmed. Tsuda & Kitagawa (1989) recorded P. flammula from Sabah but this record is almost certainly a misidentification of P. dorsalis based on colour and pattern following Lieftinck (1948) and is not considered in the assessment.
The female of this species has not been described at the time of writing, although female specimens are present in at least two collections.

Prodasineura haematosoma differs from P. hyperythra solely in details of colouration. However P. hyperythra shows considerable variation in colouration across its range, and P. haematosoma may merely be a junior synonym of P. hyperythra. Against this, there is to be an area between the definitely known ranges of each taxon in Sarawak where neither has been found (as of September 2018) despite the presence of suitable habitat, which could be taken as evidence that the two are distinct. On the other hand P. hyperythra was recorded from West Kalimantan without details by Lieftinck (1954) and the assessor (Dow 2005) recorded it from within the range of P. haematosoma, this was based on a sight record and could have been misidentified, but a specimen identified as P. hyperythra was collected at the same location in 2008; unfortunately the specimen in question is no longer available to the assessor to recheck the identification.

Prodasineura haematosoma differs from P. hyperythra solely in details of colouration. However P. hyperythra shows considerable variation in colouration across its range, and P. haematosoma may merely be a junior synonym of P. hyperythra. Against this, there is to be an area between the definitely known ranges of each taxon in Sarawak where neither has been found (as of September 2018) despite the presence of suitable habitat, which could be taken as evidence that the two are distinct. On the other hand P. hyperythra was recorded from West Kalimantan without details by Lieftinck (1954) and the assessor (Dow 2005) recorded it from within the range of P. haematosoma, this was based on a sight record and could have been misidentified, but a specimen identified as P. hyperythra was collected at the same location in 2008; unfortunately the specimen in question is no longer available to the assessor to recheck the identification.
As noted in Dow & Stokvis (2018) Heliogomphus borneensis is very similar to Heliogomphus kelantanensis and may eventually prove to be a junior synonym of it.
The female of Linaeschna polli is unknown.

This species was originally described as Argiocnemis alcyone. The relationship of Argiocnemis, Agriocnemis and Mortonagrion to one another, and the status of the latter two genera, need to be clarified, but this species may well belong in Argiocnemis.
Orr & Hämäläinen (2013) placed specimens from Brunei and Sarawak that had previously treated as P. triangularis into two new species, leaving only the holotype female under the name P. triangularis.

“Prodasineura peramoena was described from specimens from Lawas and Limbang District (Laidlaw 1913). Later it was recorded from the Kapit side of the main Dulit ridge and from Marudi (Kimmins 1936), but these specimens differ from the type in having reduced red colouration on the prothorax. Later similar forms, differing in having further reduced and less intensely red markings (orange-red rather than bright scarlet) were recorded from Brunei (e.g. Orr (2001) as Prodasineura sp. aff. hosei) and other parts of Sarawak (Bintulu, Kapit and Miri Divisions, including on the Kapit side of Mount Dulit). In 2016 I found specimens with even further reduced red markings in the Samunsam Wildlife Sanctuary in Kuching Division. I have compared recently collected specimens directly against the type of P. peramoena and the series examined by Kimmins, they are structurally identical but the colour differences are striking. Fresh material from locations in Limbang Division is needed, and although it is peculiar that no recently collected specimens have the bright red markings of older material, I suspect that all these forms are merely variations of P. peramoena and have listed all records from Sarawak under this species accordingly.” Dow (2019, in press), the same view is taken for assessment purposes.

Vestalis anacolosa is very likely to be the same species as V. atropha (see Dow et al. 2018), in which case since both were described in Lieftinck (1965) it will be up to the first reviser to decide which name is the junior synonym. However in the opinion of the assessor the name V. atropha is to be preferred, if for no other reason than that it has appeared in the literature more often than V. anacolosa. Records of V. anacolosa from Sarawak certainly refer to V. atropha (Dow et al. 2018).

Euthygomphus parvus was placed in Merogomphus until Kosterin (2016) transferred it to his new genus Euthygomphus. In the same publication Kosterin showed that records of E. parvus from north of peninsula Thailand actually refer to E. yunnanensis and “parvus has not been in fact reported northerly of Malay Peninsula”, leaving some ambiguity over a record in Asahina (1986) from Khao Chang Forest in Trang Province, peninsula Thailand. The record from Trang is treated as in need of confirmation for assessment purposes, but may well refer to E. parvus.

A subspecies, D. a. tiomanensis Laidlaw, 1934 occurs on Tioman Island of the southeast coast of Peninsular Malaysia.  However D. a. tiomanensis apparently differs from D. a. argyroides only in the colouration of the wing tips; it is doubtful whether tiomanenis deserves subspecific status.

The type of Enallagma maldivense was examined by K.D. Dijkstra (personal communication) and revealed to not be an Enallagma at all, but some species of Aciagrion, probably the widespread A. borneense.
Many populations from the southern Philippines were split into two new species by Kalkman and Villanueva (2011).

Pseudagrion coomansi is considered to be a junior synonym of P. williamsoni by some authorities but in the opinion of the assessor this has yet to be securely established and the two are best kept separate until a thorough investigation of this issue is undertaken.

Ceriagrion hoogerwerfi was treated as a subspecies of C. bellona by Asahina (1967) but is still treated as a separate species by some authorities. Since some differences between the two taxa in, for instance, the male anal appendages, are apparent in Asahina’s own illustrations, so Ceriagrion hoogerwerfi is kept separate from C. bellona until a thorough investigation is made.

Anisopleura yunnanensis Zhu and Zhou, 1999 might be a junior synonym of A. subplatystyla. The species has not been compared against confirmed subplatystyla specimens, and appears to be at least close to that species (Hämäläinen pers. comm. 2007, Wilson pers. comm. 2007). As-yet-unpublished molecular data from the Naturalis Biodiversity Center, Leiden does not provide any support for A. yunnanensis as a separate species. Anisopleura lieftincki Prasad & Ghosh, 1984 has already proved to be a junior synonym of A. subplatystyla.

Additionally, "Mitra and Thinley (2006) described a new species of Anisopleura with the name bella. This publication does not fulfil the requirements of Arcticle 8.1 of the Code of Zoological Nomenclature and therefore the name is not available for zoological nomenclature (Hämäläinen 2016). The characters mentioned for this species seem to fall within the variation of A. subplatystyla." Gyeltshen et al. (2017: note 6 on page 9746).
It is likely that M. euterpe Laidlaw, 1915 will prove to be a junior synonym of M. westwoodii, see Dow et al. (2019).

Some records of this species from Thailand, and possibly from other areas, may actually refer to the recently described O. priydak Kosterin. Records from Hong Kong appear to refer to a third, undescribed, species, and Judging from photographs the species occurring in Taiwan is also not the true O. atrocyana. However the true O. atrocyana certainly occurs in Yunnan.

This species has been recorded from Borneo (Hincks 1930), where it was regarded as a wind borne migrant. However Dow & Ngiam (2015) recorded Tramea species cf virginia in the interior of Sarawak, noting differences from typical T. virginia. It is possible that the taxon recorded from Borneo is not T. virginia but a distinct species, and it either case it may actually be resident on the island.

Asahina (1978) described this species from a single specimen from India. In 1987 he re-described the species based on specimens from Doi Suthep in Thailand. Hämäläinen (2003) noted discrepancies between the insect originally described and that from Doi Suthep, and described the Thai taxon as a new species in a newly erected genus Cryptophaea. Thus the only known specimen of Schmidtiphaea schmidi is the holotype.
There is some molecular evidence that M. calliope Ris, 1916 could be a junior synonym of this species (Dow et al. 2019), but this is a subject of ongoing investigation.

Macromia euterpe is at best doubtfully distinct from M. westwoodii Selys, 1874 (see Dow et al. 2019) and is likely to be synonymised with it in the near future. For assessment purposes only the type series and other records from higher altitudes on Mount Kinabalu are considered as definitely of this species.
Onychogomphus castor is placed in Lamelligomphus by some authorities, probably correctly.

Prodasineura autumnalis was originally described under the genus Caconeura Kirby from Shillong, Assam. There are several synonyms: Prodasineura corvina Lieftinck (1930) from Java, Indoneura dolorosa Needham (1930) from Hainan and Fujian, and Caconeura gaudawricus Sahni (1964) from India. Prodasineura nigra (Fraser, 1922) was described from King Island, Mergui, lower Burma. Fraser (1933) stated nigra and also Prodasineura odoneli from Bengal are very closely related to autumnalis and "may be but local races of a single species". As pointed out by Wilson and Xu (2007), using Fraser’s (1933) key, mature Chinese autumnalis keys out as nigra. Both names may prove to be synonyms. If synonymy is confirmed, a First Reviser must determine the precedence of the simultaneously published names (Art. 24.2.2, International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature). P. sita Kirby is a Sri Lankan endemic which superficially resembles immature P. autumnalis but has distinctive superior appendages (cf. De Fonseka 2000) and was erroneously recorded from Guangdong and Yunnan, China by Sui and Sun (1984). 
However P. autumnalis itself may prove to be a junior synonym of P. humeralis (sometimes treated as a subspecies of P. verticalis).
Two subspecies have sometimes been recognized for this species, P. p. ranauense from Sumatra and P. p. fraseri from parts of mainland Asia.

Two subspecies, L. p. sikkima Fraser and L. p. decipens Kirby have been recognised for this species, and there are a number of very closely related species; some records of L. praemorsus from parts of its range may refer to other species, but on the other hand possibly one or more of the closely related species may eventually prove to be a junior synonym of L. praemorsus. The entire group needs a thorough revision including a molecular analysis.

There is possibly significant variation in colouration and possibly other characters across the range of this species, particularly in females. It is possible that more than one species is being treated under the name Pericnemis stictica.

In the Nearctic the species is replaced by its sister species Aeshna septentrionalis (Burmeister, 1839). By some authors it is considered to be a subspecies of A. caerulea. As the taxon A. septentrionalis does not occur in Europe, this discussion has no influence on the European regional assessment.

Formerly, Boyeria cretensis was confused with—and regarded as a subpopulation of—Boyeria irene (Fonscolombe, 1838), but both species are clearly distinct (Boudot 1989, Peters 1991, Kohli et al. 2014).

A number of subspecies and forms have been described in the Calopteryx splendens group. Their validity is sometimes doubtful and the overall systematics and genetics of these taxa are far from being elucidated, although genetic research is currently developing rapidly. For these reasons, C. splendens will be assessed here as a collective taxon.

Until recently Ceragrion georgiferyi was considered a subspecies of Ceriagrion tenellum, but both male and female show distinct morphological characters and it is now considered to be a full species (Schneider 1986, Kalkman 2005).
The various subspecies formerly described are no more regarded as valid, due to the important variability of the species.
The European population has been regarded by some authors as a distinct subspecies (Lohmann 1992, Kiauta & Kiauta 1991), but subsequent studies showed that threre is no evidence for this.
The male of this species is unknown.
Petaliaeschna pinratanai Yeh, 1999 is a junior synonym of this species.
This species is considered doubtful, as its supposed localities are relatively well sampled.

Aeshna athalia was described from a single female specimen from Zhejiang, China (Needham 1930) and has never been recorded since. The original description of the species (Needham 1930) agrees in many respects with the female of Anax nigrofasciatus Oguma, 1915, and it is likely that Aeshna athalia is a junior synonym of Anax nigrofasciatus, but this requires confirmation.

Aeshna frontalis does not appear to have been recorded since its description where Navás (1936) notes that the species is similar to Aeshna lucia Needham, 1930, which is generally regarded as a junior synonym of A. mixta Latreille, 1805. It is therefore quite possible that A. frontalis is also a junior synonym of A. mixta, but this requires confirmation.

Although Gyeltshen and Kalkman (2017) recorded Aeshna shennong from Bhutan based on a female specimen, they note that there “are some slight differences between the type series of A. shennong and our specimen, with the yellow markings being larger and the cerci being shorter and slimmer, and further material might show that more than one taxon is involved” (Gyeltshen and Kalkman 2017: 349). Gyeltshen and Kalkman (2017) also mention a photographic record from Yunnan, but this also cannot be considered as certain.

Gynacantha dohrni was described from Sumatra (Krüger 1899) and is widespread in Sundaland. It has been recorded from Viet Nam (for instance Kompier and Holden 2017) but Kosterin and Chartier (2018) considered these records to refer to Gynacantha demeter Ris, 1911. However, G. demeter, described from Borneo, is itself likely to be a junior synonym of G. dohrni. Gynacantha dohrni and its allies are in need of revision and until this happens the identity of specimens from north of Peninsular Malaysia is best left open, and they are left out of consideration for assessment purposes here. It is also certainly possible that some records from Sundaland actually refer to different but closely related species.

Gynacantha furcata was described from a single female supposedly collected somewhere in Borneo (Rambur 1842) and has never been reported again. The original description is inadequate to reliably identify the species. Lieftinck (1954) noted that Gynacantha bayadera Selys, 1891 is likely to be a junior synonym of G. furcata but until the type of furcata is examined (if it still exists) this issue cannot be satisfactorily resolved.

Fraser (1926) recorded the south Asian species Gynacantha millardi from Java, but this was a misidentification of G. bayadera Selys (see Lieftinck 1934). However, Lieftinck’s comments on the Javan record of G. millardi were misinterpreted by many later authors as a statement that G. millardi is a junior synonym of G. bayadera, leading to a suppression of the name G. millardi (see Kalkman et al. 2020) that was followed by most (but not all) authors. Because of this confusion it is likely that some or even many records of G. bayadera from India actually refer to G. millardi, however G. bayadera also occurs in India, at least in the northeast (Kalkman et al. 2020). Recently, Priyadarshana et al. (2015) recorded G. millardi from Sri Lanka and demonstrated that it is a distinct species. As noted by Kalkman et al. (2020: note 47) “It is unclear if the two species [bayadera and millardi] overlap in distribution and a review of records of both species from the Indian subcontinent is needed.” For assessment purposes, records identified as G. millardi are considered.

Anaciaeschna megalopis was described from a single female (Martin 1908). Later Fraser (1926) described Anaciaeschna huonensis from a single male collected more than 550 km away. Lieftinck (1937: footnote on page 53) declared Fraser’s species to be a junior synonym of A. megalopis without any supporting argument, so the synonymy may not be sound.
This species may be a junior synonym of Periaeschna gerrhon (Wilson, 2005), this issue requires further investigation.
Oligoaeschna andamani is known from a single female specimen and in these circumstances the possibility that it is a synonym of some other Oligoaeshna species cannot be ruled out.

Oligoaeschna petalura was described by M.A. Lieftinck from a single male collected at Mount Wuzhi, Hainan, China on 25 May 1903 and deposited in the British Museum of Natural History. Two groups of Oligoaeschna were recognised by Lieftinck (1968). These comprise (1) pryeri-group: brightly coloured, probably diurnal, female cerci short and inconspicuous, males with prominent black T-mark on top of frons; and (2) poeciloptera group: sombre, crepuscular, females with prominent, long cerci resembling stalked paddles. Based principally on the structure of the penile organ Karube and Yeh (2001) established the genus Sarasaeschna to receive members attributed by Lieftinck (1968) to the pryeri-group of Oligoaeschna. Oligoaeschna is a member of the Gomphaeschninae subfamily whose members have an ancient lineage that were flourishing in the tertiary period. The Gomphaeschninae represent a sister group to all other extant aeshnids (von Ellenrieder 2002).

The only definite record of this species is of the holotype male from Shillong in the Khasi Hills in Meghalaya, India (Fraser 1935). The status of the species has been discussed at various times since its description, perhaps most thoroughly by Asahina (1981) who noted that the specimen considered to be the holotype (there appears to be some room for doubt over whether this specimen is really the holotype, but if it is not then the true holotype is likely to have been lost) is very similar to Periaeschna nocturnalis Fraser, 1927 and likely to be a junior synonym of that species; Karube and Kompier (2018) note that the matter is unresolved. However, the species has also been treated as a junior synonym of Cephalaeschna viridifrons (Fraser, 1922). The entire situation is very confused, Kalkman et al. (2020) do not list P. biguttata in their checklist of Odonata from South Asia, but it is not clear if this is an omission or represents an opinion that the species is a junior synonym of some other.
Periaeschna mira does not appear to have been recorded since its description, but Wilson & Xu (2008) note that Periaeschna flinti Asahina, 1978 may be a junior synonym of P. mira.
Planaeschna guentherpetersi is likely to be a junior synonym of another Planaeschna species (Kompier personal communication 2020, Kompier & Karube in preparation).

There may be a confused situation with regards to Southeast Asian Tetracanthagyna species. Tetracanthagyna degorsi, known from both sexes, is known to have polymorphic females (Lieftinck 1954), T. brunnea, known from the female only, might also have polymorphic females. It is not clear if the characters that have been used to separate the females of the two are truly diagnostic. A revision is needed but progress toward such a revision is hampered by the scarcity of male specimens in collections. Most records are of females or of larvae, and there is frequently uncertainty over the identification of females. Moreover, regarding T. degorsi Lieftinck (1954) stated that specimens from Java and Sumatra differ from typical T. degorsi. For assessment purposes all records stated to be of degorsi or likely to be degorsi are considered but a future revision may dramatically change which records are included under this species.

Populations of Caridina holthuisi appear in two allopatric clades, with one in Lake Matano, Petea River and Lake Mahalona and the other in Lake Towuti. No morphological differences have been observed so far. The existence of two cryptic species is therefore likely.
Several types of females of Ischnura aralensis occur which differ in colour and morphology. This led to much confusion and to the description the synonym Ischnura haritonovi Dumont, 1997.

A number of subspecies of Ischnura elegans have been described, of which only the widely accepted I. e. elegans (Vander Linden, 1820), I. e. ebneri Schmidt, 1938 and I. e. pontica Schmidt, 1938 are recognised in this assessment; all are treated together here.

Fraser (1933) noted that in his original description of Pseudagrion bidentatum Morton (1907) appeared to have mixed up the descriptions of two species (P. hypermelas and P. spencei). It is very likely that P. bidentaum is a synonym of one of these two species, probably P. hypermelas, but the type specimen, if still in existence, does not appear to have been re-examined since the species was described and the name has persisted in species lists despite the lack of any later record.
Pseudagrion daponshanensis is a highly dubious species, almost certainly a junior synonym of some other.

A number of subspecies of Pseudagrion pilidorsum are currently recognised (some of which may eventually prove to be distinct species). Pseudagrion p. pilidorsum (Brauer, 1868) is known from Borneo, the Philippines, Taiwan and southern Japan. Pseudagrion p. enganoense Lieftinck, 1948 is known from Engano Island off of Sumatra, Pseudagrion p. declaratum Lieftinck, 1936 is known from the east of Java, Bali and a number of the Lesser Sunda Islands, Pseudagrion p. deflexum Lieftinck, 1936 from Timor and part of the Moluccas, Pseudagrion p. obscurum Lieftinck 1936 from Nias Island off of Sumatra and Pseudagrion p. simalurum Lieftinck, 1948 from the Mentawei Islands. The form occurring in the Andaman Islands has not been assigned to a subspecies yet (Hämäläinen et al. 1999). It should be noted that in recent years a number of photographs taken in Sulawesi identified as P. pilidorsum have appeared in online sources, all of these seen by the assessor are actually either P. ustum Selys, 1876 or (in at least one case) P. crocops Selys, 1876.

Schmidtiphaea chittaranjani was described in Bayadera by Lahiri (2003). Hämäläinen (2013) transferred it to Schmidtiphaea; it may be a junior synonym of Schmidtiphaea schmidi Asahina, 1978. However the condition of the holotype of S. schmidi is such that a resolution of the issue awaits the collection of fresh specimens of S. schmidi.

Most records of this species are of larvae and it is possible that some of them will eventually prove to be of some other closely related species. A single male from Samar in the Philippines differs in some respects from typical examples from Borneo, and may represent a distinct but closely allied species.

There are some morphological differences between specimens of this species from Java and from Sumatera and it is possible that they will eventually prove to be distinct species. However all are treated as Acrogomphus walshi for assessment purposes.
As noted in Dow and Stokvis (2018), Heliogomphus borneensis is very similar to Heliogomphus kelantanensis and may eventually prove to be a junior synonym of it.

Macrogomphus abnormis is only known from the female and it has been suggested that it is a junior synonym of M. quadratus (for instance by Lieftinck 1954). However the assessor has examined the type material and differences in the markings are outside of the variation known from confirmed M. quadratus, so that the species should certainly be maintained as distinct at least until more information becomes available.

The situation with Macrogomphus parallelogramma and M. phalantus appears confused, with some records of the latter from Peninsular Malaysia possibly really referring to the former. These issues will remain unresolved until the group is revised and for assessment purposes records listed as M. phalantus from Peninsular Malaysia are treated as in need of confirmation.
Phaenandrogomphus safei may not be correctly placed in Phaenandrogomphus, possibly belonging in Nychogomphus. This is discussed in Dow et al. (2018).

Lestes praecellens is very similar to L. praemorsus and could possibly be merely a variant or form of that species. However this is an open question and several species may currently all be treated as L. praemorsus.

Theischinger and Richards (2014) noted that Microtrigonia petaurina is known from a single female specimen and that “this specimen is the only known specimen of the species and is clearly close to M. gomphoides we retain it as a distinct species until further material is available”; it is possible that the two species will eventually prove to be synonyms.

Prodasineura flammula was described (Lieftinck 1948) from a single male from East Kalimantan, and stated to differ from P. dorsalis by an orange band between the eyes, deeper orange markings on the thorax and slightly different anal appendages. However the first two characters vary from east to west in P. dorsalis, with specimens from the east of Sarawak and further east identical to P. flammula. The third character, in the assessor’s opinion, is almost certainly due to distortion or a slight rotation of the anal appendages compared with the typical state. However the holotype of P. flammula must be checked before this can be confirmed.

The description of Prodasineura hanzhongensis, or at least the English summary given in Yang & Li (1995), appears to be inadequate and not deal with structural characters likely to be truly diagnostic. It is likely that the species is a junior synonym of some other Prodasineura species.

Prodasineura longjingensis (described in Caconeura) is (Zhou 1981) stated to only differ from Prodasineura auricolor only in a few details of colouration and size and is likely to actually be a junior synonym of P. auricolor or some other Prodasineura species.

Prodasineura nigra is extremely similar to P. autmnalis (described in the same publication: Fraser 1922) and even Fraser (1933) doubted that they were distinct species. However P. autumnalis itself is likely to be a junior synonym of P. humeralis (which is currently and probably incorrectly treated as a subspecies of P. verticalis by some authorities).
Neurothemis manadensis was previously considered to be a subspecies of N. stigmatizans but was split off as a distinct species by Seehausen & Dow (2016).

Onychothemis celebensis was described as a subspecies of O. culminicola and is still treated as such by some authorities. The true status of the species will only be determined by a thorough revision of the genus.
Phyllothemis raymondi and Phyllothemis eltoni are very similar to each other and may eventually prove to be the same species.
Rhyothemis pygmaea has been confused with R. fulgens, with all records of the former from west of the Wallace line actually referring to R. fulgens (see Dow et al. 2015).

There has been confusion over the identification of Tyriobapta kuekenthali and T. laidlawi at least since the publication of Orr (2003) and probably for longer; this issue is discussed in Dow et al. (2020) and the reader is referred to that discussion. One consequence of the confusion is that records of T. laidlawi in a number of publications (Cleary et al. 2004, Lieftinck 1953a, Lieftinck 1953b, Thompson & van Tol 1993 and Noorhidayah-Mamat et al. 2014) may actually refer to T. kuekenthali, most of the specimens concerned are available to be checked in principle but this check has not been carried out at the time of writing. Therefore the records from the listed publications are simply left out of consideration for mapping and most other assessment purposes at this time, other records are used in corrected form. This has little effect on the threat category in which either species is placed in practice, but does have implications for their distributions. In particular if the record of T. laidlawi from Peninsular Malaysia in Noorhidayah-Mamat et al. (2014) actually refers to T. kuekenthali then T. laidlawi is only known from Borneo.

There has been confusion over the identification of Tyriobapta kuekenthali and T. laidlawi at least since the publication of Orr (2003) and probably for longer; this issue is discussed in Dow et al. (2020) and the reader is referred to that discussion. One consequence of the confusion is that records of T. laidlawi in a number of publications (Cleary et al. 2004, Lieftinck 1953a, Lieftinck 1953b, Thompson & van Tol 1993 and Noorhidayah-Mamat et al. 2014) may actually refer to T. kuekenthali, most of the specimens concerned are available to be checked in principle but this check has not been carried out at the time of writing. Therefore the records from the listed publications are simply left out of consideration for mapping and most other assessment purposes at this time, other records are used in corrected form. This has little effect on the threat category in which either species is placed in practice, but does have implications for their distributions. In particular if the record of T. laidlawi from Peninsular Malaysia in Noorhidayah-Mamat et al. (2014) actually refers to T. kuekenthali then T. laidlawi is only known from Borneo.
Macromia corycia is very similar to M. gerstaeckeri Krüger, 1899 and may eventually prove to be a junior synonym of that species.

This species pertains to the Ischnura pumilio (Charpentier, 1825) group and is a close relative of the Asian I. forcipata Morton, 1907. Field separation with the latter is almost impossible and close examination under the microscope is needed. Keys to Middle East Ischnura species including I. intermedia are provided by Schneider (1986) and Kalkman (2006). Further comparisons with I. forcipata are to be found in Dumont (1974) and Dumont and Borisov (1995).

Until recently this species was regarded as subspecies of Pyrrhosoma nymphula. Kalkman and Lopau (2006) illustrated the differences between the two taxa and confirmed that they should be treated as two full valid species.

There have been speculations about Sicilian populations being a distinct subspecies, Cordulegaster bidentata sicilica Fraser, 1929. However, more recent genetic studies found no evidence to support the validity of this subspecies (Froufe et al. 2014, Boudot and Holusa 2015). Still, the overall systematic organisation of the various members of this taxon remains unclear (Boudot 2001, Boudot et al. 2009).

Until recently, four subspecies were described: Cordulegaster boltonii boltonii, C. b. immaculifrons in southern France and Iberia; C. b. iberica in Iberia; and C. b. algirica in southern Spain and northern Morocco. A molecular study found no clear separation among the four subspecies, with the exception of the populations of Cordulegaster boltonii algirica from North Africa (Froufe et al. 2014) . Therefore we do not longer consider C. b. immaculifrons and C. b. iberica to be valid.

Three subspecies have been described: Cordulegaster helladica helladica, C. h. buchholzi and C. h. kastalia, but the separation between them remains very difficult and even intermediate forms between those subspecies have been described.

The two subspecies described: Cordulegaster heros heros Theischinger, 1979 and Cordulegaster heros pelionensis Theischinger, 1979. These subspecies differ only by the shape or the lack of the black band on the frons in male imagoes, and are not assessed separately for the Red List.

Many records of this taxon have been published under the closely related Cordulegaster boltonii, but both taxa are structurally well distinct, although colour pattern is almost similar. Ongoing genetic investigations confirms the full species rank for this taxon.

The Easternmost populations in the Russian Far East and Japan are sometimes regarded as a distinct subspecies (Cordulia aenea amurensis), but as no definite range can be ascribed to these populations, which are poorly differentiated, this is not consensually accepted (J.-P. Boudot, pers. comm.)

All the Siberian populations previously described as subspecies (Epitheca bimaculata sibirica Selys, 1887, E. b. altaica Belyshev, 1951) are now regarded as synonym of the nominotypical form, so that E. bimaculata extends over an enormous range going from western France to the Far East of Russia and Japan.

Neither S. exuberata nor S. meridionalis are included within the European assessment. Somatochlora coreana Doi, 1938 cannot be a synonym of S. metallica as the latter doesn't occur really in Korea, where it is replaced by S. exuberata, formerly considered as a subspecies of S. metallica. Presently, S. exuberata '= S. coreana Doi, 1938 = S. japonica Matsumura, 1911) is regarded as a full species.
Three autumnal records of Paragomphus costae Selys, 1885 from the central Sahara (Reymond 1952) should be regarded as Paragomphus genei rather than O. costae, as the latter does not fly in October.

Ophiogomphus obscurus, O. spnicornis and O. reductus were formerly considered as subspecies of O. cecilia. Presently these Asian taxa are regarded as full species and as they do not occur in Europe, this discussion has no influence on the European regional assessment.

Further east L. rubicunda is replaced by L. intermedia, which almost reach the boreal Urals (Kosterin & Zaika 2010, Kalkman & Lohr 2015). Since L. intermedia does not occur in Europe it has no bearing on the European assessment.

The species is currently split into two subspecies: Orthetrum coerulescens anceps (located in northern Africa, Sardinia, the southern Balkans and parts of Asia) and O. c. coerulescens. Intermediate forms occur in Iberia, Sicily and large parts of south-eastern Europe (Dijkstra and Lewington 2006).

Mauersberger (1994) suggests that O. coerulescens and O. anceps are not full species but either members of a superspecies or even subspecies which would have to be united under the older name Orthetrum coerulescens (Fabricius). The species overlaps with Orthetrum coerulescens, in Europe and hybrids have been recorded.
It has been discussed whether S. nigrifemur is a subspecies of S. striolatum. But here it is assessed as a valid species.

Parts of the Balkan populations are refered to the subspecies Platycnemis pennipes nitidula (Brullé 1832). It has a very narrow range and seems to hybridize with the nominotypical subspecies so that its precise range is still unclear. Both taxa are assessed together here, although some people regard them as distinct species due to their structural differences.

Previously two subspecies of Megalagrion koelense were listed: M. koelense peles and M. koelense waianaeanum. The subspecies status is doubted, therefore only the nominate species is currently considered (see Polhemus 1997, Polhemus and Asquith 1996).

Vestalis anacolosa is very likely to be the same species as V. atropha (see Dow et al. 2018), in which case since both were described in Lieftinck (1965) it will be up to the first reviser to decide which name is the junior synonym. However in the opinion of the assessor the name V. atropha is to be preferred, if for no other reason than that it has appeared in the literature more often than V. anacolosa. Records of V. anacolosa from Sarawak certainly refer to V. atropha (Dow et al. 2018).

An year after the description of C. samarcandica (Bartenev, 1912), its author proposed a new name for it, Calopteryx maracandica  (Bartenev, 1913: 185) and used it later on, as well as some later authors. That new name erection was not justified from the point of view of the current International Code of the Zoological Nomenclature and is just a junior subjective synonym.

Calopteryx unicolor Bartenev, 1912 was described by teneral, not fully coloured specimens of C. samarcandica.Their conspecificity was supposed still by the author of both specific names (Bartenev 1913). Both species were described in the same comprehensive paper (Bartenev 1912). The following wording (translated from Russian) in (Bartenev, 1913: 185): “At present I provisionally attribute all the specimens to the same species Calopteryx samarcandica, having only changed its name, according to the proposition by A.P. Semenov-Tyan-Shanskiy (in a letter), to Calopteryx maracandica” can be interpreted as the action of the First Reviser who, in the same phrase, first chose C. samarcandica as the valid name for the species uniting the two previously presumed species, and then replaced (invalidly) this name to C. samarcandica. The synonymy of C. unicolor to C. samarcandica was assumed by Chaplina et al. (2007) and further authors.
Few known localities are scattered over the huge territory with too variable natural conditions. It may happen that under the name Stylurus occultus more than one species are lumped.

The four North Eurasian species of Ophiogomphus Selys, 1854 s. str., namely O. obscurus Bartenev, 1909, O. cecilia (Geoffroy in Fourcroy, 1785), O. spinicornis Selys, 1878 and O. reductus Calvert, 1898, are clear-cut and have very steady diagnostic characters including the male anal appendages (Bartenev 1930, Asahina 1979, Haritonov and Borisov 1990, Kosterin 2004). Some authors (Belyshev 1964a, 1973; Zaika and Kosterin 1992) erroneously considered three of them, including O. obscurus, as subspecies of O. cecilia.

Ophiogomphus obscurus in general replaces two of its congeners in the continuous forest zone but in some places of its margin coexists in sympatry with them in the same localities (all in Siberia). Sympatry of O. obscurus and O. cecilia was reported for the Isha River in the northern Altai Mts. (but at different localities 42 km from each other, with different habitats preferred by these two species) (Kosterin and Zaika 2010, 2011) and the Mana River at Kandalak village in the southern Krasnoyarsk Province (co-occurrence/syntopy) (Zapekina-Dulkeit and Dulkeit 1961; Kosterin and Zaika 2010, 2011). The reports by Wnukowsky (1928) and Belyshev (1964a) suggest that even at the type locality of O. obscurus at Tomsk City it coexists with O. cecilia. The sympatry of O. obscurus and O. spinicornis in the Onon River basin is known at Kyra (Kosterin et al. 2004) and Edinenie (co-occurrence/syntopy; A.F. Medvedev pers. comm.) villages in Transbaikalia (presently Zabaykalskiy Kray).

It should be noted that Bartenev (1909) described this taxon, as Ophiogomphus cecilia var. obscura, in a paper in Russian but next year he published the same data in English and again mentioned it as “Ophiogomphus cecilia var. obscura var. n.” as if it was the first description (Bartenev 1910: 273).

Although first described in the subspecific rank as Sympecma annulata Rasse gobica Förster, 1900, this is a good species with clear diagnostic characters and no hints of hybridising with two its congeners, Sympecma fusca (Vander Linden, 1820) and S. paedisca (Brauer, 1877) (= S. annulata Selys, 1887; = Sympycna braueri Bianchi in Jakobson et Bianchi, 1904), with which it co-exists in sympatry in large territories, e.g. in Kazakhstan (Dumont and Borisov 1993a,b).

There, however, existed a lot of confusion of these species in the past so in this assessment only proved records of S. gobica are mentioned.

The four North Eurasian species of Ophiogomphus Selys, 1854 s. str., namely O. obscurus Bartenev, 1909, O. cecilia (Geoffroy in Fourcroy 1785), O. spinicornis Selys, 1878 and O. reductus Calvert, 1898, are clear-cut and have very steady diagnostic characters including the male anal appendages (Bartenev 1930, Asahina 1979, Haritonov and Borisov 1990, Kosterin 2004). Some authors (Belyshev 1973, Zaika and Kosterin 1992) erroneously considered three of them, including O. obscurus, as subspecies of O. cecilia.

Ophiogomphus obscurus in general replaces two of its congeners in the taiga zone but in some places of its range margin coexists in sympatry with them in the same localities (all in Siberia). Sympatry of O. obscurus and O. cecilia was reported for the Isha River in the northern Altai Mts. (but different localities 42 km from each other, with different habitats preferred by these two species) (Kosterin and Zaika 2010, 2011) and the Mana River at Kandalak village in the southern Krasnoyarsk Province (co-occurrence/syntopy) (Zapekina-Dulkeit and Dulkeit 1961; Kosterin and Zaika 2010, 2011). The reports by Wnukowsky (1928) and Belyshev (1964a) suggest that even at the type locality of O. obscurus at Tomsk City it coexists with O. cecilia. The sympatry of O. obscurus and O. spinicornis for the Onon River basin at Kyra (Kosterin et al. 2004) and Edinenie (co-occurrence/syntopy; A.F. Medvedev pers. comm.) villages in Transbaikalia (presentl Zabaykalskiy Kray).

It should be noted that Bartenev (1909) described this taxon as Ophiogomphus cecilia var. obscura, in a paper in Russian but the next year he published the same data in English and again mentioned it as “Ophiogomphus cecilia var. obscura var. n.” as if it was the first description (Bartenev 1910: 273).

Descriptions of the same species as Gomphus schmidti Asahina, 1956 and Gomphus chancae Bartenev, 1956 were published in the same year (Asahina 1956, Bartenev 1956). Although the actual date of the latter publication is not known for sure, is indirect evidence suggests it was later than that of the former, so the name schmidti gets a priority (Asahina 1989).

Asahina (1942, 1949) synonymised Trigomphus succumbens (Needham 1931), described from Jilin, with T. nigripes but Chao (1990) did not accept this synonymy admitting that T. nigripes is more closely related to T. citimus (Needham 1931). T. nigripes must be present in NE China, but unless the true relationship of the above mentioned taxa is clarified no report can be associated with it for sure.

In the original description (Asahina 1949), Trigomphus ogumai Asahina, 1949 was compared to T. melampus (Selys, 1869) but not to T. nigripes. At the same time it is so close to T. nigripes that looks as its Japanese subspecies or even a full junior synonym.

Trigomphus anormolobatus Bartenev, 1913 is known only by a holotype female allegedly originating from Vladivostok and differing from T. nigripes only by a prominent knob at the vulvar lamina base (Bartenev 1913); it is not excluded that will turn to be another junior synonym of T. nigripes, as Belyshev (1973) already supposed.

Both Bartenev (1956) and Belyshev (1956) independently and in the same year reported on male specimens presumably associated with ‘Gomphus anormolobatus’, and later Belyshev and Kurentzov (1964) reported another so identified males. These specimens actually referred to T. nigripes (Belyshev 1973, Malikova 1995).
Asahina (1949) synonymised Platycnemis ulmifolia Ris, 1930 and P. hummeli Sjostedt, 1932, as well as P. foliacea sensu Needham, 1930 et Navas, 1934, nec. Selys, 1886, to P. phyllopoda Djakonov, 1926.
Hybridization with Copera annulata is reported.
In Hokkaido, the hybridization with Somatochlora graeseri was reported.
In the past large specimens were identified as different species (Somatochlora atrovirens), but recently the latter is treated as a junior synonym of viridiaenea.
Morphological and genetic differences have been found between eastern and western populations in Japan.
The Japanese population is regarded as the subspecies ijimai.
The Japanese populations are classified into three subspecies: nominotypical melania in mainland, ryukyuense in north and middle Ryukyu Archipelago, and yaeyamense in south Ryukyu Archipelago.

The only published record of this species is of the holotype female. However (Matti Hämäläinen personal communication 2019) "Coll. Selys includes one male specimen which appears to be the undescribed male of pallidifrons. The specimen was collected by Elio Modigliani at ‘Si Rambi’, where he visited in Dec. 1890 – Jan. 1891.  I cannot locate the place, but it should be in mainland Sumatra." The assessor has also been unable to locate this place.
Experts have suggested that this species may be a spring form of Eurytides dolicaon deicoon (Tyler et al. 1994).
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies himeros; and subspecies baia Rothschild & Jordan, 1906.

Previously, some authors recognised two subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies burchellanus; and subspecies jaguarae (Foetterle, 1902). The latter was previously considered a subspecies of Parides panthonus, but was synonimised with P. burchellanus at the species level by both morphological observations as well as by genetic analysis (Mielke et al. 2004, Silva-Brandão et al. 2008).
There are currently three subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies pizarro; subspecies kuhlmanni (May, 1925); and subspecies steinbachi (Rothschild, 1905).

There are seven subspecies reported for this species: the nominate subspecies agesilaus; subspecies eimeri (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906): subspecies fortis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies neosilaus (Hopffer, 1866); subspecies autosilaus (Bates, 1861); subspecies montanum (Küppers, 1974); and subspecies viridis (Röber, 1926).

There are currently five subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies lysithous; subspecies eupatorion (Lucas, [1859]); subspecies harrisianus (Swainson, 1822); subspecies rurik (Eschscholtz, 1821); and subspecies sebastianus (Oberthür, 1879).
This species was originally described as Neurobasis chinensis race australis Selys, 1897. A subspecies, Neurobasis australis misoolensis, is known from Misool Island.

Agrionoptera bartola was described from a single female specimen (Needham & Gyger 1937) without locality information beyond the fact that it was collected in the Philippines. It is close to, and quite likely a junior synonym of, Agrionoptera sexlineata.

Laidlaw (1911) recorded a female of Orogomphus ?splendidus from Sarawak and later (Laidlaw 1914) an additional female as Orogomphus ?splendidus, also from Sarawak. These records have been repeated by subsequent authors. However there is no convincing evidence that the females from Borneo belong to the same species as the true C. splendidus from Luzon in the Philippines and they are not treated as being C. splendidus for assessment purposes. Similarly the species has been listed from Taiwan but these records appear to refer to C. risi and all records from China and Taiwan are left out of consideration for assessment purposes.

Garrison et al. (2015) highlighted Mitragomphus ganzanus (supposedly collected from Prana, Brazil) as a junior synonym of Gomphidia kirschii (a species endemic to the Philippines) and suggested that M. ganzanus was incorrectly labelled as to its locality and collector. This also means that the monotypic genus Mitragomphus Needham, 1944 is a synonym of the genus Gomphidia Selys, 1854 (Garrison et al. 2015).

A form allied to Heliogomphus olivaceus is known from Borneo, see Dow & Stokvis (2018) but it is not clear if they are the same species or not at this time. For assessment purposes the Bornean form is left out of consideration but if they do eventually prove to be the same species then re-assessment will be necessary.

Villanueva and Dow (2014) noted that there are some differences between populations of this species from mainland Mindanao and those from Dinagat and Siargao Islands. The view taken here is that these differences merely represent variation within a single species.

Diplacina guentherpetersi appears to differ from D. bolivari Selys mostly in details of colouration and wing venation and confirmation that it is really a distinct species rather than a variant of D. bolivari is needed.
Diplacina holgerhungeri appears to differ from D. bolivari Selys mostly in details of colouration and confirmation that it is really a distinct species rather than a variant of D. bolivari is needed.

A record of Prodasineura palawana from Balabac (Hämäläinen & Muller 1997) might refer to the recently described P. poncei Villanueva & Cahilog, 2013 which is only known from Balabac. However P. poncei is very similar to P. palawana structurally and might eventually prove to be a junior synonym of this species.
Prodasineura poncei is very similar to P. palawana Lieftinck, 1948, differing only in having a reduced or absent antehumeral stripe, and might eventually prove to be a junior synonym of P. palawana.

The Roland Müller collection contains a number of specimens identified as allied to Risiocnemis elegans by M. Hämäläinen (pers. comm. 2019: unpub. database of specimens from collection R. Müller identified by M. Hämäläinen); the status of these specimens is unresolved. The view taken for assessment purposes is that only the type series and other specimens identified as elegans in published sources are definitely R. elegans and other specimens are left out of consideration. Hämäläinen (1991) noted that R. varians Hämäläinen, 1991 might eventually prove to be a junior synonym of R. elegans but Hämäläinen and Muller (1997: 279) noted that material collected in Quirino Province after the publication of Hämäläinen (1991) “seems to indicate that R. elegans and R. varians are different species.”
The species was described from the female sex only and although male specimens subsequently became available, no description of the male has been published to the assessor’s knowledge.

Hämäläinen (1991) noted that Risiocnemis varians might eventually prove to be a junior synonym of R. elegans but Hämäläinen and Muller (1997) noted that material collected in Quirino Province after the publication of Hämäläinen (1991) “seems to indicate that R. elegans and R. varians are different species.” This issue has not yet been satisfactorily resolved, but the two are treated as distinct for assessment purposes.

Drepanosticta halterata and its allies are in need of revision and it is possible that records from some locations that are considered to belong to D. halterata here will eventually prove to be different species.

authority: Villanueva, Van Der Ploeg & Van Weerd, 2011
Villanueva, Van Der Ploeg & Van Weerd, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Ceriagrion hoogerwerfi was treated as a subspecies of C. bellona by Asahina (1967) but is still treated as a separate species by some authorities. Since some differences between the two taxa in, for instance, the male anal appendages, are apparent in Asahina’s own illustrations, so Ceriagrion hoogerwerfi is best kept separate from C. bellona until a thorough investigation is made.
Two subspecies of Papuagrion peschem have been recognised, the nominate subspecies and P. p. corniculatum; both occur in the same area of New Guinea.
Platylestes pertinax is placed in Lestes by many authorities.
Diplacina clymene is possibly merely a colour variant of D. ismene, but the two are widely separated geographically (Orr & Kalkman 2015).
Macromia corycia Laidlaw, 1922 is very similar to M. gerstaeckeri and may eventually prove to be a junior synonym of this species.
Until recently this species had been confused with Coeliccia erici, see Dow et al. (2018.)
Neurothemis papuensis was described as a subspecies of N. ramburii but Seehausen & Dow (2016) elevated it to a full species.

Although Macrobrachium grandimanus was previously considered to be endemic to the Hawaiian islands, it is now considered to also occur in Fiji, Tonga, the Rykyus, Moorea and New Caledonia.  As records of this species from Hainan Island (China) have been recently re-assigned to a new species, M. trichodactylum, the other non-Hawaiian records require further scrutiny.
Caridina neglecta was only recently separated (Cai and Ng 2007),  from the widely reported Caridina gracilirostris.  Some of the records of C.gracilirostris may refer to this species.

In older literature this species is usually listed under the name Caridina japonica De Man, 1892.  Cai et al. (2006) demonstrated that C. multidentata Stimpson, 1860 is a senior synonym of C.japonica.
Chace (1997) considered the possibility that C.celestinoi is the juvenile form of C. leytensis.

In the latest revision of this species by Richard and Clark (2010) the species is considered to occur from Tanzania through to New Caledonia, more taxonomic work is required to confirm this unusually broad distribution.
Asahina (1997) described Coeliccia satoi from a single male from north Viet Nam.
Described from holotype male plus paratype female and male from Shi Wan Da Shan, Guangxi (Wilson 1998).
Ris (1917) established the genus Philosina and described buchi as the type species from a series of specimens collected from Fujian.

Needham (1930) described Rhinocypha katharina from two females collected from Suifu, Sichuan by Dr. D.C. Graham in 19 May 1928, which are housed in the US National Museum. Wilson and Reels (2003) collected three male specimens from Longrui, Guangxi and Mulun, Guangxi in addition to female material collected from Mulun. Wilson and Reels (2003) described the first male and placed the species in the genus Indocypha Fraser, 1949.

Zhou and Zhou (2006) described Indocypha chishuiensis from: 'Jinshagou, Chishui City, Guizhou Province', which is less than 150 km from the type-locality of I. katharina. Hämäläinen (2014) considers it probable that I. chishuiensis is a synonym of I. katharina and Schorr and Paulson (2020) treat I. chishuiensis as a junior synonym of I. katharina.

Originally described by Chao (1955) under the genus Hagenius Sélys and subgenus Sieboldius Sélys, the former of which is now considered containing just one species, namely Hagenius brevistylus Sélys, from North America (Davies and Tobin 1985). Carle (1986) established the subgenera Hagenoides with Sieboldius alexanderi as the type species. Chao (1990) sank Carle's Hagenoides subgenus with the nominate subgenus established by Chao in 1984. Bridges (1994) considered Carle's subgenus Hagenoides valid but probably overlooked Chao (1984).

Chao (1954) described Nihonogomphus semanticus from male specimens collected from Fujian. Wilson and Xu (2009) described the first female from specimens collected across north and central Guangdong from Chengjia, Xiaokeng and Nankunshan. Chao (1995) established the Nihonogomphus subgenus Lobogomphus based, principally, on differences in the structure of the penile organ. Lobogomphus has a penile organ possessing a posterior lobe (prepuce) whereas the nominate subgenus Nihonogomphus (Nihonogomphus) does not possess a prepuce. Nihonogomphus semanticus belongs in the subgenus Lobogomphus.

Needham (1930: The Dragonflies of China) established the genus Sinolestes and described three new species within the genus in the following order: Sinolestes edita, Sinolestes truncata and Sinolestes ornata. Needham (1930) placed Sinolestes in Coenagrioninae but Lieftinck (1939) transferred the genus to Synlestidae Tillyard, 1917.

The only differences between the three Sinolestes species as described by Needham (1930) was the wing colour pattern; S. edita with hyaline wings, S. truncata wings with dark broad cross-bands and S. ornata wings with dark narrow cross-bands. Chao (1947) synonymised S. ornata with S. edita. Asahina (1956) adopted this treatment for Fujianese specimens and suggested the third species S. truncata might also be a junior synonym of S. edita. Based on a series of specimens from the same location in Guangxi, some with broad cross-bands and some with narrow cross-bands, Wilson and Reels (2003) synonymised S. truncata with S. edita.

Since Sinolestes is masculine and in accordance with the Rules of Nomenclature these specific name endings should have been latinised as S. editus, S. truncatus and S. ornatus. Both S. truncatus and S. ornatus are junior synonyms of S. editus.

Zhu and Zhou (1999) described Anisopleura yunnanensis from the Dali region of west Yunnan, China. Zhang, Hämäläinen and Cai (2014) thought that A. yunnanensis might be conspecific with A. subplatystyla. However, there are slight differences in the dorsal thoracic colour pattern and shape of the caudal genitalia of these two species and there is an abrupt and marked curve at the base of the hind wing costa of A. yunnanensis which is absent in A. subplatystyla (Zhang 2019).

Chao (1982) described Anisogomphus wuzhishanus Chao, 1982, from a single female from Hainan. Kosterin (2018) established the genus Euthygomphus to resolve a taxonomic confusion and receive species formerly placed either in Anisogomphus Selys, 1857 or Merogomphus Martin, 1904, that possess simple cerci and moderately divergent epiproct branches. Although no males of wuzhishanus have been documented the female is very similar to Euthygomphus koxingai (Chao, 1954) and undoubtedly should be placed in Euthygomphus. The only difference between E. koxingai and E. wuzhishanus is the structure of the lobes of the vulvar scale, which were illustrated with pointed lobes for E. wuzhishanus (Chao 1982, 1990) but with rounded lobes for E. koxingai (Wilson and Xu 2009).

Asahina (1988) established the subspecies Leptogomphus elegans hongkongensis based on three males and the structural difference of their caudal genitalia when compared with the nominate taxon L. elegan elegans. Wilson (2009), on discovering that females of hongkongensis were also structurally different from female elegans raised the taxon to species level. The occipital horns of L. hongkongensis are widely divergent compared to L. elegans which has more or less vertical horns. In addition, the subgenital plate of L. hongkongensis is slightly broader and more divergent when compared with L. elegans.

Megalestes omeiensis Chao, 1965 was described from Sichuan from a single male. It is a large Megalestes (male ab. 64 mm, hw 45 mm) with a mainly black abdomen related to the another large Chinese Megalestes heros Needham, 1930, which has a predominantly brownish-orange abdomen.

Megalestes riccii Navás, (1935) was described from Kuling, Jiangxi from a single male and female. Between 1934 and 1936, Navás described 31 Chinese odonates. In 1961 Chao studied many of the Navás types deposited in the Zoological Institute of Academia Sinica and the following year Chao synonymised 12 Navasian species in one paper (Chao 1965). In the same paper Chao provided more accurate figures of both the holotype male and paratype female of Megalestes riccii. Chao’s (1962) drawings of the superior appendages indicate that Navás’ rather oversimplified drawing had failed to indicate the true shape and form of the superior appendages.

Chao (1965) studied all the described Chinese Megalestes and provided a full description of M. riccii, described M. omeiensis, and provided a key to Chinese Megalestes. In Chao’s (1965) redescription of M. riccii he pointed out some errors given in the Navás’ original description especially relating to the black marks on the prothorax, which are much more extensive than indicated by Navás, have a different shape and are also may be quite variable in extent as indicated in a series of specimens examined by Chao from Kuling, Jiangxi. Chao (1965) also figured good drawings of the penile organ and provided a more detailed redescription.

It is now clear that Megalestes tuska Wilson & Reels (2003) is much closer to M. riccii than the authors realised when they described M. tuska from Damingshan, Guangxi having relied on the inaccurate description and drawings provided by Navás (1935). Both M. riccii and M. tuska have very similar appearance and size (male hw: 30-32 mm and 31.5 mm respectively), share the same form of the penile organ and both have pale creamy brownish-white superior appendages. Megalestes tuska has slightly finer and more sinuous superior appendages than M. riccii and its inferior appendages have two pairs of projections; the basal pair is sharply pointed and adorned with relatively longer pale coloured stout hairs that form an upwardly curved tip. The two species were described from locations ca 1,000 km apart but there remains the possibility that M. tuska is a junior synonym of M. riccii.

Zhang (2019) remarks that Megalestes maai Chen, 1947 from Taiwan might be a junior synonym of M. ricci. It also has relatively stout and whitish-coloured superior anal appendages. Chao (1965) separated M. maai from M. riccii in his key to Chinese Megalestes by its inferior appendages, which have a pair of bluntly pointed dorso-lateral teeth, which are pointed apically in M. riccii. Wilson and Reels (2003) remarked that this latter feature may be variable in M. tuska as their type male had inferior appendages with bifurcated basal projection and a paratype's basal projection was pointed but not bifurcated. A recent revision of the genus Megalestes defined both M. maai and M. tuska as junior synonyms of M. ricci (Yu and Xue 2020).

Asahina (1956) reinstated Caliphaea consimilis as a good species after it was erroneously synonymised with Caliphaea confusa Hagen in Selys, 1859 by Fraser in 1929 (Fraser 1934). It was originally described from Ta-chien-lu in central Sichuan, China (McLachlan 1984). Davies and Yang (1996) treated Caliphaea nitens Navás, 1934 as a synonym of C. consimilis  but Hämäläinen (2004) reinstated C. nitens as a good species based on a study of Fujian specimens and the original description of the type C. nitens from Zhejiang. The Guangxi records of Caliphaea consimilis from Huaping, Dayaoshan and Cenwanglaoshan provided by Wilson and Reels were stated by them to be of the ‘nitens’ form (Wilson and Reels 2003) and these records should all be treated as Caliphaea nitens. All Caliphaea records recorded from Guangdong belong to C. nitens (Wilson and Xu 2007). The records of Caliphaea consimilis from Guangxi in Needham (1930) are also likely to belong to Caliphaea nitens.
Bayadera forcipata was described by Needham (1930) from a single male held in the US National Museum, collected by Dr. D. C. Graham west of Yachow, central Sichuan, 8 June 1923.

Burmagomphus collaris was described under the name Gomphus collaris by Needham (1930) from a single female obtained from Foochow, Fujian, China. In the same publication Needham (1930) also described Gomphus campestris from three males collected from ‘Hopei’ (Hubei province). Chao (1954) placed collaris in the genus Burmagomphus and also synonymised Gomphus campestris with Burmagomphus collaris. Although campestris was described first in the 1930 publication on page 57 as opposed to page 60 for collaris, under the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (24.2.1), the 'First Revisor' has the choice to declare the valid name. As such, Burmagomphus collaris should be treated as the senior synonym following Chao (1954) as the First Reviser. Davies and Tobin (1985), Bridges (1994), Steinmann (1997) and Lee (2001) all erroneously listed B. collaris as a junior synonym of B. campestris.

Needham (1929) listed both G. collaris and G. campestris as new species in a publication titled: Key to the Adults of Peping Odonata. Jan van Tol of the Leiden Museum (pers com) is of the opinion that the names listed in the 1929 key are available and in consequence the author citation should be Burmagomphus collaris (Needham, 1929).

Lamelligomphus choui was described by Chao and Liu (1989) from a single male from Anhui, China. Lamelligomphus choui tienfuensis Chao 1995 was described from a single male from Sichuan. Chao (1995) considered the presence of semi-circular prominences above the lateral ocelli and depressed areas at each side of the occiput indicated that this taxon belonged to L. choui. According to Chao (1995) its colour pattern differs markedly from the nominate species by the following: (i) labrum predominantly yellow, (ii) crest of synthorax yellow and joined to yellow collar stripe, antehumeral stripe absent, (iv) three yellow spots on metepisternum (v) most abdominal segments with a basal ring. Chao (1995) stated there were no distinct structural differences when compared with the nominate subspecies but figured the posterior hamulus without a markedly curved tip, which is present in nominate choui. Wilson and Xu (2009) remarked that the shape of the hamuli of L. choui tienfuensis are identical to those of L. ringens (Needham 1930) and the overall body pattern and colouration is very similar. There is a distinct possibility that L. choui tienfuensis is a junior synonym of L. ringens.

Wilson (2019) reviewed the genus Stylurus Needham 1897 as follows: Stylurus is a Holarctic genus with representatives found in temperate and subtropical areas from North America, Asia and Europe. In the first edition of the Dragonflies of North America (Needham and Westfall 1955) Stylurus was treated as a subgenus of Gomphus Leach 1815 but following many taxonomists’ opinions, including Needham (1948), Asahina (1978), Carle (1986), Chao (1990) and Schmidt (1987), it is now universally accepted at generic level. The key characters used to determine the genus are small, simple post-like or narrow blade-like anterior hamules without hooks or teeth, simple and divaricate male cerci, short female subgenital plate (=<1/4 length of 9th sternite) deeply notched at tip, fourth segment of the penile organ very short, a short and wide post frons, absent or vestigial burrowing hooks on the larval mid and front tibia and elongate abdominal segment nine. Although the males of some species possess straight abdomens the majority have broadly clubbed abdomens with widely expanded abdominal segments 7-9. Chao (1991) noted that the genus Stylurus in China can easily be recognized by the shape of the posterior hamuli as well as by the colour marking on the frontal surface of the synthorax (dorsal stripes not confluent with collar stripe as observed in Asiagomphus). The posterior hamuli are long, narrow and always perpendicular or tangential to the longitudinal axis of the body.

Stylurus gaudens was described under Gomphus by Chao (1953) from a single female in the Kellogg collection collected in 1930 from Sichuan and housed in the US National Museum. Chao (1990) place gaudens in the genus Stylurus. Stylurus gideon was described under Gomphurus from male and female specimens collected from Chengdu, Sichuan (Needham, 1941) and transferred to Stylurus (Needham, 1948). Chengdu is just 65 km from the S. gaudens type locality. Stylurus gaudens was described with wide, u-shaped ridge above and between lateral ocelli but this feature has never been directly compared between the two species. Chao (1990) produced a key to Chinese Stylurus and could only separate these two species in a couplet based on minor colour differences observed in the labium i.e. S. gaudens having a mostly yellow labrum with narrow brown margin whereas S. gideon has a labrum with basal half black and a pair of large transverse yellow spots. These are minor differences and S. gaudens may prove to be a junior synonym of S. gideon.

Described from holotype male and paratype female from Beijing City. The authors considered Macromia beijingensis closest to Macromia amphigena Selys 1871, which is known from further north in China (Heilongjiang, Jilin) and also Japan, Korean Peninsula and Russia (Urals, Siberia and far east south Russia). There are clear colour pattern and structural differences including a distinctive yellow spot at the central base of the labrum, entirely dark dorsal antefrons, a pair of conical tubercles on the dorsum of abdominal segment 10 in addition to a unique form of caudal and secondary sexual appendages.

Described from single holotype male from Guizhou (Zhou 2003). It is similar to Macromia manchurica Asahina, 1964, which Zhang (2019) considered might be a senior synonym. Males of M. manchurica have a more developed yellow abdominal colour pattern but possess a similarly-shaped posterior hamulus. The M. hamata hamulus does not have such a sharply pointed hook at its apex, which is smoothly curved and rounded at its apex. Some records of M. manchuria in south China may refer to M. hamata. M. Manchuria is known from northeast China (Heilongjiang, Jilin, Liaoning, Beijing), Korean peninsula, south far east Russia (Zhang 2019, Malikova and Kosterin 2019).

Chao (1953) published a very detailed account of the external morphology of Onychogomphus ardens Needham. Later, Chao (1990) selected ardens as the genotype species for his new genus Melligomphus, which he established to receive Chinese onychogomphines with, inter alia, superior appendages shorter than inferior appendages and without markedly hooked tips, as in seen in the genus Lamelligomphus Fraser. Wilson (2009) stated the genus Melligomphus is reliably characterised by: (i) inferior anal appendages of male slightly longer than superior appendages, (ii) both branches of superior appendages more or less parallel, (iii) penile organ with a prominent postgenital lobe and a pair of raised, prominent, nose-like sclerotized structures, (iv) anal triangle of male 4-celled, (v) anal loop 2-celled or occasionally 1 or 3-celled, and (vi) posterior hamulus with an acuminate tip, not overtly hook-like. Wilson (2009) transferred Ophiogomphus guangdongensis Chao, 1994 to the genus Melligomphus and synonymised Melligomphus moluami Wilson (1995) as a junior synonym of Melligomphus quangdongensis.

Chao and Zhu (1999) described Nihonogomphus huangshaensis from a single female collected from Huangsha, Guangxi. Wilson (2005) described the first male from Nonggang, Guangxi and noted it was one of the few members of the genus with divaricate inferior appendages and black labrum. Chao (1995) established the subgenus Lobogomphus based, principally, on differences in the structure of the penile organ. Lobogomphus has a penile organ possessing a posterior lobe (prepuce) whereas the nominate subgenus Nihonogomphus (Nihonogomphus) does not possess a prepuce. Nihonogomphus huangshaensis belongs in the subgenus Lobogomphus.

Carle (1986) established the subgenus Nychogomphus and Chao (1990) raised its status to genus and placed flavicaudus, which Chao had previously described from Hainan in Onychogomphus, into the newly established genus.
Chao and Xu (1987) established the subgenus Orientogomphus when describing Orientogomphus armatus from Fujian, south China.

The genus Philoganga was established in 1890 by Kirby. It was long considered a member of the Amphipterygidae (Davies and Tobin 1984) but has now been placed in its own family (Dijkstra et al., 2014). Philoganga robusta was described by Navás (1936) and overlooked by many early taxonomists until Chao (1953) reviewed its status, redescribed P. robusta and reidentified many specimens previously identified as P. vetusta Ris, 1912. Wilson and Reels (2001) reviewed the status of many Chinese Philoganga and remarked that P. robusta can be separated from P. vetusta based on its larger size, general dark colouration, the presence of a complete or partial antehumeral stripe, lack of a bright-coloured abdominal dorsum in the male and slightly more robust penile organ.

Zhou and Wilson (2001) established the genus Priscagrion within the subfamily Megapodagrioninae and described two species under the genus namely: Priscagrion kiauta Zhou & Wilson, 2001 and Priscagrion pinheyi Zhou & Wilson, 2001. The taxonomic affinities of the genus has caused considerable interest. Zhou and Wilson (2001) considered Priscagrion to be an archaic genus hence its name (Latin Priscus = ancient). De Marmels (2002) considered the closest relatives of Priscagrion are species of the Australo-Papuan Argiolestinae. Yu and Bu (2011) undertook a cladistic analysis and found Priscagrion along with Mesopodagrion, Philosina and Austroargiolestes formed a polytomy group of four branches at the base of a cladogram and agreed with De Marmels (2002) that Priscagrion’s closest relatives might be Argiolestinae. Based on a molecular phylogenic assessment Dijkstra et al. (2014) considered a close relationship to Argiolestidae is unlikely and that Priscagrion may represent a separate family perhaps together with Sinocnemis Wilson & Zhou, 2000. It is currently unclassified at family level as intertae sedis Group 5 (Schorr and Paulson 2019).

As noted by Petrulevičius et al. (2008) only the representatives of the tribe Megapodagrionini have their CuP veins proximal to the arculus and distal to the base of the anterior analis and the only extant members are Megapodagrion and Priscagrion.

Zhou Wen-bao (2003) described Rhipidolestes fascia from male and female specimens collected in Guizhou, China. Males have very distinctive dark brown, broad medial cross bands on both for and hind wings.

The species is closely allied to R. yangbingi Davies 1998, which also has abdominal S9 with a bifid projection, similar caudal appendages and very similar penile organ. The only differences are a black labrum and very extensive medial wing bands in R. fascia as opposed to pale yellowish-brown labrum and wings having brown patches medially as described for R. yangbingi. The only structural difference was stated by Zhou (2003) to be: basal one third of superior appendages expanded with a prominent dorsal projection. The latter is not actually a projection but merely a slight angle in the superior appendages when viewed laterally in R. yangbingi. The exact same bend or angle is seen in other specimens of R. fascia depicted in Zhang (2019). It is not unusual to have minor colour variation in the labium (yellow-brown as opposed to black) and the degree of wing colouration can also vary within populations. It is likely that R. fascia is merely a colour form of R. yangbingi.

Lieftinck (1948) described Rhipidolestes juncundus from Fujian based on three males and two females. Lieftinck remarked that his new species resembled R. malaisei but was a good deal smaller with different anal appendages.

Wilson and Reels (2003) described Rhipidolestes laui from Guangxi based on two males. It is a non-pruinosed, large-sized Rhipidoletes with a yellowish-orange face. The authors remark that R. laui is allied to R. janetae and R. aculeatus but is much larger with slightly different caudal appendages and penile organ.

Zhou (2003) described Rhipidolestes lii from Guizhou based on a single male. It is a non-pruinosed, medium-sized Rhipidoletes with a yellowish-orange face and hyaline wings. The authors remark that R. lii is allied to R. bastiaani Zhu and Yang (1998) from Shaanxi, which has a salmon pink face and smokey-brown wing tips. Its caudal appendages are very similar.

Between 1928 and 1931 three species of Rhipidolestes Ris, 1912, all with dark faces, were described from Zhejiang Province, China. The first of the trio was described as Taolestes nectans by Needham (1928) from a single female, collected from Hangzhou, Zhejiang. In the same publication Needham had erected the new genus Taolestes to receive it. Needham (1930) subsequently described the larvae of nectans, again under the Taolestes genus. The female nectans description included a blackish face with a very narrow pale stripe across the front of the clypeus, a broad yellow stripe between eyes. The male colouration was not described but the male abdominal segments 9-10 were figured showing a very small basal spine and the characteristic form of the superior appendages were shown in lateral and dorsal view. We now know, from photos taken in the field of live male Ripidolestes nectans in Zhejiang, that its upper head, lateral synthorax (excluding metepimeron), and abdominal segments 8-10 are heavily pruinosed white (Zhang 2019: 1145).

Rhipidolestes bidens Schmidt (1931) was the second of the trio to be described from Zhejiang at Hsiieh-Tau-Gebirge, Ninpo, Tsche-kiang (probably Xuedou Mountain, Ningpo, Zhejiang). Schmidt described the face as brown-black, labrum shimmering dark metallic green and blue, head black and both forehead and midsection pruinosed white, synthorax brown-black with bright humeral stripes and lower lateral up to second suture plus coxae pruinosed, abdomen dark metallic blue-green with S8-10 matte brownish-black. Schmidt figured the tip of the abdomen showing a very small basal spine and the characteristic form of the superior appendages were shown in lateral and dorsal view.

The third species, Ripidolestes apicatus Navás (1934), was described from a male from T’ien-Mou-Chan, Chekiang (Tianmushan, Zhejiang). Navás (1934) described the labrum and clypeus as: ‘caeruleo-viola-ceis, nitendibus’ i.e. shining or glittering blue-violet, perhaps equivalent to black with metallic violet-blue reflections. Navás (1934) figured the caudal appendages R. apicatus including abdominal segments 9-10 showing a very small basal spine. Navás described the lateral synthorax and abdomen with segments 8-10 pruinosed. The caudal appendages and S9 basal spine are identical to those figured for R. nectans by Needham (1930).

Most Rhipdolestes have black faces with orange, red or blue markings.
