Lieftinck (1948) noted, when describing Rhipidolestes juncundus, that R. bidens, R. nectans (Needham, 1929) and R. apicatus all have dark faces, partly or almost wholly black, or metallic blue-green. Asahina (1956) tentatively synonymised R. bidens with R. nectans based on male and female R. nectans specimens collected from west Tien-Mu-Shan, Chekiang (Tianmushan, Zhejiang), which is the same locality at the type-location for R. apicatus. He felt Needham’s male description rather inadequate to decide the true identity of R. nectans but nevertheless stated that it was highly probable that his specimens belonged to R. nectans. Asahina (1956) also examined the type female nectans in the California Academy, which he stated was ‘quite similar’ to his female specimens and summarised: ‘I should tentatively make our material belong to Needham’s “nectans”…’

Both Davies and Tobin (1984) and Steinmann (1997) accepted Asahina’s synonymy and treated R. bidens as a junior synonym of R. nectans.

Chao (1962) noted that during 1934 to 1936 Navás published 31 new Chinese species most of which were deposited in the Zoological Institute of Academia Sinica. Navás paid scant attention to the published odonate literature and after Chao examined many of the types in 1961 he found most of them were not new to science. Chao (1962) sank 12 of Navás’ types in a single paper. As mentioned R. apicatus was described from the same locality as Asahina’s (1956) R. nectans material from Tianmushan, Zhejiang, which Asahina argued was a senior synonym of R. bidens. The description of R. apicatus and drawings of caudal abdomen and anal appendages provided by Navás (1934) exactly match the description given for both R. bidens by Schmidt (1931) and that given for R. nectans by Asahina (1956). It is clearly a junior synonym of R. nectans as stated by Asahina (1956).

The only known Rhipidolestes species currently known from Zhejiang are R. nectans, R. bidens and R. apicatus plus a putative new reddish-brown faced species clearly allied to R. rubriceps Navás known from neighbouring Jiangxi (Zhang 2019).

It is now evident that both R. bidens and R. apicatus are junior synonyms of R. nectans as already indicated by previous authors.

Davies (2003) described Rhipidolestes yangbingi from male specimens collected in Sichuan, China. It is closely allied to R. fascia Zhou, 2003, which also has abdominal S9 with a bifid projection, similar caudal appendages and very similar penile organ. The differences include a black labrum and very extensive medial wing bands in R. fascia as opposed to pale yellowish-brown labrum and wings having brown patches medially as described for R. yangbingi. The only structural difference was stated by Zhou (2003) to be: basal one third of superior appendages expanded with a prominent dorsal projection. The latter is not actually a projection but merely a slight angle in the superior appendages when viewed laterally in R. yangbingi. The exact same bend or angle is seen in other specimens of R. fascia depicted in Zhang (2019). It is not unusual to have minor colour variation in the labium (yellow-brown as opposed to black) and the degree of wing colouration can also vary within populations. It is likely that R. fascia is merely a colour form of R. yangbingi.

Needham (1930) described Sieboldius herculeus from a single female collected by C.R. Kellogg in Fujian. Asahina (1972) suggested that Sieboldius deflexus (Chao, 1955) described from male only specimens from Fujian and separated from S. herculeus based only on minor colour differences might be a junior synonym of S. herculeus. Wilson and Xu (2009) described a female S. deflexus from Guangdong and closely compared the female with Needham’s original description. They could find no overt structural differences and noted only a narrowly divided yellow transverse frons stripe as opposed to an almost divided frons stripe. With so few records of Sieboldius known at that time Wilson and Xu (2009) refrained from synonymising S. deflexus with S. herculeus. However, it is most probable that S. deflexus, which has now been recorded from Anhui, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guixhou, Hubei, Taiwan and Zhejiang (Zhang 2019) is a junior synonym of S. herculeus. No further records of S. herculeus have been made since its original description.

Wilson and Zhou (2000) erected the genus Sinocnemis within Platycnemididae to receive two new species S. dumonti and S. yangbingi. Sinocnemis dumonti was described from Guizhou, China. Wilson and Zhou (2000) noted that both species did not appear to be closely related to any other members of the Platycnemididae. The true taxonomic affinities within Zygoptera along with Priscagrion Zhou and Wilson (2001) have caused mush debate in recent years.

Kalkman (2008) considered Sinocnemis should be placed in Megapodagrionidae. Van Tol's (2009) analysis indicated Sinocnemis to be sister to all zygopterans except lestids. Dumont et al. (2010) remarked that Sinocnemis was neither a megapodagrionid nor a platycnemidid. Yu and Bu (2011) carried out a cladistic study and also concluded that Sinocnemis was neither a megapodagrionid nor a platycnemid and might warrant a family of its own. Dijkstra et al. (2014) stated the different genital ligulae and their molecular data implied there was no close relationship to Megapodagrionidae and that Sinocnemis may represent a separate family perhaps together with Priscagrion. It is currently placed in Incertae Sedis Group 5 in Schorr and Paulson's (2020) World Odonata List.

Wilson and Zhou (2000) erected the genus Sinocnemis to receive two new species; S. dumonti and S. yangbingi. Sinocnemis henanese Wang (2003) was described shortly afterwards from Henan based primarily on its lack of a bluish-yellowish stripe at the posterior base of the humeral suture and the presence of an ‘apophysis’ at the distal margin of the penile organ. Kalkman (2008) considered that the differential diagnosis provided by Wang was inadequate to describe a new species and considered S. henanese to be a junior synonym of S. yangbingi. Yu and Bu (2011) examined further specimens of both S. yangbingi and S. henanese and reinstated S. henanese as a valid species based on its penile organ (ligula) and the clear protrusion at its tip, which is lacking in Sinocnemis yangbingi and S. dumonti.

Wilson and Zhou (2000) erected the genus Sinocnemis within Platycnemididae to receive two new species S. dumonti and S. yangbingi. Sinocnemis yangbingi was described from Sichuan, China. Wilson and Zhou (2000) noted that both species did not appear to be closely related to any other members of the Platycnemididae. The true taxonomic affinities within Zygoptera along with Priscagrion Zhou and Wilson (2001) have caused mush debate in recent years.

Kalkman (2008) considered Sinocnemis should be placed in Megapodagrionidae. Van Tol's (2009) analysis indicated Sinocnemis to be sister to all zygopterans except lestids. Dumont et al. (2010) remarked that Sinocnemis was neither a megapodagrionid nor a platycnemidid. Yu and Bu (2011) carried out a cladistic study and concluded that Sinocnemis was neither a megapodagrionid nor a platycnemid and might warrant a family of its own. Dijkstra et al. (2014) stated the different genital ligulae and their molecular data implied there was no close relationship to Megapodagrionidae and that Sinocnemis may represent a separate family perhaps together with Priscagrion. It is currently placed in Incertae Sedis Group 5 in Schorr and Paulson's (2020) World Odonata List.

May (1935) established the genus Sinogomphus when he described S. nigrofasciatus and named it the genotype species. However, May overlooked Gomphus scissus McLachlan 1896, a senior synonym, that has now replaced it as the genotype species S. scissus following Klots (1947). Chao (1984) described S. asahinai based on both male and female specimens collected from Guangxi. It is similar to S. telemon (Lieftinck, 1939) and S. suensoni (Lieftinck, 1939) but the males of these two species do not possess a deeply cleft inferior appendage and females lack horns on the occipital margin which are both features found in S. asahinai.

Asahina (1997) described Sympetrum nomurai from male and female specimens collected from high altitude mountains (3,300 m) in Sichuan. These are the only specimens recorded for this taxon. The male specimens have strongly upturned superior appendages similar to S. eroticum Selys, 1841, but the abdominal body colour is pale brown above and black below S2-10 rather than red above and less extensive black below as seen in S. eroticum. The female vulvar scale is broadly divided whereas the vulvar scale of S. eroticum is closed.

Chao (1953) listed just the name: ‘Trigomphus needhami sp. nov.’ from Fujian but Chao (1954) ultimately described it as Trigomphus carus in his formal description.

The genus Trigomphus was established by Bartenov, 1911. Trigomphus nigripes (Selys, 1887) is the genotype species. Chao (1954) divided the genus into two groups viz: agricola group with female valvular vulvae deeply cleft and reflexed outwards at tips but cleft less than half length of subgenital plate and carus group with deeply cleft female valvular vulvae that exceed the overall length of the subgenital plate.
Lieftinck (1963: 752) noted that Nannophlebia braueri is likely to be the same species as N. amphicyllis, this issue is not yet resolved.

The known species range comprises two disjunct areas, one in the Caribbean coast of Honduras and another in southern Nicaragua and northern Costa Rica. However, the Honduran subpopulations are currently of unclear taxonomic status and deserve further taxonomic studies, not being considered here.

B. andrewi is known from a single male supposedly from the island of Cuba (Smith 1992). However, the holotype is lost and there is no other information about the species. Probably it will be considered as nomen dubium after future taxonomic revision.

This species is known from a single female, described in 1917 and reportedly from the Dry Tortugas islands, Florida, USA (Chamberlin 1917). This species will likely be reevaluated as nomen dubium after an ongoing taxonomic revision is published.
An ongoing revision indicates that B. fossorium belongs to a different genus, thus, the taxonomic position of this species could change in the near future.
Due to a misidentification by Schmidt (1992a), subsequent errors were done by different authors, which identified B. hamorii specimens as being B. smithi (Mendoza and Francke 2017).
Probably the status of this species will change with the future publication of the taxonomic revision of the group.
CITES still records the synonym Brachypelma annitha as a valid species.

This species was listed by CITES for many years as Brachypelma embrithes (Chamberlin & Ivie, 1936). Despite being known and currently present in several zoological collections, the male of this species remains undescribed.
Ongoing taxonomic revision indicates that Brachypelma vagans seems to be a complex of species. The status of this taxon will be clarified in the future.

Although Preradović et al. (2018) described the pupa under the name of Merodon aureus, new molecular data reidentified this pupa as an immature stage of Merodon calidus (Vujić et al. 2020). Speight (2020) listed the biological data under the name Merodon aeneus.

The species belongs to Eumerus olivaceus group. E. alpinus Rondani, 1857 was resurrected from synonymy of E. olivaceus Loew, 1848 and considered a good species by Grković et al. (2015). Until than the name of E. olivaceus was used for both species.

Vujić et al. (2013) successfully used an integrative taxonomy approach for delimitation of Pipiza noctiluca from related species. P. noctiluca can be separated from related species using molecular data and geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013).

Pipiza luteitarsis can be separated from other European species of genus using key from Vujić et al. (2013). Vujić et al. (2008) provide a key distinguishing P. luteitarsis from other known European species of the luteitarsis group and also figure the male terminalia. Species of the luteitarsis group can be separated from other European Pipiza species by the lack of a pair of apico-ventral ridges on the hind femora, which are present in the other species (Speight 2020).

Vujić et al. (2008) provide figures of the male terminalia and the key distinguishing Pipiza luteibarba from other European members of the luteitarsis group. The luteitarsis group of species may be distinguished from other European Pipiza by the lack of apicoventral ridges on the hind femora. P. luteibarba can be separated from other European species of the genus using the key provided by Vujić et al. (2013).

Vujić et al. (2013) successfully applied an integrative taxonomy approach for delimitation of Pipiza lugubris. P. lugubris can be separated from related species using molecular data and geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape. This species can also be distinguished from P. laurusi by the distribution.

Pipiza laurusi cannot be separated using traditional morphological characters, only with molecular data and using geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013). Distribution can also be used to separate this species from Pipiza lugubris.
Pipiza fasciata can be separated from other European species of genus using key from Vujić et al. (2013)
Pipiza carbonaria can be separated from other European species of the genus using the key provided by Vujić et al. (2013).
Pipiza austriaca can be separated from other European species of genus using key from Vujić et al. (2013)

This newly-recognized European monotypic genus has been discovered and described recently (Vujić et al. 2019). The systematic position of the taxon is within the tribe Rhingiini. Katara connexa is shiny, black species with broad, oval abdomen, which is distinctly broader than thorax in both sexes. Eyes are separated in both sexes (Vujić et al. 2019).

Claussen et al. (1994) provided the key in which Heringia adpropinquans is distinguished from H. heringi (Zetterstedt, 1843) and figured the male terminalia. In the male of H. adpropinquans the surstylus is noticeably broader in the apical half of its length, whereas in H. heringi it is almost parallel-sided, from base almost to apex (Speight 2018).

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia. Cheilosia venosa belongs to the Cheilosia caerulescens-group for which Ståhls and Barkalov (2017) provided the key. This species is inadequately differentiated from C. caerulescens, C. herculana and C. kerteszi in the existing keys (Speight 2018).

Based on the presence of a precoxal bridge, Cheilosia varnensis belongs to the Cheilosia angustigenis-species group. Claussen (2000) provides features separating C. varnensis from other species in this group and figures the male terminalia.

A species of the subgenus Taeniochilosia. For identification see key to males of European Taeniochilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia. Both sexes can be easily confused with C. sahlbergi Becker and females can easily be confused with C. pedestris Becker (Speight 2018). Claussen and van der Weyer (2004) provided an additional key for its identification.

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia.

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia.

Cheilosia pini belongs to the nominal subgenus. Vujić and Claussen (2000) redescribed the male and provide a description of the female, together with figures of the male terminalia and the key separating C. pini from other species of the pini group (Speight 2020).
Cheilosia rhynchops belongs to the nominate subgenus. It is extremely difficult to separate this species from C. lenta. The main difference is the presence of pilosity at mid of katepisternum.

Cheilosia rhodiolae belongs to the nominate subgenus. Schmid (2000) figures the male terminalia and provides a key distinguishing this species from related C. fasciata and C. semifasciata. Speight et al. (2017) review the features available for separation of C. rhodiolae from C. fasciata and C. semifasciata and provide another identification key. Unpublished findings of Cheilosia semifasciata mining in leaves of Rhodiola rosea in Enontekiö, Finnish Lapland complicates the taxonomic interpretation of C. rhodiolae, which was previously believed to use a different host plant from C. semifasciata. Its species status remains doubtful as comparisons of mtDNA COI barcode sequences of adults and larvae from Central Europe, southern and northern Finland of both Cheilosia semifasciata and C. rhodiolae show identical mtDNA barcode sequences (Lair et al. 2021), and the morphological characters to separate the species are not informative.

Cheilosia redi belongs to the nominal subgenus. It was originally described (Vujic 1996) as a subspecies of Cheilosia melanopa, it was raised to species level by Francuski et al. (2009), on the results of a comparative morphometric study of the adult insects involving C. lasiopa, C. melanopa and C. variabilis (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia ranunculi belongs to the nominate subgenus. Doczkal (2000) provides features for distinguishing the male of Cheilosia ranunculi from males of the closely-related C. albitarsis. Males of C. albitarsis and C. ranunculi can also be separated using the keys provided by van Veen (2004). Females of these two species cannot be distinguished. C. ranunculi and C. albitarsis are indistinguishable in the field and may be found in flight in the same place and on the same day, so considerable care is required in determining specimens.

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia.

Cheilosia psilophthalma belongs to the nominate subgenus. In some recent keys this species would usually key out to C. urbana, since C.psilophthalma can have antennae that are from pale orange to almost black, and the keys do not accommodate this range of variation. This species can also be confused with C. latigenis (Speight 2018).

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia.

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia. The female of this species is remarkably similar to the female of C. alpestris, from which it may most easily be distinguished by its hairy metasternum (the metasternum is bare in C. alpestris; Speight 2018), and by the shape of alula on the wing.

Cheilosia pascorum belongs to proxima group of species of nominal subgenus. For identification see key of European species of proxima group in Vujić et al. (2013) who figure the male terminalia. In general appearance C. pascuorum closely resembles C. gigantea, but has abdominal tergites that are entirely pale (yellow-brown) haired, whereas in C. gigantea black hairs are also present. Where it meets R4+5, vein M1 is curved slightly toward the wing base in C. pascuorum. In the other species it either meets R4+5 at a right angle or is pointing more toward the wing apex, in consequence reaching R4+5 at an angle less than 90° (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia orthotricha belongs to the nominate subgenus. It is related to Cheilosia canicularis and C. himanthopa (Vujić and Claussen 1994). The long pleural hairs are smooth. Other diagnostic features presented in (Vujić and Claussen 1994).

Cheilosia nebulosa belongs to nominal subgenus. The male terminalia are figured by Claussen and Speight (1988). The adult insect is illustrated in colour by Stubbs and Falk (1983). Species with black r-m cross-vein on wing.

Cheilosia naruska belongs to nominal subgenus. Haarto et al. (2007) describe both sexes of this proxima group species and figure the male terminalia. The comprehensive key in which C. naruska has so far appeared is that provided by Bartsch et al. (2009).
Cheilosia montana belongs to alpina species group of the subgenus Montanocheila. Features that distinguished this species from other members of this group were given by Claussen (1998).

Cheilosia lucense belongs to the subgenus Montanocheila. It is most similar to C. chrysocoma. Males can be distinguished by using features of terminalia. Females can be separated by angular facial tubercle and pollinose sternum 2. Ricarte et al. (2014) describe both the male and female, figure the male terminalia and show how C. lucense can be incorporated into the key to the European alpina group of species (Claussen 1998).
Cheilosia limbicornis belongs to nominal subgenus. The male is described by Torp Pedersen (1971). Diagnostic features are mentioned by Pérez-Bañón et al. (1996).
Cheilosia lenta belongs to the nominate subgenus. It is extremely difficult to separate C. lenta from C. rhynchops. The main difference is absence of pilosity at mid of katepisternum.

Claussen and Kassebeer (1993) provide the key for distinguishing Cheilosia latigenis from the closely similar species C. mutabilis, C. psilophthalma and C. urbana. C. latigenis belongs to the nominate subgenus.

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia. Cheilosia laeviventris belongs to the caerulescens species group of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia (former Nigrocheilosia) for which Ståhls and Barkalov (2017) provided the key.

Cheilosia laeviseta is a species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia.

Cheilosia kerteszi belongs to the caerulescens species group of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia (former Nigrocheilosia) for which Ståhls and Barkalov (2017) provide the key. It can be distinguished from the most similar species (Cheilosia circassica) by the presence of a few black bristles on the postalar callus.
Cheilosia katara belongs to nominal subgenus Cheilosia. An identification key distinguishing C. katara from other related species was provided by Vujić and Claussen (2000).

Cheilosia insignis is a member of subgenus Taeniocheilosia. An identification key is provided by Claussen and Van der Weyer (2004), Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) figure the male terminalia. Verlinden (2000) points out problems in the identification of C. insignis and provides features that help to identify C. insignis with more certainty.

Cheilosia ingerae is a member of the nominative subgenus. Nielsen and Claussen (2001) described Cheilosia ingerae from northern Norway, and figured the male genitalia. They also provided characters to separate C. ingerae from C. gigantea. This species is included in the keys to northern European Cheilosia species in Haarto and Kerppola (2007) and Bartsch (2009).

Cheilosia impudens belongs to the genus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia.

Cheilosia iberica belongs to Cheilosia s.str., and is a member of the proxima species-group. Marcos-Garcia and Claussen (1989) described both sexes of this species and figured the male terminalia and the head of the female.

Cheilosia hypena belongs to the nominate subgenus. There is no key in which C. hypena is adequately distinguished from related species. Verlinden (1999) redescribed the species, providing detailed information on separation of this species from C. frontalis Loew. Goeldlin de Tiefenau (1974) mentioned some distinguishing features of C. hypena (as C. capitata). Claussen established that Cheilosia capitata Goeldlin, 1974 is a junior synonym of C. hypena.

Cheilosia himantopa belongs to canicularis species group of the subgenus Cheilosia. From the closely similar Cheilosia canicularis it can be distinguished based on features published by Stuke and Claussen (2000).

Cheilosia hercyniae is a member of subgenus Taeniochilosia, and shares characters with members of the Cheilosia caerulescens species group. Ståhls and Barkalov (2017) provide a key for the separation of this species from others of the caerulescens group. The female of C. hercyniae is distinguished from related species by its possession of a very large, yellow-orange, third antennal segment, with, low down on its internal face, a very distinct, straight, slit-like antennal pit. An additional distinguishing feature of this species is that, in both sexes, the postero-dorsal triangular extension of mesanepisternite 1 carries long hairs (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia herculana belongs to subgenus Taeniochilosia, and the caerulescens species group. Barkalov and Ståhls (2017) provide a key for the separation of this species from others of the caerulescens group. This species closely resembles C. caerulescens (Mg.).

Cheilosia grisella belong to subgenus Taeniochilosia. An identification key to differentiate this species from other members of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia was provided by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997), and a key for Taenichilosia males by Speight in the StN volume (Speight 2018).

The mtDNA COI barcode partly shared with other grisella-group species (G. Ståhls pers. comm. 2020).
Cheilosia griseifacies can be distinguished by features in the key presented in Vujić (1994). It has previously been confused with Cheilosia canicularis, but there should be less confusion now.

Cheilosia gagatea belongs to subgenus Taeniochilosia. An identification key to males of European Nigrocheilosia (=Taeniochilosia) species is provided in the StN Keys volume and by  Barkalov and Ståhls (1997), the latter study also figure the male terminalia. The length of the aristal hairs is variable in this species (Speight 2020).

Cheilosia faucis is a member of the subgenus Taeniochilosia. An identification key to males of European Taeniochilosia species is provided in StN Keys volume, and the key bare-eyed, black-legged Cheilosia species with partly red/orange antennae by Claussen and Van de Weyer (2004). Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) figure the male terminalia.

The species is a member of the subgenus Taeniochilosia. Identification keys are provided by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) and Speight (2020) to males of European Taeniochilosia (as Nigrocheilosia). Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) figure the male terminalia. A particular feature of C. derasa is that in the wing the alula is more than six times as long as its maximum width, appearing strap-like, almost parallel-sided, a condition most unusual among Cheilosia species and shared only with Cheilosia alpestris.

Cheilosia cynocephala is a member of the nominal subgenus. C.cynocephala is more variable in size than many other Cheilosia species, from the dimensions of C.melanura down to those of C. vernalis. Distinction of the males from C.melanura and C.vernalis on any basis other than the blue-black colour of C.cynocephala can be difficult. The surstyli of the male terminalia are figured by Stubbs and Falk (2002). Falk (2004) discusses the differences between males of spring and summer populations of C. cynocephala in Britain and how they may be distinguished from C. vernalis.

Cheilosia crassiseta belongs to subgenus Taeniochilosia. A key to males of European Nigrocheilosia (= Taeniochilosia) species is provided in StN Keys volume. An additional key, for identification of the bare-eyed, black-legged Cheilosia species with partly red/orange antennae, is provided by Claussen and Van der Weyer (2004). Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) figured the male terminalia.

Cheilosia clausseni belongs to subgenus Taeniochilosia. Identification keys include key to males of European Nigrocheilosia (=Taeniochilosia) species in StN Keys volume, and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who also figure the male terminalia, and a key for identification of the bare-eyed, black-legged Cheilosia species with partly red/orange antennae by Claussen and Van der Weyer (2004).

The species belongs to Cheilosia s.str. The male of this species bears a superficial resemblance to C. nebulosa Verrall, while the female resembles C. psilophthalma, though its eyes are entirely bare and its claws are paler in colour (Speight 2020). Vujić and Claussen (2000) provide information for discerning C. clama from the similar species C. pini and C. alba.

Cheilosia caerulescens is a member of the subgenus Taeniochilosia, and the caerulescens species-group. Ståhls & Barkalov (2017) provide a key for the separation of this species from others of the caerulescens group. Cheilosia caerulescens is a morphologically very variable species. Dark forms of this species may be mistaken for C. laeviventris Loew or C. venosa Loew, and the male terminalia of these species are indistinguishable.

Cheilosia beckeri is a member of subgenus Taeniochilosia. Strobl (1910) included a number of males in his description of Cheilosia beckeri, but whether they all belong to the same taxon is doubtful (Speight 2018). The female lectotype was redescribed by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) and included in their key to females, and the male was tentatively included in the key to males but no male specimen was available for study, see also key to males of European Taeniochilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume in Speight (2018). Barcoding of recently obtained specimens links male specimens with the females (Ståhls, in prep.), which will enable the accurate inclusion of the males in identification keys based on diagnostic characteristics.

Cheilosia barbafacies was described by Vujić et al. (2013). The species is a member of the nominal subgenus and the proxima group. Vujić et al. (2013) provided descriptions of both sexes of the species, figured the male terminalia and provided an identification key distinguishing C. barbafacies from closely related species.

Cheilosia balkana belongs to the proxima group of species of the nominal subgenus, and it  morphologically closely resembles the species Cheilosia pascuorum. For identification see the key for European species of the proxima group in Vujić et al. (2013), who figured the male terminalia.

This is one of several small, black Cheilosia species of the subgenus Taeniochilosia endemic to the Alps. The thickened antennal arista is readily observable and facilitates identification (also in the field), identification key is provided by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997).

Cheilosia antiqua belongs to the subgenus Taeniochilosia. The species is morphologically similar to Cheilosia nigripes, and identification keys are provided by Barkalov and Ståhls (1997), and StN keys in Speight (2020).

The species belongs to the nominal subgenus Cheilosia s. str. Torp Pedersen (1971) described the male of this species, and Marcos-Garcia (1987) described the female. This species is apparently similar to C. rhynchops (C. Claussen pers. comm. 2020).

Identification keys include Barkalov and Ståhls (1997; including figures of the male terminalia) and the key to males of European Taeniochilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in the StN Keys volume (Speight 2018). In general appearance this species is similar to C. derasa Loew and the female to the female of C. pedemontana Rondani, separating characteristics provided in Barkalov and Ståhls (1997).

Cheiloisa alba is a member of the nominative subgenus. The species is similar in general appearance to Cheilosia clama, C. flavipes (Panzer, 1798), C. nebulosa Verrall, 1871 and C. uviformis Becker, 1894. Vujić and Claussen (2000) provide details for their separation.

Until recently (e.g. Peck 1988), Claussenia hispanica has been regarded as a synonym of Heringia heringi (Zetterstedt). It may be found in flight with H. heringi and the two species are virtually indistinguishable in the field, though males of C. hispanica are usually slightly larger than those of H. heringi (Speight 2018). A key distinguishing these two species is provided by Speight and Sarthou (2017). One of the features used to characterise C. hispanica is the presence of hairs at the ventral extremity of the median lobe of the lunule. These can be absent in the female (Speight 2018). Claussen et al. (1994) figured the male terminalia.

Cheilosia vujici belongs to the nominal subgenus. It is very similar in general appearance to the smallest specimens of C. psilophthalma and C. latigenis. Main diagnostic features are presented in Claussen and Doczkal (1998).

Cheilosia uviformis belongs to the nominate subgenus. It is not satisfactorily distinguished in existing keys. It is included in the keys provided by van Veen (2004), but specimens lacking scutellar marginal bristles could be misidentified as C. laticornis, and others with a heavily-dusted face could be identified as C. rufimana. It is redescribed and its diagnostic features are detailed by Speight and Claussen (1987), who also figure features of the male terminalia (Speight 2018).
The record of the species from Romania (Bradescu 1991) is considered to refer to Pipizella zloti (Vujić 1997), and according to van Eck (2011), Portuguese records refer to Pipizella thapsiana.

Pipizella certa and P. brevis are very similar morphologically, even male genitalia structure. P. certa proposed as a junior synonym of P. brevis by Kuznetzov (1987), but van Steenis and Lucas (2011) reinstated P. certa a valid species. P. brevis is a generally ”southern species“ (Spain, Austria..), whilst P. certa is a ”northern“ (Finland...) species.

Records of this species from Anatolia (Turkey) require confirmation; they probably refer to Pipizella orientalis (van Steenis and Lucas 2011), and P. annulata is considered to be endemic to Europe here.

According to some authors (e.g. Burgio et al. 2015), P. ascoensis, P. haemorrhous and P. tibialis belong to a single polymorphic taxon with high intraspecific variability. If this approach is accepted, the senior name would be Paragus tibialis (Fallén, 1817).
Speight (2011) notes that the identity of this species is uncertain; its description (Gimmerthal 1842) is undiagnostic and its its maleterminalia have never been figured.
This species was described from North America, however, Speight et al. (2013) confirmed the species to be European in origin.

Barkalov and Stahls (1997) figure the male terminalia. An additional key, for identification of the bare-eyed, black-legged Cheilosia species with partly red/orange antennae, is providedby Claussen and van der Weyer (2004). C. clausseni is easily mistaken for C. pilifer (Speight 2020).

Cheilosia pedestris belongs to the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. It was described by Becker (1894), based on a solitary female. Claussen and van der Weyer (2004) described C. romigi from Italy. The synonymy of C. romigi with C. pedestris was established by Claussen and Speight (2007) (Speight 2018).

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figure the male terminalia. Genitalia have complicated structures which can make identification more difficult than for other species of the subgenus.

Two different taxa are clearly encompassed by the names Cheilosia morio and C. scanica, but correct application of these names and consequently relative range limits remain to be established (Speight 2020). The identities of Cheilosia morio (Zetterstedt 1838) (Syrphidae, tribe Rhingiini) and of its synonyms are reviewed by Doczkal and Claußen (in prep.). This work referred Cheilosia scanica Ringdahl, 1937 to the synonymy of Cheilosia morio (Zetterstedt, 1838) and determined that the name C. morio had been widely misapplied to a distinct species, for which these authors resurrected the name Cheilosia luteicornis (Zetterstedt, 1838). This nomenclature was used in a few recent publications (Nilsson et al. 2012, van Steenis 2016).

Cheilosia morio belongs to the subgenus Neocheilosia. From the most similar species it can be distinguished by its smaller size, presence of black pile around facial knob and black pile on terga. In Bartsch et al. (2009) this species is mentioned as Cheilosia morio B.

Cheilosia melanopa belongs to nominal subgenus. Vujić (1996) figures the male terminalia and differentiates the Balkan subspecies C. m. redi, that is now recognised as a species in its own right, C. redi Vujic. C. melanopa is also included in the keys provided by van Veen (2004) and Haarto and Kerppola (2007).

A species of the subgenus Taeniocheilosia. For identification see the key to males of European Taeniocheilosia (as Nigrocheilosia) species in StN Keys volume; and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997) who figured the male terminalia. Not an easy species to identify, closely related to other species but the genitalia are distinct.

Cheilosia lenis belongs to nominal subgenus. It can be difficult to separate C. lenis from its allies in central Europe. In western Europe, it is probably most easily confused with C. bergenstammi Becker. In C. lenis the eye hairs are long, vary from black to pale grey and extend to the ventral surface of the eyes. In C. bergenstammi they are shorter (especially in the female), pale brown and absent from the ventral quarter of the eye surface. The posterior margin of the scutellum can possess only fine hairs in this species, or fine hairs with some thin, black bristles, or hairs with some well-developed black bristles (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia frontalis belongs to the nominative subgenus. There is confusion in the literature between this species and C. hypena (Becker). Verlinden (1999) details distinctions between C. frontalis and C. hypena. The keys provided by van Veen (2004) help to distinguish females of C. frontalis and C. melanopa. This species is also included in the keys of van der Goot (1981), and keys to northern European Cheilosia species in Haarto and Kerppola (2007, provided in both Finnish and English).

Cheilosia brachysoma belongs to the nominate subgenus. The male of C. brachysoma is similar to C. vernalis in general appearance and the species has to be regarded as a member of the vernalis species group, whose component taxa still pose considerable taxonomic problems. Claussen and Vujic (1995) provide means of separating females of C. brachysoma from females of C.clama. The species is difficult to identify even for people with significant expertise.
The species belongs to the Eumerus obliquus group.
<span class="datalabel1">

The species belongs to Eumerus olivaceus group. E. alpinus Rondani, 1857 is resurrected from synonymy of E. olivaceus Loew, 1848 and considered as bona species in Grković et al. (2015), until than the name of E. olivaceus was used for both species.

The identity of Callicera rohdendorfi Zimina, 1982 with respect to C. macquarti requires confirmation. Zimina (1986) described details of Callicera rohdendorfi which led to the assumption that it should be C. macquarti. Callicera rohdendorfi was considered to be "almost certainly the same" as C. macquarti by Speight (1991), however this requires confirmation based on review of the Zimina holotype and/or paratype specimens of Callicera rohdendorfi. If C. rohdendorfi is a synonym of C. macquarti, then the range of C. macquarti extends to Crimea and the Caucasus, probably to Azerbaijan.

Callicera macquarti is probably synonymous with C. fagesii according to recent results from DNA analysis, but Callicera macquarti is maintained as a valid species until its identity is formally revised.

Cheilosia ahenea belongs to the subgenus Taeniochilosia. The species is included in identification keys in the StN Keys volume (Speight 2018), Speight and Claussen (1987) and Barkalov and Ståhls (1997), the latter figure the male terminalia.

Cheilosia fasciata belongs to the subgenus Pollinocheila. Both sexes of this species have the central area of the mesoscutal disc entirely undusted and brightly shining black, separating C. fasciata from both C. rhodiolae and C. semifasciata, in which the mesoscutum is uniformly dusted over its entire surface. A key for the separation of these three species is provided in Speight et al. (2017).
A recent record (Mutin and Barkalov 2018) of this species from Omsk (Siberia) refer to another species, with genetic confirmation (A. Grković pers. comm. 2021).

Cheilosia thessala belongs to the longula species group closely resembling the species Cheilosia scutellata. Claussen and Ståhls (2007) provided the key to separate this species from others in the C. scutellata group and also figured the male terminalia (Speight 2018).

Cheilosia semifasciata is a small species with hairy eyes and dark legs with at least the apical ends of all femora and/or the base of all tibiae yellow in both sexes. High altitude specimens may have entirely black legs (Schmid 2000). It is the most similar with C. rhodiolae Schmid, 2000. To separate these two species from one another it is necessary to refer Schmid (2000). The surstyli of the male terminalia are figured out by Stubbs and Falk (2002).

Vujić et al. (2013) successfully used an integrative taxonomy approach for delimitation of Pipiza notata from related species. P. notata can be separated from related species using subtle characters in male genitalia, molecular data and geometric morphometric evidence: wing size and shape (Vujić et al. 2013).
The species is morphologically similar to Palumbia eristaloides (Portschinsky, 1887), and further research is needed to determine whether they may be the same taxon.
<span class="datalabel1">

authority: J. van Steenis and W. van Steenis, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species is similar to Melanostoma scalare. It is separable from it using the characters provided by Haarto and Ståhls (2014), but prior to this work the two species are likely to have been confused.

This species has been recently described (Haarto and Ståhls 2014) and many labelled specimens of Melanostoma in collections all over Europe should be revised to understand the actual distribution of this species.

This species has been reported from outside Corsica (the French mainland, Sardinia and from Italy) by other authors (Burgio et al. 2015, Speight et al. 2018), but Eupeodes vandergooti is difficult to distinguish from related species, such as E. lucasi, and has not reliably been confirmed from outside Corsica. The species is considered here to be endemic to Corsica pending further work.

This species was recently discovered amongst specimens labelled as C. festivum from the Balkan Peninsula. Black-haired specimens of C. festivum from high altitudes were found to be this new taxon (C. tomentosum) and they can now be separated from the typical C. festivum based on the characters described by Nedeljković et al. (2013). These recent updates in the taxonomy of C. festivum warrant the revision of the C. festivum from other parts of Europe to obtain a clearer understanding of the range of C. festivum and C. tomentosum in the continent.

The species Dasysyrphus lenensis Bagatshanova, 1980 was described based on specimens from eastern Siberia (Yakutia). Doczkal (1996) introduced this name for Dasysyrphus species collected in Central European woodlands that was previously confused with other similar species e.g. D. pinastri and D. pauxillus. Barkalov (2007) proposed synonymizing the name D. lenensis within Dasysyrphus nigricornis (Verrall, 1873). This synonymy was proposed only on the characters based on similarity of pictures from papers of Bičík and Láska (1995) and Doczkal (1996), without study of D. nigricornis type specimens and Central European D. lenensis specimens. Distribution ranges as well as habitats of D. nigricornis and D. lenensis seems to be strongly different in Europe (D. Doczkal pers. comm.; Bartsch et al. 2009). Nevertheless the habitat on the type locality of Dasysyrphus lenensis seems to be more similar to habitat of D. nigricornis in northern Europe.

Locke and Skevington (2013) used the name D. lenensis for Central European specimens of Dasysyrphus that are clearly genetically separated from specimens from the northern Nearctic region referred as D. nigricornis, unfortunately specimens from northern Europe were absent within the analysed specimens of D. nigricornis. As such this assessment treats the two species as distinct pending more detailed taxonomic work.

There is uncertainty as to which genus Epistrophella coronata should be referred to because the only other species of this genus - E. euchroma - is consigned by some authors to the genus Meligramma (Speight 2020).
This species is very close to, and may be a synonym of, Eupeodes curtus, being distinguished only by pale hairs on scutellum and different abdominal pattern.

The species has been recognized relatively recently. This species was confused with several similar Eupeodes species previously (Mazánek et al. 1999). Male terminalia are almost identical with E. goeldlini.
This species is similar to Eupeodes luniger. To date it is known only from the male holotype, an extremely dark specimen. Its validity is uncertain and its identity requires confirmation.

This species can be found in literature under the genera Melanostoma and Meligramma. It resembles Melanostoma species but it can be separate from them by the abdominal markings, which widen progressively towards the lateral margins of the tergites, meeting the lateral margins at full width. In addition, the second tergite bears a pair of narrow, transverse, whitish yellow bars, which come to a point towards the mid-line, while tergites three and four each exhibit either a pair of bars or a narrow, transverse band, of the same colour as the markings on tergite two (Speight 2020).

This species is known only from the type series described from San Petesburg by Kuznetzov (1990). Goeldlin de Tiefenau (1996) in his revision of European species of the genus Syrphus included this species in the identification key.

Further faunistic and taxonomic research is needed to determine whether this is a valid species or not. If valid, this species can be separated from other Syrphus by the following characters: Second basal cell of wing bare on the anterior quarter or more; setae on the basitarsis all yellow; face mainly black; yellow bands on tergites divided.

Smit et al. (2004) supports the validity of X. babyssa and placed X. parahyalinatus as a synonym of X. babyssa, following Wakeham-Dawson et al. (2004).

However, there are some doubts about the validity of X. babyssa (Speight 2020), which appears in recent literature as Xanthandrus parahyalinatus. The fact that X. babyssa is found only on Madeira island - from which other endemic hoverflies are known - provides sufficient justification to consider it valid until new studies integrating morphology and molecular biology are undertaken.

authority: Schönrogge, Barr, Wardlaw, Napper, Gardner, Breen, Elmes & Thomas, 2002

taxonomicNotes:
Tachypleus tridentatus and T. gigas are sometimes the subject of misidentification. In China, three horseshoe crab nature reserves were established in Guangdong Province in 2004 for the protection of T. gigas (Kwan et al. 2016), even though T. gigas has not been recorded in these areas (Liao and Li 2001, Liao et al. 2001a).

In Hong Kong, the occurrence of T. gigas, T. tridentatus and C. rotundicauda was reported (Mikkelsen 1988), but recent population studies did not reveal any presence of T. gigas in Hong Kong waters (Li 2008, Shin et al. 2009, Morton and Lee 2010) and a recent literature review suggests previous reports of the presence of T. gigas in Hong Kong was a case of mistaken identity, based on the wrong labelling of photographs in a popular natural history book at the time (Laurie 2011, unpublished).

On 23 May 2012, five horseshoe crabs were seized at Sam Ratulangi International Airport, Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia under PP No. 7/1999 (Indonesia Government Regulation No. 7/1999). Although described as T. gigas, photographs indicate the seized animals were T. tridentatus (BKIPM 2012).
This species was previously considered synonymous with Parhelophilus frutetorum but the two species were separated in 2000 (Speight 2020).
This species may be misidentified with Eristalis rupium (Speight 2020) and also with Eristalis obscura (Prokhorov and Popov 2017).
The proper identification of this species, which is very similar to Eristalis nemorum (and Eristalis interrupta), is only possible using the specific key (Vujić et al. 2004).

This species is recently described (2001) and might need genetic verification to confirm that it is a separate species. It is very close to Anasimyia transfuga which is a widespread species but has not been found in the same locality as Anasimyia femorata (Speight 2020).

Vujić (1999) figures the male terminalia and discusses distinctions between this species and the closely similar Neocnemodon pubescens and Neocnemodon vitripennis. According to Vujić (1999) the body length of Neocnemodon larusi is 7-8.5 mm. The body length given for Neocnemodon larusi by Bartsch et al. (2009) is 4-6 mm, exactly the same as given by those authors for Neocnemodon pubescens. Delucchi and Pschorn-Walcher (1955) give the body length for Neocnemodon pubescens as 5.5-6.5 mm. Whether the small size of the Scandinavian Neocnemodon larusi specimens indicates a regional size difference or confusion with Neocnemodon pubescens is a moot point. Re-appraisal of central European Neocnemodon pubescens material would seem worthwhile. All this information has been extracted from Speight (2020).
This species is very close to Ceriana vesipformis - it was quite recently split into two species by van Steenis et al. (2016).
Some differences with the male genitalia showed in different publications suggest more than one species might be included inside Psilota anthracina (Speight 2020).
Described from Sicily, was a synonym of the North African species Platynochaetus rufus but is now confirmed as a valid species (Speight 2020).
Opilio lencinai is a junior synonym of O. barbarus since it has been compared with the type material (H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
O. cilicicus, O. taeniatus and O. tilloides are included in the O. taeniatus complex, which needs taxonomic revision (P. Audisio pers. comm. 2015, H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
O. cilicicus, O. taeniatus and O. tilloides are included in the O. taeniatus complex, which needs taxonomic revision (P. Audisio pers. comm. 2015, H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
This species could be the male of Tillus mozabitus (H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).

This species was described in 1966 based on a single specimen and it is closely related to Platycerus caraboides (Linné, 1758); according to the original description, it can be distinguished by the denser punctuation of the pronotum and the shape of the aedeagus (Schweiger, 1966). It seems that only the type specimen is known at date.
Bott (1955) treated this species as Sudanonautes (Convexonautes) aubryi monodi. Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999) redescribed this species as Sudanonautes monodi.
This species was described by Cumberlidge (1993) with additional localities and ecological notes provided by Cumberlidge (1997, 1998, 1999).
Prior to 2003, this species was treated as Caliphae confusa Hagen in Sélys, 1859. In 2003, Hämäläinen described the population from northern Thailand as a separate species, C. angka.

Phan et al. (2020) have questioned the status of Coeliccia hainanense as a species distinct from C. scutellum Laidlaw; C. hainanense was originally described as a subspecies of C. scutellum and later considered a full species. This issue remains open.
The subspecies "Seychelles fineliner damselfly" (T. a. alluaudi), originally classified as Critically Endangered (CR) on the IUCN Red List, is regarded as a synonym to the nominate species.

Chao (1990) described Sieboldius maai from male and female specimens reared from larvae collected in Shaowu, Fujian and further material from Zhejiang. The male anal appendages and secondary sexual apparatus are very similar to those of S. alexanderi Chao (1955). Chao (1990) separated S. maai from S. alexanderi based primarily on its yellow dorsal stripe conjoined with the collar stripe whereas these two stripes are separate in S. alexanderi.  In addition, the terminal margin of the vulvar scale is almost straight in S. maai and highly incised in S. alexanderi.
The genus Borbo was split into three lineages by Fan et al. (2016); Borbo, Pseudoborbo and Larsenia. Borbo holtzi falls into the final of these three lineages.
Coeliades keithloa currently has no recognized subspecies as all of the taxa formerly accorded this rank have been raised to distinct species (Henning et al. 1997, Chiba 2009, Cock 2010).
There is some uncertainty as to whether Platylesches tina found in South Africa is the same species as that found further north in Africa (S. Collins pers. comm.)
The genus was recently revised by Libert (2010).
Anthene princeps subsp. smithi (Mabille, 1877) was raised to species level by Libert (2010); A. princeps thus does not contain any subspecies.
Pelopidas thrax ssp. inconspicua (Bertoloni, 1850) was synonymized with P. thrax (Hübner, [1821]) by Larsen (2005).

This species has two subspecies. The nominate subspecies Charaxes candiope ssp. candiope is found on mainland Africa, while the subspecies C. c. ssp. velox is limited to the island of Socotra. The latter has been treated as a separate species by some, and it is likely that future reassessments of the species will need to assess the two concepts separately.
The genus Euxanthe Hübner, in which this species was previously placed, was recently synonymized with Charaxes Ochsenheimer (Aduse-Poku et al. 2009).
It can only be distinguished from its congeners Leptotes babaulti, L. brevidentatus and L. pirithous by examination of the genitalia.

The two recognized subspecies, Tuxentius calice ssp. calice Hopffer, 1855 (Type locality: Mozambique: Querimba) and Tuxentius calice ssp. gregorii Butler, 1894 (Type locality: Kenya: Bondoni and Kapte Plains), are probably distinct species (Larsen 1991).
It can only be distinguished from its congeners Leptotes babaulti, L. jeanneli and L. pirithous by examination of the genitalia.
Can only be distinguished from its congeners Leptotes brevidentatus, L. jeanneli and L. pirithous by examination of the genitalia.
As many as 27 subspecies have been described for this species.

The P. varii species complex appears to be a group of isolated populations with distinctive characteristics which may be in the process of speciating. The possibility exists that there are more taxa than the two named species - P. varii van Son, 1955 and P. swanepoeli van Son, 1955 (Curle, A.I. & Curle, N.I. 1995). Some of these populations show similarities to P. swanepoeli van Son, 1955, and taxonomic work to resolve the situation is needed.
Previously placed in Eronia Hübner, [1823]; Afrodryas Stoneham, 1957 was re-instated as a valid genus by Nazari et al. (2011).
Cacyreus virilis has no recent synonyms or recognised subspecies. It is difficult to separate from C. lingeus.
We follow e.g. LepIndex (Beccaloni et al. 2021) and Wiemers et al. (2018) in placing this species in the genus Freyeria, but in Williams (2020) it is retained in genus Chilades.
Libert (2004) synonymized Deudorix penningtoni van Son, 1949 with D. vansoni Pennington, 1948.
The genus is in need of a taxonomic review.

Pinhey, cited by Pringle et al. (1994), regarded Lepidochrysops glauca var. swinburnei Stevenson, 1939 as only a form of glauca (Trimen). It is not clear, however, whether Pinhey formally synonymized swinburnei with glauca. It has been stated that glauca and swinburnei are sympatric and synchronal, and this precludes the latter being a subspecies of glauca (Williams 2010). D'Abrera (2009) suggests that swinburnei is a synonym of glauca but makes no formal taxonomic change.

Gomphidia krueger was described by Martin (1904) from ‘Tonkin’, north Viet Nam. Chao (1955) established the subspecies G. krueger fukienensis from Fujian. Zhang (2019) stated that apart from the colour pattern differences the posterior hamulus and female vulvar laminar are structurally different and raised the taxon to species status.
This genus is in need of revision.
Status of this taxon was revised by Heath and Pringle (2007).
The boundary between Chrysoritis palmus ssp. palmus and C. p. ssp. margueritae is not clearly defined, and intermediate forms occur in the Riversdale area, for example.
This taxon was formerly treated as a subspecies of Anthene otacilia (see e.g. Williams 2020).

Although this subspecies is generally recognised as being restricted to the Eastern Cape, there are a number of populations found in the mountains of the Western Cape which resemble this subspecies and whose status needs to be resolved.
There is debate concerning whether the subpopulations from the Kamiesberg should be classified as an additional distinct subspecies.
Chrysoritis pyramus subspecies balli, was originally described as a distinct species, but accorded subspecific status by Heath and Pringle (2007).

There remains some doubt as to the status of the Stilbaai population, and whether it is mithras, since subpopulations of nominate Chyrsoritis thysbe ssp. thysbe can be found as far east as Mossel Bay (Edge 2005). A phylogenetic study by the Museum of Comparative Anatomy at Harvard should resolve this. DNA work currently in progress suggests that this may be a distinct species, with no relationship to thysbe.

A study of molecular phylogenetics in Omiodes moths, found some evidence that Omiodes asaphrombra may be a variant of O. anastreptoides, based on genetically indistinguishable mitochondrial DNA sequence data (Haines 2011). They do, however, exhibit distinct morphological characteristics, such as wing coloration patterns (Haines 2011). More research is needed. If O. asaphombra and O. anastreptoides are indeed the same species, then the name O. asaphombra would have taxonomic priority. A detailed comparison of the type specimens of O. asaphombra and O. anastreptoides would be necessary to determine whether the two species are distinct.

There is some taxonomic uncertainty regarding this species because adults very closely resemble Omiodes blackburni. The species description is based only on variation in wing colouration and pattern, which may not reflect an actual distinction (Haines pers. comm. 2019).
There is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding this species.

Molecular evidence suggests Omiodes accepta may be comprised of five cryptic species (Haines 2011). Data from mitochondrial and nuclear genes revealed O. accepta grouped into five clades, differing from each other by 1.1% to 3.6% (Haines 2011).  One of these clades included individuals from all the Hawaiian Islands within the range of O. accepta, two occurred only on Hawai‘i, and two occurred only on O‘ahu and Kaua‘i (Haines 2011).

A study of molecular phylogenetics in Omiodes moths found some evidence that the rare species Omiodes asaphombra may be a variant of O. anastreptoides, based on genetically indistinguishable mitochondrial DNA sequence data (Haines 2011). More research is needed to compare the type specimen of O. asaphombra to variants of O. anastreptoides.

Molecular evidence suggests Omiodes antidoxa may be comprised of two cryptic species, representing two isolated populations, one from O‘ahu and one from Kaua‘i (Haines 2011). Data from mitochondrial and nuclear genes revealed these two haplogroups differing from each other by 1.9% (Haines 2011). More research is necessary to identify morphological or ecological differences between populations on O‘ahu and Kaua‘i.

Zimmerman (1958) noted that Omiodes giffardi is morphologically very similar to O. accepta and may merely be a subspecies or variety of O. accepta. Swezey (1921) described this, and several other species, based only on variation in wing colouration or pattern without citing differences in genitalia or other morphological characteristics (Haines 2011). A more detailed morphological assessment of this group of species is necessary to determine whether O. giffardi is a discrete species.

It has been suggested that Omiodes iridias may be a synonym of O. scotaea (Haines and Foote 2004). Minor differences in wing pattern and caterpillar coloration are currently used to differentiate them, so it is thought O. iridias may simply be a variant of O. scotaea (W. Haines pers. obs.). Additional research is necessary.
There is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding this species. It appears to be unique from the closely related Omiodes blackburni (W. Haines pers. obs.),

Molecular evidence suggests that subpopulations of Omiodes monogramma, geographically separated by island, are also genetically isolated from each other (more than 1% divergence) and many constitute cryptic species (W. Haines pers. obs.).

Swezey (1948) described this species based purely on larval characters. As the adult form is unknown, it may be a variant of the closely related species, Omiodes blackburni (W. Haines pers. comm. 2019).

It has been suggested that Omiodes scotaea and O. iridias may be a single species (Haines and Foote 2004). Minor differences in wing pattern and caterpillar colouration are currently used to differentiate them, so it is thought O. iridias may simply be a variant of O. scotaea (W. Haines pers. obs.). Additional research is necessary.

Two subspecies are currently recognized for the taxon: Aloeides dentatis ssp. dentatis and A. d. ssp. maseruna.

A. dentatis is a taxonomically difficult species that needs a great deal of research to determine the correct status of the various subpopulations included. Some of the taxa in dispute have been treated as A. d. ssp. maseruna, but they may have to be included in the nominate subspecies or recognized as a new subspecies or even a new species when adequate research has been conducted.
The genus is in need of revision. This species is recognized as having the two subspecies Tarsocera cassus ssp. cassus and T. c. ssp. outeniqua.

The Powesheik skipperling was first described by Parker in 1870. While the species was named for Poweshiek county, the Iowan county in which it was originally found, Parker mistakenly spelled it Powesheik in his original description. In 1981, Miller and Brown used a corrected spelling in A catalogue/checklist of the butterflies of America, north of Mexico (p. 31). According to the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature [rule 32(c)ii], the spelling can be corrected since it was a case of an original incorrect spelling. Use remains mixed, with some authorities using the corrected spelling and others retaining Parker's original spelling.
This species was included in the subgenus Stereosa Casey, 1909 (Verdugo 2005) but more recently, it was changed to the subgenus Cypriacis Casey, 1909 (Kubán 2006).

The identity of this species needs to be revised. According to Kirby (1897) Micrathyria cambridgei differs from M. didyma in the number of post-triangular cells. This character is likely to be variable. Therefore,  this species needs revision.

Micronaspis floridana is the only named species in this genus (Lloyd 2018). Two subpopulations occur: one along the Florida coastline, and another on some northern islands of the Bahamas (Faust 2017). Although Lloyd (2018) suggests the Bahamas subpopulation may eventually be described as a new species, here we treat both the Florida and Bahamas varieties as the same.

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. Ellychnia autumnalis is part of a widespread species complex, wherein the division of E. autumnalis, E. lacustris, and E. corrusca is not entirely straightforward (Fender 1970). However, these species can be distinguished by differences in the male genitalia (Marvin 1965).

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. Green (1949) notes that Ellychnia bivulnerus is morphologically very similar to Pyropyga fenestralis Melsh., and that the two species may be mixed in some collections. P. fenestralis is now synonymized with P. nigricans (Green 1961). This species is not a true congener with the type of the genus (E. corrusca). Taxonomic revision should eventually remove it to another genus but its Mexican affiliates, if any, are not known. Fender (1970) placed it in its own subgenus, Greeneana, and that has sufficed so far.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.

Ellychnia corrusca is a widespread species complex probably composed of several closely related, undescribed species (Faust 2017, S. Lower pers. comm. 2019). Given wide size variations and some differences in behaviour and seasonality, eastern Ellychnia corrusca may eventually be split back into the three older species of E. lacustris, E. autumnalis, and E. corrusca; western Ellychnia may represent additional species (Faust 2017). This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. ITIS and most other sources list the taxonomic authority for this species as LeConte, 1857. However, Keller and Branham (2018) have proposed nomenclatural changes for a number of species, including Ellychnia facula, which has a corrected date of publication of 1854. Thus the current accepted name for this species is Ellychnia facula LeConte, 1854. At the western edge of this species’ range in the Cascade Mountains of Oregon and Washington, it is possible there is some intergradation with Ellychnia hatchi and E. greeni (R. Lyons pers. comm. 2020).
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. Lyons (2015) has observed that the range and even some of the paratype localities of Ellychnia hatchi and E. greeni overlap across most areas west of the Cascade Mountains. Given the fact that multiple specimens of each species have been collected from the same sites, often on the same day by the same collector, it is possible that these species represent an unresolved species complex with individual morphological variation (Lyons 2015). Fender (1970) also notes considerable variation in morphological features of many western Ellychnia, and states that small specimens of E. hatchi may be confused with E. greeni.

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. Lyons (2015) has observed that the range and even some of the paratype localities of Ellychnia hatchi and E. greeni overlap across most areas west of the Cascade Mountains. Given the fact that multiple specimens of each species have been collected from the same sites, often on the same day by the same collector, it is possible that these species represent an unresolved species complex with individual morphological variation (Lyons 2015). Fender (1970) also notes considerable variation in morphological features of many western Ellychnia, and states that small specimens of E. hatchi may be confused with E. greeni.

This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision. Previously, eastern Ellychnia were split into three species: E. corrusca, E. autumnalis, and E. lacustris (Luk et al. 2011, Faust 2017). Although Ellychnia lacustris is currently listed as a valid species (ITIS 2020), supported by distinct differences in genitalia (Marvin 1965), it is considered by many to be part of the larger E. corrusca complex (Faust 2017) with lingering questions about its taxonomic status.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.
This genus of diurnal fireflies is greatly in need of taxonomic revision.

Green (1948) correctly asserted that “the generic designations for Lucidota species (atra, punctata, and luteicollis) cannot be determined until the generic types have been properly tabulated.” The original description of species ‘luteicollis’ was published by LeConte in 1878 who placed it directly into the genus Lucidota. Subsequently, Henshaw (1882) moved the species to Pyropyga. Green (1948) returned the species to Lucidota in order to maintain Pyropyga as a homogeneous collection of species. Lucidota was, at that time, and continues to be at present, a heterogeneous collection of unrelated species that unreconciled types could be set aside in. Poole et al. (1966) listed the species as “Pyropyga luteicollis LeConte 1878 (Lucidota)” which suggests that they didn’t know of Green’s revision. This reversion to Pyropyga has been ignored by subsequent authors and should not be considered as a formal re-reversion of the species’ taxonomy.

 

Currently, Lucidota luteicollis stands fully vested as the nomen for LeConte’s type; however, the type of the genus is the South American species banoni, and luteicollis is very likely not congeneric with it. The species will certainly be designated as a new genus if a modern author takes up the species problem and removes it from Lucidota sensu lato. Lucidota is long due a full revision, and when this eventually happens, downsizing will also remove it to a new genus.

There is no taxonomic uncertainty regarding this species (Green 1957), although there are other fireflies with similar courtship signals, that can be confused with this species (L. Buschman pers. comm. 2020).

This taxon may in fact represent a species complex, as it occurs over a wide range and is variable in coloration and flash behaviour (Green 1957, Lloyd 2018). The eastern and western varieties of this species may eventually be classified as distinct species (Buschman 2016, Faust 2017).

Pyractomena linearis is part of a complex of closely related species, including P. dispersa, P. palustris and P. limbicollis (Green 1957, Faust 2017). There are also several flash patterns observed in P. linearis, adding further confusion to the taxonomic certainty of this species (Lloyd 2018).

Lloyd (2018) suggests there is a distinction between the sub-populations of Pyractomena lucifera in the northern and southern portions of its range, and the individuals in the southern portion of the range will soon be designated a new species. For the purpose of this assessment, the two sub-populations are treated as one species, P. lucifera.

This species is difficult to identify unless flash patterns are observed (Faust 2017). It is aligned with the P. linearis species complex, which requires additional work to resolve taxonomic relationships (Lloyd 2018).

It is possible this species is conspecific with Pyractomena doralis Motschulsky, 1853, a species collected only once from “Mexico”. The binomial P. doralis would have priority if these two species are in fact one and the same (Green 1957).

There is debate about whether Pterotus curticornis is distinct from P. obscuripennis. The type locality is isolated from suitable P. obscuripennis habitat nearby, but additional taxonomic studies are necessary (J. Cicero pers. comm. 2020).
Zaragoza-Caballero (1992) synonymized Pleotomus pallens and P. davisii under P. pallens.
Pleotomus nigripennis was synonomized under P. pallens (Zaragoza 1992) but was subsequently restored to species status (Zaragoza and Ramirez 2009).

Photuris walldoxeyi a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Faust and Davis 2019, Barber 1951, McDermott 1967). Genetic and cladistics research, to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species complex, is ongoing (Faust 2017).

Photuris versicolor is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris tremulans is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris salina is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Genetic and cladistics research, to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species complex, are ongoing (Faust 2017).

Photuris quadrifulgens is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris pyralomima is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris potomaca is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris pensylvanica is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Prior to the work of Barber (1951) and McDermott (1967), many Photuris species were lumped together and referred to as P. pennsylvanica (notice the misspelling). Therefore, this species is over represented in the collection record.

Unlike other species of Photuris, which are difficult to distinguish from one another morphologically and are often placed into species complexes, P. mysticalampas has a morphological character—an oval outline when viewed from above—that clearly distinguishes it from other species within its range (Heckscher 2013, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris missouriensis is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Members of the Photuris genus can be difficult to discern from one another. The taxonomy was recently revised by Lloyd (2018), but work on this complex genus is ongoing. Photuris lucicrescens is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences between species (Faust and Davis 2019). Although Lloyd (2018) suggests this may be the only common Photuris in this group that can be recognized from preserved specimens, Faust (2017) acknowledges that locality records remain a bit uncertain due to difficulties in species ID when flash data are lacking. Genetic and cladistics research to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species group are ongoing (Faust 2017).

Photuris lloydi is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observations of male flash patterns, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Photuris lloydi which is distinguished by a male flash pattern consisting of short, single, crescendo flashes emitted continuously, may itself turn out to be a species complex.

Photuris lineaticollis is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Furthermore, this species, also known as the Giant Red, is within a group of species called the “Red Group”, the trim of which is distinctively redder in colour than most, generally yellowish Photuris (Lloyd 2018).  The Red Group species can often be distinguished from each other by their flash patterns. It is unclear which of these Red Group variants was collected by V. Motschulsky when P. lineaticollis was described in 1854, because there is no holotype or information on flash pattern (Lloyd 2018).

Photuris hebes is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable only by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Lloyd 2018, Faust and Davis 2019). Genetic and cladistics research, to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species complex, are ongoing (Faust 2017). According to C. Heckscher (pers. comm. 2019) inland and coastal variants of P. hebes are likely represent two separate species, but they have not yet been officially designated as such.

Photuris floridana is difficult to distinguish from, and was once considered a subspecies of, P. brunnipennis, which is found in Cuba (Lloyd 2018). It is also very similar in flash pattern and ecology to P. congener but is distinguished by seasonal occurrence and latitude (Lloyd 2018).

Photuris fairchildi is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018).

Photuris cinctipennis is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Lloyd (2018) notes that several similar-looking species, including some that occur in the southeastern United States, may occur within a smaller cintcipennis group. Further complicating matters, although Barber's (1951) description includes its distinctive coloration (pale legs and pale hind margins on ventral abdominal segments), he did not observe the male flash pattern of this species. Genetic and cladistics research to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species complex are ongoing (Faust 2017).
