Photuris caerulucens is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Furthermore, P. caerulucens belongs to a poorly resolved group of low-flying species, within the versicolor complex, whose primary flash pattern consists of a long, steady glow, one second or more in duration. It is also morphologically similar to the taxonomically dubious, sympatric species Photuris aureolucens. Although the two species differ slightly in colouration, more notably, the duration of the male flash is much longer in P. caerulucens (Lloyd 2018).

Photuris bethaniensis is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Genetic and cladistics research, to clarify taxonomic relationships within this species complex, are ongoing (Faust 2017).

Photuris aureolucens is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). Furthermore, it is morphologically similar to the sympatric species Photuris caerulucens, although the duration and colour of the male courtship flash differs (Lloyd 2018).
Photinus tanytoxus is easily confused with P. collustrans. However, slight morphological differences and nightly timing of courtship displays differentiate them from each other (Lloyd 1966a).

Photinus scintillans is difficult to distinguish from P. marginellus in the field, especially in the regions where their range overlaps (Faust 2017). These two species can be differentiated by discrete morphological characteristics and slightly different flash patterns (Green 1956, Lloyd 2018).

There is some debate about whether this species is conspecific with Photinus curtatus, as their ranges overlap, their courtship displays are almost identical, and there are only small differences in coloration and the morphology of their genitalia (Green 1956, Lloyd 1967). Furthermore, where they are sympatric, hybrid forms, with differing degrees of “genitalic intermediacy”, have been found (Lloyd 1967).

Photinus macdermotti is a member of the consanguineus group of Photinus, which contains several morphologically similar species distinguishable primarily by male flash pattern (Green 1956, Lloyd 1966a). P. consanguineus is most easily confused with P. macdermotti due to overlapping distributions, shared habitat preferences, and morphological similarities (Lloyd 1966a, Faust 2017). Photinus consanguineus and P. macdermotti can often be separated by morphological characteristics, but flash behavior (male pulse interval) is needed to positively identify some specimens (Lloyd 1966a). It is possible that new species remain to be described from this group.

There are no changes or doubts/debates over the validity of this species. Its aedeagal configuration (Green 1959) is anomalous and is the primary basis for its distinction from other species of the genus. Further support for its taxonomic stability comes from molecular studies of the genus (Usener and Cognato 2006).

Based on molecular analysis of mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I and luciferase DNA and morphological similarities, Microphotus fragilis Oliver 1912 and M. decarthrus Fall 1912 were recently synonymized under M. fragilis (Usener and Cognato 2006). However, based on differences in mating behaviour and ontophenology, as well as geographic and temporal allopatry (J. Cicero pers. comm. 2020), it is possible that M. decarthrus may regain species status again in the future.

This species was originally described as Lampyris reticulata (Say 1825). Some large specimens of Phausis reticulata archived in collections have been misidentified as the European species L. splendidula (Lloyd 2018). Phausis reticulata-like specimens from various localities throughout this species’ range suggest another undescribed species may occur; however, for now, these are considered P. reticulata (L. Faust pers. comm. 2020).

Le Conte considered Photinus obscurellus a variety, then a synonym of P. ardens, after he described them as separate species in 1852 (Lloyd 1969). After observing courtship flash behaviours, however, Lloyd (1969) asserted they are distinct species.
Photinus collustrans is easily confused with P. tanytoxus. However, slight morphological differences and nightly timing of courtship displays differentiate them from each other (Lloyd 1966a).

Photinus consanguineus is a member of the consanguineus group of Photinus, which contains several morphologically similar species distinguishable primarily by male flash pattern (Green 1956, Lloyd 1966a). P. consanguineus is most easily confused with P. macdermotti due to overlapping distributions, shared habitat preferences, and morphological similarities (Lloyd 1966a, Faust 2017). Photinus consanguineus and P. macdermotti can often be separated by morphological characteristics, but flash behaviour (male pulse interval) is needed to positively identify some specimens (Lloyd 1966a). It is possible that new species remain to be described from this group.

There is some debate about whether this species is conspecific with Photinus marginellus, as their ranges overlap, their courtship displays are almost identical, and there are only small differences in colouration and the morphology of their genitalia (Green 1956, Lloyd 1967). Furthermore, where they are sympatric, hybrid forms, with differing degrees of “genitalic intermediacy”, have been found (Lloyd 1967).

Photinus frosti has been collected very few times. The closely related species P. umbratus is sympatric with this species (Lloyd 1966). However, according to Green (1956), the punctuation on the pronutum of this species distinguishes it from all other Photinus, except P. punctulatus, which is found in the Midwest United States, unlike this species.
Photinus greeni is a member of the double-flashing Photinus consanguineus complex, distinguished from P. macdermotti and P. consanguineus primarily by differences in male flash pattern (Lloyd 1969).
Specimens from New Brunswick that were previously identified as Photinus ardens LeConte were recently redetermined to be P. ignitus Fall (Webster et al. 2016).

Zhang (2019) lists this species from China but judged from the photographs this is based on a mis-identification of some other species and the species is not considered to occur in China for assessment purposes.

According to Fraser (1933) Pseudagrion andamanicum is separated from the very widespread P. microcephalum (Rambur, 1842) only by details of the markings of the synthorax and abdominal segment 2. However these markings are variable in P. microcephalum and it is entirely possible that P. andamanicum is merely a junior synonym of that species. A detailed study of P. microcephalum and its allies is needed.

Somatochlora nepalensis was described from locations in Nepal (Asahina 1982) but Asahina himself noted that his species was very close to S. daviesi Lieftinck, 1977 (known from India and Bhutan) and that he had seen a specimen from Assam that appeared to be intermediate between the two. However the two have never been formerly synonymised, although Kalkman et al. (2020) consider them synonyms.

“The differences between D. ducatrix and D. kompieri are slight and based on a comparison of very few specimens. But at the same time the complete set of differences should enable identification, although the authors stress that it is important to collaborate their findings with DNA analysis in the future, when the extent of the populations is more clear and more specimens are available” Kompier (http://odonatavietnam.blogspot.com/search/label/Devadatta, post of Saturday 1st August 2015). Indeed D. kompieri is very likely to be merely a junior synonym of D. ducatrix which is variable in the characters used to differentiate it from D. kompieri, this is an issue in need of further study.

Indolestes davenporti has in the past been confused with Indolestes birmanus (Selys, 1891) and is often treated as a subspecies Indolestes gracilis davenporti of Indolestes gracilis (Hagen in Selys, 1862); see Kalkman et al. (2020).

Pornothemis serrata was described from a location in the Sukaranda area in North Sumatra (Krüger 1902), since then it has been recorded from many locations over a wide range in southeast Asia. However, it is now known (based on both morphological and molecular data) that (at least) three superficially very similar species are currently being treated under the same name. The type specimen of P. serrata is in a museum in Poland and until its accessory genitalia can be examined in detail it is not possible to know which of the three (possibly, although unlikely, it is not any of them) is the true P. serrata. All records are lumped together under the name serrata for assessment purposes, but only that of the type specimen is considered to certainly be serrata for assessment purposes until this taxonomic tangle is resolved.

Copera rubripes was described (in Platycnemis) from a single teneral (freshly emerged) female, see Hämäläinen (2003) who notes “Two other Copera [all these species are now placed in Pseudocopera] species are known from this area, C. annulata (Selys, 1863) … and C. tokyoensis Asahina, 1948 … Thus, P. rubripes may be conspecific with one of these two or (less likely) with C. ciliata (Selys, 1863), the range of which is known to reach northwards at least to Fujian and Taiwan”. It is likely that C. rubripes is indeed a junior synonym of a Pseudocopera species.
Megalestes palaceus is an inadequately described species that may well prove to be a junior synonym of some other Megalestes species.
The tribe Iolaini does not have subtribes.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.

Deloneura belongs in the tribe Pentilini not Liptenini. Subtribes are no longer used in the subfamily Poritiinae, so the name Durbaniina should be deleted. Deloneura is not divided into subgenera. The type locality of D. immaculata is "Bashee River, Kaffraria [Eastern Cape Province, South Africa]".
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
A genetic study is underway to determine how closely related the Nkandla subpopulation is to the central KwaZulu-Natal Midlands population.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
This species was sunk in the early 2000's and then reinstated a few years later in 2011.

Historical records from north of the Magaliesberg (Wonderboom and Nylsvley for example) are believed to represent Lepidochrysops vansoni and have been removed from the distribution data related to this species.

It is recommended that DNA comparisons are undertaken between samples of the four disjunct populations of this butterfly (southern Highveld grassland; eastern Mpumalanga; southern KZN and KZN Midlands).
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues regarding the taxonomy of this species. The relationship between Tsitana dicksoni and other members of the Tsitana genus should be researched.
The specimens from Eswatini are in the USA and were studied from photographs supplied. The assessment author is satisfied that they represent this species.

This species was described from a colony near Houtbosdorp, Limpopo. This colony is under severe threat and may be extinct. However, the taxonomic position of the populations to the south, currently assigned to Pseudonympha varii, needs to be revised.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
Several specimens found at from Elandshoogte near Nelspruit have extended the range of the taxon southwards, but more material needs to be studied from this locality to confirm the identification.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).

All records from the southern Cape for Cassionympha cassius will have to be re-examined, because many are likely to represent this new species. Until this is done, its distribution will remain unclear.

The taxonomic relationship between Chrysoritis aureus and a Chrysoritis entity that occurs near Morgenzon in Mpumalanga has been resolved as this entity is being described as a subspecies of C. aethon.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.

The taxonomy of this species needs to be reviewed. Several new populations have been found which may be referable to this taxon. There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of a number of Namaqualand populations which may or may not belong to this species (Henning et al. 2009).
There are no notable issues.

There are small morphological differences between the subpopulations on the West Coast and those on the South Coast, but not sufficient to justify distinction at subspecies level. Genetic comparisons are not possible because there are no extant subpopulations on the West Coast from which to obtain DNA samples for comparison.

Morphologically, Kedestes sarahae is similar to Kedestes barberae. 

The subspecies Kedestes barberae bonsa displays features transitional between K. b. barbarae and K. sarahae, and the latter may thus represent another subspecies of K. barberae.

It is recommended that DNA comparisons are undertaken to help resolve the relationship between these taxa.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
It has been hypothesised that Chrysoritis lyncurium is the most westerly form of a cline with adults becoming gradually paler until it becomes C. lycegenes in the east (Owen-Johnson 1991).
There are no notable issues.
Should be subtribe Polyommatina.

There is some uncertainty about the taxonomic status of subpopulations in the Bitterfontein-Garies area. Some authorities (see Pringle et al. 1994) contend that they are referable to Lepidochrysops bacchus while others regard them as belonging to L. penningtoni. Further research (including molecular genetics), is needed to clarify this.
There are no notable issues.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004). No taxonomic issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.

The Waterberg population of Erikssonia was formerly thought to represent Erikssonia acraeina. This population has subsequently been described as a new species, Erikssonia edgei, by Gardiner and Terblanche (2010).
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.

The genus is in need of revision. In the Eastern Cape at least, Crudaria wykehami and C. leroma appear to be distinct, with populations of leroma being found in the Fish River Valley, and those of wykehami on the higher ground on both sides overlooking this valley and beyond. They, therefore, overlap but without any evidence of intermingling so far (E.L. Pringle, pers. comm.). It has also been noted that, unlike leroma, the females of wykehami have a black tip to the abdomen (A. Heath pers. comm., Heath 1997). 

There is good evidence to suggest that the type locality of Fraserburg given for this taxon was erroneous, and that the original specimens were found in the Eastern Cape. There are, therefore, no proven records from the Northern Cape.

There are no notable issues. Abantis bicolor is a distinctive species that cannot easily be mistaken for other members of its genus. All subpopulations show some variation in the extent of the black upper side markings, and this variation appears to be consistent across subpopulations. Flight range is based on behaviour on sites where males are found on hilltops and females lower down on flowers; typically these sites are of the order of 1,000 m apart.
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
There are no notable issues.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004). No notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
Genus recently revised by Heath and Pringle (2004).
No notable issues, but the genus is in need of revision.

Previous records from Angola were presumed to be incorrect. However, T.B. Larsen has recently confirmed that this species does occur in that country (M.C. Williams, pers. comm.).

A research paper distinguishing two subspecies from the nominate subspecies has been submitted for publication. One of these subspecies comprises the population in Angola.
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
There are no notable issues.
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
Subtribe should be Polyommatina.
There are no notable issues.

A population discovered at Suikerbosrand has characteristics intermediate between Orachrysops mijburghi and Orachrysops lacrimosa (Terblanche and Edge 2007).

At a locality near Greylingstad, both above-mentioned species occur, although at different times of the year (Dobson pers. obs.).
There are no notable issues.
There are no notable issues.

Lepidochrysops littoralis is quite a variable species with populations at the limits of its range showing differences, e.g. Mossel Bay (Edge 2005). A future investigation may show some taxonomically significant infraspecific variation.

The species is possibly nothing but a variation of the common and widely distributed Dixeia doxo with which is has been recorded sympatrically. The pattern of lowland distribution of the species seems an unlikely one for an endemic species, with no obvious biogeographical or ecological rationale. However, A. Gardiner of the Harare branch of the Lepidopterist's Society of Africa (pers. comm. 2008) considers it should be maintained at species level.

Larsen (2011), in his assessment of this taxon in the IUCN Red List doubted the veracity of treating it as a species distinct from Dixeia doxo parva. This reservation is unfounded. The male genitalia of D. leucophanes are very different from those of D. doxo parva, and in wing characters of the male D. leucophanes differs as follows:
  • forewing apex more acute than in D. doxo parva;
  • ground colour bluish white with an opalescent sheen in very fresh specimens, more creamy white in D. doxo parva;
  • discocellulars of fore- and hindwing underside without a distinct black spot, except a faint one in some specimens (the main wing distinguishing characteristic used in the original description of D. leucophanes), D. doxo parva has distinct discocellular spots;
  • subcostal vein on hindwing upperside white in basal half, entirely black in D. doxo parva; 
  • forewing upperside costa pronounced and bluish grey in colour, less pronounced and black in D. doxo parva. 

The females exhibit similar but less obvious differences, the forewing apex being very acute and the dark markings generally more precise and smaller in D. leucophanes.
There are three known subspecies: lidderdalii, spinosa, and ocellatomaculata.

This species is part of the coon species group which was considered as part of the Atrophaneura by Hancock (1988); the group occurs from Assam and Hainan in the north to the Andaman Islands and Sumatra in the south (Hancock 1988). Other authorities elevate the subgenus Losaria to full genus level (Häuser et al. 2017).

There are eight subspecies reported for this species: the nominate subspecies coon, doubledayi (Wallace, 1865), cacharensis (Butler, 1885), sambilanga (Doherty, 1886), delianus (Fruhstorfer, 1895), palembanganus (Rothschild, 1896), patianus (Fruhstorfer, 1898), and insperatus (Joicey & Talbot, 1921).

This species was considered part of the coon species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs from Assam and Hainan in the north to the Andaman Islands and Sumatra in the south (Hancock 1988). However, since then the subgenus Losaria has been elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. GLoBIS), and we follow this treatment here.

The females of the species Papilio mayo are mimics of this species (Collins and Morris 1985).

This species was considered part of the genus Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). However, since then the subgenus Byasa has since been elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; LepIndex; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here. 

Three subspecies have been listed for this species: the nominate subspecies plutonius; subspecies tytleri (Evans); and subspecies pembertoni (Moore, 1902) (Collins and Morris 1985, Gupta and Mondal 2005, Racheli and Cotton 2010).

Subspecies pembertoni has been listed under B. alcinous in Nepal (Smith, 2010 and 1989).  Mention of Byasa plutonius plutonius has not been made in Nepal’s record till date. Smith (1989) mentioned that this species sometimes is misnamed as Byasa plutonius.

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). Subgenus Byasa has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here.

This species has six subspecies (Racheli and Cotton 2010): the nominate subspecies latreillei; subspecies afghana; subspecies kabrua (Tytler, 1915); subspecies ticona; subspecies genestieri (Oberthür, 1918); and subspecies robus (Jordan, 1928).

This species is part of the latreillei species group within the Byasa (Racheli and Cotton 2010), which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (referred to in Hancock 1988 under Atrophaneura). 

This species has five subspecies (Collins and Morris 1985, Kato and Yagi 2004, Racheli and Cotton 2010). These include: B. a. alcinous, B. a. yakushimana (Esaki and Umeno, 1929), B. a. loochooanus (Rothschild, 1896), A. a. miyakoensis (Omoto, 1960), and B. a. bradanus (Fruhstorfer, 1908). B. a. mansonensis (Fruhstorfer, 1901) is occasionally mentioned as a subspecies, but this entity was also listed as a subspecies of Byasa confusus, which was previously considered a subspecies of alcinous. There are some differences in the male genitalia and other morphological characters as well as molecular data which suggest that Byasa confusus should be treated as a separate species from Byasa alcinous (Wu and Bai 2001, Racheli and Cotton 2010). We follow this treatment here.

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). However, the subgenus Byasa has been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this treatment has been followed here.

There are five subspecies: B. d. dasarada, B. d. ravana (Moore, 1857),  B. d. barata (Rothschild, 1908), B. d. ouvrardi (Oberthur, 1920), and B. d. melanurus (Rothschild, 1905) (Racheli and Cotton 2010, Jan Moonen pers. comm. February 2019).
The subgenus Pachliopta has been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this treatment has been followed here.

This species was previously considered conspecific with P. jophon (Collins and Morris 1985), but was since elevated to species level. This species was considered part of the polydorus species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs in Indo-Australia (Hancock 1988).  However, the subgenus Pachliopta has also since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this here. The species is considered to be part of the liris species group, together with jophon, oreon and liris (Racheli and Cotton 2010).

Hancock (1988) considered the species under the genus Atrophaneura. The subgenus Pachliopta was elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this is followed here.

There are three known subspecies: the nominate subspecies varuna; subspecies astorion; and subspecies zaleucus. Subspecies zaleucus has in the past on occasion been considered a separate species (e.g. Collins and Morris 1985, Hancock 1988), but is here assessed as a subspecies of A. varuna following Racheli and Cotton (2010).

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). However, since then the subgenus Byasa has been elevated to full genus level by some authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; LepIndex; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here.

There is no taxonomic uncertainty with Zerene cesonia. It co-occurs with the California Dogface (Zerene eurydice) in certain parts of its range, but there are is no evidence of hybridization (Opler and Wright 1999).

Limenitis weidemeyerii hybridizes with Limenitis loruini in the narrow band where their distributions overlap, from east-central California to Idaho and western Montana (Opler and Wright 1999). However, due to limited gene flow through the hybrid zone, apparent hybrid inferiority, and slight genetic incompatibility, they are considered separate species (Boyd et al. 1999).
Schneider et al. (2018) regard the taxa Gomphus amseli and G. schneiderii transcaspicus as synonyms of G. schneiderii.
Dijkstra et al. (2015) confirmed that Lestinogomphus bivittatus is a junior synonym of Mastigogomphus chapini.

Anisogomphus solitaris and Heliogomphus ceylonicus have both been assessed before 2010 as Critically Endangered (Bedjanič 2006, 2009). According to Bedjanič and van der Poorten (2013) they both fall under synonymy of Anisogomphus ceylonicus (Hagen in Selys, 1878).

Three subspecies of Chlorogomphus nasutus are currently recognised. The nominate subspecies is known from China, Laos and Vietnam, C. n. satoi Asahina, 1995 is known from China and Vietnam and C. n. hamalaineni Karube, 2013 is only known from Vietnam.

Zhang (2019) treats this species as a junior synonym of Chlorogomphus suzukii (Oguma, 1926), however this synonymy, although quite possibly correct, has not been firmly established at the time of writing, so the two are treated as separate for assessment purposes.

Fraser (1934) regarded Cyclogomphus vesiculosus Selys, 1854 as “probably merely a small specimen of C. ypsilon” and Kalkman et al. (2020) consider it a junior synonym of C. ypsilon Selys, 1854; this view is followed for assessment purposes.

There is no information about the validity of this species. In 1863, Hagen wrote that he is not aware of the description of Agrion oedipus: "A. oedipus, Eichwald aus Derbend, von dem eine Beschreibung mir nicht bekannt ist; vielleicht mit einer der vorigen Arten identisch." (Hagen, H., 1863, Die Odonaten- und Nenropteren-Fauna Syriens und Klein-Asiens, Wiener Entomologische Monatschrift 7, pp. 193-199: 198).

Libellago indica was treated as a subspecies of L. lineata for many decades. Hämäläinen (2016) treated L. indica as a separate species, this view was followed by Subramanian et al. (2018) and Kalkman et al. (2020) and is followed here. Some records of L. lineata in the Indian literature actually refer to L. indica, but since both species occur in the country and their ranges may overlap, in some cases it is not possible to be sure which species is being referred to. Subramanian et al. (2018) only list L. indica from the Western Ghats, so here we have treated records of L. lineata from the Western Ghats as L. indica and assumed by default that all other records of L. lineata from India are actually that species unless they are given as of L. l. indica. Subramanian et al. (2018) list the species from Goa, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu and this is treated as the confirmed distribution here, records of L. indica or L. lineata indica from other states in India are treated as in need of confirmation for assessment purposes; this does not reflect any opinion by the assessor that these records are actually incorrect.

Van Tol and Günther (2018) excluded specimens from two locations from the type series of Rhinocypha flavipoda. One of these locations (“South Tomoni”) is not far from the locations where the type series was collected and was excluded on the basis of a small difference in colouration. A single specimen labelled from the Takala Mountains in South Sulawesi was also excluded, van Tol and Günther (2018) do not include this area in their summary of the distribution of this species and, although not explicitly stated, appear to regard the given location as mislabelling. Specimens excluded from the type series are treated as presence uncertain for assessment purposes and in particular, given their remoteness from the other known locations, the Takala Mountains do seem to be an unlikely location for this species.

Although van Tol & Günther (2018) did not exclude specimens from the Takala Mountains in South Sulawesi from the type series of Rhinocypha virgulata (in marked contrast to their exclusion of a single specimen of R. flavipoda van Tol & Günther, 2018, from the same location from the type series of that species, which has a similar distribution) it is clear from their other comments (e.g. “Probably restricted to streams running into or from Lake Poso or the Malili lakes”) that they consider the Takala Mountains location highly unlikely. Here we consider the Takala Mountains location as presence uncertain (but very unlikely) for this species, probably it is the result of mislabeling.

There appears to be a confused situation over whether Agriocnemis naia Fraser, 1923 or A. nana Laidlaw, 1914 or both (or neither) occurs in Peninsular Malaysia. Agriocnemis naia was described without location (Fraser 1923) but later it was revealed that the type series is from King Island (Kadan Kyun) in southern Myanmar (Fraser 1933), A. nana was described from further north in the same country, some authorities have considered them synonymous. The only other record stated with certainty to be A. naia is from Penang Island in Lieftinck (1954) who states “I have seen good series of both sexes from Penang I., which correspond in every respect with the existing descriptions.” Unfortunately a number of similar statements made by the same authority have proven to be incorrect so the statement about A. naia cannot be taken as conclusive (also see below). Wilson & Gibert (2005) list Agriocnemis cf naia from Endau Rompin National Park. The assessor is not aware of any other records referred even provisionally to A. naia. Orr (2005) only listed A. nana from Peninsular Malaysia and subsequent publications have followed this view. However the separation of these two species, which appear to be similarly coloured, may ultimately prove to rely on small structural details and the available illustrations of, for instance, the male anal appendages are of inadequate quality and detail. As-yet-unpublished DNA barcoding data of samples of from Peninsular Malaysia and of material identified as A. nana from Cambodia does not provide support to the notion that the two are the same. The view taken here, largely for convenience, is that only the type series from Myanmar can be regarded as certainly referring to A. naia at the present time. Study of the type material of both A. naia and A. nana as well as more recently collected material is needed to resolve these issues.
Ceriagrion chromothorax may be a junior synonym of the at least very similar C. calamineum, the latter species is not considered by Joshi & Sawant (2019) in the diagnosis of their species.

authority: Kompier & Yu in Ning, Kompier, Yu & Bu, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Karube (2012: 55) criticized the paper in which this species was described (Lohmann 1993), stating “Formerly, Lohmann (1993) revised Cordulegastridae and described some new species including Anotogaster. However his revisional work sadly gave us only poor knowledge, because He mistook the groupings of the species, due to too much depending on his own systematic viewpoints, mainly based on body and wing maculation, and also described two new species (A. xanthoptera and A. flaveola) based on only female holotypus, preserved in old collections of European museums. I think a full revisional study of this genus is required in the near future.” It is certainly possible that this species will eventually prove to be a junior synonym of some other.

Karube (2012: 55) criticised the paper in which this species was described (Lohmann 1993), stating “Formerly, Lohmann (1993) revised Cordulegastridae and described some new species including Anotogaster. However his revisional work sadly gave us only poor knowledge, because He mistook the groupings of the species, due to too much depending on his own systematic viewpoints, mainly based on body and wing maculation, and also described two new species (A. xanthoptera and A. flaveola) based on only female holotypus, preserved in old collections of European museums. I think a full revisional study of this genus is required in the near future.” It is certainly possible that this species will eventually prove to be a junior synonym of some other.

Karube (2012: 55) criticised the paper in which this species was described (Lohmann 1993), stating “Formerly, Lohmann (1993) revised Cordulegastridae and described some new species including Anotogaster. However his revisional work sadly gave us only poor knowledge, because He mistook the groupings of the species, due to too much depending on his own systematic viewpoints, mainly based on body and wing maculation, and also described two new species (A. xanthoptera and A. flaveola) based on only female holotypus, preserved in old collections of European museums. I think a full revisional study of this genus is required in the near future.” It is certainly possible that this species will eventually prove to be a junior synonym of some other.
Ictinogomphus alaquopterus apparently differs from I. rapax only in details of colouration and wing venation and is likely to be a junior synonym of that species.
Ictinogomphus pugnovittatus apparently differs from I. angulosus only in details of colouration and wing venation and is likely to be a junior synonym of that species.

Unfortunately it is now known that the female described as that of Sinogomphus mobydick by Kompier (2017) does not actually belong to that species. This means that the only definitely known specimen of the species is the holotype male.

Kosterin (2019) recently pointed out errors in the key to South Asian Lestes in Fraser (1933) that would likely lead to misidentification of other species as L. patricia. This means that recent records of the species from Pakistan (already considered as in need of confirmation) cannot be taken as certainly referring to L. patricia with re-identification of the material concerned.

Macromia whitei was described from “Bengale” (Selys 1871). Fraser (1936 and in earlier publications) lists Macromia whitei as a junior synonym of M. cingulata Rambur, 1842 and for this reason the species appears to have been ignored in all publications on Indian Odonata since Fraser’s time. However Fraser gives no reasons for listing M. whitei as a synonym of M. cingulata (although it is entirely plausible) and the name M. whitei has persisted in world Odonata catalogues.

Caconeura obscura was described in Indoneura, from a single male collected in the Eastern Ghats of India (Fraser 1933). Lahiri (1989) listed C. obscura as a species not recorded again after its initial description.

Calicnemia porcata is stated (Yu & Bu 2008) to be similar to C. miles from which it differs primarily in a small feature of the penis which may not actually be either consistently present (since only a single specimens is known this cannot be judged) or diagnostic. Taxonomic work is needed to determine if porcata is really a distinct species.

As noted in Phan et al. (2019) it is possible that P. ngoai is a junior synonym of P. robusta Fraser, 1933 which is known only from a single female collected in Laos and it also it might be a junior synonym of Protosticta taipokauensis Asahina & Dudgeon, 1987 (which could in turn be a junior synonym of P. robusta). Additionally some or all records of Protosticta grandis Asahina, 1985 from northern Vietnam may actually refer to this species.

Van Tol (2008) defined a “dark form” of Protosticta satoi Asahina, 1997. Later Kompier (2016a) considered this dark form as a separate species, P. nigra Kompier, 2016 but only provided a description and list of type material in Kompier (2016b).
Material from Vietnam identified as Protosticta khaosoidaoensis Asahina, 1984 by van Tol (2008) was shown to actually belong to Protosticta pseudocuriosa by Phan and Kompier (2016).

The original description was based on specimens from Banks Island, Torres Strait, Queensland (Tillyard 1913). Additional taxonomic information is provided by Houston and Watson (1988). Tony Watson has not been able to separated Isosticta handschini, thereafter Rhadinosticta handschini, from Rhadinosticta banksi (Houston and Watson 1988, Watson et al. 1991). Theischinger and Hawking (2006) considered R. handschini  a junior synonym of R. banksi.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.

Henning et al. (2009: 104) state that "... there is an undescribed coastal subspecies of this insect from the Northern Cape." A series of some 20 specimens recently captured by Williams and Garvie (October 2010) inland of Port Nolloth shows no obvious differences from topotypical material.
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).

This genus is in need of a taxonomic review. This species is very similar to Crudaria wykehami and doubtless often overlooked by non-specialists also because of its resemblance to the common Crudaria leroma (Pringle et al. 1994).
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Species group needs to be reviewed.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Species group in need of taxonomic revision.
Two distinct populations are currently allocated to this species. The northern population requires taxonomic review.
Taxonomic status with regard to the relationship to A. gowani and A. bamptoni to be investigated.
A similar taxon in south-east Botswana has been located (T.B. Larsen, pers. comm.); images of the adults show that the Botswana material is referable to L. rossouwi.
Northern and southern populations may represent distinct taxa. This possibility needs to be researched.
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004).
The genus is in need of revision.
Previously placed in Colotis Hübner, [1819]; Teracolus Swainson, [1833] was re-instated as a valid genus by Nazari et al. (2011).
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.
The genus is in need of revision.

There are populations intermediate with C. lyncurium in western KwaZulu-Natal (Owen-Johnston 1991), e.g. some localities such as at Bushman's Nek have intermediate forms and this may be a hybrid zone. A full DNA study of the various populations should help to clarify these relationships. Furthermore there is a population closest to C. lycegenes near Morgenzon in Mpumalanga that requires further investigation (Owen-Johnston 1991).
Taxonomic status of populations presumed to be referable to this species in the east and north-west parts of its range uncertain.
Heath & Pringle (2007) synonymised C. lycia with C. chrysaor, and recognised the Leipoldtville and Matjiesfontein populations as form lycia.

Genus recently revised by Heath & Pringle (2004). Thestor swanepoeli Pennington, 1971 was treated in Dickson & Kroon (1978) and Pringle et al. (1994) as a distinct species; the taxon was synonymized with T. rossouwi by Heath & Pringle (2004).

The type locality for Acisoma panorpoides ascalaphoides is Madagascar. It is not currently certain that the populations of Madagascar and mainland Africa are similar (K. Schütte in Dijkstra and Boudot 2010), so it is likely that the present subspecific name will have to change in the future for Africa.

This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Acisoma panorpoides ssp. ascalaphoides but it has now been promoted to Acisoma ascalaphoides.

Fraser (1927) described it as Agrionoptera insignis dorothea. Prasad and Varshney (1995) listed this subspecies of A. insignis as a separate species A. dorothea. Recently, in Mitra (2002) A. insignis dorothea has been listed as a synonym to A. insignis (Rambur, 1842). Agrionoptera dorothea has therefore been assessed as a separate species due to taxonomic ambiguity.

According to Soldati F. (pers. comm. 2016), Allecula suberina might be conspecific with Allecula semilivida Pic, 1891 (now considered junior synonym to Allecula morio (Fabricius, 1787). Research is ongoing to revise the status of Allecula semilivida - type material to be studied and status changes to be published when confirmed.

The genus Amietina Cambefort was only described in 1981 and now comprises four species (ScarabNet 2009). The relatively recent discovery of Amietina larrochei probably owes to its small-body size, forest distribution, and probable specialized habits.

There is a possibility that Amphicnemis amabilis is a junior synonym of A. bicolor (Martin, 1897), in which case the known range of A. bicolor will be considerably increased and reassessment of A. bicolor will be needed.

There is a possibility that Amphicnemis amabilis Lieftinck, 1940 is a junior synonym of A. bicolor, in which case the known range of A. bicolor will be considerably increased and re-assessment of A. bicolor will be needed.
Known only from the holotype.

Conniff et al. (2019) reviewed the taxonomic history of Anaciaeschna donaldi and concluded that A. donaldi is a junior synonym of A. martini. Additionally, the status of A. montivagans, once wrongly synonymised with A. martini, is now resurrected as a valid species (Conniff et al. 2019).

Anax rutherfordi was considered for a long time as a synonym to Anax speratus, which is widespread in eastern and southern Africa. Only recently this synonymy was remove (Dijkstra, Kipping, Mézière 2015)
Anthene fulvus has no recent synonyms. It was previously placed within the genus Neurellipes (T. Larsen pers. comm. 2009). There are no subspecies currently recognised.

This species consists of two subspecies, the nominate and ssp. littoralis. Subspecies littoralis is better known than the nominate subspecies, but is also thought to be much less common than the nominate subspecies.
This species was described from a single female. A male has never been found.
Two subspecies are known: Asiagomphus amamiensis amamiensis (Amami islands) and A. amamiensis okinawanus (Okinawajima island)(Ozono et al 2012).

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
This species was transferred by Wilson and Xu (2007) to the genus Atrocalopteryx.

This species has nine subspecies, distributed around the Philippines: subspecies semperi; subspecies albofasciata; subspecies aphthonia; subspecies baglantis; subspecies imogene; subspecies lizae; subspecies melanotus; subspecies sorgosona; subspecies supernotatus; and subspecies justini (Treadaway 1995, Page and Treadaway 2004).

This species were described by Needham (1930) with type locality is "Cheking", China. It is closely related to B. kirbyi Wilson & Reels (2001) from Hainan province, China, but it is can be easy separated to these two species by the wings in bidentata hyaline, dark wings tip in kirbyi. In addition, the nodus in kirbyi is located much closer to the wing center than is the case with bidentata; and inter alia, the inner, upper halves of the mid and hind femora are coloured creamy white, whereas the legs of kirbyi are entirely black.
This species contains two subspecies: B. i. ikelemba and B. i. kamituga.

The two subspecies B. p. phantasiella and B. phantasiella simulata have been proposed but simulata is highly likely to be another species. It has not been possible to examine this taxon, but a search for B. phantasiella revealed no material from east of Cameroon and so in all likelihood simulata pertains to another species.

The nominate subspecies of this butterfly was described from Ethiopia and Sudan. Two additional subspecies are recognized from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and Rwanda (ssp. extendens) and another from western Tanzania (ssp. similis).

The type series of Bornargiolestes fuscus comes from Gunung Mulu and Lambir Hills in Sarawak and Ulu Temburong National Park in Brunei; when Dow (2014) described the species, structurally similar female specimens from the upper Baram, Mount Dulit and the Lanjak Entimau Wildlife Sanctuary were included but excluded from the type series because of differences in colouration. It is possible that the females from the aforementioned locations belong to another species. For purposes of assessment only the populations from Gunung Mulu, Lambir Hills and Ulu Temburong are treated as certainly belonging to this species.

The female of Bornargiolestes nigra is not known, although it is conceivable, but unlikely, that females treated as B. fuscus Dow, 2014 but excluded from the type series of that species (Dow 2014) are really those of B. nigra; the reader is referred to the assessment of B. fuscus and Dow (2014) for further discussion of these females.

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). However, the subgenus Byasa has been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and this treatment has been followed here.

This species was previously considered part of the genus Atrophaneura (Hancock 1988). Subgenus Byasa has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this treatment here.

Racheli and Cotton (2010) list two subspecies, impediens and febanus. Subspecies Byasa impediens febanus is sometimes acknowledged as a separate species by some authors.

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). However, since then, the subgenus Byasa has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; LepIndex; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and we follow this here.
The taxonomic history of this species is summarised by Hämäläinen (2011), who raised it to full species status.

Calicnemis sudhaae species resembles C. pulverulans, but can be distinguished from the latter by small hind wing and black labium. Though the existence of this species was reported in 1994 (Mitra 1994), full description of the species was published in 2002 (Mitra 2002). This species needs to be re-examined, it may merely be a form of C. pulverulans.
The true taxonomic status of this species requires clarification.

C. paludivagus was originally described as a distinct species (Lucas, 1842), then (Lucas, 1846) regarded as “une varieté du C. cerdo”. Here we follow Sama (2008) who claimed it to be a distinct species, more similar to C. multiplicatus Motschulsky, 1860 than to C.scopolii, and not a variety of the latter or an aberration, or a subspecies.
Some females of this species are difficult to identify with full confidence, however, this is a valid species (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).

This butterfly has the nine subspecies Charaxes imperialis imperialis, C. imperialis albipuncta, C. imperialis dargei, C. imperialis graziellae, C. imperialis lisomboensis, C. imperialis nathaliae, C. imperialis pauliae, C. imperialis ugandicus and C. imperialis werneri.
Confused with C. consueta of southern Africa; taxonomy is discussed by Dijkstra (2003).
Karube (2002) transferred this species to Chloropetalia Carle, 1995.

Coeliccia kazukoae was previously known under two different names (Kosterin, 2011; Kosterin and Kompier 2017) and at the same time two different species were implied under this name (Kosterin and Kompier 2017). The simultaneously described Coeliccia kazukoae Asahina, 1984 and Coeliccia megumii Asahina, 1984 (Asahina 1984) are synonyms (immature and mature individuals, respectively); of these names C. kazukoae was chosen as valid by the first reviser at synonymisation (Kosterin 2011). The specimen reported as C. kazukoae from the southern Vietnam, Gia Lai Province, K’bang, Ka Nak by Steinhoff and Do (2013) and, most probably, as “C. megumii (kazukoae)” from Sekong, Attapu and Champasak Provinces in the southern Laos by Yokoi and Souphanthong (2014) in fact represented a later described closely related species Coeliccia rolandorum Kosterin and Kompier 2017, which ranges in the Annamense Mountains in the eastern Cambodia and the southern Vietnam and Laos (Kosterin and Kompier 2017). Neither of the two species, separated by the vast Cambodian Lowland, are still known from the Dangrek Mountais (the southern escarpment of the Korat Plateau) at the border of Thailand and Cambodia, where either or both could be potentially present (or not) and specimens from where would be important to clarify taxonomical relations of these species.
A subspecies, Coeliccia scutellum hainanense Laidlaw, 1932 was recognised for this species, but was split off as a separate species by Steinhoff and Uhl (2015).

Described by Brauer (1878) the type locality for nominate Cratilla lineata lineata is Malacca, Sumatra. Förster (1903) described Cratilla calverti from Malabar, India but Fraser (1936) considered this taxon to be just a late stage maturation colour form. Lieftinck (1953) recognised calverti as a subspecies of lineata. Davies and Tobin (1985) treated the nominate from to be restricted to East Asia whereas the range of C. l. calverti includes India and Indo-China. The subspecies Cratilla lineata assidua Lieftinck 1953 was described from Java and this subspecies ranges from Bali and Java to the Philippines.
This species was previously misidentified as Cupidesthes lithas. It was redescribed with the present name in Larsen (2005).
The female of the species is not known.

The genus Diastellopalpus Lansberge, 1886 is restricted to intertropical parts of the Afrotropical region and currently comprises 32 described species (Josso and Prévost 2000), most of which show montane or rainforest distributions (Davis and Scholtz 2010). D. thomsoni is considered to be represented by two subspecies, D. thomsoni thomsoni (Bates, 1888) and D. thomsoni malawiensis Josso & Prévost, 2000.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

Genus Disparocypha is currently considered as monotypic. But in fact there are obvious differences in colouration and size of specimens between different populations (e.g. Günther 2006). An urgently needed revision is likely to lead to the description of new taxa.

The relationships between Dysphaea dimidiata from Java (from where it was described), from Borneo and from the rest of its range “are not entirely clear” Hämäläinen et al. (2015:484), the reader is referred to the discussion in that publication. However any differences between these populations are not likely to warrant more than subspecific status for the non-Javan populations, and all populations are included in the assessment as D. dimidiata. However populations from north of Songkhla and Trang provinces of Thailand have been separated as a distinct species D. vanida.
Elattoneura tsiamae was previously considered a synonym of Elattoneura vrijdaghi and only recently regained full species status (Dijkstra & Clausnitzer, 2014).
The species was described in the subgenus Entoxylon (Merkl 2008).
The species was described as Euphaea decorata Hagen in Selys, 1853 but is placed by some authors in Anisophaea rather than in Euphaea; the validity of the Anisophaea as a genus is unresolved.
The female of this species is undescribed.
Euphaea pahyapi was recently (Phan et al. 2018) recorded from Cambodia and Viet Nam, however these records are incorrect (Matti Hämäläinen pers. comm. 2018) and are not considered in the assessment.
This species is split into the four subspecies E. losinga losinga, E. losinga wardi, E. losinga limita and E. losinga knoopi. These subspecies do not differ much from each other.
This butterfly has the two subspecies E. s. splendens and E. splendens ghanaensis.

The genus Genieridium (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) was described and revised by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). It presents seven species that are distributed throughout Colombia, Venezuela, non-Amazonian Brazil, eastern Bolivia, Paraguay, and northeastern Argentina. All species that compose the genus were originally described in Pedaridium.
Initially described as Parablops aetnensis.
A subspecies, G. a. audax Lieftinck, 1948 is recognised from south Sumatra.

There are two distinct populations of G. dravida (one in the Western Ghats, and one in eastern and northeastern India), and it may be that these are separate subspecies or even species. More research is needed to confirm this. Prior to 1960 it was treated as Gynacantha hyalina. Fraser (1936) notes that it is very difficult to separate from G. subinterupta; the relationship of these two taxa should be re-examined.
Heliaeschna crassa is very similar to H. idae (Brauer, 1865), and may ultimately prove to be a junior synonym of that species.
Heliaeschna beesoni (Fraser, 1922) is variously treated as a junior synonym or as a subspecies of H. uninervula. It is treated as a synonym here.

Originally described by Ris (1912) under the genus Leptogomphus Selys, 1878 the type-locality for Heliogomphus retroflexus is Tonkin, northern Vietnam. Laidlaw (1930) transferred the species to Heliogomphus Laidlaw 1922. Asahina (1977) described the larvae collected by Mr Matsuki from Taiwan, which was the first larval representative described from the Heliogomphus genus.
Dijkstra (2007) reviewed the taxonomy of this species and showed that records from Africa in fact refer to distinct species.
There is some uncertainty regarding the distinction between Hobbseus petilus and Hobbseus prominens (S. Adams pers. comm).

The species was first definitively raised to species rank by Larsen (1997) and until then had been under-reported. Until 1997, six valid species were subsumed under one or two names (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).

Ris (1912) recorded Idionyx optata Selys from Tas-Yiu-San, Guangdong, China, but Fraser (1926) described Idionyx carinata from the same Tas-Yiu-San specimens. Zhou (1984) described Idionyx lieftincki from Zhejiang, China but Asahina (1987) treated this species as a junior synonym of I. carinata. Schorr et al. (2009) listed I. lieftincki as a junior synonym of I. carinata.

Idionyx selysi is sometimes considered to be a junior synonym of I. yolanda Selys, 1871, but is clearly distinct from that species (for instance see Lieftinck 1960 pages 254-256). A species very similar to, and possibly identical to, I. selysi occurs in Sarawak (e.g. Dow and Reels 2008, 2010) and probably other parts of Borneo. As the status of the Sarawak species is unresolved, it is considered as distinct from I. selysi for the purposes of this assessment.

Indocypha svenhedini Sjöstedt, 1932 is sometimes considered to be a junior synonym of I. vittata. However svenhedini is actually not a synonym of vittata (M. Hämäläinen pers. comm.) and is not considered as one in this assessment.

Originally described under the genus Onychogomphus Sélys 1854. Fraser (1922) originally established the genus Lamelligomphus. Following Carle (1986), Chao transferred many Chinese species, previously considered belonging to Onychogomphus, to Lamelligomphus.

Females from Gunung Penrissen and the Matang Range in south-western Sarawak exhibit some morphological differences from typical L. williamsoni; males have not yet been collected west of the Lupar River in Sarawak. Dow et al. 2017 treated the south-western form as L. species cf williamsoni and noted that may it represent a distinct species.

The genus Liatongus Reitter 1893 shows a wide disjunct distribution in the Afrotropical, Oriental, eastern Palaeartic and western Nearctic regions. In the Afrotropical region, it is currently represented by fifteen valid species (ScarabNet 2009).

This species was considered part of the coon species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs from Assam and Hainan in the north to the Andaman Islands and Sumatra in the south (Hancock 1988). However, the species has been regarded within a separate genus, Balignina, by a number of authors (e.g. Page and Treadaway 2004). This, in turn, is considered a junior synonym of Losaria by some (e.g. LepIndex; Cotton et al. 2005). However, it is thought to be distinct in the structure of the antennae, wings and genitalia of both sexes (Page and Treadaway 2004). We retain the name Losaria in this assessment until further evidence.

This species has a number of subspecies: L. n. neptunus, L. n. doris, L. n. padanganus, L. n. creber, L. n. dacasini, L. n. siborangitana, and  L. n. matbai. Cotton et al. (2005) describe another subspecies, L. n. manasukkitti, found alongside L. n. neptunus in Thailand. The subspecies are all distributed around different regions of Malaysia, Burma, Sumatra and the Philippines. L. n. fehri, L. n. sumatrana are generally considered varieties rather than subspecies (Cotton et al. 2005).

Macromia clio Ris, 1916 was described from a single female collected from Taiwan and Macromia hamifera was described by Lieftinck (1955) from a single male collected from Fujian. When Wilson (1998) described the first female M. hamifera from Guangxi it became apparent that M. hamifera and M. clio might be conspecific. Wilson and Reels (2001) subsequently synonymised the two species when it was discovered from examination of specimens from mainland China and Taiwan that both shared a tiny nipple-like protuberance at the anterior part of the dividing groove on the dorsum of the frons. Matsuki and Lien (1982) described the larvae and its habitats. Wilson and Reels (2001) also stated they considered Macromia macula Zhou et al., 1994, described from Zhejiang Province was likely to be a synonym.

Two taxa, M.  erratica Lieftinck, 1948 and M. shanensis Fraser, 1927, are variously treated as subspecies or synonyms of M. genialis. M. erratica at least differs consistently from M. genialis in colouration, and probably deserves at least subspecific status. For the purposes of this assessment both are treated as subspecies.

In older literature as Anacordulia tillyardi. Anacordulia stuberi Lieftinck, 1938 and Anacordulia maccullochi Tillyard, 1926 are normally considered to be junior synonyms of Metaphya tillyardi, following Lieftinck (1961). However M. stuberi is still listed as a separate species in the World Odonata List on 15 April 2015 (Schorr and Paulson 2015). For assessment purposes M. stuberi is treated as a synonym of M. tillyardi.

A subspecies, Microgomphus chelifer thelyphonus Lieftinck, 1929 is known from Java, but some specimens from Thailand and Malaysia have been identified as this subspecies in the Japanese literature (e.g. Asahina 1990, Kitagawa 1997). As most records are of females, often freshly emerged, or of larvae, which are extremely difficult to identify to species, considerable doubt must remain over what species or subspecies is really referred to in many records. As pointed out in Hämäläinen and Pinratana (1999, note 28), the chelifer-group of species is in need of revision.
The original concept of the species was recently split into three distinct species by Libert (2000) during a genus revision.
This species is split into the two subspecies Myrina sharpei sharpei and M. sharpei fontainei.
This butterfly has the two subspecies N. fulgurata fulgurata and N. fulgurata platyptera.
The genus Nesocordulia needs revision.
The genus Nesolestes needs revision.
The genus Nesolestes needs revision.
This species known from the type male only. The genus Nesolestes needs revision.
The genus Nesolestes needs revision.

As there are no differences between this species and O. rammei, the latter represents a junior synonym of O. fallax and synonymization of both taxa is necessary (J. Skejo pers. comm. 2015). There are differences in the altitudinal and habitat preferences (at 1,600-1,750 m altitude in Velebit Mountain and down to 200 m in the northern part of its distribution) of some subpopulations of O. fallax. Although the slight morphological differences suggest a possible taxonomic subdivision (G. Szovenyi pers. comm. 2015), they actually seem to highlight the high morphological variability of the species.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastern Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.

The genus Ontherus was revised by Génier (1996). Its consists approximately of 60 species that are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in southeastern Brazil and the Andes (Génier 1996). The species that compose the genus are divided into three subgenera: Caelontherus, Planontherus and Ontherus.
A subspecies, Onychothemis culminicola celebensis Ris, 1912 is known from Sulawesi.

Individuals of this species from drainages near the known range may represent undocumented variation within this species or a new species.  For example, no Orconectes (Hespericambarus) spp. have a described range including the Pearl River drainage, so the one female O. (Hespericambarus) sp. collected in that drainage cannot be definitively identified (S. Adams, pers. comm. 2009).
This butterfly consists of the two subspecies O. faunus faunus and O. faunus camerunica.
This species is part of the phlegon pecies group within the Pachliopta (Racheli and Cotton 2010). It had previously been listed as in the polydorus group of Atrophaneura by Hancock (1988).

This species was previously thought to be synonymous with Atrophaneura phegeus, for example in Collins and Morris (1985). However, phegeus was found to be invalid by Kocak (1983) and substituted the name buraki. However, leytensis takes precendence, with buraki a synonym of leytensis (Treadaway 1995).Since then the subgenus Pachliopta has since been elevated to full genus level by many authorities (e.g. GLoBIS; Treadaway 1995), and we follow this here.
This butterfly has the three subspecies P. violinitens violinitens, P. violinitens coniger and P. violinitens bwamba.
There are two recognised subspecies: P. g. gundlachianus (Felder and Felder 1864) and P. g. alayoi (Hernández et al. 1995).

The status of this species and its relationship with Canariola nubigena needs to be studied. Both species are flightless, but overlapping ranges have been documented. Canariola willemsei has even been documented from two islands (La Gomera and Tenerife).
This species needs to be taxonomically studied due to uncertainty of its relationships with Pholidoptera rhodopensis and the possible synonymy of both taxa.

Records from Peninsular Malaysia seem closer to Phyllothemis raymondi Lieftinck, 1950 (Orr 2005), otherwise known from Sumatra, than to P. eltoni.

However P. raymondi is very similar to P. eltoni, and is likely to be a junior synonym of eltoni. For this assessment records from Peninsular Malaysia are treated as raymondi.
Two subspecies are known: Planaeschna milnei milnei (Mainland Japan) and Planaeschna milnei naica (Amami islands)(Ozono et al 2012).
The subspecies pallidus is known only from Marojejy National Park, but is now tentatively treated as a good species (pers. comm. K.-D.B. Dijkstra).
Rhyothemis fulgens has been confused with R. pygmaea, with all records of the later from west of the Wallace line actually referring to R. fulgens (see Dow et al. 2015).
The great morphological variation and genetic similarity (Kaya et al. 2012, D. Chobanov pers. comm. 2015) suggest close relationships between P. tauricus and P. pliginskii.

authority: Schurian, van Oorschot & Van den Brink, 1992
taxonomicNotes:
This species was first described in 1992 from four Turkish provinces (Konya, Adana, Kahramanmaras and Gaziantep). Then in 1994 Frédéric Carbonell described a new subspecies, P. (A.) theresiae larseni from Lebanon.

In 1999, a thorough review by Olivier et al. of all the theresiae specimens had the following outcomes:
-  Genetic study established that P. t. larseni should be elevated to a full species. P. theresiae was thus restored to being a Turkish endemic.
-  The specimens which had been used to establish the karyotype and chromosome number for theresiae came from Konya whilst the type specimens came from Adana. However, the Adana specimens were found to have a different chromosome number. It was thus decided to describe the Konya population as a new species: P. guezelmavi.
-  The specimens from Kahramanmaras and Gaziantep were identified to be Polyommatus poseidon.
 
 It was thus established that theresiae is an endemic species known only from the type locality in Adana.
This species was previously placed in the genus Platycnemis but it has now been moved to Proplatycnemis.
The genus Protolestes needs revision.
The genus Protolestes needs revision.
The female of the species is not known.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Pseudagrion isidromorai was, for some time, considered a synonym to P. glaucoideum. It regained full species status by Dijkstra and Clausnitzer (2014)
Madagascan species of the genus Pseudagrion need revison.
Some have considered that Pseudagrion coomansi Lieftinck, 1987 from Borneo is a junior synonym, but this is unsubstantiated and probably based on the misleading description of that species.
The species have been compared by Carlton and Leschen (2009) with all other Pseudotriphyllus already described. Those authors confirmed the species status.
The species is very close to P. globulicollis and its status (valid species or subspecies of P. globulicollis) is unclear, pending molecular data (Rapuzzi and Sama 2013).

Rhinagrion viridatum Fraser, 1938 was incorrectly placed in the synonymy of R. mima by Lieftinck (1954), this error has been corrected by Kalkman and Villanueva (2011); R. mima and R. viridatum are treated as distinct species in this assessment. Because of the disjoint distribution of R. mima Kalkman and Villanueva (2011) also raise the possibility that “that R. mima is not monophyletic and that it should be divided into two species”, one on Sumatra, the other in mainland Asia, this is a subject of ongoing investigation.

Rhinagrion viridatum Fraser, 1938 has been treated as a junior synonym of R. mima, but Kalkman and Villaneuva (2011) have shown convincingly that it is a separate species; accordingly it is assessed separately.

The taxonomic history of this species, and confusion over the female are discussed in detail in Hämäläinen (2009). However females stated to be of this species in Hämäläinen (2009), from Mount Kinabalu, where the altitude of collection is known, are from higher altitudes than have been recorded for the male (the species was described from somewhere on Mount Kinabalu, but the exact type locality and its altitude are not known) and might not actually belong to R. stygia.
Two species of Rhinoneura are known, both apparently confined to high altitudes in north Borneo.

There are old records of this species which are now thought to be related to R.ungaricus. According to Sama (2002) the whole genus is problematic from a nomenclatural point of view since all type specimens are lost. A taxonomic revision is necessary.
Family Synthemistidae is sometimes treated as a subfamily of Corduliidae.
The genus Tatocnemis needs revision.
The genus Tatocnemis needs revision.
A revision of the Teinobasis of Sulawesi and the Moluccas is needed, and might result in changes to the identification of some populations listed as T. helvola in the assessment.

A small series of specimens from a location high on Mount Dulit were treated as Telosticta dayak in Dow and Orr (2012) but excluded from the type series because of some differences, principally in markings and size. However it appears increasingly likely that this population does not belong to T. dayak, and it is not considered to belong to T. dayak for assessment purposes.

A population from Mount Dulit in Sarawak listed under Telosticta dayak Dow & Orr, 2012 in Dow & Orr (2012), but excluded from the type series of that species, might actually be closer to T. kajang, although it is also possible that it represents a third species. Because of the uncertainty surrounding the Mount Dulit taxon it is not considered further for assessment purposes.
The female of Telosticta tubau is not known,

The female of Telosticta ulubaram has not been described. A female possibly belonging to this species has been collected in Pulong Tau National Park in Sarawak (Dow unpublished), but because the association is not definite, this record is not considered in the assessment.

There is uncertainty about the validity of some of the specimens recorded under the name Triplax cyanescens due to confusion with Triplax melanocephala Lacordaire, considered a synonym erroneously (Benoît pers. comm. 2016). At present, only its presence in Algeria and Portugal can be verified under this name.
Triplax peyerimhoffi is a synonym of T. lacordairii
Following D'Abrera (1975), most authors consider Trogonoptera trojana to be a distinct species, but Igarashi (1979) regards it as a subspecies of T. brookiana.

Five subspecies are known: the nominate subspecies T. a. aeacus (C. & R. Felder, 1860), T. a. kaguya Nakahara & Esaki, 1930, also referred to as T. a. formosanus Rothschild, 1899 (occurring in Taiwan), T. a. malaiianus Fruhstorfer, 1902 (occurring in the southern Malay Peninsula) , T. a. insularis Ney, 1905 (occurring in northeastern Sumatra) and T. a. szechwanus Okano & Okano, 1983 (occurring in China).

Note, for the birdwing butterflies, genera Ornithoptera, Trogonoptera and Troides, specific and subspecific status follows D'Abrera. Subsequent revisions have been referenced but only totally new taxa have been added. Subspecies are listed where possible as they may occasionally be listed as full species. For this species, three subspecies are recognised; two were recognised in the previous assessment by Collins and Morris (1985): the nominate subspecies andromache, subspecies marapokensis Fruhstorfer, 1899, and subspecies nishikawai Kobayashi, 1992. Ohya (2001) does not recognise marapokensis as a subspecies.
Some authorities consider this to be a subspecies of Troides rhadamantus (see LepIndex; Ohya 2001; UNEP-WCMC 2012).
This upland species has no recent synonyms or any  recognised subspecies.
Erikssonia acreaina has been split into E. acraeina and E. edgei (Gardiner and Terblanche 2010).

Martin (1908) states “N'existe, à notre connaissance, dans aucune collection. L'exempilaire décrit par Fabricius sonible perdu et l'espèce est douteuse [To our knowledge, does not exist in any collection. The example described by Fabricius is lost and the species is doubtful.]” Nothing can be added to this except the species is indeed doubtful but in the absence of any type specimen it may never be possible to know for certain what it actually is.
Solomonargiolestes bougainville was described as an Argiolestes and transferred to their newly erected genus Solomonargiolestes by Kalkman and Theischinger (2013).
Agriocnemis luteola is likely to be a synonym of some other species of Agriocnemis or, maybe more likely judging from the sketch of the anal appendages in Navás (1936), a Mortonagrion species.

Agriocnemis materna was described from an unspecified location in Sumatra (Selys 1877); it was noted to be similar to A. incisa Selys, 1877, itself a junior synonym of A. femina Brauer, 1868, but to be larger and to differ in some other details. The species was recorded from Sumatra again by Karsch (1891) and Krüger (1898) but after these publications it appears to have been implicitly considered to be a junior synonym of A. femina. However, the assessor is not aware that any formal declaration of A. materna as a junior synonym of A femina has ever been made or that a justification for such a decision has ever been presented (although it is entirely possible) and the name has persisted on some lists of Odonata species. Hämäläinen (personal communication 2019) reports finding not only A. femina in Sumatra in 1997 but also specimens conforming to, and identified as, A. materna. The issue of the relationship of A. materna to A. femina cannot be regarded as settled and requires further investigation, the two are treated as separate species here, pending a resolution of this issue.

Although Pericnemis bisaya is known from Cebu, Mindanao, Negros and Panay in the Philippines, Villanueva & Dow (2020) expressed some doubts over whether populations from outside of Cebu really represent the same species. However all populations are treated as a single species for assessment purposes.

Although Pericnemis yakal is known from Samar and Leyte as well as Mindanao, Villanueva and Dow (2020) expressed some doubts over whether populations from outside of Mindanao really represent the same species. However, all populations are treated as a single species for assessment purposes.
Both the general appearance and the structure of the anal appendages of Pseudagrion schieli suggest that it might be better placed in Archibasis.
Neallogaster choui is considered likely to be a synonym of Cordulegaster jinensis Zhu & Han, 1992 by van Pelt (1996).
Anormogomphus exilocorpus appears to differ from A. kiritschenkoi Bartenef, 1913 mainly in size and details of colouration and may prove to be a junior synonym of that species.

Perissogomphus asahinai is similar to the Himalayan species Perissogomphus stevensi Laidlaw, 1922 from which it appears to differ only in details of its markings that could merely represent variation.

Epophthalmia kuani is doubtfully distinct from Epophthalmia elegans Selys. The anal appendages as illustrated in the original description (Jiang 1998) appear to be within the variation occurring in E. elegans and other characters stated to be diagnostic are either insignificant or appear to be the result of confusion (e.g. the statement that the penis bears three long flagellae when the illustration only shows a very typical penis for the genus with only two long flagellae).

Bott (1955) treated this species as Potamonautes (Potamonautes) depressus depressus. Gouws and Stewart (2001) treated it as Potamonautes depressus depressus and described its distribution and habitat. Cumberlidge and Tavares (2006) argued that this species should properly be referred to as Potamonautes depressus.
This species was described by Daniels, Stewart and Gibbons (1998) who provided details of its distribution and habitat.
Potamonautes tuerkayi has been diagnosed primarily based on genetic evidence with an overall morphology that is congruent with that of Potamonautes parvicorpus.
Following genetic and morphological work, part of what was formerly included under this name has now been split off as Potamonautes tuerkayi (Wood and Daniels 2016).
There is considerable variation across the range of this species; this variation needs to be re-examined, at present a subspecies, Agriocnemis femina oryzae is recognised from parts of the range.

No other specimen than the female holotype is known of this species. The species belongs in the hydroporoides species group of Copelatus, but two other Malagasy species placed in this group have turned out to be misidentified Madaglymbus or Exocelina, but the type locality data is fairly exact, suggesting against misidentification (Ranarilalatiana et al. 2019). It is much smaller than C. peridinus but may be closely related.

Régimbart (1895) described this species as Copelatus duodecimstriatus Aubé from Madagascar but later realised it was not conspecific with Aubé’s C. duodecimstriatus from the Mascarene islands. It was therefore renamed C. distinguendus.
Copelatus marginipennis (Laporte 1835) was previously treated as a junior synonym of C. pulchellus Klug, 1834 since Aubé (1838).
This species is very similar in appearance to C. amphibius (Ranarilalatiana and Bergsten 2019).
Two subspecies are recognised: the nominate subspecies and Capys alpheus ssp. extentus.

Morgan (1997) named Euastacus dharawalus after the Dharawal aboriginal language, but did not designate an official common name. However, he did refer to specimens of Riek’s crayfish in the Australian Museum collection as Fitzroy Falls Crayfish. The common name Fitzroy Falls Crayfish has been used ever since. There are no recent taxonomic changes or doubts as to the species validity.

Warren (1912) suggested this species may be a form of Agrotis lucicolens, which was subsequently synonymized with A. photophila, but Zimmerman (1958) disagrees with this assertion. It is therefore treated as a separate species.
