This species was listed as a synonym of Agrotis cremata by Warren (1912), but Zimmermann (1958) does not agree with that assessment.
The Global Lepidoptera Names Index (LepIndex 2018) gives the spelling as Agrotis epicremma. As per the original description, this is an error, and the spelling should be Agrotis epicremna.

Zimmerman (1958) suggests this species could be synonymous with Agrotis mesotoxa. Additional specimens are needed to be sure, as only the female form of A. mesotoxa and male form of A. giffardi are known.

Due to variable colouration in the adult form, Agrotis hephaestaea was described multiple times, under the synonyms Euoxoa diplosticta and Euxoa wikstroemiae (Swezey 1944). Swezey (1944) synonymized these three species and Zimmerman (1958) accepted this change. Some sources still address Agrotis diplosticta (Euoxoa diplosticta) as a species, but it is unclear why synonymy is not recognized (SCAN 2020, J. Boone pers. comm. 2020, Nishida 2002). This assessment considers the two former species as synonyms of Agrotis hephaestaea.

Zimmerman (1958) suggests this species could be synonymous with Agrotis giffardi. Additional specimens are needed to be sure, as only the female form of A. mesotoxa and male form of A. giffardi are known.

Zimmerman (1958) synonomized the paler Maui form of this species, which was described as Agrotis spoderopa Meyrick,1899, under Agrotis tephrias, due to the similarities in the pattern on the forewings.
Kim (1998) created the new genus, Chejuanomala, to hold this species; however, Zorn (2004) placed Chejuanomala into synonymy with genus Anomala.

There are subspecies of this species on the Australian mainland and Tasmania: the nominate subspecies macleayanum; subspecies moggana Couchman, 1965; and subspecies wilsoni Couchman, 1965 (e.g. in Common and Waterhouse 1981) but treated by some sources as a synonym of the nominate subspecies (see of Living Australia 2021). A fourth subspecies, subspecies insulanum (Waterhouse, 1920), has been described from Lord Howe and Norfolk Islands (Common and Waterhouse 1972).
‘Zirafy’ means ‘giraffe’ in Malagasy (Wood and Scharff 2018).

Cheilosia candida Vujić et Radenković, 2020 is a member of the subgenus Convocheila Barkalov, and endemic to Europe. The species was described based on a single male specimen. Radenković et al. (2020) provide images of the male, including the male genitalia, and an identification key to separate the species from all other members of subgenus Convocheila. The species is morphologically similar to C. paralobi Malski, and distinguishing characters are provided in Radenković et al. (2020).

Orr and Hämäläinen (2007: 66) note that two forms of this species exist, differing in size, and that "Further field studies are required to clarify the biological status of these two possibly seasonal forms."

Somatochlora lingyinensis was described from a single female from a location in Zhejiang, China (Zhou and Wei 1979) and might eventually prove to be a junior synonym of some other Somatochlora species.

Zhang (2019: 944) notes that the two species of Epiophlebia known from China are “very porly known and not taxonomically well supported” and that “E. sinensis is known only by the first author of the species and unavailable for examination by other workers, a circumstance which makes the status of this claimed species very much open to question.” Li et al. (2011) give only details of the colouration of the male abdomen as characters to differentiate their species from the Japanese E. superstes (Selys, 1889) and it is certainly possible that E. sinensis will ultimately prove to be merely a form of E. superstes.

Chao (1990) treated Davidius miaotaiziensis as a junior synonym of D. chaoi Cao & Zheng, 1988, as did Zhang (2019). However Chao’s opinion does not appear to have been widely accepted (or perhaps simply went unnoticed) and the name D. miaotaiziensis has persisted in lists of the world’s Odonata.

Chao (1990) treated Davidius qinlingensis as a junior synonym of D. davidi shaanxiensis Zhu, Yan & Li, 1988, as did Zhang (2019). However Chao’s opinion does not appear to have been widely accepted (or perhaps simply went unnoticed) and the name D. miaotaiziensis has persisted in lists of the world’s Odonata.

Zhang (2019) treats Nihonogomphus lieftincki as a junior synonym of N. thomassoni (Kirby, 1900) without giving a justification for this decision; although this may be correct it has not been satisfactorily established and the two taxa are treated as separate species for assessment purposes.

Sinogomphus peleus is known from eastern China. Kompier (2017) described S. p. fuscatus from a male and a female from a single location in central Vietnam. The main difference given by Kompier (2017) between the two subspecies is in the markings of the synthorax but he also notes a difference (possibly more significant) in the inferior anal appendages of the male and from the photographs provided there may be additional differences in the accessory genitalia. It is possible that S. p. fuscatus will eventually be raised to species rank, but it treated as a subspecies of S. peleus for assessment purposes at this time.

Indolestes extraneus has been considered to be a junior synonym of I. peregrinus (for instance by Wilson & Xu 2007, Zhang 2019) which is likely to be correct but this synonymy does not appear to have been formally established at the time of writing and the name persists in the literature.
Laccophilus transversovittatus is closely related to L. laeticulus and L. occidentalis (Biström et al. 2015).

Bayadera hyalina was described from the Khasia Hills in Meghalaya, India and although the species has since been recorded from a much wider range, doubts persist over whether or not the species found outside of the Khasia Hills is really B. hyalina (for instance see Phan et al. 2018). However all records are treated as B. hyalina for assessment purposes for the time being.
For the purposes of this assessment, Trachelophorus giraffa is considered the accepted species name (Alonso-Zarazaga and Lyal 2020).

Gonzalez-Soriano (2020) suggests that this species might have been confounded with Micrathyria laevigata. However, he suggests that further research is needed in order to confirm or refuse the overlapping of both species in Central America.
This species has been suggested to be a synonym of Macrothemis inacuta (Hämäläinen 2016). Further research is needed in order to confirm this supposition.

The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful. It has been described based on a single female and De Marmels (2007) suggested that this species could be a junior synonym of Desmogomphus tigrinervis

Dow and Price (2020) synonymised Megalogomphus icterops (Martin, 1903) with M. sumatranus (Krüger, 1899) but separated Bornean populations that had been treated as M. icterops as M. borneensis (Laidlaw, 1914) and those that had been treated as M. sumatranus as M. buddi Dow & Price, 2020.
Megalogomphus buddi Dow and Price, 2020 had been treated as Megalogomphus sumatranus (Krüger, 1899) until Dow and Price (2020) demonstrated that it is a distinct species.

Megalogomphus borneensis (Laidlaw, 1914) was described as a Bornean subspecies of M. icterops (Martin, 1902) and later treated as a junior synonym of that species. Dow and Price (2020) synonymised M. icterops with M. sumatranus (Krüger, 1899) but separated M. borneensis as a distinct species, endemic to Borneo.

The extremely complex nomenclatural history of this species - resulting from a type series consisting of two species, the lack of an unambiguously identified holotype, and a long history of inconsistent usages of the names Ogyris halmaturia and O. waterhouseri - was discussed iin detail by Braby and Douglas (2008), who referred O. halmaturia to the synonymy of O. otanes. 

Braby et al. (2011) subsequently reviewed the evidence presented in favour of multiple proposed treatments and upheld the lectotype designation by Tindale (1923). The consequence of this action is that O. halmaturia represents a valid species, of which O. waterhouseri is a junior synonym following Grund (2010), and this treatment is followed here.

Two Australian Museum specimens from the area north of Mount Hyland, within the distribution of the similar Diorypogyx niger, appear to represent D. duplodentatus. Further taxonomic research is required to clarify their assignment, and it is possible they represent an undescribed species (C. Reid pers. comm. 2021). These records are excluded from this assessment pending resolution of this issue.
The endemic Australian genus Aulacopris White, 1859 comprises three species (Matthews 1974, T. Weir pers. comm. and G.B. Monteith pers. comm.).
Each of the three river catchments in which this species occurs holds a genetically distinct subpopulation (J. Mynott pers. comm. 2021).

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work currently in preparation has identified species-level clades within K. tristis, K. cuneatus and K. usitatus, and confirms that K. cognatus as presently understood is paraphyletic with respect to K. tasmanicus (Umbers et al. 2021).

Work is ongoing to resolve the relationships between members of the K. usitatus clade sensu lato, and the traditional concept is applied here pending full resolution of this species' taxonomy.

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. cuneatus, with strong evidence that K. cuneatus proper is restricted to the Australian Capital Territory and northern New South Wales mountains (Umbers et al. 2021) and the remaining clades within K. cuneatus being undescribed species. 

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cuneatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has confirmed that K. cognatus as presently understood is paraphyletic with respect to K. tasmanicus (Umbers et al. 2021). The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cognatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

Further research may be needed to confirm that the name Kosciuscola cognatus is applicable to the species concept applied here, as two major clades exist within this complex (Umbers et al. 2021). Comparisons with the holotype are needed to determine the appropriate usage of this name. Range limits between the two clades of K. cognatus are unclear, but seem to be divided based on elevation with ‘true’ K. cognatus inhabiting lower elevation sites

scientificName: Kosciuscola sp. nov. 1 'K. tristis Bogong Clade'
authority: K. Umbers et al., in prep.
taxonomicNotes:
Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. tristis.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. tristis pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. tristis pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. cuneatus, with strong evidence that K. cuneatus proper is restricted to the Australian Capital Territory and northern New South Wales mountains (Umbers et al. 2021) and the remaining clades within K. cuneatus are undescribed species.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cuneatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

authority: K. Umbers et al., in prep.
taxonomicNotes:
Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. cuneatus, with strong evidence that K. cuneatus proper is restricted to the Australian Capital Territory and northern New South Wales mountains (Umbers et al. 2021) and the remaining clades within K. cuneatus are undescribed species.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cuneatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

scientificName: Kosciuscola sp. nov. 5 'K. cuneatus Mt Buffalo and Sth Vic Clade'
speciesName: sp. nov. 5 'K. cuneatus Mt Buffalo and Sth Vic Clade'
authority: K. Umbers et al., in prep.
taxonomicNotes:
Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. cuneatus, with strong evidence that K. cuneatus proper is restricted to the Australian Capital Territory and northern New South Wales mountains (Umbers et al. 2021) and the remaining clades within K. cuneatus are undescribed species.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cuneatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

scientificName: Kosciuscola sp. nov. 8 'K. cognatus NSW and Vic Clade'
speciesName: sp. nov. 8 'K. cognatus NSW and Vic Clade'
authority: K. Umbers et al., in prep.
taxonomicNotes:
Two major clades exist within the K. cognatus complex (Umbers et al. 2021) So far as is presently known, the species assessed here does not range as far as the K. cognatus type locality in the Australian Capital Territory and so it is treated as an undescribed form, but it is possible that this taxon may range into the ACT and comparisons with the holotype are needed to determine to which of the two lineages the name K. cognatus properly applies. Range limits between the two clades are unclear, but seem to be elevational with this undescribed clade being restricted to high elevations. Molecular work has confirmed that K. cognatus as presently understood is paraphyletic with respect to K. tasmanicus (Umbers et al. 2021).

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is here considered sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. cognatus pending formal publication of the forthcoming taxonomic revision, and to assess the undescribed congeners.
The taxonomy of this species has to be reviewed in the T. baudueri complex (H. Brustel pers. comm. 2015).
According to Alekseev (2015), this genus is in need of revision.

Macrogomphus parallelogramma was described by Burmeister (1839) based on a single female specimen from an unspecified location in Java, later Selys and Hagen (1858) published a fairly detailed description of the female specimen (the holotype), it is not clear to the assessor if this specimen is still in existence. Later Selys (1878) described males from Java that he supposed to be the same species and also described M. albardae Selys, 1878 from specimens stated to be from the south of Sumatra although Lieftinck (1935) states that one of these is actually from Banka off the coast of southern Sumatra. Lieftinck (1935) treated M. albardae as a subspecies of M. parallelogramma and this view was followed by most authorities until Kosterin (2019) treated M. albardae as a separate species, but noted that it might actually be a junior synonym of M. parallelogramma. The fundamental problem here is that of correctly associating males with the holotype of M. parallelogramma and this problem remains unresolved. In these circumstances, only the holotype can be definitely regarded as M. parallelogramma.

This species was described in a self-published manuscript by James E. Lloyd (Lloyd 2018). Photuris forresti is a member of the P. versicolor species complex which contains many closely related species, distinguishable primarily by observed flash pattern, as there are few morphological differences (Barber 1951, McDermott 1967, Lloyd 2018). This species is morphologically indistinguishable from Photuris tremulans. It can only be identified by its flash pattern, which is typically a series of 4-11 pulsed flashes. It is also very similar to P. walldoxeyi, though the ranges, elevations, and habitat preferences of these two species differ markedly (Faust and Davis 2019).
This species was previously treated as Protogoniomorpha anacardii ssp. duprei but has since been split as a separate species (see Williams 2020).
This Grayling used to be considered a subspecies of Brown's Grayling, or Buff's Asian Grayling (P. mamurra), which occurs in the Asian part of Turkey.
This species has two subspecies, the nominate subspecies meeki from the Solomon Islands, and subspecies inexpectatum from Bougainville (Miller and Miller 1982).

There are four subspecies currently recognised: the nominate subspecies mendana, with its type locality at Aola, Guadalcanal; subspecies acous (Ribbe, 1898) with a type locality at Aco, Bougainville; subspecies neyra (Rothschild, 1895), with type locality of New Georgia; and subspecies aureofasciatum (Racheli, 1979) (see Tennent 2002), with a type locality at Dala on northwest Malaita (Racheli 1980).
There are two subspecies recorded for this species (Collins and Morris 1985).

No subspecies have been described.

This species is closely related and similar in appearance to several other Parantica species endemic to Sulawesi, namely P. toxopei Nieuwenhuis, 1969, P. kuekenthali Pagenstecher, 1896, P. sulewattan Fruhstorfer, 1896, and P. dabrerai Miller and Miller, 1978. The last is particularly close in appearance to this species and flies in the same montane localities in central Sulawesi (Morishita 1985).
The nominate fasciatus occurs on Kepulauan Banggai (Peleng) and adorabilis Fruhstorfer, 1918, occurs on the main island of Sulawesi (Vane-Wright and De Jong 2003).
Several subspecies have been described.
Several subspecies have been described.
In addition to several invalid synonyms, eleven subspecies are currently recognized for this taxon (Yata 1991).

Several subspecies have been described from <st1:country-region w:st="on">Australia</st1:country-region> and <st1:country-region w:st="on"><st1:place w:st="on">Papua New Guinea</st1:place></st1:country-region>.
There are several recognized subspecies of this butterfly (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2009).
No subspecies have been described.
Twenty subspecies were recognised by Yata (1995).
Several subspecies have been recognised (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2008).
Several subspecies have been described.

At least ten subspecies have been recognised by various authors, including Amblypodia vivarna samina Fruhstorfer, 1904, from Sulawesi  – regarded by some authors (e.g., Igarashi and Fukuda 2000) as a distinct species. Vane-Wright and de Jong (2003) followed Cantlie (1964) in regarding samina as a subspecies of A. vivarna.
The status of this butterfly is not entirely clear; it may represent a form of Arhopala agesias Hewitson (Pinratana 1981, Corbet and Pendlebury 1992). No subspecies have been described.
Two subspecies have been described. Nominate bazaloides occurs throughout most of the species’ range; Arhopala bazaloides lanka Evans, 1957, was described from Sri Lanka (Evans 1957).
Several subspecies have been described.

The name 'loxias' has often been misspelled 'loxius'. The original description cites 'loxias' on both the text page in volume 1 of Hewitson’s 'Illustrations of Diurnal Lepidoptera' (1863), and on the accompanying plate data in volume 2. No subspecies have been described for the taxon at present.
Four subspecies have been described.
Nominate itys is restricted to the north of Sulawesi; M. i. remulina Fruhstorfer, 1897, occurs on the remainder of the island; M. i. sulensis Grose Smith & Kirby, 1896, is restricted to Kep. Sula.

It should be noted that Vane-Wright and de Jong (2003) state that the taxonomic authority is Moore, 1898. This species is also regarded by some authors (e.g. Eliot 1969) as a subgenus of Neptis.
Three subspecies are recognised: nominate neriphus from Kepulauan (Kep.) Sula; L. n. tawayana Fruhstorfer, 1899, from Sulawesi, Kep. Togian, Kep. Banggai (Peleng), Butung, Kabaena and Muna; and L. n. sangira Fruhstorfer, 1908, from Kep. Sangihe (Vane-Wright and de Jong 2003).
Several subspecies have been described.
Three subspecies have been described. These are Neptis celebica celebica, Neptis celebica oresta (Fruhstorfer, 1913) and Neptis celebica arachroa (Fruhstorfer, 1913).
The species varies little throughout its wide range. Some four subspecies have been recognized (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2009).
Six subspecies have been described.
Several subspecies have been described.
A number of subspecies have been described. Many of the larger islands where this species occur have a distinct race.
Nine subspecies are formally recognised for this taxon (Yata 1992).
Several subspecies have been described.

The nominate enniana was described from Geelvink Bay; Delias enniana reducta Rothschild, 1915, from the Eilanden River in West Irian; D. e. eceicei Joicey & Talbot, 1916, from further east, in Papua New Guinea. Parsons (1998) believed subspecific separation was doubtful. Taxonomy of the closely related D. dice Snellen van Vollenhoven, 1865, D. ribbei Röber, 1886, D. maudei Joicey & Noakes, 1915, and D. akikoae Morita, 2001, some of which are allopatric in some localities, is highly subjective and open to interpretation (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2008).
Up to seven subspecies have been described: Delias periboea periboea, D. p.wallacei, D. p. livia, D. p. pagenstecheri, D. p. alorensis, D. p. floresiana,and D. p. atakei.
Several subspecies have been described.

Approximately five subspecies have been described. A. eryx agis Fruhstorfer, 1914, was described from Borneo, but structural (genitalic) differences suggest it is better regarded as a distinct species.
Although northern and southern subpopulations of this species appear phenotypically quite distinct, no subspecies are formally recognized for the taxon at present.

Hirowatari (1992) considered this species to be conspecific with Una philippensis Schröder & Treadaway, 1986 from Mindanao. The assessors follow Treadaway (1995), who regarded Una philippensis a distinct species.
Several subspecies have been described.
At least four subspecies have been described.
A number of subspecies are recognized throughout the range of this species (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2008).
There are several synonyms of the name chrysargyra including chrysargyrus. No subspecies are currently recognised.
Several distinct subspecies have been described for this taxon.
Three subspecies have been described.
Several subspecies are recognised.

Three subspecies of this species are recognised. These are merope (in Queensland, South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales), duboulayi (in Western Australia) and salazar (in Tasmania) (Herbison-Evans and Crossley 2009).
No subspecies have been described.

The nominate subspecies is restricted to the main island of Sulawesi. The species was recently discovered on the island of Taliabu (Sula group) and described as Symbrenthia hippalis taliabuensis Yagishita, 2005 (Yagishita 2006).
A number of names have been raised to describe insular subpopulations (W.J. Tennent and C.J. Muller pers. comm. 2008).
No subspecies have been described.
Several subspecies have been described.
Identification of the Bushbrowns is difficult, especially during the dry season (Van der Poel and Wangchuk 2007).
No subspecies have been described.
Several subspecies have been described.

For more than a century, Xixuthrus terribilis Thomson, 1877 was erroneously considered a junior subjective synonym of the Giant Fijian Longhorn Beetle (Xixuthrus heros (Gräffe, 1868)) until it was restored to full species status (Yanega et al. 2004). For nearly sixty years, the Taveuni Beetle was known by the name X. heyrovskyi Tippmann 1945, a junior synonym of X. terribilis (Yanega et al. 2004).

The species was transferred from its original combination with Pachyrhynchus by Faust (1892). Gressitt (1966) included the species in his Division A comprising the cacao associated species of the genus Pantorhytes and it is part of a complex of at least 11 species that are commonly referred to as the Cocoa Weevil Borer (Stibick 1978). In 1978, Stibick described a new species, Pantorhytes hassani Stibick, based partially on specimens previously misidentified as P. biplagiatus from San Cristobal and Guadalcanal Islands where P. biplagiatus is not believed to occur. In this assessment, we follow the taxonomic treatment of Stibick (1978) and have excluded specimens from these two islands. Pantorhytes biplagiatus (Guérin-Méneville, 1841) should not be confused with Pantorhytes biplagiatus Bates 1877, which is a junior synonym of Pantorhytes plutus (Oberthür) (Heller 1905).

This species was redescribed by Schreibers (1802) when he transferred Fabricius’ species to the genus Lucanus Scopoli and it was first placed in Lamprima by Latreille (1804).  Hope, in Westwood (1845), created an unwarranted new name, L. schreibersii, based on the assumption that Schreibers' redescription was a new taxonomic act. Moore & Cassis (1992) corrected the error but placed the synonym under the wrong species (L. aurata Latreille) and the synonym was correctly attributed to L. aenea in Reid et al. (2018). Lamprima subrugosa was an unneccessary new name for the same taxon, later corrected by Thomson (1862).

The species was originally described by Heer in 1868 in a work published by Gräffe (Gräffe 1868), but Heer was not appropriately credited for the description. Thus, the scientific name cannot be attributed to Heer under the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (ICZN 1999) and authorship is instead attributed to Gräffe (Evenhuis 2007). A larva of Xixuthrus heros was also described in the same work but has since been determined to belong to the genus Olethrius Thomson (Yanega et al. 2004).
Xixuthrus ganglbaueri was originally described by Lameere in 1912 (Lameere 1912) and a neotype was designated by Yanega et al. (2004) after the holotype could no longer be located.

Lamproptera paracurius was discovered and described in 2014, it is similar in general appearance to L. curius, but can be easily distinguished by an extra whitish subterminal band on the forewing of both sexes. An unpublished DNA barcoding analysis confirmed its species identity differed from its sibling species, namely L. curius and L. meges (Hu et al. unpublished data).

authority: Olivier, Puplesiene, van der Poorten, de Prins & Wiemers, 1999

taxonomicNotes: The genus Lychas included several species that were thought to belong to other genera. The relationships have been resolved and the two African species transferred to a new genus Afrolychas (Kovařík 2019).

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. tristis (Umbers et al. 2021), and provided strong evidence supporting the elevation of K. tristis restrictus to species level as K. restrictus (Song et al. 2021).

Differences in morphological, ecological and behavioural traits suggest that the current five-species arrangement does not accurately reflect species diversity within Kosciuscola (Tatarnic et al. 2013, Umbers et al. 2021). Molecular work has identified species-level clades within K. tristis, and provided strong evidence that K. tristis sensu stricto is restricted to the southern New South Wales mountains (Umbers et al. 2021), with the remaining clades within K. tristis representing undescribed species.

The recent emergence of major threats from climate change and bushfire, combined with the narrow ranges of these taxa as now understood, is potentially sufficient to justify assessing the reduced species concept of K. tristis, and to assess the undescribed congeners.

Metapocyrtus (Artapocyrtus) willietorresi was described based on two female specimens collected from May to July of 2017 at an elevation of 1,000 m at the slopes of Mount Apo (Cabras and Medina 2018).

Based on a growing body of molecular and morphological evidence, tiger beetles are now placed under Cicindelidae (Vogler and Pearson 1996, Maddison et al. 1999, Pearson and Vogler 2001, Putchkov and Cassola 2005, Bouchard et al. 2011, Duran and Gough 2020). Thopeutica petertaylori Medina, Cabras and Wiesner (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae) was described under Cicindelidae from 16 specimens collected in December 2019 (Medina et al. 2019).
There are no notable issues.

The Asian subpopulations east of northern Urals in the north and east of western Siberia in the south refer to subspecies Leucorrhinia dubia orientalis, which is sometimes considered as a good species (e.g., World Odonata List; Paulson et al. 2022). In the European assessment, we follow Kosterin & Zaika (2010) and regard this taxon as a subspecies of L. dubia. As the taxon orientalis does not occur in Europe, this discussion has no influence on the European regional assessment.
The genus Gegenes is currently being investigated by Larsen (in prep.), and Williams (2019) places this species in Afrogegenes.

This taxon has a slightly convoluted taxonomic history. For a long time considered as part of the genus Gegenes but recently de Jong and Coutsis (2017) erected a new genus, Afrogegenes, in which they placed this species.

It was originally described as Hesperia letterstedti and later moved to Genges until it was decided by Evans (1946) that it should be replaced by Papilio niso, although the exact reason for doing so is uncertain and further discussion about this renaming is made in de Jong and Coutsis (2017), and in conclusion they decide that the name Afrogegenes letterstedti should be used. They also raise the subspecies ocra to full species status, which had at different times been treated as a subspecies of G. hottentota and G. niso.

However, Savela (2022) does not currently included the taxonomic changes as proposed by de Jong and Coutsis (2017), instead retaining the species in Gegenes, and retaining the species epithet niso. The subspecies ocra is also considered to be a subspecies of G. hottentota.

In the current assessment the taxonomic status as appears to have been used in the South African Butterfly Conservation Assessment (SABCA; Mecenero et al. 2013) is used. This appears to place subspecies ocra as part of G. niso (SANBI in litt. 2019), and the genus change to Afrogegenes had not been made. Further taxonomic rearrangement will, therefore, likely be needed in the future, which will then require reassessment of the species' Red List status.

In addition to the nominotypical subspecies, this taxon includes subspecies Calopteryx virgo ssp. meridionalis Selys, 1873 from the southwestern Mediterranean (Iberia and most southern part of France)) and Calopteryx virgo ssp. festiva (Brullé, 1832) in southeastern Europe (from Slovenia to Greece). The nominotypical subspecies occurs throughout most of Europe.

Calopteryx japonica Selys, 1869 occurs in the eastern part of the Palearctic region, this taxon was for a long time considered to be a subspecies of C. virgo. As a result, the range of these two species in parts of Asia is still unclear. C. japonica occurs east of Lake Baikal, whilst west of the Ural Mountains occurs C. virgo, but the border between them in western Siberia is unclear.
There are two subspecies, the nominate and rare mansfieldi and the more abundant pulchristriata Saigusa & Lee, 1982.

This species was considered part of the latreillei species group within the Atrophaneura, which occurs across Southeast Asia and Japan (Hancock 1988). Other authorities have elevated the subgenus Byasa to full genus level (e.g. LepIndex; GLoBIS; Racheli and Cotton 2010), and here we follow this treatment. This species was previously considered to be a sub-species of A. dasarada (Collins and Morris 1985).
Subspecies Zizian otis ssp. antanossa has been referred to as Z. antanossa but presently it is considered a subspecies of Z. otis (Yago et al. 2008).

Because there appears to be no geographical division between the two described subspecies it appears that they may represent forms of the same species or that they may be different species (Mecenero et al. 2013). The listing of this species within Apallaga follows (Williams 2020), whereas Beccaloni et al. (2021) place it in Celaenorrhinus.
The genus Anthene was revised by Libert (2010). In this revision, livida was raised from being a subspecies of Anthene butleri to full species status.

This butterfly is made up of the four subspecies Iolaus diametra diametra, I. diametra congco (formerly referred to as I. diametra littoralis), I. diametra natalica and I. d. zanzibarensis. A previous assessment referred to three named subspecies (excluding I. d. zanzibarensis), but the assessment did explicitly also refer to a subspecies restricted to Zanzibar. As this is the only subspecies to be restricted to Zanzibar, then it is deemed that there has been no change in taxonomic concept between assessments.
This species occurs in three subspecies, the nominate, ssp. peuceda and ssp. penningtoni.
The listing of this species within Pyrrhiades follows (Williams 2020), whereas Beccaloni et al. (2021) place it in Coeliades.
This treatment of this taxon follows Williams (2019). Other taxonomies, e.g. Beccaloni et al. (2021) place it as a subspecies of Spialia diomus.
This butterfly has the two subspecies C. guderiana ssp. guderiana and C. g. ssp. rabaiensis.
Two putative subspecies have been proposed for this butterfly: Junonia oenone ssp. oenone and J. o. ssp. epiclelia.
This butterfly has the three subspecies J. h. ssp. hierta, J. hierta ssp. cebrene and J. hierta ssp. paris.
This species has the two subspecies Heteropsis perspicua ssp. perspicua and H. p. ssp. camerounica.
This butterfly is separated into the three subspecies, Bicyclus anynana ssp. anynana, B. a. ssp. centralis and B. a. ssp. socotrana.

A previous assessment of this species included four subspecies: Protogoniomorpha anacardii ssp. anacardii, P. anacardii ssp. ansorgei, P. anacardii ssp. duprei and P. anacardii ssp. nebulosa. P. anacardii ssp. duprei has since been split as a separate species (see Williams 2020).

This butterfly has 18 subspecies: Amauris echeria echeria, A. echeria abessinica, A. echeria chyuluensis, A. echeria contracta, A. echeria fernandina, A. echeria jacksoni, A. echeria katangae, A. echeria kikuyu, A. echeria lobengula, A. echeria meruensis, A. echeria mongallensis, A. echeria mpala, A. echeria occidentalis, A. echeria septentrionis, A. echeria serica, A. echeria steckeri, A. echeria terrena and A. echeria whytei. Potentially only thirteen of these subspecies may be considered valid (T.B. Larsen pers. comm. 2008).
This butterfly has two subspecies called Precis octavia ssp. octavia and P. octavia ssp. sesamus.
A large number of subspecies are described for this extremely widespread butterfly.
Previous placed in Colotis Hübner, [1819], but Teracolus Swainson, [1833] was re-instated as a valid genus by Nazari et al. (2011).

Previously placed in Colotis Hübner, [1819]; Teracolus Swainson, [1833] was re-instated as a valid genus by Nazari et al. (2011). The subspecies contracta (Gabriel, 1954) from Arabia appears to be valid, while other subspecies may be questionable (e.g. ssp. johnstoni Butler, 1886 from the eastern Cape Province).
